title: A message from Mark Ruffalo and Doctors Without Borders
description:
It's the end of the year, and it’s a time for giving - to friends, family, and humanitarian aid. 

Thanks to @markruffalo and independent supporters like you, your gifts help Doctors Without Borders teams save lives in Gaza, Sudan, Ukraine, and more than 75 countries around the world. 

This season, consider supporting Doctors Without Borders. Now more than ever, your donations will go where the needs are greatest. Visit doctorswithoutborders.org to learn more. ❤️

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Gaza: Will there be less medical care in 2026?
description:
If Israeli authorities revoke MSF’s access to Gaza in 2026, a large portion of people in Gaza will lose access to critical medical care, water, and lifesaving support. 

Our activities serve nearly half a million people in Gaza through our vital support to the destroyed health system. This year we handled over 100,000 trauma cases, administered 45,000 vaccinations, and distributed more than 184 million gallons of water. 

MSF has been working in Palestine since 1989 and calls on the Israeli authorities to ensure that INGOs can maintain and continue their impartial and independent response in Gaza.

title: Our hopes and wishes for 2026
description: Share yours in the comments⬇️

title: Trailer | Sudan: El Fasher under siege
description:
Mawahib, Mohammed, Nasr, and Nour built their lives in an area that has become one of the most violent flashpoints in Sudan’s raging war—El Fasher in Darfur. In the documentary film “El Fasher under siege”, we catch up with them in neighboring Chad, where they’ve sought refuge, as they recount what they witnessed and experienced during the destruction of their city. After two years of ongoing violence, displacement, and a collapse in the healthcare system, we need to get loud and #talkaboutsudan. Watch the full documentary: https://youtu.be/k2LP-A-sXXw 
#sudan #sudanwar #documentary #doctorswithoutborders

title: Perilous lives in DR Congo
description:
MSF field communications manager Sam Bradpiece shares the experience of some of the MSF patients he met during his time working in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).  

“I saw young children, some as young as 3, in the hospital wounded by shrapnel or bullets,” Bradpiece said. “They were born into war. Often when I was visiting medical facilities, I would ask, ‘Do you see an end to the violence here?’ And many people would just say, ‘Well, it's all I've ever known.’” 

For three decades, communities in eastern DRC have suffered from ongoing armed conflict. More than 100 armed groups operate in the region, including M23/Alliance Fleuve Congo, which seized control of the country’s capital Goma in late January 2025. This year has seen a spike in violence in eastern DRC, with MSF medical teams treating more than 3,600 people in the first six months of the year alone.

#drcongo #doctorswithoutborders #drc

title: Ukraine: Suffering from power cuts in winter
description: An MSF medical team visited a shelter in Dnipro, Ukraine, that is hosting more than 200 people who fled the front lines, including two babies. “Just when our team arrived, the electricity went out,” said project coordinator Enrique Garcia Quiroz. “Dark corridors, cold rooms, and no way to heat food.”

title: Sudan: El Fasher under Siege | Documentary
description:
Mawahib, Mohammed, Nasr, and Nour built their lives in an area that has become one of the most violent flashpoints in Sudan’s raging war—El Fasher in Darfur. They were forced to flee when the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and their allies stepped up attacks and tightened their siege on the city, joining the exodus of thousands of Sudanese people who have been displaced by the ongoing conflict.  

In the documentary film “El Fasher under siege”, we catch up with them in neighboring Chad, where they’ve sought refuge, as they recount what they witnessed and experienced during the destruction of their city. #sudan #talkaboutsudan #sudanwar #documentary #doctorswithoutborders 

Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: The latest on medical evacuations from Gaza: Yamen's story
description:
There's an urgent need for a clear medical evacuation mechanism, so patients can receive the care they need—and eventually return home safely. 

More than 18,500 people are registered for medical evacuation from #Gaza. But people are dying while waiting. Between July 2025 and November 28, 2025, 1,092 patients died awaiting medical evacuation, according to the Ministry of Health.  
 
Yamen, a child who suffered a dangerous relapse in his heart condition, is a patient inside Nasser Hospital awaiting medical evacuation. Months of displacement, poor nutrition, and harsh living conditions have weakened his heart muscle. Listen to his mother Shireen share his story.

title: In Afghanistan, families struggle to reach health care
description:
Ahmed is just one of millions of people in Afghanistan who struggle to access quality medical care. Despite the critical need for robust health care systems, many communities and families face severe barriers in accessing essential services at all levels—from primary care to specialized treatment—which can have far-reaching consequences for people’s health.  

Ahmed, however, was able to receive high-quality care from MSF staff. Our teams are witnessing the urgent need for comprehensive support – ranging from improved healthcare infrastructure to better-trained medical professionals – to reduce preventable deaths and enhance people’s overall health. #afghanistan #afghanistannews #news #doctorswithoutborders 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Violence in eastern DRC: "All they've ever known is war"
description:
For three decades, communities in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) have suffered from ongoing armed conflict. More than 100 armed groups operate in the region, including M23/Alliance Fleuve Congo, which seized control of the country’s capital Goma in late January 2025. This year has seen a spike in violence in eastern DRC, with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams treating more than 3,600 people in the first six months of the year alone.  

Through photographs he took during his time in the eastern DRC, Sam Bradpiece, MSF field communications manager, describes what many patients are experiencing.  

“I saw young children, some as young as 3, in the hospital wounded by shrapnel or bullets,” Bradpiece said. “They were born into war. Often when I was visiting medical facilities, I would ask, ‘Do you see an end to the violence here?’ And many people would just say, ‘Well, it's all I've ever known.’” 
#democraticrepublicofcongo #drcongo #drc #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: Watch: Traces of the genocide Gaza documentary
description:
Take a minute to hear the stories of Sami and Zaher, two MSF staff members who have returned to work in Gaza City after MSF teams were forced to leave due to the Israeli offensive on the city that escalated in September. They found their homes and neighborhoods in ruins, a painful reality of the utter destruction left behind by Israeli forces.  

Despite the so-called ceasefire, people in Gaza continue to suffer the consequences of the genocidal war waged by Israel for the past two years. The Israeli authorities must immediately stop their blockade of humanitarian aid throughout the Gaza Strip. 

You can watch the full documentary at the link in our bio or @doctorswithoutborders on YouTube.

title: West Bank: The mental and physical toll of settler violence
description:
Abu Sari, an MSF patient, shares the mental and physical toll of settler violence in the West Bank, Palestine. There, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams provide mental health consultations and see the intense psychological trauma caused by the rise of settler attacks, home demolitions, forced displacement, and daily trauma of witnessing two years of Gazans being killed in real time. Both children and adults are exhibiting alarming behaviors, including depressive symptoms and worsening generational trauma. 

Israel’s genocide in Gaza and deepened annexation of the West Bank is not only a physical assault but an attack on the psyche and collective humanity of Palestinians. The psychological harm is profound and far-reaching.

title: Today at UN Security Council: Protect civilians in DR Congo
description:
Earlier today, this is what Dr. Javid Abdelmoneim, International President of MSF told the UN Security Council during his briefing on the humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. 
“For people living through this conflict, the question is not whether the Council understands their reality—it is why that understanding so rarely translates into meaningful protection. The disconnect is damning. That failure is profound.” Watch the full speech at https://youtu.be/M0f0Vx5NuJk 
#democraticrepublicofcongo #drc #unsecuritycouncil #unitednations #doctorswithoutborders #news

title: Full Speech | MSF International President addresses UN Security Council on DR Congo
description:
Dr. Javid Abdelmoneim, International President of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), briefed the United Nations Security Council on the humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) today. "Generation after generation of Congolese have seen their lives and dignity sacrificed at the altars of politics and profit," Dr. Abdelmoneim said, "civilians are not expendable, and their rights—to safety and to dignity—are non-negotiable. Not in DRC. Not anywhere civilians are under threat." #democraticrepublicofcongo #drc #news #unsecuritycouncil #unitednations #doctorswithoutborders 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: What's happening in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo
description: Watch live at https://webtv.un.org/en/asset/k12/k128ujpf65 Dr. Javid Abdelmoneim, International President of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), will brief the United Nations Security Council on the humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo during a 10 a.m EST session on Friday, December 12.

title: Witnessing the war in Ukraine: Yuliia's story | Full documentary
description:
In Dnipro, a city that faces regular drone attacks and sporadic bombardments, a number of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff live and work, frequently travelling to Pavlohrad to support people displaced by the shifting frontline. Dnipro itself is often the target of drone swarms and bombardments, while those who inhabit the city have little choice but to maintain their daily routines with all the additional safeguards that come with living in a country at war.

This film captures the perspective of MSF Communications Officer, Yuliia Trofimova, who acts as our eyes and ears in Ukraine, often documenting MSF emergency responses to mass casualties and strikes, all while trying to personally reconcile life before the invasion with the present.

Chapters:
00:00-00:41 Yuliia remembers the moment she started reporting on the escalation of the war in Ukraine in 2023.
00:42- TKTKTK
02:10-03:02 Yuliia arrives at the Doctors Without Borders office
03:03-03:56 Yuliia travels to Pavlohrad by car while telling her driver about her friends who had to sleep in a school shelter the night before. 
03:57-05:06  Yuliia shows the destroyed remains of the building where she had her high school prom, which was bombed during the war, and describes how her hometown has transformed as a result of the conflict. She shares how the war feels like it's getting closer and pervading every aspect of life. 
 05:07-05:36  Yuliia calls her mom from the car to tell her she's in Pavlohrad.
 05:37-07:29 Yuliia arrives at an evacuation transit center for people displaced from areas near the frontlines of the war, where she speaks with Doctors Without Borders staff about their work.
07:30-08:56 Yuliia records an interview with an elderly woman who was displaced when two bombs struck her home and her dog guided her out through the smoke. 
08:57-12:06 Yuliia meets up with her performance theater troupe at a rehearsal space where they reenact testimonies from the war. 
12:07-14:03 We walk with Yuliia through Dnipro as she talks about the intense beauty she rediscovered in her community during the war, and highlights the importance of remembering those who have died in the conflict.

title: Russian airstrikes damage MSF staff house and vehicles in Ukraine
description:
“The explosion shattered all the windows,” said Enrique Garcia Quiroz, MSF project coordinator. “From the shelter we saw a fire spreading to nearby homes. Families stood outside with their children as firefighters tried to contain the flames.”
 
During the night of December 4, while Russian forces carried out a major aerial attack on Sloviansk, a blast was felt just feet from the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff house.

The explosion seriously damaged the building, two MSF vehicles, and an ambulance of our partner organization, Cadus. Thankfully, our colleagues were already in a shelter space and no one was injured.
 
With the front line shifting rapidly, hostilities becoming more unpredictable, and damage to civilian and medical structures now a regular occurrence, Sloviansk is now too dangerous to be a permanent base for our staff. Nevertheless, we aim to continue ambulance referrals and primary health consultations in the area, working from an alternative base nearby.

title: This year in South Sudan: escalating violence and health care collapse
description:
In 2025, the situation in South Sudan has worsened significantly. Communities are facing multiple overlapping crises: conflict, large-scale displacement, flooding, malnutrition, and disease outbreaks—including the largest cholera outbreak in South Sudan’s history.  

International support, however, continued to decline this year despite people’s living situations and access to essential services getting worse. 

The urgent needs of people in South Sudan demand coordinated action, renewed commitment, and genuine international solidarity. The world can’t look away, especially not now.

title: Gaza City: Traces of the genocide
description:
In mid-October, after a fragile ceasefire took hold, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) nurses Sami Al-Jamal and Zaher Okasha returned to Gaza City to resume work in what was left of the medical facilities there, including Al-Shifa Hospital. MSF’s teams had been evacuated about three weeks prior as Israeli forces’ ground invasion swept through the city.  

"The good thing is that our departments in Al-Shifa are still okay,” said Sami. “We can provide our services. But as humanitarian aid and medical supplies remain in short supply, there are still many challenges in providing medical care to the many people who need it. At least the building exists, but tools and supplies are not there. Will we have enough supplies?"  

Chapters

00:00-02:00 Scenes of destroyed parts of Gaza City and Al-Shifa Hospital today. We meet MSF nurses Sami Al-Jamal and Zaher Okasha.  

02:01-02:40 Zaher describes the days before the MSF clinic in Gaza City was evacuated. 

 02:41-03:26 Sami describes the dangers of walking to work at Al-Shifa after he was displaced for a few weeks to the south.  

03:26 - 04:20 Sami worked later at the MSF field hospital in Dier Al Balah and saw some of his patients from Al-Shifa.  

04:21 - 06:00 Zaher and Sami talk about the huge medical needs once they were able to resume work in Gaza City, the relief of being able to provide care, and the fear of not having enough supplies.  

06:01- 06:53 Zaher goes back to his home, which was destroyed in the fighting.  

06:54-07:10 Despite the destruction, Zaher still feels hope for the future.

title: Witnessing medical evacuations from Gaza
description:
After two years of intense war that has destroyed the health care system, 16,500 Palestinian patients need urgent medical evacuation from Gaza.
 
Only a tiny fraction have been able to do so. We call on Israeli authorities to facilitate medical evacuations of all patients who require care unavailable in the Strip, without prejudice to their right to a safe, voluntary, and dignified return to Gaza.
 
Dr Hani Isleem was part of the MSF team that coordinated medical evacuations with the Swiss authorities. “Watching patients die while waiting for evacuation is the worst feeling imaginable.”

title: The strength of women in Somalia amid aid cuts
description:
The Somali health system has been stretched to its limits. As funding declines and health services shrink, access to free, lifesaving care is becoming increasingly rare.  

Mothers are often forced to travel for hours on unsafe roads to find care for their families because nearby clinics cannot handle emergencies. This needs to change: We need aid directed to maternal health, nutrition, and vaccination so parents do not have to choose between transport and treatment. #somalia #somali #somalicommunity #internationalaid #malnutrition #doctorswithoutborders #news  

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: How the funding cuts are having a devastating impact for the people in Sudan
description:
In early 2025, our teams in El Geneina Teaching hospital, West Darfur had identified a critical gap in maternal care. 

Safe delivery services were almost non-existent. 

Only two public hospitals in the entire state remained functional, private facilities were unaffordable, and rural areas had no ambulances or referral systems. 

To help fill this gap, MSF had reached an agreement with an international humanitarian actor in El Geneina to manage maternity services at the hospital. But shortly before their work was due to begin, they withdrew after losing their USAID funding, leaving this critical gap in care still unmet, to which MSF had to urgently find an alternative solution.

In March 2025, we partnered with the Sudanese Family Planning Association (SFPA), a local Sudanese NGO, to ensure continuity of care. Through this collaboration, MSF now finances SFPA to provide free, non-complicated deliveries, while our teams continue to manage complicated deliveries inside El Geneina Teaching Hospital. 

In a rapidly changing humanitarian landscape, our teams in El Geneina are building pragmatic partnerships to keep essential health services running, and to save lives.

title: A quiet revolution in HIV care: Youth clubs in DR Congo
description:
HIV treatment abandonment among young people is a real concern in DR Congo. Check out this innovative youth club initiative from the Congolese association Jeunesse Espoir (“Youth Hope”) and MSF to address this. 

The goal is simple: to offer adolescents and young adults living with HIV a safe, confidential, and friendly space, linked to a formal health care structure where they can meet, share, and support one another. https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/quiet-revolution-hiv-care-youth-clubs-dr-congo

© Emilia Brazy-Nancy/MSF
This work was the result of an anthropological research project conducted in 2024 with four HIV+ youth clubs in Kinshasa, carried out by MSF's Emilia Brazy-Nancy and supported by MSF and Jeunesse Espoir. These clubs offer medical and psychosocial support, helping adolescents break isolation and confront stigma.

title: How to make life better for kids with #diabetes in South Sudan
description:
In South Sudan, many children struggle to keep their type-one diabetes under control. The MSF clinic at the Aweil State Hospital is currently only able to provide them with vials of insulin that they need to store in clay pots to keep the insulin cool enough in the hot climate. Patients need to come to the hospital on a monthly basis to collect their supply of insulin and for their monthly check-ups. However, many live in rural areas and cannot afford the cost of transport, so they miss their appointments – and they also often run out of insulin. 

Insulin pens and glucose monitoring devices are making it easier for patients in South Sudan to manage their diabetes and avoid future complications. In order to expand access to these life-saving devices, manufacturers must lower their prices.

title: #TalkAboutSudan: After the fall of El Fasher, people still alive are trapped
description: After harrowing journeys, for survivors who were able to reach nearby Tawila, they now need shelter, medical care, food, water, and latrines.

title: #Sudan: Civilians continue to bear the brunt of violence
description: Civilians continue to bear the brunt of violence in Sudan. You might have seen the horrifying stories coming out of El Fasher in North Darfur. This is what our teams in nearby Tawila are seeing. And remember to #TalkAboutSudan

title: Despite the ceasefire, people are still not safe in #Gaza
description:
On November 22 Israeli airstrikes hit multiple locations across Gaza, and we treated seven patients in our field hospital in Deir Al Balah who had been severely injured. More than 20 people were killed and over 80 injured, according to the Ministry of Health.

"We were only 30 feet from the house then we were thrown into the air," said Ibrahim, a patient MSF treated in Nuseirat camp.

title: Aid shift: Standing up for global health in a time of turmoil
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have decades of experience responding to all kinds of emergencies, from wars to disease outbreaks to natural disasters. But 2025 brought an unprecedented catastrophe caused by policy changes and massive cuts to international humanitarian aid by the United States government and other donors. This seismic shift has shaken the aid sector and the communities we assist.  

On November 20,  MSF hosted a webcast exploring how slashed aid funding is impacting people around the world. MSF is not directly affected by these cuts, as we do not accept any US government funding and rely on generous support from independent donors. However, we work hand in hand with many local and international organizations that have been forced to scale back or halt activities altogether.   

Our teams are bearing witness to the consequences on the ground: people losing access to care at local clinics, vaccination campaigns disrupted, medications out of stock, and clean drinking water in short supply.  

MSF remains committed to providing medical humanitarian aid where it’s needed most—but we can’t do it alone. Together, we’ll discuss how we’re adapting to the stark new realities.

title: Soaked in Gaza: What life looks like right now
description:
Rains are flooding makeshift tents and shelters, soaking belongings, and exposing people to the elements ahead of winter. What can Palestinians do?"
#gaza #palestine #doctorswithoutborders

title: Mini-documentary: In Ukraine, help from the front line
description:
This is what a rotation at a hospital looks like for a health worker during war in Ukraine: 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Kherson, southern Ukraine, prepare for patients to shelter in the basement when shelling is nearby, they create a makeshift gym and sleeping area for themselves, and doctors deal with power cuts in the middle of surgery. During their two-week rotations, medical teams cannot leave the hospital because the security situation is too tense.

Chapters:
00:00-00:28 Footage from Kherson city being struck by bombs.
00:29-01:22 MSF paramedic Valentyna Myz makes Ukrainian varenyky, a type of dumpling, in the hospital kitchen for the team to eat later.
01:22- 03:51 MSF surgeon Yevhen Zhuk walks through a section of the hospital that was partially destroyed during shelling, then treats a patient during a power cut.
03:51-07:00 MSF anesthetist Olha Severyn walks through the basement of the hospital that is often used as a bomb shelter and a gym, then has a consultation with a patient while air raid sirens sound in the background.
07:00-08:33  Valentyna checks on one patient and then leaves to visit another patient who has undergone a partial amputation of her leg.
08:33-09:15  Valentyna visits the patient, who was a member of a village choir, and listens to her sing.
09:15-10:13 Valentyna works on the varenyky in the kitchen and other members of the team come in. They sit down for a meal together.
10:14-10:43 Scene of the hospital in the afternoon while bombs explode in the distance.

title: Gaza: Children being children
description:
Moments of joy to watch and hear: Children being children in Gaza, singing, playing, jumping, and painting. At the Doctors Without Borders clinic in Al Mawasi, mental health counselors run "carnival" sessions for children through songs, stories, and art.These sessions are a safe space for children to express themselves and receive psychological support after experiencing so much pain and trauma. The clinic also offers individual psychological support, family counseling, and pain management for children.
#gaza #mentalhealth #doctorswithoutborders

title: In Gaza, waiting for a medical evacuation
description:
Hadeel, a Palestinian mother, shares how, despite the ceasefire, her family is still unable to access the critical treatment they need: “My daughter got a referral for medical evacuation a year and a half ago, and my son died while waiting for medical evacuation.” 
Over 16,500 people in Gaza are waiting to be medically evacuated. MSF calls on governments around the world to drastically and urgently increase medical evacuations for thousands of patients who cannot access lifesaving care they need. 
#worldchildrensday #gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: We're back on the Mediterranean to save lives
description: We’ve returned to the central Mediterranean Sea with a new vessel for search and rescue activities: the Oyvon. It's been a busy few days. Over the weekend, we carried out our first rescue with support from the search and rescue vessel Louise Michel. All 41 survivors—many of whom had fled the ongoing war in Sudan—have disembarked in Lampedusa, Italy. Then last night, 27 people were brought on board from a raft. All have disembarked safe and sound in Lampedusa this morning.

title: Bangladesh: How we treat diabetes in a refugee camp
description:
Imagine trying to manage #diabetes in a refugee camp. Our teams support patients in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, by providing self-monitoring tools, insulin pens, and clay pots for safe insulin storage without electricity. #bangladesh #diabetesmanagement #diabetesawareness #diabetesawareness #doctorswithoutborders 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Gaza: Through Nour's eyes
description: Nour is documenting life after the ceasefire in Gaza. She’s an extraordinary MSF communications officer, sharing what our Palestinian humanitarian workers and patients have been enduring for years. The #ceasefire has not ended the suffering.

title: Why is John Green obsessed with tuberculosis?
description:
Best-selling author and philanthropist John Green traveled to the Philippines to learn about tuberculosis work in the country, specifically our project in Tondo, Manila. Tune in to @vlogbrothers on November 13th at 9 am EST for a panel talk about access to TB care with experts.

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: The climate crisis is a health crisis
description:
Millions of people all over the world are facing severe health impacts from the climate crisis, particularly those who lack access to basic health care. Every day, MSF teams see Indigenous communities and people affected by conflict, displacement, and poverty suffering the health consequences of climate events. The crisis compounds preexisting vulnerabilities and overwhelmingly affects people who have contributed the least to its causes.  

#climatechange #cop30 #doctorswithoutborders

title: Gaza: We medically evacuated seven children; many more need care
description:
Seven wounded children from Gaza were recently evacuated to Switzerland for advanced medical care. 
 
Suleiman Mallah and Line Soukouti, MSF interpreters for medical evacuations, speak about the strength and resiliency of these children, the dire conditions from which they came, and the trauma the children and their families experienced. 
 
There are more than 15,600 people—3,800 of whom are children—who are still awaiting lifesaving medical evacuation from Gaza.  
 
We continue to call on all governments and Israel to urgently scale up medical evacuations for thousands of patients unable to access care in the Strip, with no prejudice to their right to a safe, voluntary, and dignified return.

title: Jamaica: How MSF is responding after Hurricane Melissa
description:
This is the damage from Hurricane Melissa to the town of Black River, Saint Elisabeth parish. Our emergency teams are actively assessing the most imminent needs in #Jamaica, including in remote areas where people have been completely cut off due to road damage, and damage to hospitals. In St. James parish, we’re repairing the damage to the roof of a hospital and an operating theater, and providing medical supplies. In St. Elisabeth Parish we're preparing to provide supplies, water and sanitation, and logistical support. Here, Meinie Nicolai, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) General Director, updates about what we’re doing to help affected communities. #jamaica #hurricanemelissa #doctorswithoutborders #news 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: #Haiti: Haitian civilians are trapped in a violent conflict and need access to medical care
description: As Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince, sinks deeper into a crisis marked by violent clashes between armed groups and police forces, people are having to flee their homes and neighborhoods. Jackson and Jacqueline’s story is just one example of the thousands of people who just want to return home.

title: Impact: Installing water tanks in Tigray
description: We’re working to make sure displaced people in Sheraro, Ethiopia, have the water they need, as international funding cuts disrupt and threaten consistent access to essentials. For the past few years, we’ve been supporting the recovery of the health care system in northwest Tigray, and many needs remain.

title: What we are seeing in Sudan
description:
Mass atrocities in El Fasher, Sudan: From North Darfur, MSF's Sylvain Pénicaud spoke with Nick Schifrin on @PBSNewsHour on October 31.

In the nearby town of Tawila, we've been treating people who fled El Fasher. Given the state of people who escaped and made it barely alive to Tawila, it’s clear that they are in urgent need of medical and nutritional care, psychosocial assistance, shelter, water, and humanitarian assistance.

title: On empathy and connection with #Sudan: The Humanitarian Lens podcast
description:
“We are all human.”⬇️ 

As the war in Sudan continues, we must continue to pay attention and talk about the impact it is having on millions of Sudanese people. Earlier this year, Dr. Mohammed Fadlalla told The Humanitarian Lens podcast host, Avril Benoît, why his belief in our shared humanity will continue to get more people to engage with the crisis in Sudan. 

Watch the full episode at the link in our bio or on Spotify. 
#videopodcast  #podcastclips #empathy #humanity

title: URGENT: We’ve been treating people fleeing El Fasher to the nearby town of Tawila
description: People are relying on animal feed to survive. Malnutrition in Sudan is reaching alarming levels: over 8.7 million people face emergency or famine-level food insecurity. Children under 5 are most affected, and cases of moderate and severe acute malnutrition are increasing rapidly. #TalkAboutSudan

title: This is what it’s like living and working in the West Bank
description:
The anxiety of checkpoints, the sound of bombs at night, the frustration of not knowing if you can reach your patients—these are the struggles Shorouq and Shireen share of working in the West Bank.  

They have been working with Doctors Without Borders for 20 years. Every day, they travel across the northern West Bank to help people who need psychological support. Movement restrictions imposed by the Israeli military have dramatic daily consequences for Palestinians. 

Watch the full video: Mental health in the West Bank: “After October 7, everyone’s lives changed"

title: Mental health in the West Bank: “After October 7, everyone’s lives changed"
description:
Shorouq Al-Madmooj, a social worker, and Shireen Nazzal, a psychological counselor, have worked with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in the West Bank for 20 years. In this short documentary, they talk about their work and the impact of political violence on their patients and themselves.  

“After October 7, everyone’s lives changed,” said Nazzal. “For example, people living next to a settlement—now, when they want to leave their homes, they can’t leave them empty; someone must stay inside the house.  

"Depression levels have increased. PTSD [post-traumatic stress syndrome] comes with multiple symptoms; among them are flashbacks, fear, anxiety, and stress. They associate things like going out with the traumatic event they experienced. For instance, if they witnessed an attack or were attacked by soldiers, they remain constantly on alert and afraid.”  

Make sure you don’t miss weekly video updates and ongoing series about our work in crisis zones across the world. Subscribe to our channel here: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

Chapters:
00:00-01:30
Life in Palestine has changed since October 7, 2023; the stresses of daily life in the West Bank have increased.
01:30-03:00
Shorouq Al-Madmooj, MSF social worker, and Shireen Nazzal, MSF psychological counselor, describe the challenges of their job providing mental health care to residents in the West Bank.
03:00-05:26 
They describe how political violence is tangled up in everyone’s personal lives, and how they see this in their work with mothers whose children have been killed and the relatives of prisoners.  
05:26-07:14 
Children are deeply affected by the violence in the West Bank. Shorouq and Shireen explain the approaches they use to help ease children’s anxiety and fear.  
07:14-08:57
Shorouq describes why staying at home helps her feel a sense of control that she doesn’t have when moving around in the West Bank, and how she dreams of peace and equality.

title: Sudan: A doctor’s voice note on what’s happening in El Fasher
description: This is the voice of MSF pediatrician Dr. Giulia Chiopris. She is in Tawila, Sudan, where our teams are receiving people fleeing El Fasher with gunshot wounds and severe malnutrition.

title: Sudan: People fleeing El Fasher seek care in Tawila
description: As the Rapid Support Forces advance into El Fasher, Sudan, after 500 days of siege, MSF teams in nearby Tawila are receiving people who’ve fled the fallen city. There are reports of mass killings and other atrocities, and MSF staff in Tawila are seeing many children with severe, acute malnutrition.

title: Doctor in Gaza: Attacks continue during ceasefire
description: On October 29, MSF teams across the Gaza Strip cared for patients severely wounded in attacks by Israeli forces, despite the ceasefire that was announced in early October. “When I got to the emergency room, it was a desperate situation,” said MSF doctor Martin Rostrup at Al-Aqsa Hospital. “There is no doubt this is an attack on civilians, with so many children being injured and killed. Do we really call this a ceasefire?”

title: Fighting the ongoing mpox outbreak in Kenya
description:
Strengthening community-level case detection and addressing stigma that discourages people from seeking care are key to fighting the spread of mpox. The MSF team in Mombasa is working in partnership with the Ministry of Health to ensure free, timely, and quality medical care for mpox patients, and promoting vaccination among high-risk groups.  #outbreaks #news #kenya #kenyanews #doctorswithoutborders #mpoxoutbreak #mpoxvirus #mpox 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Gaza: Despite ceasefire, humanitarian emergency continues
description:
Despite the ceasefire, people in Gaza continue to endure extreme suffering, as Israel’s two-year-long genocidal campaign has left them traumatized, injured, and dangerously exposed to the elements as winter approaches. Without immediate improvements to water, sanitation, shelter, and nutrition, more people will die from entirely preventable causes. #gaza #news #doctors 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Child malnutrition in Nigeria—prevent and treat
description: In Katsina state, Nigeria, MSF has helped treat more than 112,000 malnourished children this year so far. MSF and the Danish Refugee Council also have been providing cash to caregivers of malnourished children so they can buy food and help prevent the risk of relapse—more than 5,500 caregivers have received this support. Urgent short-term solutions and sustained long-term strategies are needed to stop recurring malnutrition crises.

title: Gaza: More medical evacuations and aid urgently needed
description: Thousands of people are awaiting lifesaving medical evacuations from Gaza—people with traumatic injuries from bombs, people with cancer, and people suffering from kidney failure. These evacuations must be accompanied by a sustained effort to maintain the fragile ceasefire, and the continued facilitation of delivering humanitarian aid.

title: MSF emergency doctor in Gaza describes receiving dozens of wounded people after Israeli airstrike
description: "In the emergency room it became pretty packed with severely injured people." MSF emergency doctor Morten Rostrup, working inside Al-Aqsa Hospital, describes receiving dozens of wounded people after the Israeli airstrikes across the Gaza Strip on October 19 2025, which killed more than 45 people and injured over 150, according to the Ministry of Health. Since the ceasefire on October 11, a total of 80 people have been killed and 303 injured.

title: Detained Palestinian surgeon must be released
description: Dr. Mohammed Obeid, a respected Palestinian orthopedic surgeon and long-time MSF colleague, was not released as part of the recent ceasefire agreement in Gaza. Dr. Obeid was arrested on October 26, 2024, by Israeli forces during a military operation at Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza. He was detained along with 57 others and has since been held without contact with his family for nearly a full year. We call for his immediate and unconditional release.

title: Painting Sudan: War, resilience, and beauty
description:
“Even the people who are very close to me are reluctant to talk about it because I think they only think about the war and suffering.” Over the years, Narin Fandoglu has relied on watercolor painting to process emotions from her work with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). During two recent visits to Sudan, art also became a way to document the beauty of daily life beyond the war, offering a rare and inspiring view into the strength and human connection that persist despite conflict and displacement. By sharing her art and stories about the people of Sudan, Narin hopes to create a connection that forces us to pay attention and break the silence surrounding one of the world’s largest humanitarian emergencies. #Talkaboutsudan  #sudan #doctorswithoutborders #sudanwar 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: MSF staff member in #Gaza shares about the immense needs and the ceasefire
description: Nadia Eid, MSF medical coordinator support in Gaza, shares about the immense needs and the ceasefire: "The majority of people have already lost their houses, which means that they will continue living in tents under inhumane conditions. They don't have access to clean water. They don't have access to food or hygiene. So the war has ended for now, but they don't get to go back to their houses."

title: Destruction and displacement in the West Bank
description:
In one community in Masafer Yatta, more than 85% of homes have been reduced to rubble. 
Find out more at: 
#news #westbank #palestine #doctorswithoutborders

title: Haiti: A family displaced by gang violence in Port-au-Prince
description:
Jackson and Jacqueline Jean, a father and daughter from Haiti, share their stories of displacement due to the ongoing outbreaks of violence in Port-au-Prince. They are two of 300,000 people in the capital city who have been forced to leave their homes and neighborhoods to flee from attacks. Our teams in Haiti are seeing an alarming uptick in civilian causalities at our facilities. As movement becomes more limited and health facilities shutter due to the violence, MSF remains committed to supporting the Haitian population. It is imperative that civilians, health care workers, and medical facilities be protected.

description:
Watch the full video “Oya,” a beautiful and inspiring collaboration of music, video, and dance between MSF and West African artists, is shining the spotlight on the impacts of climate change in Africa. 

#climatechange #dancevideo #westafricanmusic

title: CBS: In Gaza, "shelter, water, food—that's what they want"
description:
"What I hear from my colleagues is just that they want an end to this. They want peace. They want security. Shelter, water, food, that's what they want." Dr. Aqsa Durrani spoke with CBS on Wednesday, before the announcement of a tentative ceasefire deal in Gaza, about the extraordinary medical needs she witnessed there. Three of our colleagues have been killed in Gaza in the past few weeks. MSF was forced to pull out of Gaza City, leaving vulnerable patients without care - including new moms, newborns, and patients with amputations. We need a ceasefire now, along with an urgent and massive scale up of humanitarian aid to address the overwhelming medical, psychological, and material needs across a devastated Gaza.

title: #Italy: Providing mental health care to migrant youth
description:
Nearly 9,500 unaccompanied foreign minors have arrived in Italy in 2025 after crossing the Mediterranean. Many are fleeing situations of extreme violence and poverty and have endured traumatic experiences during their journey, which require dedicated support services. 

In Agrigento in July 2024, Doctors Without Borders launched “People on the Move,” a project that aims to provide medical care and psychological support to unaccompanied minors arriving from the Central Mediterranean route. Through creative workshops and other activities, these boys learn to recognize and name their emotions, to regain trust, and imagine a new future.

title: Doctors Without Borders staff member in Gaza reacts on CNN to news about ceasefire plan
description: MSF communications officer Nour Alsaqqa spoke from Gaza with Christiane Amanpour on reaction to the potential ceasefire agreement today. While there is some sense of relief, she also described lingering uncertainty and numbness. This potential ceasefire agreement comes after “two years of indiscriminate mass killing and destruction of every aspect of life, whether it's infrastructure, health facilities, homes.” She called for “an urgent and massive scale-up of humanitarian aid to address these overwhelming needs–whether it's medical needs, whether it's psychological needs, whether it's material needs.”

title: Gaza: Two years of war in one minute
description: Two years. The words of our staff and the scenes from inside the hospitals where we've worked show the impact of this brutal, unrelenting war on civilians and our teams as they try to save lives. Israel is committing a genocide against Palestinians in Gaza. Stop the genocide. Ceasefire now. Watch the full montage on YouTube.

title: Killed in #Gaza: A physiotherapist helping burn patients and amputees
description:
This is a devastating loss - Abed El Hameed Qaradaya is the 15th MSF colleague killed in Gaza. He died a few days after sustaining critical injuries in an October 2 attack that also killed our colleague, Omar Hayek. The attack, carried out by Israeli forces in #gaza, struck a street where our teams were waiting to take a bus to go to work at an MSF field hospital in Deir Al-Balah. All staff were wearing MSF vests, which clearly identified them as medical humanitarian workers. Here is Abed back in January 2025 explaining how he worked to help wounded patients amid supply shortages. The physiotherapy teams at Nasser Hospital were creating custom compression suits for burn patients and designing locally sourced crutches for people with amputations. #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: How to stop malaria
description: In Burundi’s Cibitoke health district, MSF teams are supporting 20 health centers to implement a “triple protection” strategy against malaria. This includes malaria vaccination, long-term preventive treatment, and providing insecticide-treated mosquito nets—all at the same time. This simple and inexpensive strategy has yielded a significant drop in malaria admissions—especially of severe cases—compared with the same period last year.

title: Gaza: What two years of war looks like
description:

It includes parts of interviews with MSF patients and staff and helps to paint a picture of the impact of this brutal, unrelenting war on civilians and our teams as they try to save lives.

title: 10 years since the deadliest attack on an MSF health facility
description:
We are marking 10 years since the deadliest attack ever perpetrated against a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) facility. 

On October 3, 2015, our trauma hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, came under intense and prolonged US airstrikes. The attack killed 42 people, including 14 MSF staff—nurses, doctors, and support workers. Patients were burned in their beds; people lost limbs; and some were shot while fleeing the burning building. 

At the time, our hospital was a lifeline for people wounded in Afghanistan’s ongoing conflict. A decade later, in a country no longer at war, the city and the nature of the wounds have changed. MSF runs a new 79-bed trauma center in Kunduz equipped with an emergency room, an intensive care unit, inpatient and outpatient departments, operating theaters, and a space for physiotherapy. Our staff, many of them survivors of the 2015 attack, provide care for patients injured in road accidents, falls, and unexploded ordnance.

title: Celebrating the legacy of outgoing MSF USA CEO, Avril Benoît
description:
Avril Benoît has served as the CEO of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières USA (MSF USA) since 2019, leading the organization through a period of remarkable growth and change. Avril spent 19 years working with MSF across various leadership roles in headquarters and in project assignments around the world, including Haiti, Nigeria, Sudan, South Sudan, Syria, Iraq, Ukraine, Democratic Republic of Congo, and many more countries. 

At MSF offices around the world, we maintain a healthy custom for top leaders to step away after serving roughly six years. This regular opportunity for leadership renewal helps make space for fresh perspectives and keeps our organization nimble.  

As Avril passes the baton to a new CEO of MSF USA, we celebrate her incredible journey with MSF over the past 19 years. “Our organization, and the entire MSF movement, is stronger thanks to Avril and the team she has built,” said Dr. Rasha Khoury, MSF USA Board President. “During Avril’s tenure, we faced the COVID-19 pandemic, the racial reckoning in the US and in the aid sector, and extraordinary emergencies such as the war in Sudan and genocide in Gaza. We are immensely grateful to Avril for successfully steering the organization through these turbulent times.”

title: Doctors call to let Gaza live
description: Doctors and other health staff in Gaza are trying to save lives under impossible conditions while an entire population is being destroyed. Doctors can’t stop genocide. World leaders can. That’s why MSF is calling on the US government to suspend arms transfer to Israel, facilitate a surge of lifesaving humanitarian aid, and call for an immediate and sustained ceasefire in Gaza. #gaza

title: BBC: MSF forced to suspend medical activities in Gaza City
description:
BBC interviewed Dr. Aqsa Durrani, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) pediatrician, on Saturday, September 27. The relentless Israeli offensive in #gazacity has forced MSF to suspend its vital medical activities in the area due to the rapidly deteriorating security situation, including continued airstrikes and advancing tanks less than half a mile from our health care facilities. 

This difficult decision leaves vulnerable people without medical care despite enormous needs in the north of the Strip. There is not a single fully operational hospital in the whole Gaza Strip, and those still partially functional are overwhelmed due to severe shortages of staff, supplies, and fuel. 

MSF teams will continue to provide critical care in southern #gaza. In Khan Younis, MSF supports Nasser Hospital and runs three primary health care centers. In the Middle Area, MSF supports Al-Aqsa Hospital’s emergency department and wound care clinic and operates two field hospitals in Deir al-Balah.

title: Explaining cholera: A preventable killer
description:
You’ve probably heard about cholera in the news or on social media. Cholera is a highly contagious intestinal disease that has existed for centuries and continues to infect between 1.3 to 4 million people and kill up to 143,000 people worldwide each year. It’s often transmitted through contaminated drinking water or food. But did you know that cholera is both preventable and treatable? With timely response, the right tools, and a commitment to equity, we can prevent countless deaths and hopefully bring cholera to an end by 2030.  

In this video, we explain how Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) responds to cholera outbreaks around the world, and we answer common questions about this deadly disease: What is cholera? Is cholera fatal? How does a cholera outbreak spread? How can you prevent cholera?

description:

title: CNN: In Gaza City, MSF forced to suspend medical activities
description:
CNN interviewed Dr. Aqsa Durrani, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières  (MSF) pediatrician, on Saturday, September 27. The relentless Israeli offensive in Gaza City has forced MSF to suspend its vital medical activities in the area due to the rapidly deteriorating security situation, including continued airstrikes and advancing tanks less than half a mile from our health care facilities. 

This difficult decision leaves vulnerable people without medical care despite enormous needs in the north of the Strip. There is not a single fully operational hospital in the whole Strip, and those still partially functional are overwhelmed due to severe shortages of staff, supplies, and fuel. 

MSF teams will continue to provide critical care in southern Gaza. In Khan Younis, MSF supports Nasser Hospital and runs three primary health care centers. In the Middle Area, MSF supports Al-Aqsa Hospital’s emergency department and wound care clinic and operates two field hospitals in Deir al-Balah.

title: Lebanon one year after the ceasefire
description:
Despite the ceasefire agreement made in November 2024, Israeli attacks remain an almost daily reality in Lebanon, hindering people’s ability to recover and restricting their access to care. Israeli forces are still occupying several points along Lebanon’s southern border, leaving more than 82,000 displaced while preventing their return. What can you do? Be informed and share this video with someone who should know about this. #lebanon #lebanonlatestnews #doctorswithoutborders #news

title: World leaders: Stop the genocide in Gaza
description: As world leaders convene in New York City for the United Nations General Assembly, MSF Secretary General Christopher Lockyear is getting out the message: our medical staff is doing all they can to save lives in Gaza, but world leaders are the only ones who can stop genocide.

title: Doctors cannot stop genocide. World leaders can. And they must act now to save lives in Gaza.
description:
Urgent message for leaders gathering at the United Nations General Assembly: Doctors cannot stop genocide. World leaders can. And they must act now to save lives in Gaza.  

We are calling on states to stop sending weapons to Israel that are being used to kill and maim Palestinians. Providing US military assistance to Israel despite its near-total siege and severe restrictions on humanitarian aid in Gaza is a violation of US law. We are demanding urgent action to comply with US law, help save lives, and ease the catastrophic suffering of Palestinians in Gaza. 

We are also calling on US lawmakers to:  

Secure an immediate surge in independent, lifesaving humanitarian aid to people in Gaza 
Suspend US arms transfers to Israel in compliance with section 620i of the Foreign Assistance Act 
Call for an immediate and sustained ceasefire in Gaza 
Add your name to our petition (link in bio), share this post, and speak out for Gaza.

title: Healing through friendship in Jordan
description: Iyad sustained a gunshot wound in the leg from Israeli forces in Gaza. Hossam was burned in an ISIS attack in Iraq and underwent 17 surgeries there. After MSF transferred both of them to Amman, Jordan, for specialized surgical care, the two young men became close friends. They now spend their free time playing soccer and video games and are supporting each other in recovery.

title: Gaza: Sign the petition, share this video, speak out
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are doing everything we can to respond to the humanitarian catastrophe in #Gaza. But we are confronting a grim reality:  Doctors can’t stop genocide. World leaders can. In this video, Avril Benoît, MSF USA CEO, explains why we’ve launched a petition calling on US lawmakers to: 
✅ Ensure a surge of lifesaving humanitarian aid to Palestinians in Gaza 
✅ Suspend arms transfers to Israel 
✅ Call for an immediate and sustained ceasefire in Gaza 

Sign the petition, share this video, speak out. 🔗 https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/campaigns/stop-genocide-gaza-petition 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Gaza: Doctors can't stop genocide. World leaders can.
description:
As humanitarians, we are in #Gaza to provide care. But our 1,118 colleagues working there face a heartbreaking reality: Doctors can’t stop genocide. World leaders can. This week, we stood in front of the United Nations to demand urgent action from world leaders to save lives. 

For nearly two years, Gaza’s hospitals have been bombed relentlessly. Medical and aid workers have been killed. Israel’s siege continues to choke off access to food, water, medicine, fuel, and other necessities. Aid is being weaponized, and civilians are shot while trying to get food. 

Demand action. Add your name to our petition [link below] to call on US lawmakers to: 
- Secure an immediate surge in independent, lifesaving humanitarian aid to people in Gaza.
- Suspend US arms transfers to Israel in compliance with section 620i of the Foreign Assistance Act.
- Use US influence with Israel to ensure an end to attacks on civilians in Gaza, including attacks on health workers and hospitals.
- Call for an immediate and sustained ceasefire in Gaza. 

Link to our petition: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/campaigns/stop-genocide-gaza-petition

SUBSCRIBE to our channel: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: “Oya,” a striking West African climate change intervention through music and dance
description:
The climate crisis is a health crisis, and the African continent—where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has most of our projects—is disproportionately affected. Vulnerable communities are paying with their health and their lives for a problem they did not create. Urgent action is needed now to limit the damage and to support the communities that are suffering the most.  

"Oya" features original music and choreography created by West African artists. This co-creation features singers Mao Sidibé and Def Mama Def and dancers from the prestigious Senegal-based École des Sables. The original song was written for MSF by Mao Sidibé, and the lyrics are an artistic interpretation of testimonies from our projects in Niger, Cameroon, and Madagascar.  

The choreography was specifically made for this project by École des Sables to represent different elements of the environment. The video features images from some of the countries where MSF works that are impacted by climate change.

title: Stop the genocide in Gaza
description:
MSF teams are witnessing a genocide in Gaza committed by Israeli forces. We see the impacts of mass killings; forced displacement; destruction of vital civilian infrastructure; and a punishing siege cutting off access to food, water, medicines, and other humanitarian supplies. Israeli authorities are systematically destroying the conditions necessary for Palestinian life in Gaza.

#gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: Gaza City offensive: Where can 1 million people go?
description: Filmed in early September, these doctors and patients from the MSF clinic in Gaza City hear the Israeli bombing intensify day and night. They face an impossible choice.

title: Supporting survivors of violence in Papua New Guinea
description:
Nearly 60 percent of women and girls in Papua New Guinea face physical or sexual violence—almost double the global average.  

Today we’re sharing a look into how MSF’s new project in Jiwaka province, in the Western Highlands region, is facilitating survivor-led safe spaces, essential health care for violence survivors, and an effort aimed at empowering a future generation of women and girls in the province.

title: In the West Bank, Palestinians are facing forced mass displacement
description:
Across the West Bank, Palestinians are facing forced mass displacement by Israeli forces and settlers, significantly heightening the risk of ethnic cleansing in the occupied territory. 

In Kisan village, where MSF has been working, recent settler violence and demolition orders have forced 23 families to flee. MSF is witnessing policies and practices that are blatantly designed to remove Palestinians from their land and prevent any possibility of return. https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/risk-ethnic-cleansing-west-bank

title: In Bangladesh, Rohingya artists use the taro leaf as a powerful symbol for self-advocacy
description:
Water droplets roll off the water-repellent, heart-shaped taro leaves, a powerful metaphor for the Rohingya experience of statelessness. The leaves embody the feeling of floating, belonging nowhere, and being caught between countries that do not want them.

Eight years after a mass exodus of the Rohingya from their homeland in Myanmar, more than 1 million people live in overcrowded camps in Bangladesh’s Cox’s Bazar—now the largest refugee settlement in the world. Their struggles over successive cycles of violence and persecution have long been an underreported crisis.

Rohingya bamboo weaver Nurul Islam: “We don’t have anywhere to settle. If they can settle us back in our home, we can leave in peace. This is what we are trying to say with the taro leaf.”

title: CNN interview: "Nowhere is safe in Gaza today"
description:
CNN interviewed Amande Bazerolle, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) deputy program manager in charge of Palestine, about the missile strikes on Nasser hospital in Gaza that killed 22 people, including five journalists on August 25, and the lack of essential aid coming into the Gaza Strip.

title: Rohingya refugees adopt a symbol representing their struggle and their power
description:
August 25, 2025, marks eight years since the campaign of extreme violence by the Myanmar authorities against Rohingya people in Myanmar’s Rakhine state in 2017. Myanmar's military forced more than 700,000 Rohingya to flee to Bangladesh, where the new arrivals joined thousands of other Rohingya who had left during earlier waves of violence and persecution in Myanmar. Most of these refugees still live in fragile shelters in overcrowded settlements. They are not permitted to work and must rely on dwindling humanitarian aid for survival. 

The Rohingya are a predominantly Muslim ethnic minority who have lived in Myanmar for hundreds of years. Because they are denied citizenship by Myanmar’s government, they are officially stateless and face particular challenges obtaining access to health care and other basic rights.

In this video, Rohingya community members, artists, and advocates in Cox's Bazar, Bangladesh, describe how they feel about their situation and why they have adopted the taro leaf as their symbol.

Credits:
Nurul Islam, bamboo weaving
Nuru Sabar, fish net weaving
Mohamed Kolim, woodworking
Senu Anara, embroidery
Mr. Kali and Ms. Beshi Bala, ceramics
Sahat Zia Hero, photography
Rayhana Begum, cuisine
Mohammed Yakub, storytelling
Mohammed Faruk with ten Rohingya children, illustration

Read more about the Rohingya: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/rohingya-refugee-crisis

title: #DRC: MSF teams provide care to recent influx of South Sudanese refugees
description:
Nearly 30,000 refugees have fled from South Sudan to neighboring DR Congo (DRC), a country that is engulfed in a crisis of its own. MSF has teams in South Sudan, responding to disease outbreaks, and in DR Congo providing care to people amid conflict.  

This past May, we launched an emergency intervention to provide lifesaving medical care in Ituri province in northeastern DRC, where most South Sudanese are crossing. Even before the recent influx of refugees, health systems in the province were under strain and almost non-existent in the border area.

title: In Gaza, malnutrition continues to escalate
description:
Janna is 8 months old and suffers from severe malnutrition. In the waiting area, mom Saja gives her a bottle of water: "She only sleeps after drinking water, pretending it’s milk. There’s nothing else to give her."  

Inside our Al-Attar clinic in Khan Younis, Gaza, mothers wait for care while MSF team members hold health sessions and measure mid-upper-arm circumference to check babies like one-year-old Adam for malnutrition.❤️‍🩹

People are starving.  
Food has been weaponized. 
North of Khan Younis, in Gaza governorate, famine was officially declared today, August 22, by the UN-coordinated IPC mechanism. Famine is projected to expand to other parts of the strip, including Khan Younis, by the end of September. 

Let Gaza Live.

title: I am a humanitarian
description: To be a humanitarian means to help alleviate people’s suffering, reaching out to those who find themselves in the most difficult circumstances. On this World Humanitarian Day, we honor our diverse staff, supporters, and colleagues around the world—and everyone who believes in our shared humanity.

title: Let Gaza have water
description:
Israel is deliberately depriving people of water in Gaza as part of its genocidal campaign. The amount of water available for Palestinians is wholly insufficient. MSF and other organizations could increase the production of water in Gaza, but the Israeli authorities continue to prevent us from bringing in critical water items.

#gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: Syrian mother freed from prison shares her story
description:
“I was taken to solitary confinement while my daughters were locked in another cell," said Suha*, a 50-year-old Syrian woman who was detained in 2018 without charge and held for six years. “I didn’t care about the beatings I took, hoping that when the beating stopped, I would find out the fate of my daughters.”  
 
Suha*, like hundreds of Syrian prisoners and detainees, gained her freedom when the gates of prisons were opened in the wake of the collapse of the Assad regime in December 2024. Many people spent years in detention under very harsh conditions and exposed to endless cycles of physical and psychological abuse. Survivors suffer from injuries, trauma, and chronic health conditions due to these years of systematic torture and neglect. In response to these huge medical and mental health needs, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched a program for survivors of torture in Syria.
Learn more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/facing-ghosts-torture-syria
#doctorswithoutborders #mentalhealth #syria 

*Name has been changed

title: Doctor operates in Ukraine while bombs cut power
description: In Kherson, southern Ukraine, an MSF medical team continues surgery while explosions at the nearby frontline cause electricity cuts.

title: Ukraine: My country’s at war and I’m documenting it
description: Former news reporter, now MSF communications officer Yuliia Trofimova documents our medical teams' responses to mass casualties and missile strikes while trying to reconcile life in her country before the full-scale war with the present.

title: Emergency: Cholera outbreak in Sudan
description:
In the midst of an all-out war, people in Sudan are now experiencing the worst cholera outbreak the country has seen in years. Clean water shortages mean people are drinking contaminated water. In one year, there's been almost 100,000 suspected cholera cases. We need a bigger international response - water and sanitation, cholera vaccinations, and medical care. #sudan #talkaboutsudan #doctorswithoutborders #news 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: #Chad: “During the rainy season, it’s like being in a prison.”
description:
These are some of the experiences of community members in Sila, eastern Chad, where extreme rains during the rainy season can make travel difficult and dangerous, and community resources even more vital. To protect people’s health in Chad this season, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing water and sanitation services, as well as vaccination and community health support. 

Community members play a key role in decision-making and implementing activities, helping us to design a health program that fits their needs. They also worked behind the camera to produce this video capturing their day-to-day surroundings and critical roles.

title: Doctors and nurses in Gaza speak about overcrowded hospitals
description:
Lift the siege. Stop the genocide. 

Doctors and nurses in Gaza speak about overcrowded hospitals: “Patients are dying while waiting, dying from infection, dying from complications that are entirely treatable if this were anywhere else.”

title: This is what it's like to get food in Gaza right now
description:
(No sounds effects or alterations were made to this footage.)
An analysis of MSF medical data, patient testimonies, and firsthand medical witnessing point to both targeted and indiscriminate violence by Israeli forces and private American contractors against starved Palestinians at food distribution sites run by the so-called Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF). These are sites of orchestrated killing and dehumanization. The GHF is a deadly scheme that must be dismantled. People need access to food and lifesaving aid now. 

Our report (link below): “This is not aid. This is orchestrated killing” documents the horrors witnessed by MSF staff at two clinics in Gaza that regularly received mass influxes of casualties following violence at sites run by the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation.  

Read the report: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/us-backed-aid-distribution-points-gaza-are-sites-orchestrated-killing

title: GHF in Gaza: This is not aid, this is orchestrated killing
description:
The GHF (Gaza Humanitarian Foundation) is nothing but a deadly scheme, institutionalizing the Israeli policy of using starvation as a weapon of war in Gaza. Israel has imposed a full siege on Gaza since March 2 as part of an ongoing genocidal campaign.

title: US: Dehumanizing migration policies
description:
The current US administration has implemented the most restrictive and dehumanizing migration policies seen in years, abandoning hundreds of thousands of people hoping to seek asylum in the US and leaving them stranded in Mexico and Central America. This suffering is deliberately made invisible, hidden by the inaccurate narrative that migration has stopped. #mexico #immigration #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: Funding cuts for humanitarian aid in Ethiopia lead to overwhelmed MSF clinic
description: Our teams are overwhelmed by the increasing number of patients we are seeing at the Kule refugee camp, one of seven camps in Ethiopia’s Gambela region hosting mostly South Sudanese refugees. The general decline of humanitarian funding, including from key partners such as USAID, has led to the suspension of nutrition services in four of the camps, leaving around 80,000 children under the age of 5 at risk of life-threatening malnutrition.

title: ABC News interview: MSF sees fourfold increase of malnutrition patients
description:
On August 5, 2025, MSF project coordinator Caroline Willemen spoke to ABC News about the humanitarian situation in Gaza. From Gaza City, Willemen described the devastating situation: “We’ve had a fourfold increase of patients in our malnutrition program since May. On top of that, we continue to see patients who are getting shot or crushed at aid distribution sites.”  

Our teams are receiving an increasing number of malnourished patients while they themselves struggle to find sufficient food. Among screenings at MSF facilities in July, 25 percent of children aged 6 months to 5 years old and pregnant or breastfeeding women were malnourished. The ongoing hunger crisis in Gaza will not be solved with military-controlled aid distribution models. A principled, UN-led humanitarian response must be restored immediately. 

Link in bio for the full interview: https://abcnews.go.com/International/video/gazas-population-hungry-months-doctors-borders-coordinator-124385433

title: #Nigeria: In the fistulas ward, women are finding care, support, and community
description:
At Jahun General Hospital in northern Nigeria, MSF teams are providing reconstructive surgery, mental health care, and rehabilitation to about 300 women every year who have obstetric fistulas, a debilitating complication of childbirth. Fistulas can lead to complications such as infection or infertility, and incontinence. 

Clémence Chbat, medical referent for women's health at MSF : “The fistula unit is a place where women can talk about what they're going through. Because they have experienced the same difficulties, they form a special relationship. Together, they do their best to heal from their wounds. It's a place where you can see a lot of hope.”

title: Life after evacuating Gaza: "Leaving Gaza" Documentary
description:
Emad, an MSF nurse supervisor, was evacuated with his family to France in March 2025  from Gaza, after surviving 17 months of bombing and multiple displacements. One of his three daughters, Sila, suffers from a congenital heart condition, which led to their evacuation. She is now receiving medical treatment in France.  

Emad and his family are constantly in touch with relatives and friends who are still in Gaza struggling to find food. “[My mother] asked me ‘are you eating meat over there? We can’t even find lentils to cook.’ And honestly, you feel powerless. There’s nothing you can say in response,” says Emad. 

Watch the short documentary “Leaving Gaza” on our YouTube channel.

title: Leaving Gaza: Emad, from Gaza to Marseille
description:
Emad was evacuated with his family from Gaza to France in March 2025. Together, they survived 17 months of hunger, bombings, and multiple displacements. A nursing supervisor, Emad has worked with MSF for the past nine years in several health facilities in Gaza. His 7-year-old daughter, Sila, suffers from a congenital heart condition, which eventually led to their evacuation to France, where she is now receiving medical care. Currently, at least 12,000 patients, including thousands of children like Sila, need to be evacuated urgently from Gaza to access vital medical care. Here is their story.
Credit: 

Interview Mohammad Ghannam 

Images Manon Tarasconi 

Translation Basheer Al Hajji 

Edited by Simon Rolin 

Written by Agnes Varraine-Leca, Armelle Loiseau 

Produced by Médecins Sans Frontières, 2025

title: Gaza: The health system is collapsing
description:
MSF’s Al Zawaida field hospital in Deir Al-Balah, central Gaza, is over capacity, with no space for new patients. Most trauma cases require major surgeries for limb and abdominal injuries, yet we have no stock of external fixators to heal broken bones. We are running out of other supplies, including blood and critical antibiotics. The ongoing blockade and the dangerous and disorganized practices of providing the bare minimum of food to a starving population are fueling desperation and internal violence, while placing an unbearable burden on Gaza’s collapsing health system. “The health system is overwhelmed and it's collapsing,” said Dr. Mohammed Fadlalla, MSF medical activity manager in Gaza. “As we speak, it's collapsing.” #gaza #doctorswithoutborders #news

Israeli authorities are intentionally weaponizing food and aid at unprecedented levels. Caroline Willemen, project coordinator at the MSF clinic in Gaza City, shares how “people have been hungry for months” and why “a small, small trickle of food” aid is simply not enough. We must reject military-controlled distribution models and restore a principled, UN-led humanitarian response immediately. #gaza #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: Syria: Health care for neglected communities
description:
For over a decade, people’s health needs in Syria were neglected due to the war. Health facilities were systematically damaged and destroyed, leaving some people, especially those living in rural areas, with little to no health care access.  

MSF teams are responding to the medical and humanitarian needs of the people in #syria with services such as specialized burn treatment, emergency care, and maternal health care. We remain committed to closing the gaps in medical access across the country. 
Learn more: 
#news #doctorswithoutborders

description:
Medical activities manager Dr. Mohammad Fadlalla joins Chris Jansing on MSNBC Reports to share the grim reality of starvation in Gaza - telling Chris to imagine health workers working a hospital shift, not able to eat, exhausted, and going home where their families are hungry.

title: Extreme heat is a not just a climate issue, it’s a public heatlh emergency
description:
Extreme heat kills nearly 500,000 people worldwide each year. Our bodies need to stay around 98.6 F to function properly, but rising temperatures put millions at risk. Children, elderly, pregnant women, and people who work outdoors are especially vulnerable. Learn the difference between dry and humid heat and why it matters for your health. 

#climatechange #climateaction #doctorswithoutborders

title: CNNi interview: The people of Gaza are starving
description:
There is barely any food available throughout most of  Gaza. Israeli authorities are intentionally weaponizing food and aid at unprecedented levels. Caroline Willemen, project coordinator at the MSF clinic in Gaza City, shares the impact this is having on patients and health care workers alike who are fighting to survive. “I have colleagues asking for cans of milk for their babies and I have no way to support them for something as simple as that," Caroline told CNN International. We must reject military-controlled distribution models and restore a principled, UN-led humanitarian response immediately. #gaza #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: CNN interview: Dr. Mohammed Abu Mughaisib speaks on acute hunger and starvation in Gaza
description:
“Unfortunately, now in Gaza, doctors and paramedics just do the consultation and diagnose malnutrition, but we don't have [anything] to give or treat it. They need supplements. They need milk formula. It’s not available at all.” 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières Deputy Medical Coordinator in Gaza Dr. Mohammed Abu Mughaisib speaks to CNN about the devastating situation in Gaza amid acute hunger and starvation. Israeli authorities’ deliberate use of starvation as a weapon in Gaza has reached unprecedented levels, with patients and health care workers themselves now fighting to survive.

title: Doctor in Gaza experiencing hunger explains how starvation destroys the body
description:
It's truly unbearable to have to show this: A Doctors Without Borders colleague sent us a video from Gaza explaining how starvation destroys the body. Dr. Mohammed Abu Mughaisib, MSF deputy medical coordinator is eating maybe one meal a day, and health workers themselves are fighting to survive alongside our patients. Israeli authorities’ deliberate use of starvation as a weapon in Gaza has reached unprecedented levels.

#gaza #doctorswithoutborders #news #humanitariancrisis

title: Measles outbreak in Yemen
description:
Measles is surging in Dhamar, Yemen. Many people do not have access to health care, and this outbreak is a clear reminder of the importance of vaccination and strengthening preventative measures. #measlesoutbreak #measles #vaccination #vaccines #vaccinessavelives #yemen 
Find out more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/childrens-lives-are-risk-measles-surges-yemeni-governorate

title: #Gaza: MSF staff member recounts recent attack on church that injured his three-year-old son
description: Yesterday, on July 17, Israeli forces struck the Holy Family Church in Gaza City, where hundreds of displaced people, including MSF staff and their families, were sheltering. Three people were killed and several others were injured, including Carlos, the three-year-old son of our colleague Edward Antone, who works as a driver for MSF.

title: The mental toll of settler and military violence in the West Bank
description:
The practices and policies of the Israeli government to reportedly annex the West Bank are impacting the physical and mental health of our patients. Palestinians in the West Bank, especially those living in Hebron’s southern countryside in areas like Masafer Yatta, face daily threats of forcible transfer, injury, and death. The constant fear of aggression and violence committed by Israeli settlers and armed forces takes a massive toll on the mental health of Palestinians. #westbank #westbanknews #doctorswithoutborders #news 
Find out more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/devastating-mental-toll-constant-settler-and-military-violence-west-bank
