title: The search for clarity on the killings of three MSF staff in Ethiopia
description: MSF has published the findings of an internal review of the brutal murder of three of our colleagues—María Hernández Matas, Tedros Gebremariam Gebremichael, and Yohannes Halefom Reda—in central Tigray, Ethiopia, on June 24, 2021. The review confirmed that the attack was an intentional and targeted killing of three clearly identified aid workers. It also established that a convoy of Ethiopian National Defense Forces (ENDF) was present at the time of the incident, on the same road where the MSF personnel were killed. We hope that by pursuing the truth of what happened to our colleagues, we can contribute to building a safer environment for humanitarians around the world. Find out more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/search-clarity-killings-three-msf-staff-ethiopia-executive-summary  #tigray #tigraynews #doctorswithoutborders #news

title: Thousands of people need urgent medical evacuation from Gaza
description:
More than 56,000 people have been killed and around 125,000 wounded in Gaza since October 7, 2023. Among the wounded, thousands require specialized medical care that is unavailable because the health care system in Gaza has been decimated by Israeli forces . To make matters worse, Israel has reduced medical evacuations to a near halt, with many critical cases being delayed or denied regardless of medical urgency. 

 Israel must immediately facilitate the medical evacuation of the thousands of patients in need of lifesaving care and countries must open their doors to provide health care to these patients. A clear and predictable medical evacuation system with safe corridors and without family separations must be urgently established, while ensuring Palestinians’ right to return to Gaza after treatment. 

00:00-00:19 - Gaza urgently needs medical evacuations
00:19-1:21 -  How the medical evacuation process works and the challenges faced at different stages
1:21-2:15 - How medical cases are being blocked from evacuation 
2:15- 3:02 -  The limited options in countries opened to taking these cases
3:02-4:30 - The challenges MSF have observed while doing medical evacuations 
4:30-5:00 - We call to other countries to participate in medical evacuations and for better system

title: Gaza: “Who are we not to have hope?”
description: Dr. Aqsa Durrani, a US-based pediatrician and epidemiologist, worked with MSF at a field hospital in Deir al-Balah, in central Gaza. There is still hope in Gaza—don’t turn away from what’s happening there. Let Gaza live.

title: Starvation in Gaza: Listen to what these moms are going through
description:
Many families are surviving on just one portion of food a day—often only rice, lentils, or pasta—with no access to bread, fresh vegetables, or enough protein. 

Parents are skipping meals to feed their children. Even malnourished women who receive therapeutic food end up giving their own treatment supplements to their children. 

At MSF clinics, injured patients beg for food instead of medicine. The lack of food prevents healing. 

The existence of malnutrition in Gaza is the result of deliberate, calculated choices by Israeli authorities: to restrict the entry of food to the bare minimum for survival, control and militarize its distribution, and destroy local food production capacity.

title: Innovative waste treatment for refugees fleeing the war in Sudan
description:
MSF has constructed a fecal sludge treatment site in Aboutengue camp, eastern Chad, which hosts approximately 45,000 Sudanese refugees. The treatment site, locally referred to as the "poop factory,” processes waste from 932 latrines built by MSF to support improved sanitation. This project stands out because it’s not only focused on sanitation but also on environmental sustainability. It requires minimal energy to operate, apart from the fuel needed for the motor pumps. In the future, we may explore using solar-powered pumps to make the system even more eco-friendly. #innovation #humanitarianaid #wastemanagement #ecofriendlysolutions #environmentalsustainability 

Find out more about this project on our website: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/innovative-waste-treatment-helping-make-sudanese-refugees-safer-chad

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Let Gaza Live
description:
Israel has crossed every red line in Gaza. Civilians are being killed and maimed. People are being starved. Health workers don't have the supplies they need to do their jobs. 

 The world is watching while blood continues to spill, dignity is stripped away, and our shared humanity is under attack. We do not accept this systematic destruction of Palestinian lives.

title: The Humanitarian Lens #podcast: A doctor's experience in Gaza
description:
On this episode of the Humanitarian Lens podcast, host Avril Benoît speaks with Dr. Aqsa Durrani, a US-based pediatrician and epidemiologist, whose latest assignment took her to an MSF field hospital in Deir al-Balah, in central Gaza.  

Dr. Durrani describes the immense suffering of civilians across the Gaza Strip after more than a year and a half of an all-out war and a brutal siege. Israeli forces are systematically destroying the conditions necessary for Palestinian life. 

During her assignment, Dr. Durrani, along with her MSF colleagues, treated patients of all ages affected by injuries from airstrikes, burns, fractures, and gunshot wounds, among others. The vast majority of patients she saw were women and children. 

The Humanitarian Lens, a new podcast from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) USA, explores some of the world’s most urgent humanitarian emergencies through the personal experiences of our aid workers.

Watch the full episode on our YouTube channel or Spotify, and listen to it on Apple Podcasts and Castbox audio platforms. 

#humanitarianorganization #podcast #podcastclips #gaza #news #newspodcast

title: Finding hope in Gaza
description:
Twenty-one months into all-out war, with tens of thousands of Palestinians killed by bombs, hunger, and lack of access to medical care, we asked Gazans at an MSF clinic how they feel about hope right now. “I see hope in people's eyes, in the eyes of the children, in the eyes of the patients who come to us,” says Yasser Btniji, a staff member of the MSF clinic. There is still hope in Gaza—don’t turn away from what’s happening there. Let Gaza live. 

#doctorswithoutborders #gaza

title: A doctor's account from Gaza
description:
On this episode of the Humanitarian Lens podcast, host Avril Benoît speaks with Dr. Aqsa Durrani, a US-based pediatrician and epidemiologist, whose latest assignment was at an MSF field hospital in Deir al-Balah, in central Gaza.  

Dr. Durrani describes the immense suffering of civilians across the Gaza Strip after more than a year and a half of an all-out war and a brutal siege. Israeli forces are systematically destroying the conditions necessary for Palestinian life. 

During her assignment, from February 24 through April 24, 2025, Dr. Durrani and her colleagues treated patients of all ages for injuries from airstrikes, burns, fractures, and gunshot wounds, among others. The vast majority of patients she saw were women and children. 

Learn more about MSF’s response in Gaza on our website: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: Climate impacts nutritional health on remote island
description: The people of Kiribati, an island nation in the Central Pacific, are on the forefront of climate change, and this significantly affects their health. Women and their children are particularly impacted, and MSF is addressing issues including increased risks of infant and maternal death, birth complications, and waterborne and insect-related illnesses.

title: Gaza: Two MSF staff and their children injured in airstrike
description:
After being rescued from underneath the rubble, the family of five has been forced to seek care between three hospitals, and travel from the north to the center of Gaza, because no single facility can provide the care they need.
#doctorswithoutborders #ceasefirenow

title: In Sudan, a child loses his hand and is uprooted again by violence
description:
Eleven-year-old Mahanat also lost his father in the blast that caused him to lose his left hand. He and his family had fled violence in Tawila and were sheltering in Zamzam camp in North Darfur when the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces attacked. MSF brought Mahanat across the border to Chad for surgical treatment.
#talkaboutsudan #doctorswithoutborders #sudan

title: PBS interview: In Gaza, dozens killed by Israeli strikes and gunfire
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières doctor Mohammed Fadlalla is working at a field hospital in Gaza. On July 1, 2025, he spoke to PBS Newshour about the injuries he’s seeing from patients who had been waiting for food. The Israeli-US food distribution scheme, operating under the name the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, launched a month ago and is forcing Palestinians to choose between starvation or risking their lives for minuscule amounts of aid.

The Humanitarian Lens #podcast: How MSF is responding to the world’s worst humanitarian emergency
description:
New video podcast alert!  

We are excited to launch The Humanitarian Lens, a new podcast from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) USA, which explores some of the world’s most urgent humanitarian emergencies through the personal experiences of our aid workers. 

On this first episode, host and MSF USA CEO Avril Benoît discusses the crisis in Sudan with Dr. Mohammed Fadlalla, a physician who has completed multiple assignments with MSF over the past five years, most recently in Omdurman, Sudan. Sudan is currently convulsed by a conflict that has been raging for more than two years, and the fighting is fueling the world’s worst humanitarian crisis. In this episode you’ll hear first-hand from Dr. Fadlalla about the lifesaving work MSF teams are doing under some of the most difficult conditions imaginable. 

Watch the full episode on our YouTube channel or Spotify, and listen to it on Apple Podcasts and Castbox audio platforms. 

#DoctorsWithoutBorders #HumanitarianLens #Podcast #sudan

title: In #Gaza, aid distribution sites have become "a death trap"
description: For a month now, since May 27, the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF)—a privatized, militarized US-Israeli run aid distribution system—has turned aid distribution sites into death traps, killing and injuring desperate and starving people. Our teams bear witness to the daily aftermath of these aid distribution sites in our clinics and field hospitals. MSF demands the immediate dismantling of GHF and calls for unrestricted, dignified aid distribution to stop this systematic carnage.

title: Sudan: How MSF is responding to the world’s worst humanitarian emergency
description:
What is happening in Sudan?

On this first episode of The Humanitarian Lens podcast from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) USA, join host Avril Benoît and MSF doctor Mohammed Fadlalla for a deep dive into the spiraling humanitarian emergency in Sudan.

More than two years of war in Sudan between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have left more than 30 million people in need humanitarian aid. More than 12 million have fled their homes, including millions of refugees who have crossed into neighboring Chad and South Sudan.

Sudan's health system has been pushed to the point of collapse, and medical needs in the country are dire. And this crisis is unfolding amid unprecedented cuts to international humanitarian aid, not only from the US government but other nations, which have caused massive disruption to global health and humanitarian programs.

Dr. Fadlalla has completed multiple assignments in Sudan with MSF over the past five years, including most recently in Omdurman, Sudan’s second most populous city. In this episode, he shares his experience coordinating medical activities, working closely with locally hired Sudanese colleagues and staff from Sudan’s Ministry of Health in two hospitals in Omdurman from mid-November 2024 to March 6, 2025.

Learn more about the crisis in Sudan and MSF’s work on our website: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/sudan-crisis-response

Follow MSF USA on social media for updates about our medical humanitarian work. 
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/doctorswithoutborders/
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/msf-usa
BlueSky: https://bsky.app/profile/doctorswithoutborders.org

title: One donkey cart ride at a time, a refugee helps others in Dadaab camp
description:
Hassan Ali Shakur, a refugee in the Dadaab camp in Kenya, has transported hundreds of patients in need of care to the hospital in his donkey cart. MSF has been providing care to refugees in Dadaab for decades. Today, 443 refugee staff are part of our teams, supporting access to care for disease outbreaks, emergency treatment, and basic health services.

#worldrefugeeday #doctorswithoutborders

title: Fear as a border: an animated poem about migration
description:
On the migration corridor through the Americas, fear isn't just a consequence of forced displacement, it's also a tool used systematically to terrify people on the move. From Central America to Mexico’s northern border, MSF has witnessed firsthand how fear of abuse, extortion, eviction, detention, even just voicelessness, shapes every decision and profoundly affects the physical and mental health of those seeking protection. 

 #doctorswithoutborders #worldrefugeeday

title: MSF Live from Mexico City: Providing medical care for migrants and asylum seekers on the move
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) invites you for a virtual tour of our medical and mental health projects in Mexico City on Tuesday, June 17, at 12:00 pm ET.   

In May 2023, the United States introduced legislative changes that severely restrict access to asylum, which has had a significant impact on the people who end up stranded at Mexico's northern border. Migrants continue to live in dire conditions, with little access to protection, shelter, water and sanitation, or medical care. Furthermore, many of them have been traumatized by exposure to violence during their journeys. Despite this, Mexico recorded an unprecedented number of migrants last year.

Since 2017, MSF has been providing specialized multidisciplinary care to people who have experienced torture or extreme violence at our Comprehensive Care Center (CAI) in Mexico City. Many of the patients at this facility are migrants or asylum seekers who have experienced violence along the migration route. Doctors, phycologists, social workers, and physical and occupational therapists help these patients heal from trauma and connect them with the resources they need to adapt to their new lives in Mexico.

We will meet a few of these dedicated MSF staff members during our virtual tour of CAI, and will hold a live discussion with Joaquim Guinart Verdaguer, MSF project coordinator at CAI, and Mercedes Alarcón, medical doctor. We will also hear testimonies from Cassandra Melendez, community health promoter, and Isaac Torres, psychologist. The event will be moderated by Avril Benoît, MSF USA’s chief executive officer.

Join us to learn more about MSF's work and how teams are responding to growing challenges at Mexico's northern border.

title: Gaza: Every red line has been crossed, EU must act
description: The hypocrisy and inaction of the European Union and its member states have allowed Israel to freely continue its massacre of Palestinians in Gaza with total impunity. MSF calls for impartial, needs-based aid to be facilitated into the Gaza Strip at scale, the protection of civilians, and the immediate restoration of a sustained ceasefire. European governments must act decisively to expedite this.

title: Why MSF vaccinates kids against measles
description: US funding to the only organization supporting a community in northeast Kenya was cut, leaving a dangerous gap in disease surveillance and making a timely response to outbreaks extremely challenging. MSF has been supporting the Kenyan Ministry of Health’s emergency medical response to a measles outbreak in the northeast of the country.

title: Breaking down barriers and stigma in #kenya
description:
Powel is a transgender woman who works as a peer mentor, leading awareness sessions and sharing her expertise with young people who have just arrived at the center. Here, she explains the barriers to care that people experience.  
 
In Mombasa, we work with key populations in particular, a group defined by the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV and AIDS (UNAIDS) as men who have sex with men, transgender people and those with diverse gender identities or expressions, people who use drugs, and sex workers. MSF also works with other vulnerable groups like young people experiencing homelessness, as well as those living with disabilities. These identities and experiences can often intersect, which further increases vulnerability. 
 
All too often, the people we work with have already found themselves excluded from the mainstream health care system. When they seek help, they face discrimination. We see this every day. That's why we have put communities at the heart of our project.

title: Burn care in Haiti: "When [my mother] saw me, she was shocked"
description: After months in the hospital, Stanley returned home to see his family, equipped with his 3D compression mask. “When [my mother] saw me, she was shocked,” he said. “But when she saw my face regain color with the mask, she regained hope. So did I.” MSF’s Tabarre hospital in Port-au-Prince is the only place in Haiti providing free care for patients with severe burns.

title: Answering Google Search Questions About Doctors Without Borders
description:
How do I join Doctors Without Borders? Does Doctors Without Borders actually help? Does Doctors Without Borders receive US government funding? Does Doctors Without Borders do abortions? Chigozie Ahunanya of MSF USA People and Culture answers these questions and more. #doctorswithoutborders

title: Answering Google Search Questions About Doctors Without Borders
description:
In this video, we answer the web’s most searched for questions about Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) on Google. Does Doctors Without Borders actually help? Does Doctors Without Borders receive US government funding? Does Doctors Without Borders do abortions? Doctors Without Borders how do I join? Why doesn't Doctors Without Borders work in the US? title: Displacement orders in Gaza are psychological warfare
description:
In Gaza, the constant state of alert and unpredictability of displacement orders have devastating consequences for people’s mental health.  

“Israeli forces are destroying all means of life for Palestinians in Gaza through psychological and physical warfare," says Claire Manera, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) emergency coordinator. "Forced displacements are part of the Israeli forces and authorities’ campaign of ethnic cleansing of the Palestinian people. They have nowhere else to go.”

title: Earthquake Response: How to pack an emergency kit for a family
description:
We continue to support people affected by the earthquake in Myanmar that hit in March. Our teams are providing medical care, distributing non-food items kits, and working closely with local communities. #myanmar #myanmarnews #myanmarearthquake #myanmarearthquaketoday #doctorswithoutborders #news 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: In Gaza, three generations in one tent: Sahar
description: “We were displaced many times, maybe 10 or 11 times. We kept moving. The last few months have been the hardest,” says Sahar, who shares a tent with three generations of her family, on the ruins of their home in Beit Lahia in northern Gaza. “In the future, I just wish for my children to live a better life than the one they have now. I don’t wish for anything more than that.”  Watch the full documentary “Gaza: Displaced lives” on the Doctors Without Borders/MSF USA YouTube channel.

title: In Gaza, three generations in one tent: Hanan
description: “The day my daughter was killed, my life shut down,” says Hanan, a mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother who lives with surviving family members in a tent in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza. “It’s been nearly a year and a half of living like this: gathering wood, water, and such things. It’s exhausting, especially the smoke from the fire.” Watch the full documentary “Gaza: Displaced lives” on the Doctors Without Borders YouTube channel.

title: The daily lives of a family in #Gaza: "Displaced Lives"
description:
Since October 2023, nearly 90% of the population of Gaza has been displaced. Families are living in makeshift camps and overcrowded shelters, with limited access to water, food, and medical care. Following the temporary ceasefire that began in January 2025, more than half a million people returned to northern Gaza to see what remained of their homes. 

This short documentary, “Displaced Lives,” follows the experiences of four generations of women from the same family as they navigate displacement in this conflict zone.

title: #Syria: 3D printing masks for burn patients
description:
After 13 years of war in Syria and the fall of the Assad regime, over 7.2 million people remain displaced in the country, living in camps without basic services like heating and electricity. Since the US terminated most humanitarian aid funding this year, conditions have worsened, and many health facilities have closed. Burn injuries from unsafe heating methods are common.  Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) treats thousands of victims with severe burns each year at our hospital in Atmeh, northwest Syria. We use 3D -printers to make facial compression masks that reduce scarring and improve recovery. #syria  #syriaupdate #news #doctorswithoutborders 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: #Gaza: Food is running out
description:
Palestinians in Gaza are facing a death sentence.  More than two months ago, Israel launched a total siege on Gaza, and since then has prevented any humanitarian aid from entering. Food and medical supplies are running out. Fuel, which is necessary to run ambulances, health care facilities, and water desalination plants, is running dangerously low. We are running out of time to save lives. #gazawar #gazaconflict #gazanews #news #doctorswithoutborders 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Finding hope after a traumatic kidnapping in Honduras
description:
MSF teams at the Comprehensive Care Center for victims of extreme violence in Mexico City have seen a significant increase in mental health consultations and new patients over the last six months. Here, Estefany (not her real name) tells her story of being kidnapped by a gang in Honduras, getting separated from family members, and subsequently struggling with her mental health. 

#mentalhealth #doctorswithoutborders #migration

title: #Chad: Providing mental health care for displaced youth
description:
Mental health and living in a displacement camp: Mudathir is 20 years old and from Darfur, and hasn't found a way to continue his studies since arriving. The Metché camp in eastern Chad is home to over 43,000 Sudanese people who have fled war. It's in the middle of the desert, isolated on all sides, in a region where there is almost nothing to do. 

 The climate is harsh, with extreme heat and hardly a tree under which to shelter from the sun. Living conditions are extremely difficult: recurrent shortages in food distribution, very limited access to water and electricity, and the only structures are made of straw or plastic-and are not secure.  

In the camp, our mental health teams help refugees and host communities. We have community spaces where mental health counsellors offer individual sessions. Among the main symptoms observed, our teams mention psychological distress, difficulty sleeping, nightmares, and mood disorders such as depression and psychotic symptoms.Those under the age of 20 are also greatly affected, as they struggle to envisage a better future and are more vulnerable to chronic stress and anxiety.

title: Palestinians in Gaza are facing a death sentence
description:
We are running out of time to save lives. The humanitarian situation in Gaza is catastrophic, as a result of the ongoing Israeli-imposed siege that has lasted for over two months. We call on the Israeli authorities and their supporters to abide by International Humanitarian Law and follow the principles which allow for unhindered humanitarian aid for people trapped inside the Strip.
#gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: "Libya at the crossroads" teaser
description: The "Libya at the crossroads" documentary features stories of migrants who faced devastating hardships while trying to survive in Libya. Both workers and refugees live in precarious conditions and are subjected to violence and abuse inside and outside of the country's notorious detention centers. Access to healthcare for these migrants is severely hindered though they are often in desperate need of it.

title: “Libya at the crossroads” documentary
description:
Around 725,000 migrants were in Libya in 2024, according to the International Organization for Migration. While some people come to Libya seeking work, others attempt to reach Europe by crossing the Mediterranean Sea.  

Migrant workers and refugees live in precarious conditions and are subjected to violence and abuse inside and outside of the country's notorious detention centers, including kidnapping, extortion, trafficking, assault, and sexualabuse. Access to health care for these migrants is severely limited, though they are often in desperate need of it.  

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams provide medical support in the Libyan cities of Misrata, Tripoli, and Zuwara. Our teams provide primary health care, diagnosis and treatment of tuberculosis (TB), and care for sexual and reproductive health, mental health, and survivors of sexual violence. The most serious medical cases requiring hospitalization are referred to the capital.  

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/migrants-libya-your-destiny-can-change-any-moment

title: Sudan: Thousands of people flee after attack on largest refugee camp
description:
In Tawila, more displaced people continue to arrive. The half-million residents of #Zamzam camp in #Sudan had been starved, shelled, and deprived of lifesaving assistance before they came under attack. Now they are in a new location, food and water are urgently needed. Measles had already begun to spread in displacement sites. Malnutrition and measles can be a deadly combination in kids. #sudanwar #sudanconflict #talkaboutsudan 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Deliberate bombing of our hospital in Old Fangak, South Sudan
description:
Hospitals, health workers, and civilians must be protected. This footage shows the devastating aftermath of the hospital bombing in South Sudan on May 3. After the attack on Old Fangak Hospital, the only functional medical facility in Fangak county, more than 100,000 people are now left with no access to medical care. Mamman Mustapha, MSF head of mission in South Sudan, explains what happened.

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Supporting school feeding programs in #Sudan
description:
Going to school and getting food during war in Sudan:

In South Darfur, where humanitarian aid is scarce, we launched a three month group cash transfer program to local organizations. It ended last week, and the program enabled groups, including Baladna organization, to address urgent community needs such as school feeding programs, volunteer-run health posts, and community kitchens for displaced families.

title: Treating burns in #Gaza
description:
Tayseer Mansour was badly burned in a strike on Khan Younis that killed his mother and injured his father and brothers back in August 2024.  Burn patients require a high level of health care. They also need pain relief, nutrition, and clean water. With no food entering Gaza, patients are not getting the sustenance they need, jeopardizing their recovery. #gaza #news #doctorswithoutborders 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Ukraine: Surgery for people cut off from medical care
description:
“You focus on the patient. It’s like getting into another universe, another reality.” That’s how Dr. Khassan El-Kafarna, medical activity manager for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in the Dnipropetrovsk region of Ukraine, describes the feeling of entering the operating theater to perform surgery on patients, many of whom have serious conditions made worse by lack of access to health care due to the war. Frontline hospitals are overwhelmed with war-wounded patients and people with chronic illnesses. MSF provides support by assisting hospitals to alleviate the burden.  #ukrainewar #ukraine #ukrainerussiawar #ukrainecrisis #ukrainenews #ukraine #news #doctorswithoutborders 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: What do aid cuts mean for Doctors Without Borders?
description: The massive cuts in US foreign aid will cause widespread suffering for people caught in crises. This is an earthquake for the aid sector—and, most importantly, for the millions of people struggling to survive wars, disasters, and disease outbreaks. MSF does not accept funding from the US government, and we continue to run medical humanitarian programs in more than 70 countries. However, we cannot do this alone. We are deeply worried about the people our programs can’t reach.

title: Ukraine: Surgery for people cut off from medical care

“You focus on the patient. title: Poignant poem to #TalkAboutSudan: "A Refugee's Bag"
description:
In his poem “A Refugee’s Bag,” Serge Bakor Lambey, MSF’s water and sanitation supervisor in Adré transit camp in eastern Chad, speaks about the hardships Sudanese refugees have endured during the past two years of war — hatred, sorrow, hunger, and pain — while also longing for the war to end. Poignant words to #TalkAboutSudan.  

Serge and his team do critical work providing clean drinking water and maintaining sanitation facilities for refugees in the camp. He draws inspiration for his writing from his humanitarian work.

title: Switching to solar in Nigeria hospital helps save lives
description:
MSF is transitioning to solar panels as part of our commitment to halve our 2019-levels of carbon emissions by 2030. In 2024, our teams completed a transition to solar energy at Kaffin Madaki Pediatric Hospital in northern Nigeria’s Bauchi state. This marks a major step toward reducing the hospital’s reliance on diesel generators and enables our medical teams to better treat our patients. Nigeria is currently facing a dramatic malnutrition crisis and an alarming increase in malaria cases. These crises are worsened by the effects of climate change in the country.
#earthday #doctorswithoutborders #solarenergy

title: Dr. Aqsa Durrani speaks with CNN from Gaza: "They are truly bearing a burden that is unspeakable"
description:
Dr Aqsa Durrani, our medical activity manager speaks with CNN from Gaza: “We see that our staff are themselves displaced, facing massively increased food prices. They are hungry, and yet are coming to work every single day under bombardment to treat our patients and do their best.  

The most painful aspect of this is that our patients don't even have enough food. 

We are not able to provide children, new mothers, elderly critical care patients with the nutrition that they need to recover.” 

#healthworkers #Palestinian #mentalhealth #gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: Sudan: Largest displacement camp is under attack
description:
North Darfur, #Sudan: After 4 days of deadly attacks and clashes at Zamzam camp by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and allied militias, the camp was reportedly seized by the RSF and is almost empty.  The half-million residents of the camp have been starved, shelled, and deprived of lifesaving assistance.

Zamzam was the largest displacement camp in Sudan, hosting about 500,000 people. Our staff in Tawila, 40 miles away, saw more than 30,000 people suddenly arriving from Zamzam and nearby areas since April 12. Marion Ramstein, MSF project coordinator in North Darfur, sent us this voice recording about the situation in Tawila. #sudanwar #sudanconflict

title: Sudanese refugees in Chad: “We are here for each other”
description:
The war in Sudan has displaced more than 12 million people, including over 700,000 who have crossed the border into Chad, where they live in refugee camps in the desert and contend with inadequate resources and services.  

Aisha B. is a Sudanese refugee working as a health promoter with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Chad. Despite the horrors she has seen, Aisha has hope. “I see that I can make a difference with my work at Doctors Without Borders,” she says. “I tell people, ‘You are not alone. We are here for each other.’”   

Read more about Aisha at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/everyone-has-felt-bitterness-loss-sudans-war-i-have-too

title: Refugees from the war in Sudan
description:
More than 700,000 refugees fleeing the war in Sudan have crossed the border into Chad, where they live in refugee camps and contend with inadequate resources and services. Aisha B. is a Sudanese refugee who works as a health promoter with MSF in Chad. Despite the horrors she has seen, Aisha has hope. “I see that I can make a difference with my work at Doctors Without Borders,” she says. “I tell people, ‘You are not alone. We are here for each other.’” 
#sudanwar #doctorswithoutborders

title: Sudan: 2 years of war through photos
description: In this video, Stephen Cornish, general director of MSF Switzerland, reflects on his most recent visit to some of our projects in Sudan and Chad. We need to #TalkAboutSudan. It’s been two years of a devastating war — a war on people. Our teams in Sudan are treating war-wounded patients with catastrophic injuries and providing humanitarian aid and medical care in refugee camps and displacement sites, where people are living in poor conditions and lack adequate health care and basic needs. More than 12 million people have been displaced by the current conflict, including over 3 million people who have fled to neighboring countries such as Chad, Egypt, and South Sudan. #sudanwar #sudanconflict #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: It’s been two years of war in Sudan. #TalkAboutSudan
description:
Our teams across the country hear harrowing stories from people who have been forced to flee their homes in search of safety. The story in this video was recounted by one of our patients in the Nuba Mountains region in South Kordofan state. 

Our teams are supporting several hospitals and medical facilities in this remote region where displaced people arrive daily in need of care, food, and water, after experiencing violence. 

An estimated 11 million people have been displaced since the war between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the Rapid Support Forces started in April 2023 and spread across Sudan. #Sudan #SudanWar #DoctorsWithoutBorders #SudanCantWait 

Read More at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/tales-violence-and-forced-displacement-sudan

title: What's happening in Colombia?
description: Colombia is experiencing its most intense upsurge of conflict in years due to ongoing fighting between armed groups. In recent weeks, we’ve increased medical humanitarian assistance to affected areas, like Catatumbo and Arauca. At least 11 active pockets of violence are affecting tens of thousands of people, leaving them displaced or isolated without access to essential services including health care. We urge armed actors to protect medical structures and humanitarian workers from violence.  #colombia #news #doctorswithoutborders #newsstories #greenscreen

title: Crossing the world for a better life: On Foot Comic
description:
Our colleague Hugo Gonzalez captured the stories of extracontinental migrants living in a makeshift camp in Mexico City. Some people traveled for months from countries in Africa or Asia, and across several countries in the Americas. They fled hunger, armed conflicts, violence, or disease. 

Extracontinental migrants face unique challenges, including language barriers and increased vulnerability to violence along the migration route. 

Our teams are responding by providing primary health care, mental health support, and other essential services in Mexico City and other countries.

Check the full illustrated story: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/crossing-entire-world-better-life

title: Do you know what's happening in #Sudan right now?: Al Jazeera interview
description: Christopher Lockyear, Secretary General of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), was interviewed on @aljazeeraenglish about the brutal war in Sudan that has displaced more than 12 million people over the past two years. People in Sudan continue to be subjected to horrific violence as warring parties attack each other with little respect for civilian life. "It's a really horrific situation," said Lockyear, "and I think if the world knew that and saw that then the pressure to stop it would be a lot greater." #sudanwar #sudanconflict #talkaboutsudan #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: Water crisis in Gaza
description:
Gaza’s water crisis has worsened significantly since Israeli authorities cut the entry of aid and electricity into the Strip in early March, with serious consequences for people’s health. 

Electricity and fuel are essential to operate desalination plants, water pumps, and other infrastructure that provides safe, drinkable water. MSF teams are working to fill this deadly water gap, but the restrictions are making water provision nearly impossible. This video was recorded last month, and wider access to safe water is still desperately needed. #news #gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: Myanmar earthquake: Working to meet the biggest needs
description:
In Myanmar, MSF is focusing on key areas of health care impacted by the 7.7-magnitude earthquake that struck on March 28. Access to secondary-level care that people usually receive in hospitals will be a main focus while we also look at how to support primary medical care, people with chronic diseases, and mental health needs.
#myanmar #doctorswithoutborders

title: What is famine?
description: War, displacement, climate change, and political instability can all interrupt access to food, leading to hunger, malnutrition, and in the most severe cases, even famine. The term famine is used to describe a societal catastrophe that requires urgent and coordinated humanitarian response to avoid widespread loss of life. In this video, MSF Non-Communicable Diseases Expert, Anjoli Anand, explains how a famine declaration is determined and what we are doing to help people in places where there is risk of famine. #famine  #foodsecurity #foodaccess #explained #explainervideo #explain

title: Al Jazeera interview: Impact of US aid cuts
description:
Christopher Lockyear, Secretary General of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), was interviewed on Al Jazeera about the impact of US foreign aid cuts and how support from 7.3 million private donors worldwide ensures that MSF can work independently to respond where the needs are greatest. #doctorswithoutborders 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières helps people worldwide where the need is greatest, delivering emergency medical aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics, disasters, or exclusion from health care. Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: What is malnutrition?
description: Malnutrition has disastrous effects on health. It weakens the immune system, making people more likely to develop severe or even fatal cases of diseases they might otherwise survive. Children are especially vulnerable. We treat children with malnutrition in our therapeutic feeding centers around the world. In this video, MSF non-communicable diseases expert Anjoli Anand breaks down what malnutrition is and how MSF is working right now to tackle malnutrition and its serious consequences. #malnutrition #foodsecurity #foodaccess #hunger #explained #explainervideo #explain

title: Do you know the difference between hunger, malnutrition, and famine?
description:
War, displacement, climate change, and political instability can all interrupt access to food, leading to hunger, malnutrition, and in the most severe cases, even famine. In this video, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) non-communicable diseases expert Anjoli Anand breaks down the difference between hunger, malnutrition, and famine, and what we are doing to help people in places where there is severe malnutrition and the risk of famine. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières helps people worldwide where the need is greatest, delivering emergency medical aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics, disasters, or exclusion from health care. Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Migration in Latin America: 5 things to know
description: Migration policies are changing, but the reasons for migration remain. For many, returning to their home country is just not an option. Since the US eliminated the CBP One app—which was the only way to request asylum in the US—and increased security at the US-Mexico border, MSF has been seeing fewer patients on migration routes through Latin America. Many of those we are seeing, however, have serious mental health needs. #migration #doctorswithoutborders

title: Better drug-resistant TB treatment means no more sickness and pain
description:
MSF collaborated with the Ministry of Health in Karakalpakstan, western Uzbekistan, to successfully implement an effective, all-oral treatment for drug-resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB). The newer treatment is a big improvement over previous DR-TB drugs—it's shorter and easier for patients to tolerate. MSF has been working for 27 years in Karakalpakstan, supporting efforts to tackle TB, offering diagnosis, treatment, and psychosocial support to patients.
#tb #worldtbday #doctorswithoutborders

title: "Disaster" in #Gaza emergency room: March 18, 2025.
description:
Doctors Without Borders teams are responding to influxes of patients in southern and central Gaza. In the early hours of March 18, Israeli forces attacked multiple areas in the Gaza Strip, after almost two months of an already-fragile ceasefire. Hundreds of people have been killed, according to the Ministry of Health. 

#news #newsupdate #humanitarianorganization #doctorswithoutborders #gaza

title: A voice note on what happened in #Gaza: March 18, 2025
description:
Doctors Without Borders teams are responding to influxes of patients in southern and central Gaza. In the early hours of March 18, Israeli forces attacked multiple areas in the Gaza Strip, after almost two months of an already-fragile ceasefire. Hundreds of people have been killed, according to the Ministry of Health. Claire Nicolet, MSF head of emergencies, gave this voice note today:


#news #newsupdate #doctorswithoutborders #gaza

title: Doctors Without Borders briefs UN Security Council on #Sudan: "Two years of unrelenting violence"
description:
Christopher Lockyear, MSF Secretary General briefed the United Nations Security Council today on the humanitarian catastrophe caused by war in Sudan, calling for an end to violence against civilians and a new commitment to deliver lifesaving aid.

#news #doctorswithoutborders #unitednations #UNSC #NYC #talkaboutsudan #unitedstates #aid #humanitarianaid #newsupdate #Sudanwar #refugees #healthnews

title: Doctors Without Borders briefs UN Security Council about Sudan: A "war on people"
description: Christopher Lockyear, MSF Secretary General briefed the United Nations Security Council today on the humanitarian catastrophe caused by war in Sudan, calling for an end to violence against civilians and a new commitment to deliver lifesaving aid.

title: Doctors Without Borders urgent update on #Sudan to UN Security Council
description:
On March 13, 2025, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) secretary general Christopher Lockyear provided an update to the #UnitedNations Security Council on one of the largest humanitarian crises unfolding largely outside the world’s headlines. April 2025 will mark two years of war in #Sudan, where fighting between the Sudanese Armed Forces and paramilitary group the Rapid Support Forces has wrought devastation across the country. 

“Millions uprooted. Tens of thousands killed. Famine tightening its grip. Two years of suffering, met with two years of indifference and inaction.” 

Source: UN Web TV

Read the full speech:  https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-briefs-un-security-council-sudan-catastrophic-war-people

#UNSC #NYC #talkaboutsudan #unitedstates #aid #humanitarianaid #newsupdate #Sudanwar #refugees #healthnews 

00:00 - Two years of suffering, met with two years of indifference and action
01:16 - The latest examples of how this war is being waged 
06:31 - How is that such fundamental obstacles to humanitarian aid remain unaddressed?
08:58 - A fundamental shift is needed

title: MSF to speak at UN Security Council today on crisis in Sudan
description:
Christopher Lockyear, Secretary General of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), will speak at the United Nations Security Council today. Watch at https://webtv.un.org/en.
#sudan #doctorswithoutborders

title: The challenges pregnant women face in Gaza: #internationalwomensday
description:
On International Women's Day, we celebrate the courageous leadership, resilience, and dedication of women who provide lifesaving care in crisis zones. Lina Al-Batniji, MSF counselor and health educator at Nasser Hospital in Gaza, speaks to the numerous challenges that pregnant women face in Gaza from lack of transportation to hygienic medical supplies. "Every day we attempt to stand up, to rise again, and to attempt to live."

#iwd2025 #doctorswithoutborders #womensday #womenempowerment #womeninstem

title: A message from female MSF staff on #internationalwomensday
description:
On International Women's Day, we celebrate the courageous leadership, resilience, and dedication of women who provide lifesaving care in crisis zones. Here is a message from three of our female staff members working in Gaza, Mexico, and Sudan on the impacts they've seen of ongoing crisis on women.
#iwd2025 #doctorswithoutborders #womensday #womenempowerment #womeninstem

title: International Women's Day Webinar
description:
We invite you to join us on Thursday, March 6 at 1:00pm ET for a live event with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF USA), where we will highlight the courageous leadership, resilience, and dedication of women who provide lifesaving care in crisis zones. 

Through powerful stories and discussion, we will celebrate the bold voices and dedication of women in the face of adversity. This event shines a light on their courage, compassion, and the critical role they play in providing lifesaving medical care in the toughest circumstances—from the front lines of war to natural disasters and beyond. Together, we’ll explore how our female staff continue to make an impact and inspire others in times of crisis. 

Join us for a conversation with Dr. Rasha Khoury, president of the MSF USA Board of Directors, and Avril Benoît, MSF USA chief executive officer. The event will be moderated by Kavita Menon, MSF USA chief communications officer. You will also hear powerful testimonies from Naamat Adam Mohammed Saleh Madani, an MSF midwife and counselor for survivors of sexual violence in South Darfur, Sudan, Lina Al-Batniji, MSF counselor and health educator at the Nasser Hospital in Gaza, and Susana Aranda, a psychologist at the MSF Mexico City migration project.

Make sure you don’t miss weekly video updates and ongoing series about our work in crisis zones across the world. Subscribe to our channel here: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: 3 vaccines that pregnant women need
description:
Vaccination is an important part of health care for all people and it’s a priority for MSF. Many people don’t know that certain vaccinations are particularly important for women and girls because the disease or infection they prevent have far greater negative consequences for them, especially during pregnancy, or for the lives of their babies. Hepatitis E, hepatitis B, and tetanus vaccines are good examples of immunizations that can save the lives of women and/or their babies.  
#vaccine #iwd2025 #doctorswithoutborders

title: Why I got vaccinated against hepatitis E
description: Hepatitis E can be fatal for pregnant women and their fetuses. Nyakuola Nguot Gang lives with her family in Fangak County, South Sudan, an area affected by catastrophic flooding and waterborne diseases, which can include hepatitis E. While she was pregnant with her youngest child, she MSF provided her first vaccination against hepatitis E. Even having just one of two doses made her condition far less severe.

title: Midwives caring for refugee patients: “The women we care for are so strong”
description:
In Athens, Greece, MSF midwives provide sexual and reproductive health care for women who have come from countries all over the world seeking refuge. “These are women who have done—or would do—anything to protect themselves, their child, and their families,” said one midwife.
#internationalwomensday #iwd2025 #doctorswithoutborders

title: Emergency Response in DRC: "Everything is destroyed."
description:
Following fighting and evacuation orders from the group M23 (March 23 Movement)/AFC (Alliance Fleuve Congo), hundreds of thousands of people have fled displacement camps around Goma, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). 

In response, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has adapted operations, deploying mobile teams to support people who are, once again, on the move. Access to free health care is crucial for people returning from the camps, who are now in an extremely vulnerable state, often without money, crops, and in some cases, without even tools to grow them.

Read more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/move-again-dr-congo

Make sure you don’t miss weekly video updates and ongoing series about our work in crisis zones across the world. Subscribe to our channel here: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières helps people worldwide where the need is greatest, delivering emergency medical aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics, disasters, or exclusion from health care. Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

Connect with us on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/m-decins-sans-fronti-res-msf-
Sign up for our newsletter: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/quick-signup-confirm

title: Violence in #DRC: "They were hit by multiple machete blows, including the children."
description:
In Eastern DRC, we are witnessing the impact of violence on civilians in Ituri province. In February over 100 were killed in attacks in Djugu territory.  Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has treated children as young as 4 with machete wounds. These atrocities must stop and access to healthcare be guaranteed.

#news #drc #doctorswithoutborders #violence #congo

title: Gaza: After ceasefire, confronting his losses
description:
MSF driver Edward Antone and his family were sheltering in a church in Gaza City after their home was destroyed. But a subsequent attack on the church in 2023 killed his mother and sister and injured much of his surviving family. Here, Antone recalls the attack. Despite the life-threatening risks, he has continued to support the delivery of aid with MSF. 
#gaza #doctorswithoutborders #ceasefire

title: In Ukraine from the beginning of full-scale war
description:
MSF’s medical response in Ukraine has evolved over the last three years. Here, MSF head of mission Thomas Marchese recalls being there from the beginning of the full-scale war when his teams ran mobile medical clinics and rehabilitated a health center destroyed after Russian occupation. Marchese’s teams also helped establish the ambulance train that moves critically ill people away from the front lines to safer facilities in the west of the country.  
#ukraine #doctorswithoutborders #msf

title: The ongoing crisis in #DRC: Things you should know in global news
description:
A resurgence of violence in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) is worsening the already-dire humanitarian emergency in the country, forcing millions to flee their homes to overcrowded camps. The makeshift camps lack basic needs such as food, water, and proper sanitation, increasing the risk of diseases like cholera. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is currently supporting two hospitals in Goma as they face an influx of wounded patients, as well as providing resources inthe camps such as clean water and sanitation support.

#news #humanitarianaid #doctorswithoutborders #drc #conflict

title: PTSD in Ukraine: Things you should know in global news
description:
One thing to know about Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD): An issue many people have to overcome is avoidance. MSF psychologist Viktoriia Muliarova helps war-wounded people navigate mental and physical rehabilitation in the central Ukrainian city of Cherkasy. She shared a story of one patient who could not face leaving the hospital, even after he recovered physically. 
#ukraine #doctorswithoutborders #ptsd

title: Finding hope in devastated Ukraine
description:
Domenico, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) psychologist, describes helping people recovering from severe war wounds in Ukraine. “Sometimes at night I can’t sleep,” he says. “I think about patients and the stories they share with me. But there are also moments that get you back on your feet: an unexpected smile, a child who greets you as you walk.”  

Now entering its fourth year, the war in Ukraine continues to devastate lives with millions of people displaced and tens of thousands of civilians killed. Actual figures are likely higher due to restricted access to conflict areas.  

There is a huge need for physical and psychological rehabilitation care that will continue long after the war ends. Many more emergency and longer-term needs continue to grow—for chronic diseases like hypertension and diabetes, stroke, kidney diseases, and more.

title: North Gaza: There is nothing left
description:
Since the ceasefire was put into effect on January 19, 2025, MSF has been able to access northern Gaza to assess the medical and humanitarian needs. What teams have found is that there is nothing left. Neighborhoods are unrecognizable, hospitals have been razed to the ground, and people are living in the rubble of their homes. MSF is calling on Israel to ensure unhindered access for urgently needed humanitarian support.  
#gaza #northgaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: People in Haiti's Brooklyn neighborhood are trapped by violence
description:
MSF is the only source of free health care on a daily basis in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Cité Soleil, an impoverished part of Haiti’s capital Port-au-Prince. People living in Brooklyn have been trapped by gang-related violence for years. They suffer from inadequate shelter, a lack of clean water and sanitation, and little access to health care.  
#haiti #doctorswithoutborders

title: West Bank: Palestinians are dying because they cannot reach hospitals
description:
Since before October 7, 2023, MSF has witnessed a disturbing escalation of violence by Israeli forces and settlers toward Palestinians in the West Bank. Our ambulances are often blocked by Israeli forces at checkpoints while carrying critical patients, medical facilities are surrounded and raided during active operations, and health care workers are subjected to physical violence while trying to save lives.  

As the occupying power, Israel has a legal obligation to ensure Palestinians in the West Bank have access to health care and protect medical personnel. Read the MSF report “Inflicting Harm and Denying Care: Patterns of Attacks and Obstructions of Health Care in the West Bank” here: https://tinyurl.com/2es9zmj5

#westbank #doctorswithoutborders #news

title: What's the value of humanitarianism?
description: Bakor Lambey Serge, an MSF water and sanitation supervisor in the central African country of Chad, is also a poet. In his poem "Humanitarian Value," Serge reflects on his experience helping thousands of people displaced by conflict in neighboring Sudan—and meditates on the empathy and solidarity at the heart of humanitarian work.

title: In North Darfur with only the clothes on their backs
description:
An ongoing siege on El Fasher, the capital of Sudan’s North Darfur, is starving people and depriving them of lifesaving assistance. Ruqaya Saleh and her children fled the city and came to Tawila, 37 miles west of the capital, where many displaced people have gathered. In December 2024, MSF found that more than 35 percent of children in Tawila are suffering from global acute malnutrition, and 7 percent from severe acute malnutrition.  

#sudan #doctorswithoutborders #malnutrition

title: Violence near DRC capital hurting already displaced people
description:
MSF is committed to continuing to provide medical care to displaced people in and around Goma, the capital of Democratic Republic of Congo.  

The escalation of fighting among armed groups on all sides of Goma has only worsened the grim living conditions for displaced people—inadequate water and sanitation, little access to health care, and insufficient shelter. MSF is asking for more humanitarian access in Goma and urges the warring parties to do more to protect civilians.  

Photographs by Jospin Mwisha and Moises Samana. 

#drc #doctorswithoutborders

title: BREAKING in Sudan: Market in Omdurman hit. MSF’s Chris Lockyear speaks from Al Nao hospital. #news
MSF arrives at an overwhelmed hospital in DRC
description:
An MSF team arrived at Virunga Hospital in Goma, the capital of Democratic Republic of Congo, on January 31 to help support the facility, which is “completely overwhelmed,” said MSF emergency support staff Julien Binet. The escalation of fighting between armed groups on all sides of the capital has put enormous pressure on health facilities. At Virunga Hospital, there is no water, no electricity, and more patients than there are beds. MSF will support general management of the facility and set up tents with additional beds.  

#drc #doctorswithoutborders

title: Innovating physiotherapy in #Gaza - "We create our own equipment"
description:
A lack of resources and materials in Gaza means MSF physiotherapists have to create equipment like crutches and pressure garments from scratch. So many patients are suffering from gunshot wounds and bomb blast injuries and need long-term rehabilitation.  

#gaza #doctorswithoutborders #physiotherapy

title: One of thousands: Sexual violence on the migration route in the Americas
description: Sexual violence is one of the most normalized and pervasive forms of violence that migrants face on their journeys through the Americas. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Mexico are stepping up their response to the physical and mental health needs of survivors while bearing witness to patients with painful stories. To shine a light on the resilience and strength of survivors and the violence migrants face, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) collaborated with 13 Mexican artists to present “Una y Miles” (One and a thousand), an animated short documentary following two MSF patients on the path to healing, and the dangers endured while migrating in search of a better life.

title: One of thousands: Stories of Survivors of sexual violence on the migration route in the Americas
description:
Since 2022, an increasing number of women, children, and adolescents have been taking the migration route to the United States. At MSF service points, there have been more registrations of women who are young, pregnant, breastfeeding, or traveling alone or with minors. As the demographic profile of people on the move has transformed, violence against women has worsened, adding to a slew of dangers people face in hopes to reach safety. 

Sexual violence is one of the most normalized and pervasive forms of violence that migrants face on their journeys through the Americas. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Mexico are stepping up their response to the physical and mental health needs of survivors while bearing witness to patients with painful stories. 

To shine a light on the resilience and strength of survivors and the violence migrants face, MSF collaborated with 13 Mexican artists to present “Una y Miles” (One and a thousand), an animated short documentary following two MSF patients on the path to healing, and the dangers endured while migrating in search of a better life. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières helps people worldwide where the need is greatest, delivering emergency medical aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics, disasters, or exclusion from health care. Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Trump executive order closes CBP One app #mexico #migration #news
description: It’s been only a few days since executive orders announcing the closure of CBP One, and our teams in Mexico are already witnessing the physical and mental toll this news has had on many of our patients. The app provided a critical, yet limited, way for asylum seekers to avoid hazardous routes and the danger of human trafficking networks. Its abrupt shutdown leaves so many people with no legal or safe alternatives. #cpb #doctorswithoutborders #executiveorders #

title: How my colleagues in #Gaza feel: "We are alive" #doctorswithoutborders
description: So much has been lost in 15 months of war in Gaza. For Doctors Without Borders staff, news of the ceasefire has meant a range of hard-hitting emotions, from joy to relief, or even numbness. These are some of their reactions.

title: A health worker in #Gaza reacts to news of a possible #ceasefire
description: This was the reaction we received from an MSF health worker in Gaza to news of a possible ceasefire. A sustained ceasefire is only the first step in addressing the overwhelming humanitarian, psychological, and medical needs in Gaza. #ceasefireingazanow #ceasefirenow #worldnews #doctorswithoutborders #news

title: #Haiti: One survivor's journey to recovery
description: Survivors of #sexualviolence and gender-based violence in Haiti's capital, Port-au-Prince, urgently need vital services such as safe shelters, mental health support, and medical care, as rape and other forms of assault have become widespread amid the violence and insecurity the city has faced in recent years. To highlight the crisis of sexual violence in Haiti's capital, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) partnered with an award-winning Haitian visual artist in the U.S., Lyne Lucien, to animate one survivor's difficult journey to recovery. #violenceagainstwomen #portauprince #genderbasedviolence #doctorswithoutborders

title: Multiple hospitals running low on fuel in Gaza - #breakingnews #incubator  #newborn
#Uzbekistan: HIV misconceptions
description:
Do you know how HIV is treated? Or transmitted? Our team in Uzbekistan is here to clear up some misconceptions. 

Did you know that antiretroviral (ARV) treatment provides consistent protection against the effects of HIV and helps keep it undetectable? 

In Uzbekistan, we’ve partnered with the Republican AIDS Centre to offer a mobile lab that provides free rapid testing and health information in and around the country’s capital, Tashkent. Our goal is to educate people diagnosed with HIV as well as the community so that they’re informed of their options. We’re not only raising awareness about transmission but also emphasizing the importance of early detection and treatment. With regular medication, HIV can become undetectable and untransmissible.

#doctorswithoutborders #hiv #educational #health #humanitarians

title: #Gaza: “The fire intensified, my father couldn’t save my older brother or my mother.”
description:
13-year-old Rahaf is a survivor of an Israeli airstrike on October 13, 2024, that targeted an area housing displaced people inside the Al Aqsa Hospital compound in Deir Al Balah, Gaza. She suffered severe burns and shrapnel in her abdomen. Rahaf and her father are now among the more than 14,000 patients awaiting Israeli approval for urgently needed treatment abroad.  

The airstrike killed Rahaf’s mother, sister and two of her brothers, among others. From Rahaf’s family, only she, her father, and one brother survived. Her recount of the event is heartbreaking.  

“I woke up from the intense heat...I found myself lying down. My father was unconscious beside me, and my little brother was next to me. I couldn’t handle the sight; it was too hard to bear,” she recounts.  

All Rahaf wants is this: “I wish for the war to stop, for us to return to our homes, heal from our injuries, and go back to school to our normal lives, and to our families.”

#gaza #humanitarianaid #ceasefire #doctorswithoutborders

title: "You don't have AIDS. You have HIV."
description:
Mozambique has one of the highest rates of HIV in the world and, due to ongoing violence, people in Cabo Delgado province have a particularly difficult time receiving and adhering to HIV treatment, including pregnant women.  
#doctorswithoutborders #mozambique #hiv

title: HIV in Mozambique: Turning loss into hope
description:
Three women in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique, describe how they relate to HIV as a doctor, a patient, and as a peer counselor. Mozambique has one of the highest rates of HIV in the world and, due to ongoing violence, people in Cabo Delgado have a particularly difficult time receiving and adhering to HIV treatment, including pregnant women.

00:00-00:47 - Dr. Januário on how her mother's illness affected the direction of her own life.
00:47-02:56 - The main challenges to getting and keeping patients on HIV treatment.
02:56-03:34 - Peer counselor or "Mentor Mother" Cristina Virgílio: "How do we keep these mothers in care?"
03:34- 04:09 - Patient Germana Toni talks about her own challenges adhering to HIV medication.
04:09- 05:00 - Cristina Virgílio: "As a Mentor Mother, you must set an example."
05:00-05:51 - "You don't have AIDS. You have HIV."

title: #NewYears Day in Sudan - From the hospital of a camp sheltering Ethiopian refugees. #newborn
#Ethiopia: Piloting a vaccine to fight malaria
description: More than 7.3 million malaria cases have been reported in Ethiopia this year, according to WHO—which is nearly twice as many as in 2023. With cases surging to unprecedented levels in the Oromia and Gambella regions, we’re taking a multi-pronged approach that includes case management, malaria prophylaxis, vaccines, and vector control measures. Malaria is yet another challenge for the country’s health care system, which was already grappling with previous and ongoing conflict. #malaria #malariatreatment #malariaprevention #malariavaccine #vaccine #news #worldnews

title: What MSF did in 2024
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) offers medical humanitarian assistance to people based solely on need, irrespective of race, religion, gender, or political affiliation. 

Our teams of doctors, nurses, logisticians, and other frontline workers are often among the first on the scene when peoples’ lives are upended by conflict, disease outbreaks, or natural or human-made disasters. 

The decision to respond is based solely on our independent assessment of medical needs. We work to ensure that our teams can reach people in need without restriction and provide aid directly. Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

Make sure you don’t miss weekly video updates and ongoing series about our work in crisis zones across the world. Subscribe to our channel here: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: The current situation for Rohingya refugees: "It really is a crisis with no end in sight"
description:
In recent months, thousands of Rohingya people have fled escalating violence in Myanmar to seek refuge in displacement camps in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. Those who have managed to cross the border described their horrific journeys—which often took several days— to our colleagues at the camps. Many people described having witnessed their loved ones die in front of them. Others were forced to sell their remaining possessions in order to afford to travel.  

There's now an overwhelming amount of people seeking shelter in Cox’s Bazar displacement camps. The many people already living there must now share their food rations and tight living space—even though access to food, proper shelter, and sanitation is already very limited. 

Stéphanie Hoffman, former MSF project coordinator in Cox’s Bazar, shared more behind the situation and what people are experiencing.

title: Safe abortion care is essential health care, period
description:
In over 70 countries where MSF teams work, safe abortion care is an effective intervention to prevent maternal mortality and suffering. We see firsthand how safe abortion care has a real and meaningful impact on people’s health and livelihood overall. Anyone who seeks an abortion is deserving of high-quality and dignified care. 
#abortion #womenshealth #health

title: Our report is out – #Gaza: Life in a Death Trap
description:
"The total destruction of Palestinian life in Gaza must stop.” MSF secretary general Christopher Lockyear breaks down our new report, Gaza: Life in a Death Trap. The report outlines what our teams are seeing in Gaza, including signs of ethnic cleansing in the north, as people are forcibly displaced, trapped, and bombed. #gazaconflict #ceasefire #ceasefireingazanow 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: A message of humanitarian solidarity from our colleagues around the world
description:
On December 10, 1999, then-president of the MSF International Council James Orbinski began MSF’s Nobel Peace Prize acceptance speech by demanding that Russia stop bombing civilians in Chechnya. That bold challenge set the tone for a speech that became a rallying cry for MSF: save lives and speak out.  
#doctorswithoutborders #humanitarianaid #humanitarianorganization #inspirational #solidarity #nobelprize

title: Nurse shares photos from #Gaza: "They live in insalubrious conditions"
description:
Nurse Karin Huster has been to Gaza with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) three times since the start of the current war, spending more than five months there in total. Here, she shares some of her most heart-wrenching experiences.

#gaza #news #doctorswithoutborders #humanitarianaid #ceasefire #ceasefireingazanow

title: Brazil: Bringing medical care to the Yanomami Indigenous community
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works in Roraima state, in northern Brazil, to deliver health care to Indigenous communities like the Yanomami people. Our teams in the Amazon work on Yanomami Indigenous land in the Auaris region, providing general health support, as well as mental health care and malaria testing and treatment. MSF recently coordinated and financed a major renovation and expansion of the main health facility in Auaris. 

00:03-01:07 - Focusing on malaria, an endemic disease here
01:11-02:26 - Working in an intercultural context
02:30-03:14 - The greatest difficulties are logistical
03:24-04:17 - People's well-being is connected to the land

title: #Syria: Harrowing stories of former detainees
description:
Video Warning: Viewer discretion advised.  
It’s difficult to hear our staff at Salqin Hospital in Idlib, Syria, speak about two patients—a woman and her young son—who spent eight long years in Sednaya prison. The horrific abuse endured is unimaginable. MSF psychologist Omar al Omar and medical activity manager Bilal Alsarakibi are doing their best to address their varying needs, provide treatment, and work toward healing. #worldnews #news 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Update from #Syria: Displaced people lack essential services to return home
description:
We’ve been working with displaced people in northern Syria for a decade. Recent political developments have led to the of the government in Syria, and the situation on the ground is changing quickly. People are being uprooted for many reasons. Some people have no homes to return to; others cannot go home due to a lack of essential services like water and electricity.  

Right now, MSF teams are responding to needs across northern Syria. In the northwest, we continue to provide people with medical care through our existing mobile clinics, health facilities, and hospitals. Since the end of November, we have donated trauma and surgical equipment to hospitals across this region. We’ve also provided hundreds of families with hygiene kits, mattresses, and blankets. 

Video: 2023. #Syria #displacement #health #doctorswithoutborders

title: Sudan: Providing aid here is hard, “but entirely possible”
description:
MSF's Secretary General Chris Lockyear is in Darfur, Sudan, to highlight the needs people are facing there due to the ongoing war. More than half of Sudan's population is facing acute hunger and 20% of the population is displaced by violence. Humanitarian aid is being blocked, and the health system has collapsed. Nevertheless, some 1,500 MSF staff are working to meet the medical needs alongside 3,300 staff from the Ministry of Health.
#sudan #doctorswithoutborders

title: In Darfur, Sudan, a look at the needs
description:
MSF's Secretary General Chris Lockyear is in Darfur, Sudan, to highlight the needs people are facing there due to the ongoing war. More than half of Sudan's population is facing acute hunger and 20% of the population is displaced by violence. Humanitarian aid is being blocked, and the health system has collapsed. Nevertheless, some 1,500 MSF staff are working to meet the medical needs alongside 3,300 staff from the Ministry of Health.
#sudan #doctorswithoutborders

title: MSF's Nobel Peace Prize acceptance speech, 25-year anniversary
description:
In 1999, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize “in recognition of the organization’s pioneering humanitarian work on several continents.” In his acceptance speech, Dr. James Orbinski—then president of MSF’s International Council—used the speech to condemn Russian violence against civilians in Chechnya under Russian President Boris Yeltsin.

The powerful message of Dr. Orbinski’s speech still echoes today in our work, from Ukraine to Gaza to Sudan. Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/who-we-are/our-history/nobel-peace-prize-25-years
