title: One year reflection: MSF staff vigil held at UN headquarters to demand a ceasefire in #Gaza
description:
Last December, our staff and supporters held a vigil outside the UN headquarters in NY to demand an immediate ceasefire in Gaza. Today, we’re still waiting for a ceasefire. 

MSF’s Kavita Menon reflects on a testimony she read at the vigil from our emergency coordinator Nicholas Papachrysostomou. Even then, our staff was already running out of words to describe the damage and suffering across the Gaza Strip.  

Eight of our colleagues have been killed in this war. For our colleagues, for our patients, and for all Palestinians, we will keep calling for a ceasefire in Gaza. We need this violence to end. We need attacks on health workers and health facilities to end. We need a #CeasefireNow. #gaza #humanitarianorganization #doctorswithoutborders #humanitarianaid #reactionvideo

title: An inside look at a hospital treating malnourished children in Nigeria
description:
MSF USA’s Avril Benoît is reporting from Katsina, #Nigeria, to talk about the extremely concerning levels of malnutrition: “We are seeing a vast crisis of food insecurity and malnutrition in northern Nigeria, including the northwest, that requires a heightened response.”  

While our teams are doing all they can to respond across the region, we need other actors to get more involved to ensure a reliable supply of therapeutic food will be available next year. #foodinsecurity  #news  #foodsecurity  #aid  #worldnews #doctorswithoutborders #fighthunger 

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Northern Gaza: "cold, hunger, and bombs"
description:
This footage was filmed by our team headed to Gaza City on November 25. Our emergency coordinator described seeing no signs of life: “It’s just cold, hunger, and bombs.” 
#gaza #doctorswithoutborders

title: #Lebanon: "The humanitarian emergency is far from over."
description:
On November 26, thousands of families displaced by conflict started to return to southern and eastern parts of Lebanon after an agreement was reached between Israel and Hezbollah.  

But, with so much destruction left behind, this humanitarian crisis is far from over.

#lebanon #lebanoncrisis #news #gaza #humanitarianaid #ceasefire #doctorswithoutborders

title: #DRC: Water and sanitation are urgently needed in overcrowded camps
description:
The ongoing conflict in eastern DRC has led to an influx of displaced people in Goma, the capital of North Kivu. As of September 2024, around 645,000 people are still sheltering in overcrowded camps around Goma. MSF has been providing medical assistance to internally displaced people in the camps, while also conducting water, sanitation and hygiene (WatSan) activities. By the end of year, we’ll have constructed 2,334 latrines and 1,379 showers.

#drc #democraticrepublicofcongo #cleanwater #humanitarianaid #doctorswithoutborders

title: #Brazil: Collaborating to provide care in the Yanomami Indigenous Land
description:
Community engagement is a key element to serving the Yanomami people. The Yanomami Indigenous Land in northern #Brazil is the largest Indigenous territory in the country. In recent years, the people there have been struggling with rising malaria cases linked to environmental degradation caused by illegal mining. With support from the #indigenous public health system, our teams are going into communities in the Auaris region of the #Yanomami territory to reduce the number of malaria cases through prevention methods, spreading awareness, and providing treatment. 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Mom in #Gaza shares her challenges in managing health of her young daughter
description:
Rasha is Ibtissam’s mom. Inside Nasser Hospital in southern Gaza, she shares that her little girl has Tay-Sachs disease, a rare genetic condition. “She has special treatments, she also has special food, and special milk.” 

In the pediatric ward, our teams face an overwhelming number of patients. Dr. Mohammad Abu Tayyem, an MSF pediatrician working at Nasser, explains that the war has taken its toll on children who are still growing. “We are treating infants who have infectious diseases, respiratory diseases, and skin diseases.” Families are living in crowded tents or under plastic sheeting and mixed fabrics, without clean water, sanitation services, hygiene items including soap, and other basic needs. MSF teams are providing critical care, but the overwhelming need for resources and support are urgent. 

#Gaza #news #doctorswithoutborders #mom #child #humanitarianaid

title: Why we stopped our activities in Port-au-Prince, Haiti
description:
Violence and threats by police have forced MSF to suspend activities in Port-au-Prince, #Haiti.  In the past week, police officers have stopped MSF vehicles multiple times and directly threatened MSF staff members, including by threatening death and rape. #happeningnow #haiti #news #worldnews #doctorswithoutborders 
SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Why we suspended activities in Port-au-Prince, Haiti
description:
A series of threats by Haitian police forces against Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff have forced us to suspend our medical work until further notice in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. In the past week, police officers have stopped MSF vehicles multiple times and directly threatened MSF staff members, including by threatening death and rape. This follows an attack on an MSF ambulance that resulted in the execution of at least two patients and physical harm to our staff on November 11. These repeated incidents have compelled MSF to stop patient admissions and transfers to our five medical facilities in Haiti’s capital on November 20, as they clearly illustrate the direct targeting of our personnel and patients in Haiti.

MSF provides care to everyone on the basis of medical needs alone. Each week on average in the Port-au-Prince metropolitan area, MSF provides care to more than 1,100 patients on an outpatient basis, 54 children with emergency conditions, and more than 80 new survivors of sexual and gender-based violence. MSF is suspending all medical services except to already hospitalized patients at our five medical facilities and our mobile clinics in the Port-au-Prince metropolitan area, who will continue to be in MSF’s care. Our maternal health activities in the south of the country, in Port-a-Piment, will also continue.

title: Haiti: After a gruesome attack, MSF suspends activities
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Head of Mission in Haiti Diana Arroyo told Al Jazeera on November 20 that MSF is suspending all medical activities in Haiti’s capital Port-au-Prince until further notice. This follows an attack on an MSF ambulance that resulted in the execution of at least two patients and physical harm to our staff on November 11, and a series of threats by Haitian police forces against our staff.  

MSF has been working in Haiti for more than 30 years, and health care services have never been as limited for people in the country as they are right now, as the country faces unrelenting violence on top of a spiraling political and economic crisis. Though our services are urgently needed, MSF cannot resume admissions of new patients to our facilities in Port-au-Prince unless we are guaranteed unhindered security and respect for our medical and humanitarian mandate by armed groups, members of vigilante groups, and law enforcement officers.  

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/haiti-violence-and-threats-police-force-msf-suspend-activities-port-au-prince-area

title: Ukraine: Recovering from an amputation
description:
Some 300,000 Ukrainians have sustained disabilities since the start of the war in 2022, according to the Ministry of Social Policy. At the Cherkasy Hospital in central Ukraine, MSF integrates physiotherapy, psychological support, and nursing care to address the needs of war-wounded patients.
#ukraine #doctorswithoutborders #physiotherapy

title: Ukraine: Recovering from an amputation
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provides rehabilitation services for people with traumatic injuries at the Cherkasy Hospital in central Ukraine's Cherkasy region. MSF staff use a multidisciplinary approach that integrates physiotherapy, psychological support, and nursing care to address the needs of war-wounded patients. 

Since the escalation of the war in February 2022, approximately 300,000 Ukrainians have sustained disabilities, according to the Ministry of Social Policy. The demand for rehabilitation specialists has surged as the health care infrastructure struggles to cope with the growing number of patients. In the first nine months of 2024, MSF assisted more than 270 patients, using this holistic rehabilitation approach.

title: #Lebanon: How we prepare staff for treating severely injured patients
description:
At Al Hamshari Hospital in Lebanon, our teams are providing essential trainings so that doctors and nurses are better prepared to treat severely injured patients arriving to the emergency room.  

In collaboration with other partners, our teams have conducted similar trainings in 10 different hospitals across Lebanon with over 400 staff members since October 2023. 

Since the war in Gaza began in October 2023, Hezbollah and Israeli forces have been exchanging fire across the border between southern Lebanon and northern Israel. The violence escalated dramatically when Israel launched coordinated pager and walkie-talkie explosions in Beirut and other parts of Lebanon on September 18 and 19, before launching a full-scale military assault on September 23. To date, more than 2,000 people have been killed and about 10,000 wounded.  

#doctorswithoutborders #news #humanitarianorganization #humanitarianaid #lebanon #lebanoncrisis #gaza

title: Fighting dengue fever with mosquitos
description:
Climate change creates the perfect conditions for cases of dengue fever to increase. There are no effective treatments or vaccines for dengue, which can be deadly, so MSF took a different approach. One year ago, we released 8 million mosquitos that were bred with a bacteria called Wolbachia into one neighborhood in Honduras’s capital Tegucigalpa. The results are just what we’d hoped for – the number of dengue cases have been going down.

title: MSF doctor in Gaza: "Every day, somebody made me cry"
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical team leader Dr. Naina Bhalla talks to the BBC about her time working in Gaza and its emotional impact, as well as the unacceptable lack of hygiene items. 

00:00:00:00 - 00:00:01:23
One thing that I have to

00:00:01:23 - 00:00:03:24
say is that I was there for two months,

00:00:03:24 - 00:00:06:24
and every day somebody made me cry,

00:00:07:07 - 00:00:08:22
whether it was a patient,

00:00:08:22 - 00:00:10:18
whether it was a staff member,

00:00:10:18 - 00:00:12:12
whether it was just,

00:00:12:12 - 00:00:15:02
somebody telling me their story.

00:00:15:02 - 00:00:17:01
Everybody has been affected in Gaza.

00:00:17:01 - 00:00:18:09
Everybody has a story.

00:00:18:09 - 00:00:21:03
Everybody has lost loved ones.

00:00:21:03 - 00:00:22:23
In terms of the medical activities

00:00:22:23 - 00:00:24:13
that we were providing,

00:00:24:13 - 00:00:27:22
having to weekly, every week review

00:00:28:00 - 00:00:30:00
what stocks you had

00:00:30:00 - 00:00:31:07
and what supplies you had

00:00:31:07 - 00:00:31:23
and what you were going

00:00:31:23 - 00:00:33:01
to run out of in one week,

00:00:33:01 - 00:00:34:04
and what you were going to run out of

00:00:34:04 - 00:00:35:12
in two weeks.

00:00:35:12 - 00:00:38:19
And even in times where we were unable

00:00:38:19 - 00:00:40:14
to manage the number of patients

00:00:40:14 - 00:00:41:19
in our wards,

00:00:41:19 - 00:00:43:11
having to transfer them

00:00:43:11 - 00:00:45:18
to other hospitals with the supplies

00:00:45:18 - 00:00:47:01
to perform the surgeries,

00:00:47:01 - 00:00:49:17
knowing that the other hospitals were in

00:00:49:17 - 00:00:51:22
as dire need of supplies as we were.

00:00:53:03 - 00:00:55:08
It was a very difficult thing.

00:00:55:08 - 00:00:56:00
And,

00:00:56:00 - 00:00:58:02
it's not a level of care

00:00:58:02 - 00:01:00:04
that should be accepted.

00:01:00:04 - 00:01:01:02
This is the first time

00:01:01:02 - 00:01:02:06
I've ever worked for Doctors

00:01:02:06 - 00:01:03:19
Without Borders that I was not able

00:01:03:19 - 00:01:05:21
to give soap to our patients

00:01:05:21 - 00:01:07:11
because it was just not available

00:01:07:11 - 00:01:09:06
- hygiene items.

00:01:09:06 - 00:01:11:12
The living conditions

00:01:11:12 - 00:01:13:16
were so disastrous.

00:01:13:16 - 00:01:14:22
The number of skin infections

00:01:14:22 - 00:01:16:04
that we were seeing,

00:01:16:04 - 00:01:18:17
And you could not even find soap

00:01:18:17 - 00:01:21:13
or shampoo in the in the markets.

title: Doctor: My family in Sudan has scattered since the war
description:
Sudanese MSF doctor Mohamed Bashir used to provide care for people in his home country. Now, like many Sudanese people who have fled the war, he is living across the border in South Sudan where he continues to provide medical care. More than 800,000 Sudanese people have sought safety in South Sudan since the war began. 
#doctorswithoutborders #sudan

title: Sudan: Stay with the children or take the baby to the hospital?
description: A story about impossible choices from Sudan and its ongoing war—does a mother accompany her sick baby to the hospital or stay with her other children? MSF Emergency Coordinator Claire San Filippo talks about the gutting choices people make every day to keep themselves and their families alive. #talkaboutsudan

title: Lebanon: "Children will carry this trauma"
description: Children who are witnessing the violence in Lebanon will carry trauma with them well into the future, says Dr. Aida Hassouna, an MSF medical doctor. “It will have an impact, because they have seen their homes being destroyed, and their relatives and family members killed in front of their eyes.” MSF is responding to the medical and mental health needs of people in Lebanon.

title: It's #Timefor5: We went to hand deliver our petition to drop the price of lifesaving medical tests
description:
More than 200,000 people from all over the world signed our petition asking Cepheid and its parent corporation Danaher to drop the price of lifesaving medical tests sold in lower- and middle-income countries to $5. 

Our research shows that Danaher and Cepheid could sell these tests at a profit for just $5 each, but they are still charging two and three times that in the world’s poorest countries.  

This is even more outrageous considering Danaher and Cepheid received $252 million of public and philanthropic money to develop these tests, and now, they are vastly overcharging for them. 

Danaher will be receiving the petition in the mail. We want to make sure all these voices are heard.

title: A Doctor's life in #Gaza: Before and after the war
description: Our Palestinian staff in Gaza have worked tirelessly throughout a year of devastation and violence, providing care to patients while bearing the burden of war on a personal level, including the loss of loved ones and repeated displacement by Israeli forces' evacuation orders. Deputy medical coordinator of Nasser Hospital Dr. Mohammed Abu Mughaiseb reflects on his and his family's life before the war began last October.

title: What Gaza looks like now
description:
One year after the start of the war in the Gaza, the death toll is enormous and the living conditions extremely precarious. Isabelle Defourny, president of MSF France, visited Gaza in early October.

TRANSCRIPT
In Gaza today, over 80% of the population is displaced.
On site, the scale of the destruction is extremely shocking.
At least 80% of the buildings were destroyed. Almost all our local staff have lost their homes.
1.5 to 1.6 million people are now living in a small strip in the humanitarian zone, which is an area of 40 km² (15 square miles). I've rarely seen a camp so crowded. People are literally crammed on top of each other, with hardly any space between shelters, with very little water, very little food, with very few ways of ensuring their hygiene.
It's hard to find medical priorities in Gaza today, because everything is urgent. There are an estimated 90,000 war-wounded people.
But today, we're limited by the amount of aid that can't get into the Gaza Strip.
The slow arrival of humanitarian aid has a direct impact on our activities. We have just opened two field hospitals, two tented hospitals with a total capacity of 220 beds. But today, only 25 beds are open.
And this is mainly because we lack the medical equipment, medicines and renewable materials needed to open more beds.
The hypocrisy of Israel's allies, including France, is particularly shocking. On the one hand, they softly condemn the consequences of Israel's war. On the other hand, they continue to support Israel, politically and militarily.
It is urgent that they use all their influence to obtain, at last, a ceasefire. A ceasefire is more necessary than ever for the people of Gaza. It is also essential for humanitarian aid to arrive in sufficient quantities to cope with the current crisis.

title: Gaza: Medical care under fire
description:
We invite you to join us for a live online event on Tuesday, October 15, at 1:00 pm ET, with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) aid workers reflecting on the catastrophic health impacts of the war in Gaza.  

MSF teams were already active providing medical care in Gaza when conflict escalated following the horrific attacks by Hamas on Israel on October 7. In response, the Israeli government launched a ferocious military offensive on Gaza. More than 40,000 Palestinians have been killed, tens of thousands more have been injured, and some 1.9 million people have been displaced–often multiple times. Much of the Gaza Strip has been reduced to rubble.  

MSF staff are providing urgent medical care even while facing the personal impacts of the war themselves–the deaths of loved ones, destruction of their homes, and constant dangers everywhere. Hospitals and health facilities have repeatedly come under fire or been forced to evacuate. The medical needs are exploding, including the spread of infectious diseases and the risk of starvation. 

Join us for a conversation with Dr. Javid Abdelmoneim, emergency physician and former medical team leader in Gaza, and Dr. Amber Alayyan, pediatrician and medical program manager for MSF in Palestine, Afghanistan and Haiti. Dr. Mohammed Abu Mughaisib, MSF deputy medical coordinator in Gaza, will share testimony directly from Rafah, and Avril Benoît, MSF USA chief executive officer, will moderate the live discussion. Together they will bear witness to this unfolding emergency and reflect on the medical challenges ahead.

title: Timeline: One year of Gaza news highlights
description:
After one year of devastating war in #Gaza, the situation in the Strip remains dire. Our teams in Gaza are witnessing firsthand how this war has turned Gaza’s chronic humanitarian crisis into a catastrophe. Since last October we’ve continually spoken to media outlets to raise awareness about the scarcity of essential supplies like fuel, electricity, clean food, and water. We've warned that because lifesaving health care is increasingly inaccessible, the risk of disease and starvation will only grow if bombardment continues. 

We can only adapt so much to the extremely volatile conditions on the ground to try and meet the needs of our patients as best we can. What we need is an immediate and sustained ceasefire and an end to the blockade on Gaza. #ceasefireingaza #ceasefireingazanow #news #worldnews #doctorswithoutborders #humanitarian

Make sure you don’t miss weekly video updates and ongoing series about our work in crisis zones across the world. Subscribe to our channel here: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

title: Thousands trapped in northern Gaza amid Israeli forces' attacks
description:
The latest forced mass displacements of residents of Beit Hanoun, Jabalia and Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, and the bombing of entire neighbourhoods by Israeli forces are turning the north of Gaza into an unliveable wasteland, emptying it out of Palestinian life. To make matters worse, no humanitarian supplies have been allowed to enter this part of the Strip since 1 October.

Tens of thousands of people are pushed to move south to the overcrowded, so-called humanitarian zone between Al-Mawasi and Deir Al-Balah, where one million people are already living in inhumane conditions. The zone also remains unsafe for civilians and aid workers, as Israeli forces continue to repeatedly strike the area.

title: A doctor’s story of Gaza before and after the war
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)'s Palestinian staff in Gaza have worked tirelessly throughout a year of devastation and violence, providing care to patients while bearing the burden of war on a personal level, including the loss of loved ones and repeated displacement by Israeli forces' evacuation orders.  

One of our colleagues in Gaza is Dr. Sohaib Safi, an MSF medical coordinator who has remained in the Strip working after his wife and daughter managed to flee to Egypt. Here, Dr. Safi describes what he misses about life in Gaza before the war that began last October, and the uncertain future.

title: One of the few injured children medically evacuated from #Gaza
description:
15-year-old Abdul Rahman is one of the very few Palestinian children who was given permission to medically evacuate from Gaza— while most children and their caretakers' requests have been denied. 

After being critically injured on February 10 when an Israeli airstrike targeted him and his friends in northern Gaza, he was rushed to the Jordanian hospital in Gaza before being transferred to Baptist hospital where surgeons performed an emergency surgery that saved his leg. Abdul Rahman was then shuffled from one medical location to another until he was granted medical evacuation to a hospital in Cairo. A few months later, he was transferred to A Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospital in Amman where he received another surgery. He now practices daily physiotherapy to encourage the healing of his bone and is slowly recovering. 

While our teams in Amman are treating the few Gazan children we have managed to transfer for rehabilitation after they were medically evacuated to Egypt, thousands remain trapped in Gaza. Israeli authorities need to approve more medical evacuations so patients can receive the specialized care they need. #worldnews #news #doctorswithoutborders

title: Update from #Lebanon: "The humanitarian situation is indescribable"
description:
We received this audio from Luna Hammad, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical coordinator in Lebanon. As large-scale Israeli bombardment continues in Lebanon, up to 1 million people have been forced from their homes in a desperate search for safety. People are sleeping in cars on the streets and hospitals are overwhelmed with the wounded. Over 500 schools are full. Our teams are working around the clock to provide support to displaced people in shelters, including schools, in the south of Lebanon as well as in and around #Beirut. We’re providing water, psychological first aid, medical consultations, and donating essential items such as mattresses, blankets, drinking water, and hygiene kits to #displaced people. Our teams continue to assess the needs and deliver help. 

As the Israeli bombardment campaign of Lebanon continues, we reiterate our call that civilians and health care workers must be protected. #news  #worldnews   #doctorswithoutborders

title: Update from #Lebanon: "Fire and smoke all around us"
description:
We received this audio from Maryam Srour, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) field communications manager in #Beirut.  She shares her experience of what happened during and after Friday night’s bombardment in southern Beirut. Thousands of people, including MSF teams, had to flee their homes in the dark with nothing; some on foot. It’s a chaotic situation. Our teams are working around the clock in Beirut, delivering water, hygiene kits, and blankets. People are sleeping in cars on the streets and hospitals are overwhelmed with the wounded. Over 500 schools are full.

So far, teams have delivered 400 kits of basic relief items to shelters, including hygiene materials and mattresses. We are also providing water and offering psychological first aid to those in need. Our teams continue to assess the needs and deliver help.

As the Israeli bombardment campaign of Lebanon continues, we reiterate our call that civilians and health care workers must be protected. #worldnews  #doctorswithoutborders

description: Sept 25 audio from Maram Sukkariyeh, a health promotion supervisor with MSF in Lebanon: "The sounds of drones and jets never leave us." We're distributing supplies and running mobile health clinics and mental health helplines. #news #worldnews #mentalhealth

title: Does abortion affect your mental health?
description: Everyone comes to an abortion with different life experiences. A good indicator of a person's mental health after a desired abortion is their mental health before. The Turnaway Study found that relief is the most commonly reported emotion after having an abortion. What does negatively affect someone’s mental health, however, is being denied a safe abortion or encountering stigma and judgment for having one.

title: Talk About #sudan: 🎥Doctors Without Borders Dr. Tammam Aloudat at #unga
Treating severely burned patients in Haiti
description: On September 14, MSF responded to a tanker truck explosion in Miragôane, 118 miles from Haiti's capital Port-au-Prince. Staff transferred several severely burned patients to medical centers in the Carrefour and Tabarre areas of the capitol by helicopter and moved others by road convoy.

title: Patient from Gaza: "I felt the rubble on my body. I couldn't get up, I couldn't move."
description:
On October 11, 2023, 11-year-old Deema fell four stories from her balcony when her neighbor’s house in Gaza City was hit by an airstrike: “I was convinced that I was going to die.” Deema was rushed to Al-Shifa Hospital to receive emergency medical care for her fractured femur and shoulder, and an open wound on her forehead.  

In May 2024, Deema was medically evacuated to Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)’s hospital in Amman, where she continues to receive reconstructive surgery, physiotherapy, and mental health support. Our physiotherapy team hopes that Deema will one day regain the full function of her limbs. 
 
The small number of patients from Gaza receiving vital rehabilitation at MSF’s hospital in Amman represent a small percentage of the needs across the Gaza Strip. According to WHO, 14,000 people in Gaza need medical evacuation. So far, almost 60% of the requests have been rejected by the Israeli authorities.

title: Surviving on one meal a day: Sudanese refugees in Chad
description: Many Sudanese refugees are surviving on one meal a day in the camps of #Chad. Decreasing food portions could lead to rising #malnutrition rates, particularly among children.  #talkaboutsudan #sudan #foodinsecurity

title: #Flooding in eastern #Chad #news
description: Thousands of people are still #displaced, one month later. In Koukou, access to clean drinking water is almost nonexistent. People's most immediate needs are food, water and sanitation, shelter reinforcement, and primary and secondary health care. #doctorswithoutborders #climatechange #climateemergency #cleanwater

title: One way to tackle #malaria
description:
It's called a residual spraying campaign, and in #Niger, the goal is to decrease the number of kids and vulnerable adults getting sick with malaria or needing hospitalization. Malaria also complicates #malnutrition in this region. In Niger, malaria has a peak season beginning in August. When the rain comes and water is stagnant, mosquitoes breed, and the parasitic infection occurs through a bite. Climate change is also impacting the behavior and survival of the mosquitoes that carry malaria.  
 
The most basic prevention measure is to avoid bites. This can be done through indoor spraying of homes with safe, long-lasting insecticides and/or by sleeping under mosquito nets treated with long-lasting insecticide. More recently, antimalarial drugs have been used to prevent infection among the most at-risk people for limited periods of time.

title: Mpox: what is it and why is there growing concern about the outbreak in DR Congo?
description:
In DRC, mpox has been on the rise in several parts of the country for the past decade. In recent months, a virus mutation discovered in South Kivu is now being transmitted through close human-to-human contact with an infected person versus the typical way of close contact with an infected animal. Cases are especially concerning in densely populated areas, including camps for displaced people around Goma in North Kivu. 

MSF has set up several interventions to support the response to this outbreak, but the identification of cases, monitoring of patients, and care available remain extremely limited. Stay informed of the latest: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/mpox-just-one-challenge-among-many-eastern-dr-congo

title: Using Grindr to connect LGBTQI+ people with health care
description: As part of MSF’s work to get more people from the LGBTQI+ community in northern Honduras to come in for health care, our health promotion teams started reaching out to users through ads on Grindr this year. This is the first time MSF has used the dating app, which is used by members of the LGBTQI+ community, in order to engage people who might not otherwise come to a clinic to get care—and the initiative was a big success. It was one part of a campaign that also included face-to-face activities, health fairs, and outreach to other organizations. Yoruba Mitchell, MSF health promotion and community engagement specialist, explains.

title: Fighting cholera in Sudan
description: Cholera cases are not uncommon in Sudan, but providing lifesaving care and implementing preventative measures amid a 17-month war—and now destructive flooding—makes responding that much more difficult. #TalkAboutSudan

title: The alarming malnutrition crisis in #Nigeria
description:
Dr. Simba Tirima, our country representative in Nigeria, explains the alarming malnutrition crisis in the northwest of the country.  One out of every four children under the age of five is malnourished in the Shinkafi and Zurmi areas of Nigeria’s Zamfara state, according to a mass screening conducted in June by MSF and the Ministry of Health.  

We urge health authorities, international organizations, and donors to immediately intensify their efforts to tackle the escalating malnutrition crisis in Zamfara state, as well as whole of northwest Nigeria. 

#malnutrition #doctorswithoutborders #msf #nigeria

title: Gaza doctor describes polio vaccination campaign
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical team leader Dr. Naina Bhalla was interviewed by CBS News from Khan Younis in Gaza on September 4, 2024. Dr. Bhalla discussed the efforts to vaccinate some 640,000 children in Gaza against the polio disease, which has re-emerged in the area for the first time in 25 years.

The resurgence of polio in Gaza is a consequence of the continuous destruction of its infrastructure and health system by Israeli forces. The war has destroyed water and sanitation infrastructure, forced people into unhygienic and appalling living conditions, and disrupted routine vaccinations—perfect conditions for diseases like polio to spread. Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-supports-polio-vaccination-campaign-gaza

title: #Gaza Update: Al-Aqsa Hospital now stands almost empty.
description:
Field hospitals are not a solution, but a last resort in response to Israel’s dismantling of Gaza’s health care system. 

Following an evacuation order issued by Israeli forces and a recent explosion near the MSF-supported Al-Aqsa Hospital in Deir al-Balah in central Gaza this past weekend, almost 650 patients fled the hospital fearing for their lives. MSF has opened a nearby field hospital to meet some of the needs of people who can no longer go to Al-Aqsa. 

According to the World Health Organization, 20 out of 36 hospitals in Gaza are now non-functional. 

#Ceasefirenow #Gaza #healthworkers

title: Skin diseases in Gaza spread rapidly among children
description: Some 90% of the population of #Gaza is currently displaced. Their living conditions are dire: they reside in improvised tents without access to safe water and food. MSF has partnered with the Palestinian Agricultural Development Association in Khan Younis to provide emergency aid by building latrines, desalinizing water, and providing solar electricity and logistical support to newly arrived people.

title: Displaced in DRC: "If we have to flee again, I would rather die."
description:
Since 2022, hundreds of thousands of people have fled fighting in DRC’s North Kivu province, to find refuge in Goma in overcrowded camps near the front lines. In 2024, clashes between the Congolese army and the armed group M23 took place near the camps.  

This video follows the stories of four women of different generations of the same family who have been displaced in Goma, at Elohim camp, for a year and a half. They detail the deepening loss of physical and social protection and their loss of hope for the future.

title: A migrant’s journey from hardship to hope
description:
Ismail felt the only way to avoid forced military conscription in Eritrea was to leave his home country.  

He undertook a dangerous and exhausting journey over nine years to Sudan and Libya, then over the Mediterranean Sea to Italy, Germany, and finally, Belgium. Since settling into his new country, he has learned Dutch and other languages.  

Ismail now works as a community health worker with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), assisting people living without a home to access health care. His story of resilience and his motivation to help others is truly inspiring.

title: Gaza: Before October 7th
description:
Gaza’s health care system no longer exists after being systematically dismantled by Israeli forces’ attacks, including bombardment, siege, and the killing and arrests of medical professionals and patients.

Five months prior to the war that has now engulfed Gaza, we began filming this documentary to explore the impact of Israel’s 17-year blockade on Gaza’s health care system as it was before the current war, and how even then, Palestinians faced extreme difficulties importing essential medical items, such C-arms (mobile x-ray machines, essential for orthopedic surgeries). The film also showcases the relative strength of Gaza’s health care system prior to October 2023, offering advanced surgical care, research, and stewardship on antimicrobial resistance among other things.

title: Watch the short documentary "13 years of TB in Tajikistan"
description: #ShortDocsWeek presents: "13 years of TB in Tajikistan"

title: 13 years of TB care in Tajikistan
description:
For 13 years, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) closely collaborated with Tajikistan's Ministry of Health and Social Protection of the Population to greatly improve tuberculosis (TB) diagnosis, treatment, and care. “As a result of our joint efforts, the country has achieved a reduction in the incidence rate, including among children and adolescents,” says Dr. Bobojon Pirmahmadzoda, director of Dushanbe city’s TB dispensary. “In 2010, the incidence rate was 12 cases per 100,000 children. Now it is eight to nine cases." 

This documentary shows the success of MSF’s project. Key to the program was the introduction of a patient-centered approach that included contact tracing to stop the spread of infection, holistic support for survivors of domestic violence, drugs compounding at the time when pediatric formulations were limited globally, and providing mental health and psychosocial support, including counseling.  Read more about TB at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/tuberculosis

title: People don’t know this about migrants at the US-Mexico border
description: Currently, the only way for thousands of people stranded in Mexico to apply for asylum in the US is by making an appointment with US immigration officials through a mobile app known as CBP One. But migrants say the app is unreliable and confusing, and few appointments are available. MSF is supporting Tucson-based nonprofit groups that are bringing humanitarian aid to migrants and asylum seekers crossing the US-Mexico border near the Sonoran Desert.

title: Out of Libya
description:
Many migrants and asylum seekers find themselves trapped for years in Libya on their journey toward North Africa and Europe. Despite the presence of international organizations and the existence of evacuation and resettlement processes, their chances of leaving the country legally are slim to none. “Out of Libya” follows the stories of three migrants who managed to escape from Libya: Even, Rosine, and Simon, all of whom were patients of Médecins Sans Frontières teams on their journeys.  

Even, Rosine, and Simon describe systematic abuse and detention at the hands of smugglers, human traffickers, as well as the Libyan authorities. After years trying to survive in Libya, all three came to the same conclusion: despite the danger, the only possible way out of the country was by sea. 

Since 2014, more than 20,000 people have died at sea trying to reach Europe from Libya. Since 2021, a humanitarian corridor has made it possible to evacuate almost 600 people, including around 50 MSF patients from Libya to Italy. A further 1,400 people are expected to be evacuated over the next three years, of whom almost 300 will be cared for by MSF in Italy.

title: Watch the short documentary "Out Of Libya"
description:
#ShortDocsWeek presents: Out of Libya  

Follow the stories of Even, Rosine, and Simon, who like many migrants and asylum seekers on their way to Europe found themselves trapped in Libya for years.  

What they’ve encountered is difficult to imagine. All three described systematic abuse and detention at the hands of smugglers and human traffickers, as well as Libyan authorities. Left with very few options, each expressed that the only possible way out of the country was by sea — despite the enormous dangers in the central Mediterranean.

title: A powder to prevent malnutrition called Tom Brown
description: Inspired by a traditional Nigerian recipe known as “kwash pap,” Tom Brown flour is made up of locally sourced ingredients like grains, soy, and peanuts and made to eat as a sweetened porridge. It’s been improved by nutritionists over the years and has become a useful and efficient tool to prevent and treat moderate malnutrition.

title: Coffee and tough conversations: How MSF treats sexual violence
description:
Yoruba Mitchell, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) health promotion and community engagement specialist, describes how MSF treats survivors of sexual violence.

TRANSCRIPT:
TEXT: Effective treatment for sexual violence requires three things.

Number one: Proactive searching.

We don't wait for people to go looking for medical care, we go out  and find them.

We look for them in communities, in refugee camps, and other places where we work.

Health promotion teams and other trained staff identify patterns of violence in a given location and identify survivors based on that.

For example, we know that in the Darién Gap jungle, which connects Colombia and Panama, mass robberies are carried out by criminals who also sexually assault their victims.

Our health promoters will ask survivors of the Darién if they were robbed, and then try to find out if they were touched without their consent.
  
And then they'll see if any of their companions might also need to receive care.

Number two: Timely treatment.

It's essential to find survivors of sexual violence early so that we can offer medical and mental health care right away.

We can help prevent HIV, if the survivor gets treatment within the first hours after an attack.

We can help prevent unwanted pregnancies if the patient receives emergency contraceptives within five days.

We can also start preventive treatment for sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia, syphilis, and gonorrhea.

Number three: Confidentiality.

Patient confidentiality is part of medical ethics. All information provided by patients, including survivors of sexual violence, is private.

From the moment a patient arrives, our staff informs them that their information will only be used for their care.

TEXT: Medical and psychological services should always be prioritized after an attack. Legal processes should always wait until a patient is receiving care!

Read more about MSF and care for survivors of sexual violence - https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/sexual-and-gender-based-violence

title: A new start after 5 years of opioid addiction
description: MSF started providing care for people who use drugs—specifically those with opioid addictions—in Kiambu County, Kenya, in 2019, with the goal of reducing deaths due to overdose and other consequences of drug addiction. #doctorswithoutborders

title: A new start after 5 years of opioid addiction
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) started providing care for people who use drugs—specifically those with opioid addictions—in Kiambu County, Kenya, in 2019, with the goal of reducing deaths due to overdose and other destructive consequences of drug addiction.  

The medically assisted therapy (MAT) clinic was the first in the county to provide opioid substitution therapy with methadone and buprenorphine as part of its harm reduction package. The approach aims to lessen the negative health, social, and financial impacts of drug addiction. The clinic also offers services to prevent infections, transmission of HIV, and viral hepatitis, treatment for tuberculosis, mental health care, and more. 

“The MAT clinic means a lot to me,” said Michael, a former patient recovering from heroin addiction. “I could certainly be dead if the facility wasn’t around.” 

MSF handed over the project to the county department of health and its partners in June 2024, with 556 patients actively receiving care and a total of 1,619 having enrolled over nearly five years.

title: Pregnant and in danger in Haiti
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) doctor Lisa Searle described the obstacles to receiving sexual and reproductive health care in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince. MSF reaches hundreds of people in need of this care monthly through its mobile clinics, but the city’s health sector is at a breaking point, and more support is needed.

title: Pregnant and in danger in Haiti
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) doctor Lisa Searle describes the obstacles to receiving sexual and reproductive health care in Haiti’s capital, Port-au-Prince. Every month, MSF reaches hundreds of people in need of this care through its mobile clinics, but the city’s health sector is at a breaking point, and more support is needed. 

TRANSCRIPT:
Haiti is in crisis at the moment, particularly since the assassination of the president in July 2021. 

That has forced the country into a downward spiral of violence. So, for Haitians living particularly in the capital city, Port-au-Prince, to access health care services is incredibly challenging. 

We're talking about a situation where the city is segregated into different areas that are under the control of different armed groups.

We hear stories that people have left their neighborhood to seek health care in a different neighborhood, but when they try to come back into their neighborhood, they can be terrorized. 

They're even being shot. 

For a pregnant woman to access care throughout her pregnancy and to deliver in a health facility is almost impossible because of the access issues I mentioned.

Also because there is no free health care. 

We think around 60 to 80 percent of deliveries are happening at home without a skilled birth attendant present, which is an alarming figure. 

We are seeing huge numbers of cases of sexual and gender-based violence, and if care is available, then there are many things that we can prevent.
We can prevent HIV infection, we can prevent unwanted pregnancies, we can prevent infections. 

But so many of these survivors never make it to care.

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/haiti

title: What is measles?
description:
Measles is one of the most contagious diseases in the world. A person carrying the virus can infect up to 90 percent of unvaccinated people around them.  

A vaccine offers almost complete protection after two injections, so making sure that children are double-vaccinated is vital. In many countries, including Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), children slip through the cracks and measles are responsible for killing tens, and sometimes hundreds, of thousands of children every year.  

In 2022, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in DRC vaccinated more than 2 million children in 14 provinces and treated more than 37,000 children with measles; we also supported routine vaccination activities in other DRC provinces where MSF is present throughout the year.  

Read more about MSF’s work on measles at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/measles

title: Doctor in Sudan: "We found ourselves inside the battles"
description: More than 1.5 million people are caught in the fighting between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAR) and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces  (RSF) in El Fasher and its surroundings. On Thursday, June 27, the Saudi Hospital in El Fasher was hit by RSF shelling again — the ninth time a hospital in the city has been attacked since the fighting escalated on May 10. Luckily, there were no victims but the facility sustained some damage. Since May 10, MSF-supported hospitals have treated over 1,781 war wounded, and278 have died from their injuries. We urge the warring parties to ensure rapid, safe, and unhindered humanitarian access so that lifesaving supplies can be brought into the city— this includes from across borders and across front lines.

title: Tens of thousands of children in Gaza: Doctor describes their unknown fate
description:
Dr. Tanya Haj-Hassan, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) pediatrician, spoke with News Nation on June 29, 2024, about injured and missing children in Gaza. Dr. Hassan recently worked in Gaza with another aid organization.  

Regarding a report released by Save the Children on June 24 stating that an estimated 20,000 or more children are missing in Gaza, Dr. Haj-Hassan said:  

"I think the report describes them potentially trapped under the rubble, buried in mass graves, unaccompanied from their families. There are multiple ways these children can be, ‘missing,’ but all of them are very horrifying places for your imagination to go.  

I'm not surprised by that figure, even if it was gut-wrenching to see it on paper, just because even in the hospital where I was working, there were many children that would come into the emergency department injured. And when I would inquire of distant family members who had survived those attacks, they would tell me that they don't know where the younger brother is or where the older sister is of this child and family that they were able to retrieve from the rubble.  

And ultimately, they're not able to retrieve anybody else from the rubble. And those people are never buried. We don't know what their fate is. We don't know how long they survive under the rubble before they ultimately die of suffocation and their injuries.  

There were also multiple children in the hospital who were orphaned since October and separated from their families and are now living either as injured patients or as internally displaced persons within the hospital grounds, unaccompanied and being cared for by benevolent strangers from their community."

title: Danaher, drop the price of all GeneXpert tests to $5!
description:
We, at MSF, get to see the lifesaving impact of Cepheid’s GeneXpert tests to diagnose TB, HIV, hepatitis, and many other diseases. And yet, there are millions of people around the world who cannot afford these tests, who go undiagnosed and miss out on treatment. The problem is that Cepheid, and their parent company Danaher, are charging exorbitantly high prices for these tests—making them unaffordable for the people who need them most. These high prices deny people a second chance to get tested, to get treatment, and to be cured.

title: Severe malnutrition rise among children in northern Nigeria
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is seeing an alarming increase in severely malnourished children with life-threatening complications at our medical facilities in northern Nigeria. 

MSF is calling for more action from authorities and humanitarian organizations in this region, including preventative action. The persistent malnutrition crisis in northern Nigeria stems from a variety of factors, such as inflation, food insecurity, insufficient health care infrastructure, ongoing security issues, and disease outbreaks worsened by low vaccine coverage.

title: Two years after Roe v Wade was overturned, safe abortion care is essential health care
description:
When abortion is illegal and restricted, all aspects of sexual, reproductive, and maternal health are affected. Today marks two years since the US Supreme Court's Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization decision, which overturned the historic Roe v. Wade ruling and the recognition of safe abortion care as a constitutional right. We’ve witnessed firsthand how restricting access to abortion harms the health and wellbeing of the people who need it. 

Transcript:
Safe abortion care is essential health care. It's been two years since the US Supreme Court overturned Roe v Wade and the constitutional right to abortion. Let's talk about it. 

MSF doesn't currently work in the US, but we do provide safe abortion care and treatment for complications from unsafe abortion around the world. Country to country, the restrictions and the challenges are different.

But as a physician who has worked in many countries, I recognize the similarities. No matter where they live, people who are denied access to safe abortion care are at greater risk for complications than those who can access safe care. That can be because they are forced to carry an unintended pregnancy to term with its ensuing complications, or because they are forced to access unsafe means for abortion.

Another similarity are the economic and psychosocial ramifications of carrying an unintended pregnancy. That's why safe abortion care is an essential part of comprehensive health care. 

A few years ago, I was on assignment with MSF. In a country where abortion is restricted. One night, a woman came in heavily bleeding with a life-threatening complication of pregnancy. She needed us to provide safe abortion care to save her life.

The staff gathered quickly to decide how we would care for her. Not everyone agreed about abortion, but despite our differing convictions and values, we all were united by a single truth that we were there to help reduce her suffering. And that's what we agreed to do. The patient went on to receive high-quality and safe care within our MSF facility.

She was able to survive and she and her family were so grateful. At MSF, we see firsthand that restricting abortion only harms the health and well-being of the people who need it. Anyone who seeks an abortion, no matter their reason, is deserving of high-quality and dignified care.

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/abortion

#abortionishealthcare #doctorswithoutborders #safeabortioncare

title: Mental health and children in #Gaza
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mental health activity manager Davide Musardo describes the unrelenting mental health impacts of the war in Gaza on children and how MSF is working to help them. 

TRANSCRIPT:
What we are seeing in little children, especially, are symptoms related to depression, because they lost everything. They lost their parents, they lost their siblings, they lost their house, their toys, everything that makes their daily life normal.

What we see are symptoms also of anxiety, stress reaction, acute stress reaction, and many times the desire to die, instead of living this horror they are living in this moment.

Children are the most affected because they don't have the capacity to explain what is happening to them. They don't have the tools to cope with all these tragic situations.

The difficulty we are facing at this moment is that there is no space for them to fully recover. This is because they are living in a constant situation of exposure to trauma, to explosions, and to bombings.

And this doesn't allow them to start a process of healing that should be done as soon as possible—as soon as we have the ceasefire.

Because without a ceasefire, it will be difficult [for them] to get over this situation.

What we are doing with them is mainly play therapy. It's through play that we get over the trauma, the pain, how to manage the pain, how to manage some emotions that are coming and are not easy to deal with.

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

#doctorswithoutborders #mentalhealth #Gaza

title: Local volunteers provide lifesaving care for migrants at the US border
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) worked alongside Tucson-based nonprofits to better understand the medical humanitarian needs of asylum seekers crossing the US-Mexico border near the Sonoran Desert in April and May 2024.

Arizona-based organizations including Humane Borders, Tucson Samaritans, Green Valley Samaritans, and No More Deaths, as well as independent humanitarians, are providing water, shelter, and other lifesaving aid to migrants waiting to request asylum at the border. Without these volunteers, people who've just crossed the border would be left with no sustenance or services in rough terrain where the weather can be extreme—freezing nighttime temperatures in winter, and blazing hot temperatures and rain in the summer months. Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-joins-local-organizations-helping-migrants-arizona

title: Short documentary trailer: Migration in the Americas
description: "Living our own story": Migration in the Americas is the story of a family that left their home in Venezuela to migrate to the US. The family crossed the Darién Gap jungle, which was far more grueling and horrific than they had been told. Now, they are in Mexico City, awaiting an appointment to apply for asylum in the US. Watch the documentary - https://youtu.be/g38PnEfIrVY

title: "Living our own story": Migration in the Americas
description:
Adriana, Jhonny, and their four small children left their home in Venezuela in 2024.  The family crossed the Darién Gap jungle, which was far more grueling and horrific than they had heard, said Jhonny. They continued north through Central America, stopping in Mexico City, where they are currently staying in one of several makeshift migrant camps that have sprung up because the city does not have enough shelters to accommodate all the people who need them. Like many of their neighbors in the camps, the family is applying for asylum in the US. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff visit the camps every day, letting people know how they can get medical and mental health care, including treatment for sexual violence.  

Currently, the only way for thousands of people stranded in Mexico to access asylum is by making an appointment with US immigration officials through a mobile app known as CBP One. But migrants say the app is unreliable and confusing, and very few appointments are made available each day. 

Disclaimer: This interview was conducted in April 2024, prior to the opening of the project in Costa Rica in May 2024. Currently, MSF has active projects in Costa Rica, Honduras, Guatemala, and Mexico.

title: Echoes of violence in the Darién Gap
description:
Warning: This video contains distressing testimonies. 

In the mountainous rainforests and swamplands of the Darién Gap—a 60-mile stretch of wilderness known as one of the most dangerous migrant crossings in the world. Not only is the terrain extremely difficult, but people face robberies, attacks, and sexual violence at the hands of armed groups. 

Eliana, Rita*, Edward, Lis, Nehemias, and Anyela, all of whom survived crossing the Darién Gap, share what they witnessed during the crossing. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is present along the migration route providing basic medical and mental health care services. Our teams treat survivors of sexual and gender-based violence, families whose children were threatened with forced conscription by gangs, and people driven to escape extreme poverty. 

 Disclaimer: Rita is a pseudonym used to protect the survivor's identity. All interviews presented in this audiogram were conducted in 2023, with the exception of Lis', which is from 2021.

title: Violence in Mali spikes surgical needs among women and children
description:
Armed conflict and poor access to health facilities have made it difficult, if not impossible, for many people in #Mali to move about or seek medical attention when they need it. Violent traumatic injuries linked to the conflict include gunshot wounds, stab wounds, and injuries caused by improvised explosive devices. At Niono Hospital, 69% of all surgeries performed over the last four months have been on women and children, reflecting the toll this conflict takes on people in the community. #doctorswithoutborders #msf #news

Mothers in Nigeria: "We're never at peace"
description:
Why do women in Nigeria struggle to provide care for their young children? Several factors, including limited medical facilities, costs tied to travel distance and affording care, and general insecurity contribute to this. In fact, Nigeria currently has the third-highest maternal mortality rate in the world. But beyond childbirth, mothers struggle to find proper care for their young children who fall ill and need treatment. 

In Kano, Benue, Cross River, and Zamfara states, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are providing maternal and neonatal health care, and we’ll be opening a large maternity hospital in Maiduguri in June 2024. In collaboration with the state Ministry of Health, our teams are also providing emergency obstetrics and newborn care at Jahun General Hospital, located in Jigawa state in northern Nigeria. 

Yet this is still a drop in the ocean when it comes to the immense needs of #women and young children — especially with malnutrition cases on the rise. #doctorswithoutborders  #maternalhealth #maternalmentalhealth #health #mentalhealth

title: What, you come from Dandora? #shortdocumentary #Kenya

"What, you come from Dandora?": A short film on the youth center for Kenya's vulnerable population
description:
Nairobi, Kenya’s capital city, is home to over 4 million people. Currently, over half the population is living in low income settlements, which has drastically impacted young people. In collaboration with the Ministry of Health, Doctors Without Borders opened the Dandora Youth Friendly Center to provide a safe space for kids and young adults and provide them with medical and mental health care.In “What, you come from Dandora,” young people tell us about the center and how it has impacted their lives.

title: The mental health of doctors in Gaza: "Survival is not a choice"
description:
"Doctors and medical staff in general are trained to see blood, to see things that would be hard to see for most people,” says Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) psychologist Audrey McMahon. "But what they've been seeing [in Gaza] is extremely distressing and disturbing for any human being.”  

After more than six months of relentless war, Gaza’s healthcare workers have faced unprecedented challenges in providing medical care every day while trying to survive and manage the toll the conflict has taken on them personally. The impact of working in such conditions could leave scars that last for years to come.  

"We've been hearing [how] medical staff in Gaza are heroes,” McMahon says, "and I think they surely are for what they are doing. And yet it's not a choice. They are all in survival. What else can they do? They have absolutely no time to process what is happening to them. Survival is not a choice.”  

#gaza #doctorswithoutborders #mentalhealth

title: Day in the life of a psychologist in #Ukraine
We need to talk about cholera!
description: #Cholera is on the rise in many of the places where #doctorswithoutborders works. It’s a highly contagious disease that occurs in places without clean water and proper sanitation—often because of conflict, climate change and weather events. It causes profuse diarrhea and vomiting, and without treatment it can quickly lead to death by intense dehydration. Vaccination is key to preventing the spread of the disease. However, there is currently a global shortage of the oral cholera vaccine due to soaring demand and limited manufacturing capacity.

title: An open letter from a mother fleeing conflict in #Sudan

description:
For a year, fighting between the Sudanese Armed Forces and the Rapid Support Forces has brought devastation across Sudan. The conflict has forced more than 8.6 million people from their homes, including 2 million who have fled to neighboring countries.  

This animation follows a mother of six children who was living in Sudan when the war erupted. She flees with her children to South Sudan but they tragically begin to fall ill along the way.

title: "We're suffering from thirst": Sudanese refugees in Chad #sudanconflict
description:
Let’s #TalkAboutSudan. At Al-Acha camp in #Chad, water is scarce. This camp in Chad is home to about 50,000 people, among more than 600,000 #refugees and returnees who have fled #Sudan since the war broke out nearly a year ago.

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) water and sanitation technician, Sharaf Aldin, led us through the camp and shared the difficulties people face to secure #water. “They are waiting sometimes for two days and they are not getting water,” he said. “We are suffering from thirst.”

Our teams are working in several locations in eastern Chad, providing #maternalcare and surgical care, water and sanitation, and care for people with malnutrition, malaria, and other diseases. However, advanced efforts are needed to support this vulnerable community. 
#doctorswithoutborders #news #msf #refugeecamp #refugeestories

title: "The war in Sudan NEEDS our attention": Refugees in Eastern Chad
description:
Imagine one latrine for every 600+ people. That is the reality for those living in this camp in Adré in eastern Chad — a transit site where refugees from #Sudan wait, sometimes for weeks or months, before being relocated to other camps in the region. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) USA executive director, Avril Benoît, just returned from eastern #Chad, where hundreds of thousands of refugees struggle to meet their most basic needs. Her message: “The war in Sudan NEEDS our attention.”

title: Darfur, Sudan walk and talk: One year of war
description:
Let's #TalkAboutSudan – Breaking down what happened to a camp for internally displaced people in Zalingei, Central Darfur: Back in October, this camp faced atrocities that are indescribable. Now, people have no access to water and basic necessities and there is no food distribution from aid organizations that can help alleviate the needs. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has re-established a presence in this camp to support the local hispoital and provide medical care. Like in many places in #Sudan, the people in Zalingei have no access to advanced health care, and there is no referral system in place. Our emergency teams have worked to rehabilitate the town's hospital–the only one providing advanced health care in the whole of Cntral Darfur. Our aim is to reopen the maternity, emergency, and pediatric departments, and the operating room. 

MSF USA executive director, Avril Benoît, walks us through some of the challenges in Zalingei.

title: #Gaza: A timeline of the attack on Nasser Hospital
description:
On the night of February 14-15, 2024, Nasser Hospital, once the largest hospital in southern Gaza, was shelled by Israeli forces. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff members were working inside the hospital and were firsthand witnesses to the attack. This timeline shows their accounts of the events leading up to the night and their eventual forced evacuation.

title: Mothers and babies in north #Gaza “We can’t even access them”
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical program manager and pediatrician Dr. Amber Alayyan describes how children under two years old and pregnant and lactating women in north Gaza are the most vulnerable to malnutrition. A significant issue is that women who cannot access food cannot breastfeed their babies. “Those children need to be breastfed," said Dr. Alayyan. "If they can’t be breastfed, they need to have formula. To have formula, you need clean water. None of these things are possible."

title: To eat or feed my child? #Yemen
description:
The malnutrition crisis in Yemen has many underlying causes. After over a decade of conflict and an unrelenting economic crisis, many people in Yemen have lost their livelihoods. High inflation rates have reduced people’s purchasing power so they can no longer afford enough nutritious food, and diminishing food aid distributions, including the suspension of the World Food Program's general food distributions in northern Yemen, have exacerbated an already dire situation. 

At the same time, pregnant people’s access to medical care, including prenatal and postnatal care, is seriously limited due to the lack of functional primary health care facilities and the high cost of transportation, resulting in early signs of malnutrition going undetected for many.  
#news #yemenemergency #yemencrisis

title: Doctors in #Gaza facing horrific decisions, says MSF's Dr. Amber Alayyan
description:
On March 19, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Medical Program Manager for Afghanistan, Peru, Haiti and Palestine Amber Alayyan delivered a powerful statement during a press conference at the United Nations. She addressed the harsh realities our staff and patients have endured in #Gaza since October — and the overwhelming medical, mental health, and humanitarian needs they’re facing today.  

“You have doctors faced with horrific decisions of having to intubate and amputate children and adults without anesthetics in emergency rooms…No hospital in the world, high income, low income could cope with the amount of injuries that we're seeing and the needs that we're seeing on the ground.”

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: #Iraq: Looking back on MSF’s work in war-torn Hawija.
description:
Years of political instability and conflict left Iraq deeply destabilized, with massive resources allocated to the war effort while infrastructure in more than one third of the country deteriorated immensely impacting the health care system and people’s access to health care services.

To respond to the emerging critical needs, including for displaced communities, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) scaled up activities in areas where displaced people were settling, close to the front lines and in other locations across the country. Before handing over activities to the Directorate of Health this year, MSF’s activities in Hawija took a holistic approach to the treatment of chronic diseases, prioritizing mental health care and health promotion, education about lifestyle risk factors, and improving mental well being. In an area where mental health experts are scarce, this has meant investing in coaching local staff to deliver these services to a community that has experienced a crisis. 

Learn more at: https://bit.ly/4acM5OX

title: How I beat TB, the scariest kind of #TB
description:
Phumeza Tisile Is a survivor of extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB). She was first diagnosed with TB as a 19-year-old university student in South Africa and the next years of her life were a terrifying whirlwind. Here, she recounts her story, from a treatment regimen of 25 pills a day plus a painful injection to sudden deafness and an experimental drug that was her last hope. 

Today, Phumeza Tisile is a survivor and activist. She joins MSF in calling for a revolutionary diagnostic tool to be accessible to the people who need it. Read more about the issue here: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/time-5-msf-demands-cepheid-and-danaher-lower-price-medical-tests

title: Ebola, 10 years after the largest outbreak in history
description:
The deadliest Ebola outbreak on record killed more than 11,300 people and infected nearly 30,000 people in West Africa between 2014-2016. Ebola was first identified in 1976, but it had never been seen on such a large scale. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched an emergency response when the outbreak was confirmed in Guinea, followed by Sierra Leone and Liberia, but no antiviral treatments nor vaccines existed. We had few tools with which to fight such an enormous outbreak.

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/five-key-questions-ebola-expert

title: Nurse in north #Gaza: "Words can't describe it"
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) nurse Loay Harb is one of four remaining MSF staff in Gaza City. He and another nurse go to Al-Shifa Hospital as volunteers every day. "We do not have electricity, water, or [communications] connection," said Harb. "This has created a lot of instability for the people here. We have no flour, and we have no way of communicating with the world."  

The north of Gaza has been largely cut off from assistance for months, leaving people trapped and trying to survive with inadequate food, water, and medical supplies. Whole neighborhoods have been bombed and destroyed. After months of bombardment and siege in Gaza, today MSF teams mainly operate in the south of the Strip. 

#alshifa #doctorswithoutborders #msf #gaza

title: Rebuilding health care after conflict in northern #Ethiopia
description:
Northern Ethiopia’s health care system was deeply disrupted by two years of conflict. In November 2022, a peace agreement was signed, and some areas that were previously inaccessible due to insecurity began to open up and health care services were restarted. However, in many other areas, access to health care continues to be difficult for the people living there. 

In December 2022, MSF started working in the areas surrounding the towns of Alamata and Korem after finding that health facilities had been destroyed in fighting, looted, or lacked any materials, and were struggling to get supplies. Communities had been living without medical care for months and years, with serious physical and psychological consequences.

title: Bringing health care to remote communities in #Brazil
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is responding to severe gaps in the health care system in the Amazonian town of Portel, in the northern Brazilian state of Pará. Most of the problems here are related to the geographical and socio-economic context of the region, where it is difficult to access health facilities and health.
MSF is working in collaboration with the local health authorities to improve primary health care and sexual and reproductive health care, especially among children, teenagers, and pregnant women.

title: MSF scales up response as violence surges in Haiti
description:
Haiti's capital Port-au-Prince is caught in a violent crisis perpetrated by armed groups. Life in the city has become increasingly difficult and risky, while many people are trapped in their homes and public hospitals have shut down. On March 11, the country's leader resigned, adding a new level of chaos. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has scaled up medical activities to care for people injured in the violence. MSF's Tabarre Hospital has increased its capacity by 50 percent and teams are opening another hospital in the Carrefour neighborhood. A third hospital, Turgeau, has recently reopened after being shut down due to violence in December 2023.  

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/haiti-survey-reveals-extreme-level-deadly-violence-port-au-prince

title: Preventing maternal deaths in Nigeria
description:
Nigeria has the third-highest maternal mortality rate in the world. In Jigawa state, northern Nigeria, about 80 percent of deliveries happen at home. Access to health care is extremely challenging for women in this region, where primary health care facilities are often non-functional or unaffordable, and lack necessary equipment, resources, and trained staff.  

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works with the Jigawa state Ministry of Health to provide comprehensive emergency obstetrics and newborn care at Jahun General Hospital. Last year, MSF teams assisted in 15,754 deliveries, performed 1,911 Cesarean sections, and conducted 43,785 prenatal consultations. 

Read more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/preventing-maternal-deaths-jigawa-state-nigeria

title: In Chad, a Sudanese refugee offers maternity care to other refugees
description:
In conflict areas, access to maternal health care can be limited for those who need it. Khadijah is a former midwife and one of the more than 600,00 Sudanese refugees living in Chad. She is helping her community during this ongoing crisis by offering midwife services as a volunteer with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF).

title: #womensupportingwomen in Nablus, #palestine
description:
Noura Arafat is a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) intercultural mediator who has lived in Nablus in Palestine’s West Bank all her life. Since the current war in #gaza began in October, the situation across the occupied West Bank, including in Nablus, has continued to worsen as movement restrictions and violence by settlers and Israeli forces have increased. Noura helps women from her community cope and find hope in life through MSF’s mental health program.

title: Displaced in DR Congo and helping other women
description:
In many conflict settings, including the Democratic Republic of Congo’s North Kivu region, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is able to provide women’s health services due to the work of women in the affected communities. 

Henriette Mbitse fled armed conflict in North Kivu and lives, along with many others enduring extremely difficult conditions, in a displacement camp near Goma. Before she was displaced, she was a community health volunteer in her village, and she has continued her work at the camp. “I began sensitizing women here in Kanyaruchinya about access to healthcare and about sexual violence,” Mbitse said. 

Mbitse and other women have used their skills, lived experience, local knowledge, and solidarity to help more women access medical care and social support, and avoid suffering in silence.

Read more at X

title: "Left to Drown": The experience of #migrants in the Central Mediterranean Sea
description:
“Left to Drown” is based on the real-life accounts of 13 survivors who were adrift on a flimsy rubber boat in the Central Mediterranean Sea after running out of fuel. The Central Mediterranean is one of the deadliest migration routes, with over 22,700 people reported dead or missing since 2014. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have rescued 10,397 people in distress in the Mediterranean. Our teams on board the rescue vessel, Geo Barents, documented numerous cases where European coastal states, notably Malta, knowingly put people’s lives at risk by delaying or failing to effectively coordinate rescues. We urge EU institutions and European states to immediately change course and prioritize the safety of people fleeing to Europe’s shores.

Read more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/left-drown-distress-calls-unanswered-mediterranean

title: DR Congo: Inside a center specializing in trauma surgery and post-op care
description:
Over the past few weeks, we’ve observed a resurgence of violent attacks in Ituri Province, resulting in a significant number of civilian casualties. 

Since the conflict began in 1997, over 1.6 million people have been forced to flee their homes and now live in #displacement - this number represents one-third of the total population of the province. 

We’re continuing to treat the influx of patients arriving daily with complex physical traumas, but more support is urgently needed. 
 #congo #healthcare #news #doctorswithoutborders #drc

title: A family catastrophe in #Gaza - Doctors Without Borders staff shelter hit by a tank shell
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) General Director Meinie Nicolai described visiting the clearly marked MSF shelter in Al-Mawasi #Gaza that was hit with a tank shell on February 20, 2024.  

"I visited the two young women [who were injured]. Their faces burnt, their hands burnt, their mother burned to death, and the sister-in-law as well," said Nicolai. "This whole family, it's a catastrophe."

This is a story that MSF staff have experienced, but there are so many other horrific stories we hear from our patients, and we see in our clinics. This needs to stop now.

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/gaza-staff-are-risking-their-lives-do-their-jobs
