title: Lack of medical supplies reaching Rafah: "It's cynical"
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Project Medical Referent Karin Huster spoke with CNN on February 22, 2024, about what she saw in Rafah, Gaza. Much-needed medications are not reaching hospitals, and a lack of access to care means that usually treatable wounds require amputations. 

"People are unable to receive care on time. So when they come, their wounds are very infected, and you are left with no option but to do surgery—to do an amputation," Huster said.

Aid that does get through sometimes is not what is needed. "Trucks with PPE [personal protective equipment] were able to get through," she said, "but we are still waiting for anesthesia medicine, pain medicine, medicine for people who have diabetes, hypertension, or cancer."

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: #MSF emergency coordinator talks about his experience in #Gaza  #doctorswithoutborders
The impact of two years of war in Ukraine
description:
The war in Ukraine is still having a devastating impact on people’s health. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working in the east and south of the country, close to the front lines and areas that are constantly under bombardment. 

"The population has suffered a lot of violence, a lot of loss, a lot of isolation, a lot of fear,” said Diego Ráfales, an MSF project coordinator in Ukraine, "which in the end could plunge the country into a kind of trauma, collective trauma that, if not responded to in an adequate way, can lead to the development of serious mental disorders.”

Most of the health care response in Ukraine is provided by the Ukrainian health care system and local volunteer groups, who have responded to a substantial increase in needs, often working in harsh conditions near the frontlines. MSF teams continue to support the health care system by filling in the gaps aggravated and caused by the war. 

Read more at X

title: Measles outbreak could have deadly consequences in Nigeria
description:
Measles-related admissions have reached record levels at Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) facilities in Borno State, northeast Nigeria. Measles can be deadly on its own or as a precursor to malnutrition. 

Vaccination coverage is low in this region, and recent vaccination campaigns urgently need to be reinforced. However, the security situation, significant funding cuts by international donors for Nigeria, and the continuous neglect of public health infrastructure could create the conditions for a range of vaccine-preventable disease outbreaks.

MSF is warning international and national stakeholders not to ignore what could worsen the humanitarian crisis in northeast Nigeria in 2024. 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/nigeria

title: Attack on #rafah #gaza would be devastating  #doctorswithoutborders
description: A full-scale attack on Rafah would have devastating consequences for the 1.5 million Palestinians sheltering there. Before the war started over 4 months ago, Rafah had a population of just over 250,000. Now, tents have sprawled, and people are living in dire, overcrowded conditions. Food, water, medicines, and other essentials are scarce. Rafah is the end of the line. An attack on the last refuge in Gaza will be catastrophic. #ceasefirenow

title: Gaza: "A ceasefire has never been more urgent"
description:
Since October 2023, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have worked tirelessly as the world watched relentless attacks push civilians further down the strip. Rafah, at the southernmost tip of Gaza, is the last remaining refuge for most of Gaza’s population. It’s the only remaining hub of health care services and humanitarian assistance on the strip.

Many families have been displaced multiple times and are sheltering in fragile, unheated tents. Access to clean water, sanitation, food, or health care is scarce. Tens of thousands of people continue to enter Rafah from neighboring Khan Younis, where intense fighting continues. A military offensive in Rafah will result in even more deaths and destroy the only support that people have left. We need attacks against hospitals and civilians to stop immediately.

A ceasefire in Gaza has never been more urgent.

title: Gaza: “We don’t know if we will survive the next hour”
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) team members in Gaza have been sending us voice notes describing the dire situation as Israeli strikes in the south, particularly Rafah, have been intensifying. 

Nearly 1.5 million displaced Palestinians are sheltering in Rafah after being displaced from the northern and central parts of Gaza as the war has progressed. Israeli forces have threatened a ground invasion of Rafah, which would be devastating for all the people who have gathered in what was supposed to be a safe place.  

This voice message was sent by an MSF doctor sheltering with her family in Rafah. 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/gaza-we-dont-know-if-we-will-survive-next-hour

title: How #msf provides pediatric care in #Yemen
Displaced and seeking medical care Rafah, southern Gaza
description:
The lack of hospital capacity, medical supplies, and proper hygiene in Gaza means that hospitals often cannot provide adequate care to war-wounded patients. 
 
Hala Ismael Al-Talla, a patient at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)-supported Rafah Indonesian Field Hospital, was forced to leave her home in Gaza’s Middle Area after the house she lived in with her family was shelled and her leg was broken. She managed to get treatment at Al-Aqsa Hospital, but the medical staff did not have the capacity to perform a skin graft, which she urgently needed. When the hospital came under attack, Hala and her family fled for safety again, this time to Rafah. 
 
Hala was able to receive care at Rafah Indonesian Field Hospital. But attacks in Rafah have intensified recently, and Israel has threatened a ground invasion, which will be devastating for the nearly 1.5 million people gathered there, including Hala and her family.

Read more at https://bit.ly/42zVtcD

title: In Gaza, clean water is dangerously scarce
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams run a water distribution program in Rafah, but the water we can provide is merely a drop in an ocean of need. 

At least half of the water and sanitation facilities in Gaza have been destroyed or damaged, according to UNICEF, and restrictions on the flow of supplies into Gaza prevent the scale-up of water production and distribution. UNRWA reports that 70 percent of the population is resorting to drinking salty or contaminated water, putting their health at risk. 

MSF patients are suffering from intestinal disorders and the flu virus, said MSF health promotion manager Mohammad Abu Zayed. “Lately, we’ve also witnessed children suffering from skin rashes due to the lack of clean water for bathing or washing.” 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/water-resource-more-precious-each-day-gaza

title: Lost at Sea: The story of a Rohingya man in search of safety
description:
“We are the Rohingya nation; we are searching for our shore. Hang on, child; wherever you run, wind, water, and fire will chase you.” 

Muhib was haunted by these words, sung by his mother before he fled Myanmar and embarked on a dangerous sea voyage seeking refuge in Malaysia. 

"Lost at Sea" draws inspiration from Muhib's real-life experiences. He found himself stranded on a fishing boat in the Andaman Sea, where he and others witnessed the loss of 27 lives, underscoring the immense risks faced by those fleeing conflict and persecution.

The film uses documentary footage painted frame-by-frame with music and poetry from Rohingya artists to tell Muhib’s story in a unique hybrid animation format. This powerful narrative has earned prestigious awards, including the Best International Short Film at the Heroes International Film Festival in Rome and the 4th Chema Castiello Award for Best Short Film.  

Learn more about the film and about the Rohingya people at https://doctorswithoutborders-apac.org/en/remember-the-rohingya

title: A simple tool reduces #maternal mortality in #Niger  #doctorswithoutborders
Destination: Radiotherapy
description:
This documentary follows the journey of Chimwemwe and Nessie, two Malawian women diagnosed with cervical cancer, as they undergo treatment and travel to Kenya for radiotherapy. 

Cervical cancer is the fourth most common cancer among women worldwide and—despite being preventable, detectable, and treatable—it kills hundreds of thousands of women each year. In the landlocked country of Malawi in East Africa, over 4,000 Malawian women fall sick with cervical cancer every year. With 2,905 deaths due to cervical cancer in 2020, the country also has the second highest rate of mortality in the world, after Eswatini. 

In partnership with Malawi’s Ministry of Health, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs a cervical cancer project based in Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital in the southern district of Blantyre. The project focuses on providing effective, feasible, and high-impact care to prevent and treat cervical cancer through a comprehensive program that includes screening, consultations, specialized surgery, and palliative care for advanced-stage patients. Radiation therapy, which is considered the first-line treatment for cervical cancer, is currently unavailable in Malawi, though two radiotherapy projects (non-MSF) are ongoing and aim to be operational by 2024. In the meantime, MSF developed a temporary referral system to send some cervical cancer patients to Kenya for radiotherapy. Since 2022, 62 women with cervical cancer have traveled from Malawi to Kenya to receive treatment.

title: What doctors see in Gaza: “It’s not something anyone can cope with”
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Emergency Coordinator Marie-Aure Perreaut Revial led a medical team into Gaza in November and December 2023. They witnessed first-hand the “systematic destruction of health care in Gaza,” she said, and were continually exposed to scenes that no one should ever have to experience.

“[My colleagues] are beyond exhausted at this point. They come to the hospitals, they see horrific scenes. They see children really badly burned, badly injured,  their entire faces burned, eyes are gone, babies with no legs anymore that you need to amputate. The weight that we put on the health care providers in Gaza, it's not something anybody can ever cope with. The mental health trauma of what is going on now in Gaza is beyond words."

Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: What’s happening in Sudan?
description:
The conflict that broke out on April 15, 2023 in Khartoum between the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) has since then spread across the country, especially in the Darfur regions, with devastating consequences for communities. Most civilian casualties have been people caught in the crossfire or victims of indiscriminate shelling by both parties involved in the conflict. 

Near the Chad-Sudan border, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provided surgical trauma care to 1,475 wounded patients in the last six months at Adré Hospital and expanded activities to meet the urgent medical needs of a growing refugee population, as half a million Sudanese have recently sought safety in Chad. In this interview, Jérôme Tubiana, MSF advisor on migration, who has visited Sudan twice since the war started, discusses the dynamics of the conflict and the humanitarian situation in Darfur, where MSF teams operate in El Fasher and El Geneina hospitals.

title: #howto carry out a #vaccination campaign in remote areas #southsudan #msf #doctorswithoutborders
description:
In response to a deadly Hepatitis E outbreak in South Sudan, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has launched a mass vaccination campaign in collaboration with the Ministry of Health to safeguard women and girls of reproductive age, who are at greatest risk of death from the disease.
MSF's vaccination campaign is the first to be conducted during the acute stages of an active Hepatitis E outbreak anywhere in the world. It is made more challenging by the remoteness and isolation of the area of South Sudan where it is taking place. But if the campaign succeeds, it will save lives.

title: Will an abortion with pills affect my fertility?
description:
The fact is that having a safe abortion does not affect your ability to become pregnant again. We are providing reliable medical information to counter harmful misinformation and myths, so people can better understand what safe abortion is.

Learn more at https://bit.ly/SACisHealthCare

Transcript:
Are you wondering if having a safe abortion with pills will affect your fertility? 

The answer is no.

Medical evidence shows that a safe abortion does not increase the risk of infertility. 

Nor has it been shown to cause birth defects in future pregnancies.

Intentionally wrong information around abortion and fertility is often used online and elsewhere to scare off abortion seekers. 

Go to howtouseabortionpill.org or watch our full video series, for more reliable information on safe abortion with pills.

Watch our full video series here - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLa-oDa0bl_LO5udAfTft0A7Q44_x_VMFO

title: "I will walk again": Fleeing violence with an injured leg in Gaza
description:
Shorouk Al-Rantisi has fled in search of safety multiple times since the beginning of the war in Gaza. After a missile strike on Jabalia refugee camp in northern Gaza, her leg was broken, and she was trapped under the rubble. 

Eventually, she was rescued and received care. She now has a metal plate in her leg. While she was still in recovery, Al-Rantisi and her family were ordered to evacuate and had to flee again. 

"Every day I was in a different area, I became homeless,” she said. “[My leg] was starting to heal and get better, but it got badly infected.”

When they reached Rafah at the southern border, she discovered the Rafah Indonesian Field Hospital, supported by MSF, by chance. She is now receiving care again. "I will be able to walk again," she said. "And I am getting daily physiotherapy. I will get better.” 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: Out of fear: #rohingya youth trapped in violence and despair #shortdocumentary #watchnow #msf
Out of fear: Rohingya youth trapped in violence and despair
description:
Six years after being forced from their homes by extreme violence in Myanmar, Rohingya refugees in neighboring Bangladesh are trapped in the camps where they first sought safety. Hope for a safe return home has faded, conditions in the camps are poor and deteriorating, and their situation is not expected to improve. 

The United Nations body responding to the needs of around 900,000 Rohingya refugees in Bangladesh is providing less and less humanitarian assistance, Rohingya people's movements are restricted and tightly controlled, while fighting between groups for territory in the camps has led to violence and killings. 

The reality in the camps—rampant violence, no access to jobs, limited education, inadequate food and health care—affects young people in a particularly destructive way. This documentary looks at what youth in the Rohingya camps are facing now. Read more about the Rohingya refugee crisis at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/focus/rohingya-refugee-crisis

title: In Gaza, treating children with no surviving families
description:
Dr. Aldo Rodríguez, a surgeon with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Gaza, performed surgeries on 20-25 people per day at Al-Aqsa Hospital. Many of them were children. 

"Several cases caught my attention," he said, "especially two babies, one and two years old, with traumatic leg amputations. They were the only survivors. We began to use a common English term—"wounded child from non-surviving family" [WCNSF].  It means that the child's whole family dies in the bombing. The baby or child was the only one who survived. A child without a family."

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: In Gaza, "You can't be safe anywhere"
description:
On January 8, 2024, a shelter for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff and their families in Rafah was attacked. The five-year-old daughter of an MSF staff member was injured and later died from her wounds. 

"The Israeli army was notified by MSF that it was a place with only civilians looking for safety," said MSF Head of Mission Léo Cans. "This shows that in Gaza, you can't be safe anywhere."

title: Afghanistan: Filling critical gaps in health care provision in the North
description:
For more than two decades, Afghanistan's health care system has grappled with longstanding issues of understaffing, underfunding, and an inadequate response to people’s needs within the health system. In an effort to extend crucial health care services and reduce pediatric and neonatal mortality in the northern provinces of the country, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), in collaboration with the Ministry of Public Health, initiated medical services at Mazar-i-Sharif Regional Hospital in Balkh province with a focus on specialized pediatric care.
 
MSF supports a neonatal intensive care unit, providing care to premature and sick newborns, and also runs a pediatric emergency room for children up to the age of 15, which is supported by a triage system to ensure the most critical patients are admitted and given the care they need. As the sole tertiary medical facility and primary referral center in the region, it serves as a crucial hub, with patients often traveling long distances for treatment there.

Read more at https://bit.ly/3H4QVAV

title: #MSF aids #refugee camps in eastern Chad
description: MSF General Director Stephen Cornish shares the dire living conditions of Sudanese refugees in eastern Chad. Approximately 500,000 refugees fleeing the conflict in Sudan lack essential resources like food, water, and shelter. MSF clinics in Adré see around 3,000 patients weekly—mostly children with malaria, diarrhea, colds, and respiratory tract infections. If aid isn't scaled up soon, we are concerned there will be a humanitarian catastrophe.

title: A #ClimateChange message for the new year
description: Some background: Higher greenhouse gas emissions exacerbate the climate crisis and related health issues like disease outbreaks, malnutrition, and mental health effects related to increasingly frequent natural disasters. MSF has seen ecosystem damage impact health in many places, including South Sudan, where perpetually flooded lands have cut people off from healthcare, food sources have disappeared, and there have been increases in mosquito-borne diseases, including malaria.

title: The year in photos: 2023
description:
This year, Doctors Without Borders/ Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) responded to multiple humanitarian emergencies in diverse settings around the world.

From catastrophic earthquakes in Türkiye, Syria, and Afghanistan; to outbreaks of devastating conflict in Gaza and Sudan; to the health impacts of climate change in places like Kiribati and Madagascar, our teams adapted quickly to tackle often complex needs.

This collection of photos provides a glimpse of some of our projects in 2023.

Read more at: https://bit.ly/MSFYearInPhotos2023

title: The Continued Loss of Life in Gaza: "It makes me ashamed"
description:
Ricardo Martínez, a logistics coordinator for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) who recently returned from Gaza, describes the incalculable loss of human life there. 

"A lot of children are going to die. And a lot of women. Because they don't even have the basic, simple option of going to a maternity ward," he said. "It makes me ashamed as a Westerner, this lack of action on the part of the powers that be to stop this once and for all."

title: MSF Stands with the People of South Sudan
description:
In 2023, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) marks four decades of medical and humanitarian assistance in the region that is now South Sudan. 

The people of South Sudan have continued to suffer the consequences of recurrent violence, limited access to health care, economic crises, and natural disasters due to climate change. This year, more than 350,000 people have fled to South Sudan as a result of ongoing violence in Sudan.

We run one of our largest humanitarian assistance programs worldwide in response to these challenges in South Sudan. Our collaboration and engagement with local communities have made the last 40 years worthwhile.

Read more at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/where-we-work/south-sudan

title: Testimonies From Our Gaza Colleagues
description:
Our staff in New York read testimonies shared over the past two months by MSF medical staff in Gaza.

Our teams have witnessed unfathomable injuries and death. This includes the killings of four colleagues: Mohammed Al Ahel, a laboratory technician, was killed along with several members of his family when their home in Al Shati refugee camp was hit by an airstrike. Alaa Al Shawa, a nurse who worked with us as a volunteer, was killed when an MSF convoy of five vehicles came under fire from Israeli forces on November 18; the relative of another staff member also died from injuries sustained during this attack. Dr. Mahmoud Abu Nujaila and Dr. Ahmad Al Sahar were killed alongside a third doctor following a strike on Al Awda hospital on November 21. 

Health workers continue to treat the thousands of patients in need, whenever possible. With dwindling medical supplies and medicines, and no guaranteed safety in or around hospitals and ambulances, our work is becoming close to impossible.

We stand in solidarity with our staff in continuing to demand a ceasefire now. 

Read more at: https://bit.ly/VoicesFromGaza

title: Deaths and Health Care Attacks on the Rise in the West Bank
description:
Miles away from Gaza, Palestinians in the West Bank have also been experiencing a significant increase in violence against civilians and attacks on health care. 

In Jenin refugee camp, people are faced with frequent violence and military incursions, says Luz Saavedra, emergency coordinator for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). "Basic social services like health and education are continuously disrupted," she says. "People get injured and sick, and they can't access health care.

"Paramedics get harassed, they get targeted by the occupying forces, and there are even levels of detention and intimidation on a systematic basis."

title: Iraqi Surgeon Looks Back on 17 Years of Treating War-Wounded Patients
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) surgeon Dr. Rasheed Fakhri fled his country during the Iraq War. For the last 17 years, he has been working at MSF's reconstructive surgery project in Amman, Jordan, treating people from Iraq who have been impacted by the war.

“I lived through 17 years of stories," says Dr. Fakhri. "Stories that range from children scarred by terrorism to innocent victims of bombings, and those who lost their ability to speak or lost their sight. But thankfully we’ve helped them on their path to recovery. This is a source of pride for us.”

title: Migrants left without protection as Darién Gap crossings reach half a million
description:
For many migrants, attempting to cross this deadly stretch of jungle between Colombia and Panama is the only hope to reach the United States by land. Many people die in the jungle from falling off steep rocky cliffs or drowning in rushing rivers. Others are killed by criminal gangs in the area who kidnap, rape, and steal money from passersby. 
 
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams work in reception centers set up by the Panamanian government in Lajas Blancas and San Vicente and in the indigenous community of Bajo Chiquito, providing medical and mental health consultations and care to survivors of sexual violence. During 2023, MSF mobile teams also traveled along the main migrant transit routes through Colombia to provide people with medical care. 
 
The assistance available is acutely insufficient for the number of people making the crossing. MSF calls on Latin American countries to coordinate efforts to ensure safe passage and access to basic services for people on the move. 

Read more at: https://bit.ly/MSFDarienGap

title: Climate Change Spurs Dengue — MSF Fights Back
description:
Due to climate change, the spread of mosquito-borne diseases, including dengue, has increased 30-fold over the past 50 years. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has seen the devastating effects on people in Honduras where cases are growing increasingly severe. We are implementing a new, environmentally friendly prevention method to fight this disease in the region. If this method leads to a reduction in death and illness, it could become a long-term sustainable solution.

title: This week there’s been urgent updates: Fuel and medical supplies have reached critically low levels.
description:
This video update was shared by Dr. Sohaib Safi on November 29 from the MSF-supported Al Aqsa Hospital, located in the middle area of the Gaza Strip. A little more than a week before, he had been injured in a blast close to his home.

This week there's been urgent updates: Fuel and medical supplies have reached critically low levels at Al-Aqsa hospital. Our emergency coordinator warns: “We are running out of essential supplies to treat them.” On December 6, for the first time since the escalation of the conflict, the number of people killed arriving to Al-Aqsa surpassed the number of injured people. 115 people killed in 24 hours. The hospital is full. The morgue is full.

We continue to call for a sustained #ceasefirenow.

title: In Southern Gaza, Patients and Displaced People Tell Their Stories
description:
Since conflict resumed in Gaza on December 1, 2023, bombings and ground attacks have intensified in the south. Many people have taken refuge in and around Nasser Hospital, which MSF supports. Here, MSF patients tell their stories.

"I was injured in my leg, my back, and my left hand," one patient says. "I had burns and flesh wounds. My mother had her hand amputated, and my little niece was killed. What have these young children done to deserve this?”

Displaced people taking refuge outside are occupied with trying to find food and water. "We have a hard time finding bread for the kids, and if we get some we divide it to feed all the family,” one mother says. "Other than that, [we face] difficulty in [finding] water, especially fresh water.”

There is little humanitarian aid trickling into Gaza and everything is in short supply—food, water, and medicines. MSF is calling for an immediate and sustained ceasefire and the allowance of badly needed humanitarian aid to cross into Gaza.

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: A Doctor in Gaza: "After 60 days of war, I'm losing hope"
description:
Dr. Ruba is a Palestinian physician in Gaza who has continued to try to help her patients. Here, she describes her situation after two months of war.

Transcript:

We are displaced south from the valley, which is supposed to be a safe area, but every night, every day, there are airstrikes. They are targeting everybody. Nobody is safe.

There are a lot of different types of injuries. We saw burns from different kinds of sources. We saw raw areas. We saw fractures. Also, there are a lot of kids with amputations.

We have only the primary medical supplies with paracetamol, ibuprofen, and dressings, and unfortunately, we don't have access to our clinic. The Israeli army cut the road.

We treated a six-year-old female child. She was badly injured with external fixator, and there is a big raw area. She was crying, shouting.

She was begging for painkillers, for sedation, because she's tired from pain, and she's tired from inability to move her arm. In most of shelters, you will find fleas, you will find all kinds of skin diseases, all kinds of gastrointestinal symptoms, And in one shelter near where I am located, there is hepatitis A spread between people.

It's really hard to treat them because we don't have access to the needed drugs. We don't have access to anything at all. Water and food, they are not clean.

And people are now eating anything they could find, because it's really starvation here. I don't believe that anything I say will change the picture.

My only message that Palestinians have the right to be treated as human beings, have the right to live. Every day, every night I fear for my kids' life, for my life.

And I'm sorry to say that, but after 60 days of war, I'm losing hope, and I am saying that the ones who passed away in the (first) few days, were very lucky.

They didn't witness two-months of terrifying days and nights. I'm seeing my people suffer, and I cannot do anything. This world is not fair. 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: MSF holds vigil at UN to call for ceasefire in Gaza
description:
On December 6, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) held a vigil outside the United Nations headquarters to once again call on world leaders to push for an urgent and sustained ceasefire in Gaza.
 
MSF staff, along with members of the association, stood together in solidarity with our colleagues and patients, and in solidarity with humanity.
 
Our colleagues are continuing to work in Gaza to provide medical care at unimaginable personal risk and cost. Four of our Palestinian colleagues have been killed since the conflict escalated on Oct 7. Many more have been injured and lost homes and family members. As humanitarians, we demand that medical facilities be protected.
 
A sustained ceasefire is the only way to stop the suffering and death of civilians and ensure the delivery of desperately needed aid.
 
Read more at: https://bit.ly/MSFCallsforCeasefireNow

title: Doctors in the South of Gaza are Overwhelmed with Civilian Victims
description:
Dr. Tanya Haj-Hassan, a pediatric intensive care doctor who worked in Gaza with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and with other organizations in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, spoke with CNN on Sunday, December 3, 2023. 

Healthcare providers who were forced to move to the south of Gaza "are trying to find ways to help in any way they can," said Dr. Haj-Hassan. "And they describe ... seeing thousands of victims coming in, thousands of casualties. One of our colleagues today described seeing seven bilateral amputations—so that's amputations of both legs. Two were children - one age two, one age 11."

MSF is calling for an immediate and sustained ceasefire in Gaza: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/us-must-call-immediate-ceasefire-gaza

title: MSF Convoy Vehicles Destroyed in Gaza
description:
Images of the destruction of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) vehicles on November 20 and 24, 2023, and testimonies from two MSF staff who witnessed the destruction are presented in this video.

On November 18, 2023, the evacuation convoy came under fire in Gaza City in what immediately appeared to be a deliberate attack against clearly identified MSF vehicles. Two people were killed—both family members of MSF staff—including one who was a volunteer supporting MSF medical teams at Al-Shifa Hospital. 

All five of the MSF vehicles used during the convoy were subsequently destroyed on November 20 by an Israeli bulldozer and a heavy military vehicle. On November 24, an additional MSF minibus was destroyed by an Israeli tank. 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-convoy-attack-gaza-all-elements-point-israeli-army-responsibility

title: Guinea: Living positively with HIV
description:
On this World AIDS Day, members of MSF’s team in Guinea share insights on living with HIV and fighting stigma in communities.

In 2003, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened free HIV testing and treatment centers in Conakry, Guinea. 

For 20 years, MSF has been at the forefront of HIV/AIDS treatment in the country, bringing care closer to communities and building peer support networks that are a ‘lifeline’ for HIV-positive patients.

While much progress has been made, MSF is still one of the key organizations tackling the disease and major gaps remain in testing and treatment.

Read more at https://bit.ly/GuineaHIVCare

title: The War on Hospitals in Northern Gaza
description:
Since early November 2023, there have been multiple attacks on hospitals, medical staff, and patients in the northern Gaza Strip. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Palestinian staff and colleagues in the Al-Shifa, Al-Quds, and Al-Nasser hospitals in Gaza City have witnessed many of these attacks. This video is a collection of their testimonies recorded over the last month.

Hospitals, health workers, and patients must be protected. MSF is calling for an immediate and sustained ceasefire to prevent more deaths, and for the siege to be lifted so that humanitarian supplies and personnel can enter Gaza.

title: Improving Access to Insulin Pens For People Living With Diabetes
description:
Meet 10 year old Moussa who has type 1 diabetes. A decade earlier, he and his family had to flee their home in Syria and took refuge in a remote town located in north-eastern Lebanon.

In July 2022, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) re-introduced insulin pens - a painless, easy to use treatment that has a clear measurement scale - as a part of free medical care and treatment provided to patients living with type 1 diabetes in our clinics in Baalbeck-Hermel, Lebanon.

Now, kids like Moussa can use the insulin pen as needed and take it with them on the go.

MSF has a future long-term plan to shift all our patients, adults included, who use insulin to insulin pens.

Read more at https://bit.ly/47cFpyM

In response, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are distributing kits containing thermal insulation, blankets, and winter clothing in several camps in the region, in addition to continuing to provide much-needed medical services.

title: "No one hears us," Doctor in Gaza's Al-Shifa Hospital Describes the Harrowing Scene
description:
Dr. Mohammed Obeid, a surgeon with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) working inside Al-Shifa hospital in Gaza, described the situation on November 11, 2023. "Since this morning, there is no electricity. There is no water. There is no food," he said. The hospital and the areas outside the hospital where people are sheltering have been hit with bombs. A sniper has wounded patients inside the hospital. Premature babies have died because the incubator cannot function without electricity. "We need help," he said. "No one hears us."  

MSF continues to call for an immediate ceasefire and for the protection of medical facilities, medical staff, and patients, and for people who want to leave the hospital to be allowed to do so.
Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/urgent-patients-and-medical-staff-trapped-hospitals-under-fire-gaza

title: MSF Live with Avril Benoît: Responding to Emergencies and Cascading Crises
description:
We invite you to join us for a live online talk with Avril Benoît, executive director of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF-USA) on Thursday, November 9, at 12:00 pm ET.  

This year, MSF teams helped people in need in more than 70 countries around the world. From the escalation of conflicts in Gaza, Sudan, Haiti and Ukraine; to record-breaking flooding in South Sudan and Libya; to the deadly earthquakes in Afghanistan, Morocco, Syria, and Türkiye, many of the year’s most challenging emergencies unfolded in places that were already reeling from the effects of existing crises.  

Join Avril on November 9 to learn how our teams adapted their responses to tackle cascading emergencies in diverse contexts—and how we are preparing to meet the humanitarian challenges ahead.

title: In This West Bank Hospital All Cases Are Critical as Violence Rises
description: “Most of the patients we receive have been shot in the abdomen and the legs. Some have had their liver and spleen shattered while others have severe vascular injuries,” said Dr. Pedro Serrano, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) intensive care doctor in Jenin.

title: MSF Doctors in West Bank See Horrific Injuries as Fighting Spreads from Gaza
description: In the West Bank city of Jenin, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) emergency doctors are responding to critical needs resulting from escalating violence against Palestinians.

title: Majority of Patients MSF Sees in Gaza are Children, Many Left with No Family
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Communications Manager Faris Al-Jawad, based in the West Bank, spoke to ABC News on November 6, 2023, about what MSF staff in Gaza are reporting and what is happening to children who are left orphaned by the bombing.

Transcript:
I also like to ask you about this new acronym that has been created, specifically due to this conflict. W-C-N-S-F, which stands for Wounded Child, no Surviving Family. How prevalent of an issue is that?

I mean, the vast majority of the patients that we see, that our teams see in the hospitals around Gaza are indeed children. The other day after the Jabaliya camp was hit, we received many children in Al Shipper Hospital, and one of our colleagues described to me the fact that most of these children arrived without any parents, without any family that were screaming for their parents, screaming for their family. There was nobody there. So our team member had to stay with the children, obviously give them emergency medical care, but also stay with them thereafter because they're alone.

And you said that in those cases they were able to stay with those children, but if we're talking about large volumes, what happens to those kids? Do they end up then just staying at the hospital indefinitely?

Well, it's difficult to track, but indeed, the hospitals themselves are loaded with not only severely wounded patients in beds on the ground, in the corridors, but of course, thousands and thousands of people seeking shelter. So it's just carnage. There's no other way to describe it. There's nowhere for people to go. The idea to be able to evacuate these hospitals is just ludicrous. There's nowhere to go. 

And indeed, leaving the hospitals with patients, obviously, who are sick and ill and in dire shape would mean a death sentence. So it's just an untenable situation. The situation needs to stop, the bombing needs to stop. We need to cease fire now. 

Quite frankly, it's just unfathomable how this is still going on. World leaders, I don’t know how they can sleep at night, quite frankly, I do not understand it. We've been saying the same thing over and over again. It seems that our words are just falling on deaf ears sometimes. It doesn't even seem worth doing these interviews to some degree because it seems like nobody's listening.

If there's someone who's in America, in Canada, in Africa right now who wants to help, is there anything that they can do from home?

I believe it's everybody's wish and responsibility to try and push for a ceasefire. And whether that be the people of the United States or the people anywhere across the world, we need a ceasefire. 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/msf-violence-gaza-escalates-despite-calls-ceasefire

title: CNN Interview: MSF Nurse—Palestinian health staff staying in Gaza to help are "heroes"
description:
Emily “Cali” Callahan, a nurse activity manager with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) from the United States, was trapped under siege in Gaza for 26 days. She and 21 other MSF international staff were finally able to leave on November 1, 2023. Callahan was interviewed by CNN's Anderson Cooper on November 6, 2023. In this excerpt from the interview, she describes what she witnessed—and what her Palestinian colleagues are still experiencing. 

"When everything went off and we got the notice to move south of Wadi Gaza,
I was texting my nurses at Indonesia Hospital and I said—we lost a nurse [during] weekend one. He was killed when the ambulance outside the hospital was blown up and I was texting them when we got the evacuation orders and I said, 'Did any of you lose staff? Did any of you get out? Like, are any of you coming down this way?’ 

"And the only answer I got was, 'This is our community. This is our family. These are our friends. If they're going to kill us, we're going to die saving as many people as we can.' And I said, 'If I can ever have an ounce of the heart that you have, I will, I will die a happy person.' They were incredible. 

"I would like to send out a reminder that there are civilians seeking shelter there and that my doctors and nurses didn't leave out of loyalty to their community. And I know that there is an idea being pushed right now that anyone that stayed behind is going to be considered some kind of a threat. And I want to remind people that the people that stayed behind are heroes. 

"You’re talking about doctors, nurses in the hospital.

"I wake up every morning and I send out a text message and I ask, 'Are you alive?' And every night before I go to sleep, I send another message and it says, 'Are you alive?’" 

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/gaza-update-movement-staff-rafah-crossing

title: CNN Interview: MSF Nurse Describes her Experience Under Siege in Gaza for 26 Days
description:
Emily “Cali” Callahan, a nurse activity manager with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) from the United States, was trapped under siege in Gaza for 26 days. She and 21 other MSF international staff were finally able to leave on November 1, 2023. Callahan was interviewed by CNN's Anderson Cooper on November 6, 2023. In this excerpt from the interview, she describes what she witnessed—and what her Palestinian colleagues are still experiencing. 

"We said to [our Palestinian colleagues] over and over again, 'You don't have to stay. We understand if you want to leave us.' And they said, 'You are family, too. And we're not going anywhere.’

"Your staff, the Palestinians who worked for MSF, for Doctors Without Borders, were concerned about your safety.

"We would have died within a week without [our Palestinian colleagues]. They are the only reason we are alive. 

"It's incredible that this took so long to get Americans, sick people, starting to move through that Rafah border crossing. It's, it's inexplicable.
 
"And we were desperate. We did a calorie count at one point based on our supplies and figured out that if all of us, there's 50 people with us, living in a parking lot now, only ate 700 calories a day, if that's all we had, we had two days of food left and that's it. And our national staff took off. We had no cell service at that point, so we had no idea what had happened to them. There's bombs going off all around us because there's no safe place in Gaza.

"Even getting through that Rafah border crossing. What was that like? 

"They didn't leave our side for a second. 

"You're—the national staff. 

"The national staff. 

"Because they feared for your safety even at the border crossing.
 
"They made sure they were standing between us and desperate people. They made sure that they were talking to every official that they could find, trying to push us through, trying to get us on the bus, trying to get us out. 

"And we're sitting there, watching these incredible men who have sacrificed everything for us, who have sacrificed time with their families, their own physical safety, their own water supply they were giving to us. 

"And we're watching them fight to get us across the border, knowing that we were not bringing them with us. And they didn't, they didn't waver. Ibrahim was right in the front with our passports, fighting so hard to get us on, and we get to Arish that night and find out his parents are dead."

Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/gaza-update-movement-staff-rafah-crossing

title: Despite the relentless bombing, many of our colleagues continue to work to provide lifesaving care.
description:
Despite the relentless bombing of Gaza, many of our colleagues continue to work to provide lifesaving care. Staff have moved daily between the MSF premises and Al Shifa hospital, where they work 7 days a week.

This video was taken on Thursday, the day before intense bombardment caused a near total communications blackout across Gaza starting on October 27, cutting off internet and cellular phone connections. The disruption to communications limits the ability to coordinate medical assistance. People trapped under the rubble of collapsed buildings, pregnant women who are about to deliver, and older people with limited mobility are not able to seek help when they need it most.

As of Friday night, Al Shifa Hospital was at full capacity with patients seeking medical treatment, and tens of thousands of others seeking safe shelter.

Israeli authorities continue to prevent the entry of fuel into Gaza, which is essential for powering hospitals as well as the desalination plants that produce clean drinking water.

title: Airstrike in Jenin, West Bank: MSF Teams Respond
description:
On October 25th, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in the West Bank received multiple critically injured patients at Jenin hospital after an airstrike on Jenin refugee camp. MSF anesthetist Dr. Elma Wong describes how we responded to the needs of patients injured in the airstrike.

Violence in the West Bank has been rising since conflict escalated in the Gaza Strip. Since October 7, there have been 96 attacks on health care in the West Bank documented by WHO.

Read more at https://bit.ly/MSFResponseIsraelGazaWar

title: #Gaza: Hospitals need supplies and electricity #news #doctorswithoutborders #msf
description:
Hospitals in Gaza need water, and fuel to power the generators. When a hospital runs out of supplies in the operating room, it brings providing care to a standstill. Hospitals need painkillers and sterilization supplies - equipment for surgeries need to be sterilized to prevent infection.

Cliff Roberson is the Anesthesia Advisor for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and has been in contact when possible with anesthesia colleagues in Gaza.

title: Surgery Without Supplies in Gaza: "You cannot imagine"
description:
In Gaza, hospitals are overwhelmed with patients and running out of medical supplies. They are forced to operate in inadequate conditions to save lives. Here, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) surgeon Dr. Obeid describes a recent amputation on a nine-year-old boy:

"We lack instruments, and we have a lot of cases, so we just amputated under slight sedation. You can see, this other guy, he’s the anesthetist. He is trying to keep the boy’s mouth open to prevent him from strangulation.  So, we amputate him in front of his mother and his sister, because there is no space, and the sister is waiting to be operated on next.  
You cannot imagine this. This girl, this 13-year-old, waiting for an operation, looking at me, as I am amputating the mid-foot of her brother. But actually, this is the situation."

The total siege on Gaza has made running medical and humanitarian operations there extremely complicated. Some MSF staff, like Dr. Obeid, continue to support hospitals where they can. Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

title: Six months into the war in #sudan, access to #healthcare continues to deteriorate. #msf
description:
October marks six months since war broke out between rival armed forces in Khartoum, Sudan. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been on ground providing medical care, donating supplies, and working in neighboring countries where refugees have fled.

MSF Program Manager Abubakr Bashir Bakri shares an update surrounding the ongoing health crisis.

title: Chad: MSF provides water for Sudanese refugees
description:
Since fighting erupted in Sudan in April 2023, 430,000 people fled their homes to seek refuge in neighboring Chad. Around 130,000 of them have settled in Adré camp, in eastern Chad, where they are now stranded without access to many essentials, including safe drinking water. As of September 2023, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) was distributing an average of 500,000 liters of water in the camp each day, but access to safe water is still far below the recommended standard by of twenty liters per person per day and must be urgently increased.

A lack of safe water can fuel the spread of waterborne diseases such as cholera. MSF is calling on international aid organizations and donors to help provide drinking water in the camp. 
Read more at https://bit.ly/3QmHPoK

title: Health System “about to fail” in Gaza
description:
With the siege of Gaza cutting off access to essential resources like medication, medical equipment, electricity, and fuel, it will soon become largely impossible to provide medical care. The needs are enormous and growing.
 
“Now we have more than 3,000 wounded patients,” said Dr. Nedal Abed, an orthopedic surgeon with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), at Al Shifa hospital, which has a 700-bed capacity. “We have very limited medical equipment. Of course, no electricity is available. It is unknown how much gasoline is left [to run the generators]. It’s a matter of time.”
 
The Israeli military has ordered an evacuation of the northern Gaza Strip, but patients being treated in hospitals have nowhere to go. This evacuation order is a death sentence for the gravely sick and injured.
 
Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/unconditional-humanity-needs-be-restored-gaza

title: #MSF Archive: Featuring our staff in Mosul, Iraq, from 2021 #humanitarianorganization
description:
In over 70 countries, Doctors Without Borders/MSF provides independent, impartial medical humanitarian assistance to people in critical need — those affected by conflict, disease outbreaks, natural and human-made disasters, or exclusion from health care. 
 
Our teams of doctors, nurses, logisticians, mental health professionals, and other frontline workers are often among the first on the scene to provide direct care in places that are hard to reach. We speak out on behalf of our patients.

title: "Basic humanity needs to be restored in Gaza”
description:
Dr. Christos Christou, International President of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), spoke out today about the situation in Gaza. "This is unimaginable," he said. "This is inhumane. Basic humanity needs to be restored in Gaza."
See how MSF is responding: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/our-response-israel-gaza-war

Transcript:

Right now, in Gaza, the situation is catastrophic.

The hospitals and clinics that have not been evacuated are overwhelmed. They are barely functioning. There is no electricity, no medical supplies. 

Patients risk their lives either by moving, or by staying behind; in both cases perhaps to die without treatment.   

People are trapped, unable to escape. They have absolutely nowhere safe to go.

They’re deprived of essential needs – water, food, protected shelter, medicines.
 
This is unimaginable. This is inhumane. Basic humanity needs to be restored in Gaza.

The indiscriminate bombing must stop.

People in Gaza need protected spaces, and ways to reach them safely and unimpeded.

They also need clean water, reliable electricity, access to food and healthcare.

For us, and all medical staff in Gaza to work, we need basic guarantees of safety. 

As a medical and humanitarian organization, we want to do so much more. Today this is just impossible.

description: Today, Dr. Mohammed Abu Mughaiseeb, MSF's Deputy Medical Coordinator in Gaza described what he and others in the area are dealing with. “It is very dangerous. They are bombing all day. There are no humanitarian corridors.”

title: Israeli Authorities Must Show Humanity in Gaza
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is witnessing first-hand the extreme suffering in Gaza as the ninth day of bombing continues. Hospitals are overwhelmed, many sick people cannot even reach a medical facility, and facilities have run out of pain medication. Many people in the North, including our colleagues, cannot flee to safety. The water shortage in Gaza has also reached a critical point. We are calling on Israeli authorities to show some humanity and organize safe areas where people will not be bombed, an evacuation route for people to move safely, and restoration of essential services like access to water. Read more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/latest/evacuation-orders-expire-northern-gaza-msf-calls-protection-civilians

title: MSF: Israeli order to evacuate northern Gaza ‘outrageous’ #gaza #israel #news
description:
Safe spaces and safe passage urgently needed for civilians trapped in Gaza.

Ordering such large numbers of people to move in such a short period of time is impossible and will only worsen this humanitarian crisis. As for the many civilians who will not be able to leave the northern Gaza Strip, MSF is extremely concerned about their fate once the Israeli deadline expires. 

MSF repeats its call for an immediate end to the indiscriminate bloodshed and for the urgent establishment of safe spaces and safe passage for civilians trapped in Gaza.

title: Does Having an Abortion Affect Your Mental Health?
description:
It’s important to gain a deeper understanding of emotional well-being during an abortion process and find support through evidence-based information. We are providing reliable information to better understand the impact abortion can have on mental health. 

Learn more at https://bit.ly/SACisHealthCare

Transcript:
You may have heard that having an abortion negatively impacts mental health and can lead to issues like depression. 

This is not true.

In fact, a landmark study published in 2020 found that the emotion most commonly reported after a safe abortion is relief.

However, research has shown that a person's mental health can be significantly impacted if they are denied an abortion.

Around 95% of women who were denied an abortion reported increased feelings of anxiety, lower self-esteem, and lower life satisfaction in the days after being denied an abortion.

Scientific evidence clearly shows that safe abortion does not cause more mental health issues than being denied a safe abortion. 

Of course, everyone comes to an abortion with different life experiences. 

A good indicator of a person's mental health after a desired abortion is their mental health before. 

What can negatively impact the mental health of someone who has had an abortion is encountering stigma and judgment. 

Disclaimer: Everyone is different, and if you have specific questions related to your health, or are considering a course of treatment, you should obtain advice, diagnosis, and treatment directly from a qualified healthcare provider. This video is intended solely for education and information and is not intended as a substitute for qualified medical services and advice. Never disregard professional medical advice or delay seeking it because of something you have read or seen in this video or on the internet generally. While we strive to provide reasonably accurate information based on available research, you should not rely solely on these materials.  MSF is providing these materials “as is” and without any warranty, express or implied, including the accuracy, completeness, and/or usefulness. 


It’s important to have accurate information when we talk about abortion.

Go to howtouseabortionpill.org to read more.

title: South Sudan: Growing Humanitarian Needs in Renk
description:
The conflict in Sudan has displaced millions, including South Sudanese people who are now fleeing back to their home country. But upon their return many are met with a new humanitarian emergency in overcrowded camps without access to medical care and other basic services. 
 
In Eastern Nile state, near the border with Sudan, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is supporting a measles isolation ward, an inpatient therapeutic feeding center, and a pediatric ward at a camp for displaced people in Renk. But far more support is needed. We are urgently calling for a scaled up humanitarian response in the region.
 
Learn more at https://bit.ly/ResponseInSouthSudan

This is the audio sent to us.

title: #Afghanistan: MSF is responding to Herat #earthquake #news
description:
According to data from the Ministry of Public Health and Herat Regional Hospital, there have been 2,445 reported deaths and 2,440 injuries in Herat Province so far after the 6.3 magnitude earthquake hit western Afghanistan on Saturday. 

Today an emergency team left to assess some of the most-affected areas outside of Herat and to provide medical first-aid. 

As of Monday, over 540 patients have been treated at Herat Regional Hospital where MSF teams are supporting, and other patients have been treated in private hospitals. 

This morning there were still 340 patients in the regional hospital, mostly classified as mild to moderate cases. Most of the patients are women and children. Many are in the tents set up by MSF because even though they could be discharged they don’t have homes to return to. 

Teams in different parts of Afghanistan sent additional supplies yesterday, and the Herat team donated mass casualty medical supplies to the regional hospital, enough to treat 400 people. #globalnews #earthquake #heratearthquake #afghanistan #emergency #health

title: Sudan: MSF Launches Measles Vaccination Campaign in Camps for Displaced People
description:
The conflict in Sudan has displaced millions of people. Many of them are taking refuge in camps in White Nile State. As more people arrive to the already overcrowded camps and surrounding areas, people who fled the fighting are struggling to access essential services like medical care.
 
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are helping provide primary health care in three camps in White Nile State. When an outbreak of suspected measles cases occurred in Alagaya camp, MSF launched a vaccination campaign for children under five years old, many of whom had not received any previous vaccinations. These vaccinations will help to curb outbreaks, but the medical and humanitarian needs in the camps are greater than what MSF can provide alone.

title: How We See the Climate Emergency Impacting Human Health
description:
As a medical humanitarian organization, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) sees the impacts of climate change on health every day. Extreme weather events wreak havoc on countries and communities, destroying homes and the environment and causing injury and trauma. Beyond that, these disasters can result in vector-borne, food-borne, or waterborne diseases that affect humans. 

The burning of fossil fuels causes air pollution—heat waves can worsen it, creating respiratory issues and heart diseases. And it makes those already affected by these issues more vulnerable. MSF is working to address how we can prepare for and help mitigate the health impacts on the communities we serve. We are also working to lower our own carbon footprint. Read more at X

title: TB Survivors Speak Out For Better Care
description:
On Tuesday, September 19 at 12:00 PM ET join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) for a virtual conversation with Phumeza Tisile, a tuberculosis survivor and advocacy officer for TB Proof, and Stephen Anguva Shikoli, national coordinator of the Network of TB Champions. In this live discussion, you’ll learn about their experiences surviving TB, which is still the world’s deadliest infectious disease despite the fact that it is curable. 

Phumeza lost her hearing as a side effect of the older regimen of drugs often used to treat multidrug-resistant TB. She has worked in partnership with MSF for years to take on Johnson & Johnson and other pharmaceutical corporations blocking people's access to newer and safer treatments, and was recently profiled as one of the TIME100 Next leaders in global health. Phumeza and Stephen are both extraordinary leaders in advocating for access to lifesaving TB treatments and diagnostic tests for everyone, no matter who they are or where they live.   

We're hosting this conversation with Phumeza and Stephen in the run-up to the United Nations High-Level Meeting on TB on September 22. MSF and other organizations are demanding that US corporations Johnson & Johnson (J&J) and Cepheid pledge to take action ahead of this landmark meeting to expand access to the lifesaving TB drug bedaquiline and GeneXpert tests, respectively. 

MSF is one of the largest nongovernmental providers of TB treatment worldwide, and we also advocate for better care for people living with TB. Shailly Gupta, communications advisor for MSF’s Access Campaign, will moderate the discussion, and Dr. Stijn Deborggraeve, diagnostics advisor for infectious diseases for the MSF Access Campaign, will be available to answer your questions.

title: What Do I Need to Have a Safe Abortion with Pills?
description:
Do you want to know what it takes to have a safe and effective abortion up to 13 weeks?  Accurate information, quality medications, and good preparation. 

Transcript:

Having an abortion with pills is a safe and effective way to end an early pregnancy. 

It’s important to have: 

Accurate information,

quality medications,

and good preparation.

First, accurate information. 

An abortion with pills is common, safe, and effective. 

Depending on where you live, healthcare workers may be able to help you with abortion information and resources. 

Depending on where you live, healthcare workers may be able to help you with abortion information and resources. Our video series also provides accurate information about safe abortion with pills up to 13 weeks. 

And the website HowToUseAbortionPill.org addresses many of the questions you might have.  

Second, quality medications. 

There are two medications that, taken together, are scientifically proven to be a safe and effective way to have an abortion: 

These pills are called mifepristone and misoprostol, both of which can be found under a variety of brand names. 

It’s also possible to have a safe abortion with misoprostol alone. 

When women and pregnant people can’t get access to safe abortion care, they may try to induce an abortion through unsafe methods. 

This can be extremely dangerous. 

Unsafe abortion is a leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide. 

For most people, an abortion with the correct, quality medications is safe.

It’s important to know you are getting these pills from a reliable source. 

Going to your health provider to get pills is a great option. 

There are also trusted groups that provide information online in different languages, like safe2choose.org and womenonweb.org. 

Third, good preparation. 

If you are going to have an abortion with pills, be prepared. 

Find a place where you can have some privacy and access to a toilet. 

Cramping and bleeding are normal parts of the process and can last for hours. 

You’ll want to have ibuprofen and a heating pad or hot water bottle to ease the pain. 

Sanitary pads are helpful for the bleeding.  

During the abortion process, most people can eat and drink as they normally would. 

Be aware that you might experience nausea, a fever, or some diarrhea. 

This is also normal. 

After using the abortion pills, you should feel better and better each day. 

If you start to feel sicker, then you should seek medical attention.

Have a plan for who to call or what to do, just in case. 

Severe complications are extremely rare. 

An abortion with pills is so safe that most people successfully manage the process at home without any problems.

Learn more at https://bit.ly/48fzZny

Disclaimer: Everyone is different, and if you have specific questions related to your health, or are considering a course of treatment, you should obtain advice, diagnosis, and treatment directly from a qualified healthcare provider. title: What Does it Feel Like to Have an Abortion with Pills?
description:
Are you wondering what it feels like to have an abortion with pills using mifepristone and misoprostol, or misoprostol alone? Here are some things to expect. 

Transcript:

Everyone’s abortion feels different. 

But here are some things to expect when considering an abortion with pills to end an early pregnancy.

There are two medications often used together for a safe abortion – mifepristone and misoprostol. 

There’s decades of research and experience showing how safe and effective these pills are. 

It’s also possible to have a safe abortion with misoprostol alone.

If you are taking mifepristone, you might not feel much at first.

Most people start to experience cramps and bleeding after taking the misoprostol pills. 

Some have light cramping, while for others it’s very intense. 

Most people are somewhere in the middle.

Cramping is a common sign that your uterus is contracting, and the medication is working. 

You can start taking ibuprofen before the cramps begin, even before you take the misoprostol. 

A heating pad or hot water bottle can also help relieve cramps.

The heaviest bleeding will likely start four to six hours after taking the first round of misoprostol, and you might pass some large clots. 

Bleeding usually slows down within 24 hours, but it’s normal to have continued light bleeding for a few weeks.

You might have nausea, diarrhea, fever, or headaches—these can be temporary side effects of the medication.

Afterwards, you should start feeling better and better each day. 

If you start to feel sicker, then you should seek medical attention. 

For more information on abortion with pills, talk to a health provider or go to HowToUseAbortionPill.org.

Learn more at https://bit.ly/48fzZny

title: How to Talk About Abortion
description:
Ever wonder how to talk about abortion? Here are a few tips to help start conversations around this essential health care and how to use language that's free from judgement and misinformation.

Transcript:

Abortion is common. 

People have abortions everywhere, every day. 

Worldwide, more than half of all unintended pregnancies end in abortion. 

It’s essential health care for millions of women, girls, and anyone who can become pregnant. 

So why don’t we talk about it more? 

Abortion is still surrounded by misinformation, myths, and stigma. 

This can lead to an environment of secrecy, where people don’t talk about abortion because they fear judgment and rejection.

It can even push people to have unsafe abortions—a leading cause of maternal deaths.

That’s why it’s important for us to talk about abortion. 

Here's how.

First, start with compassion and understanding of other people’s experiences. 

Don’t be judgmental. 

Believing that everyone has the right to make decisions about their own bodies means no one should have to justify their decision to seek an abortion.

If you are speaking with someone who is against abortion, don’t start a debate. 

Try to ask open-ended questions about people’s attitudes and experiences with abortion. 

For example: “If someone you love had an abortion, how would you want that experience to be for them?” 

Transformation happens slowly, and usually not by losing an argument. 

Sometimes, hearing a story or being asked a thoughtful question can be enough.

Second, choose your words carefully. 

Anti-abortion groups use language that is intentionally negative and shaming. 

Avoid stigmatizing language. 

You can say “anti-abortion” instead of “pro-life”, “fetus” or “embryo” instead of “unborn child.” 

Focus your message on the pregnant person, their health, safety, and rights.

Be inclusive in your language - people of all ages and religions, from every walk of life, choose to have abortions. 

Couples often make the choice together, and men can play an active supporting role. 

Third, use reliable sources and references. 

There is a lot of misinformation out there. 

This can harm and confuse abortion seekers. 

Try to counter this with accurate information from trusted sources, like doctorswithoutborders.org and howtouseabortionpill.org. 

 Be a resource for those in need.

 Safe abortion care is health care. 

So, let's break the silence! 

Learn more at https://bit.ly/48fzZny

title: Does Anybody Care? Central African Republic Battles a Health Care Crisis
description:
Much of the world knows nothing about Central African Republic (CAR). This country receives little media coverage apart from stories focusing on security issues.  Having worked in CAR for 25 years, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have witnessed another crisis—the dire lack of access to health care in many parts of the country. 

It is estimated that less than half of the health facilities in CAR are fully functional, and the country has only 0.6 doctors per 10,000 inhabitants—less than half the average across Africa. CAR has one of the lowest life expectancies in the world, at just 54 years. The country's security and economic issues make it difficult for medical care providers and humanitarian organizations to work, but the utter lack of assistance begs the question—does anybody care?

This minidocumentary takes viewers into different parts of Mbomou prefecture, where MSF supports the regional hospital and health posts, yet so much more needs to be done. Read more at bit.ly/3OSXHxk

title: Extreme Flooding is the New Reality in South Sudan
description: Seasonal forecasts and climate change projections point to difficult times ahead for flood-prone areas in South Sudan. The young nation has seen the worst floods in the region over the past four years, exacerbated by climate change. During the rainy season, usually from June to October, floodwaters have swept away entire villages, destroyed crops, drowned cattle, and severely damaged infrastructure, while forcing hundreds of thousands of people from their homes. Floods make travel almost impossible, and the only way to get around is by boat. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) recently donated canoes to 11 villages in Upper Nile state to help transport sick people and expectant mothers when floods cut off access to care.

title: Clean Water is Crucial
How a Pregnant Woman in a Remote Indigenous Community Delivered Safely
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in  Delta Amacuro, northeastern Venezuela, help provide access to primary health care to indigenous communities, focusing on prevention, diagnosis, and treatment. 

These remote communities, located along the Orinoco River, face significant challenges in receiving health care. MSF coordinates with the state health authorities and regional health facilities to connect people with care. Teams also conduct water and sanitation services and health promotion. 

MSF works closely with the communities and local leaders to provide health services in a way that does not contradict people's cultural beliefs and customs. We also help build capacity by training local health personnel and promoting community participation in health practices. Read more at https://bit.ly/3XVQoJl

title: Stories of Survival in Haiti's Capital
description:
Around 90 armed groups are fighting in the streets of Port-au-Prince; they currently control more than 80 percent of the city.

Day after day, people just trying to live their lives risk being kidnapped, injured, or killed in street clashes between gangs, civilian self-defense brigades, and the police.

We asked people about their daily lives now.
"I love dancing with my wife, but I don’t go out anymore [...] There is no such thing as a social life anymore. Sometimes we don’t even go to church." - *Pierre (name changed)

"I was dropping my daughter off at school. When we arrived, a parent and her daughter were kidnapped right in front of us." - *Esther (name  changed)

Throughout each week, several MSF cars transport a team of doctors, nurses, psychologists, health promoters, midwives, and water specialists to treat patients in areas affected by violence in the city center.

title: These Twins Recovered from Malnutrition in Nigeria, But Are Still at Risk
description:
In northwestern Nigeria, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has scaled up what was already one of our most extensive malnutrition programs in the world. Attacks by armed groups have made it extremely difficult for people in this region to reach their farms or workplaces, affecting food supplies. 

Hadiza Sani brought her twins Husseina and Hassana to an MSF-supported hospital in Zamfara state, where they were treated for malnutrition and eventually recovered. “I am very happy with the kind of care given to them,” she said. “We were told in the hospital to take care of them by providing them with nutritious foods. Honestly, based on my situation, I won’t be able to do that.”

Without adequate nutrition, children can become caught in a downward spiral. The number of patients in MSF's therapeutic feeding centers in the region is expected to keep rising. MSF is urging all aid organizations working in Nigeria to scale up their response to this crisis and is calling on the Nigerian government to act now to prevent a catastrophic loss of life in the months ahead. Read more at http://bit.ly/3prKFhG

title: How this Torture Survivor Found New Meaning for His Trauma
description:
“Before, I felt like I was in hell. But I got out. And that’s what we’re doing right now; it’s that voice that made it out.” In this video, a survivor of torture tells the story of how he used art to find new meaning for his trauma at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Comprehensive Care Centre (CAI) in Mexico City.

At the CAI, MSF has provided comprehensive care to survivors of torture and other forms of cruel, inhuman treatment since 2017. Our patients also report having been exposed to sexual violence, assault, kidnapping, and other kinds of abuse, often at the hands of organized crime. 

The CAI uses a holistic approach to care that includes psychological or psychiatric treatment, social work, physical rehabilitation, and outpatient care. Occupational therapy often includes artmaking, where this patient finds the ability to give new meaning to his life experiences and look toward the future. Read more at X

title: Rescued at Sea: Risking It All for a Better Life
description:
"It's not you who will have to sleep with him,” Amina said to her father, who tried to force her to marry a much older man. She escaped that fate by crossing the desert on foot and was subsequently abused by her employers in Libya. Amina risked everything hoping for a better life when she attempted the most dangerous migration route in the world, from the Libyan coast to Europe. 

Her boat was in distress when she and her 75 fellow migrants were taken aboard the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) search and rescue ship the Geo Barents in September 2022. Despite the grave dangers, thousands of people attempt this journey across the Mediterranean Sea each year, forced from home by violence, persecution, and other crises. 

So far this year, 1,289 people have been reported dead or missing on the Mediterranean Sea route, according to the International Organization for Migration. MSF has called on European states to ensure safe passage for people in need of protection, including by fulfilling their obligations to conduct rescues at sea. Read more at X

title: Movement: Stories from MSF Aid Workers About Lives Uprooted
description:
We invite you to join us for a live storytelling hour with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff on Thursday, June 15 at 1:00pm ET. 

What would you do if, right at this moment, you had to leave home and never look back? What would you take with you? What would you leave behind? 

There are now more than 100 million forcibly displaced people worldwide—more than at any time in modern history. Each and every one of them carries a story. To mark World Refugee Day, join us for a virtual storytelling hour featuring MSF aid workers who have themselves experienced displacement, migration, and life on the move. You’ll hear stories of anxiety, grief, hope, and ultimately, solidarity, as we contemplate the real experiences of people forced from home. 

Stay tuned for more information about our storytellers.

title: Rebuilding Maternity Care in Southern Haiti
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has rebuilt and upgraded a maternal health center in Port-à-Piment, in southwest Haiti, that was destroyed during the 2021 earthquake. 

The high numbers of patients coming for obstetric and neonatology services since its reopening demonstrate the urgent need in a country with the worst maternal health care indicators in the Western hemisphere.

There are many more places in Haiti’s South that need post-earthquake reconstruction of health facilities and services. MSF is calling on organizations that pledged support for these needs to make good on their promises. Read more at X

title: Aisha's Life-changing Facial Surgery in Nigeria
description:
Aisha is six years old and wants to be a teacher. When she was four years old, she got noma–an infection of the face that affects children, 90 percent of whom die within the first few weeks of developing symptoms. This neglected disease impacts people worldwide living in poverty without adequate access to health care. Aisha's cheek started swelling and some of her teeth fell out. She was taken to a hospital near her home in northern Nigeria, but the treatment did not work. Quickly the flesh and bones in her face were destroyed and a hole appeared. 

Her twin brother was protective and supportive, but the children laughed at her, so Aisha stopped going out. One day a local person visited the family and took Aisha and her mother, Hauwa, on the 12-hour drive to Sokoto Noma Hospital, which is supported by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). Finally, Aisha had reconstructive surgery to repair the hole in her face. She also found the hospital to be a place where she felt safe and could find companionship. Now, Aisha is counting the days until she can go to school.
