title: Forced from Home in the West Bank
description:
For decades, the Palestinian residents of Masafer Yatta have lived under constant threat of expulsion by Israeli authorities. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have witnessed first-hand how these conditions are harming people’s physical and mental health. Located in the southern West Bank in the Occupied Palestinian Territories, Masafer Yatta was designated a closed military zone in 1981, rendering its residents “illegal” and thus eligible for eviction under Israeli law. As a result, many Palestinians have been forced from their homes in what may amount to forcible transfer, which is prohibited under international law.   

Today, 1,144 Palestinians remain in Masafer Yatta, including 569 children. In addition to demolition of their homes, schools, and other structures, residents live with limited access to food, water, education, and medical care, and increasing harassment and restrictions imposed by Israeli authorities, including more checkpoint installations, vehicle confiscation, and curfews. In response, MSF is running three clinics in the area, providing basic health care and a range of services including pediatric care, treatment for chronic communicable diseases, reproductive care, mental health care for survivors of violence, and nutritional screening.

title: Margaret's Story: Fleeing Violence in South Sudan
description:
Conflict and climate shocks have compounded hardships faced by displaced people in Twic County, South Sudan. Families living in camps across the region face a lack of food, water, and health care; recurrent outbreaks of disease; and limited capacity from aid organizations to address the situation. Margaret Abuk, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) community health worker, is one of the people who fled south into Twic County. She has been living in a shelter with her three daughters, in Majak Aher camp. “We had to run,” Margaret explained, “because of the conflict, because we were afraid, because people were killing us and our children."

title: Remote Kiribati Faces Health Impacts of Climate Change
description:
A Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) team has been working alongside local health staff in Kiribati to address health needs caused by the climate crisis. Kiribati is one of the most remote nations in the world, located in the central Pacific Ocean. 

“We can see the effect of this climate change,” said Toaki Taburuea of Kiribati Climate Action Network. "Most of our people here, we love our island and we want to stay in our place.” 

In June 2022, the government of Kiribati declared a state of disaster due to drought. The country is also facing air and sea temperature rises, storm surges and high winds, erosion, ocean acidification, flooding, malnutrition, and increased disease outbreaks.   

In many of the places where MSF works, our teams see that the climate crisis is a health crisis. It is already impacting communities in the Pacific and will become more severe over time unless urgent action is taken now.  Read more at X

title: From Haiti ❤️ Happy International Nurses Day! #doctorswithoutborders #haiti #nurse
description:
From Haiti Happy International Nurses Day! 

Here’s what Gessica Fleurmond, an intensive care nurse in Port-Au-Prince told us:

“Nursing is a noble profession, and it is a calling. 

What I wish for this generation of nurses in Haiti is that they be firm, but at the same time gentle; that they have a lot of empathy, love, great ethics, dedication, and also a lot of courage—because it does take courage.   
Our country is almost pushing us to give up but if you only look at the negative side, you’ll get discouraged before you even enter the hospital. We need to focus on the patients, because they need us.”

As a qualified sign language interpreter, she’s able to speak with people who are hearing impaired or have a speech disability. It’s another way she contributes to providing access to care. 
The trauma hospital in Tabarre provides emergency, surgical, burns, and psychological care, and physiotherapy. Gessica and her colleagues help hundreds of trauma patients each year.

title: DRC: Humanitarian Disaster in North Kivu
description:
Over the past year, about one million people have fled fighting linked to the resurgence of the M23 armed group in North Kivu province, in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The humanitarian response so far has been inadequate, leaving people highly vulnerable to health risks like cholera, measles, malnutrition and sexual violence. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have been working in informal displacement sites around Goma since May 2022, providing free medical care, drinking water, and constructing latrines and showers, but this is not enough. In Bulengo, an informal settlement a few miles west of Goma, there is just one latrine for almost 500 people—less than one-tenth of what people need in a humanitarian emergency. In recent months, the health situation has become critical in Bulengo, with suspected cases of measles and cholera multiplying over the past few weeks.

title: Ukraine: Reaching Areas Cut Off from Health Care
description:
As the war in Ukraine escalated in February 2022, many residents of the Kharkiv region—including medical staff—fled to western Ukraine or left the country. The loss of health care workers, coupled with the massive medical needs related to the war, soon pushed the health care system to the brink. In most of the villages and towns where MSF teams worked, health care workers had left, health facilities had been destroyed or looted, and people couldn’t get the medicine they needed for new or chronic conditions. The teams would set-up clinics on the street or in bus stops or town halls—frequently with the help of the residents themselves, like Lyudmila Karatsyuba, 67, a resident of Novy Burluk in the Kharkiv region who hosted an MSF team in her home. The hospitality of the people MSF assists makes emergency humanitarian aid possible and provides the teams and patients with a safe place to work. While providing care in Lyudmila’s home, the teams also worked on fixing the damaged clinic in the village.

title: As Violence Continues in Sudan, MSF Calls for Protection of Civilians
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Sudan continue to provide medical care and support to medical facilities as best as they can, given the unrelenting violence. 

People in need of care and medical staff alike face huge risks in reaching medical facilities. The needs are overwhelming, and very few hospitals are still operational. 

“Large numbers of civilians have not been able to reach hospitals and have lost their lives as a result of this conflict,” said Dr. Bakri AbuBakr, MSF operations manager in Sudan, South Sudan, and Somalia. "Therefore, we clearly call for the protection of civilians. 

"We also unequivocally call for the protection of medical and health facilities. This includes the protection of hospitals, medical staff, and ambulances.”  Read more at https://bit.ly/3HsrqKz

title: A Million Newly Displaced People in DRC Need More Humanitarian Aid
description:
The recent surge of violence in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) urgently requires a greater humanitarian response. Teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in DRC's North Kivu province are overwhelmed by the needs. 

This latest crisis is triggered by the resurgence of an armed group called M23. One million people have fled their homes over the last year, joining 2.5 million other displaced people in North Kivu. People living in displacement camps and in remote communities cut off by the fighting are facing dangerous health risks and lack access to basic necessities like food, water, and shelter. 

“Although some don’t talk, we know they’re hurting inside,” said MSF Medical Advisor Padou Kabamba Nawej. “Because the atrocities are affecting them mentally and physically."

The needs of people displaced by the violence are far greater than the available humanitarian aid.  MSF is urgently calling on the international community and the Congolese authorities to scale up their efforts. Read more at http://bit.ly/3MORWky

title: MSF Supports the Only Functioning Hospital in El Fasher, Sudan
description:
Following the violence that broke out in areas of Sudan on April 15, a large number of wounded people have arrived at the hospital supported by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in El Fasher, North Darfur. 

MSF teams are working round the clock to treat the injured—410 people have arrived at the hospital for treatment, which is now the only operational health facility in the city. 

“There is no water. There is also no electricity,” says MSF project coordinator in El Fasher, Mohammed Gibreel Adam. “Referrals of hot cases and lifesaving [treatment] at night are not possible due to a lack of security and movement.”  Read more at https://bit.ly/3oReEPi

description:

title: Earthquake Survivor in Turkey Deals with Fear and Loss
description:
Two months after the first earthquakes, people are having to grapple with the post-traumatic stress from these events. Aftershocks are still occurring.
Abdurrahman Can, a village leader in Adıyaman, Turkey, talks about the terrible loss of family during the earthquakes and the fear and stress that remain. MSF is supporting local non-profit organizations conducting psychosocial activities in affected areas.

title: CNN: MSF Interview on the Conflict in Sudan
description:
Abdalla Hussein, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Operational Manager for Sudan, South Sudan, Somalia, and Libya, spoke to CNNi’s John Vause on April 19, 2023.  Around half of the hospitals in Sudan's capital Khartoum have been out of operation due to the fighting. Medical supplies and personnel have been unable to reach facilities, and water and electricity are scarce throughout the city. MSF has had to suspend some medical projects for the same reasons, but MSF teams continue to treat wounded people where they can. "Health and humanitarian workers need access [to hospitals]," says Hussein. "Our staff are exhausted from working for the last 72 hours and more, working in the hospital trapped, and we cannot reach them...  There needs to be a letup to the conflict." 
@vausecnn @CNN

title: Violence uproots 1 million people in #DRC; MSF calls for greater aid response #worldnews
description:
The recent surge of violence in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) urgently requires a greater humanitarian response. Teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Goma, the provincial capital of North Kivu, and elsewhere in the province are overwhelmed by the needs. 

This latest crisis is triggered by the resurgence of an armed group called M23. One million people have fled their homes over the last year, joining 2.5 million already displaced people in North Kivu. People living in displacement camps and in remote communities that are cut off by the fighting are facing dangerous health risks and lack access to basic necessities like food, water, and shelter. 

So far, this crisis has not been met with a large-scale humanitarian response. MSF is urgently calling on the international community and the authorities to scale up their efforts to meet people’s needs. Read more at http://bit.ly/3MORWky

title: How Extreme Violence Affects People's Lives in Central African Republic
description:
It’s been 10 years since the start of the third civil war in the Central African Republic (CAR). This video is an introduction to “The Events” at https://car10yearsofviolence.com,
a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) multimedia project featuring 15 first-hand audio stories collected in CAR and striking photographs of the storytellers and their lives by photographer Adrienne Surprenant.

Joseph's son was murdered on Christmas Eve, Tatiana had to flee her home when she was at full term in her pregnancy. Louise underwent an amputation following a gunshot wound. And Louison was traumatized by the death of a man he tried in vain to save. 

MSF has worked in CAR since 1997 and been a witness to the devastation the fighting has wrought. Today, there are more than 3,000 MSF staff, most of them Central Africans, providing pediatric care, trauma surgery, and HIV/AIDS care in different parts of the country. Visit https://car10yearsofviolence.com

title: Emergency Treatment for Kala Azar in Ethiopia
description:
In late 2022, MSF’s teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Southern Nations, Nationalities and People’s Region (SNNPR) of Ethiopia received an alert about an unusually high number of deaths caused by visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala azar. MSF immediately prepared an emergency response, setting-up mobile clinics that actively found and treated 79 patients with kala azar in less than two months. 

“Patients come with a huge swelling of their spleen and liver, a fever, malnutrition, and sometimes even bleeding because their bone marrow is affected. It's among the neglected tropical diseases that can cause a 95 percent fatality [rate] if left untreated. So, you can understand the urgency of finding these cases and putting them on treatment,” said MSF doctor, Hiwot Melak. Read more at http://bit.ly/40FIKCM

title: How to End TB: Teach it at School
description:
Tuberculosis (TB) prevention is a major global health focus. Yet, worldwide, including in South Africa, people face barriers to TB health services, including education on the disease, testing, and diagnostics. 

Thanks to the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) TB education program, Bhekumuzi Nzuza, an educator in rural Eshowe, South Africa, was able to identify a friend's TB symptoms and guide him and his family to proper treatment.

Based on a successful HIV program that MSF first implemented in South African schools a decade ago, MSF developed a TB education curriculum for rural schools in KwaZulu-Natal province. The program empowers educators and learners to become TB advocates, not only in schools, but also their communities where there is a lot of stigma and misinformation.

The program has been rolled out in 22 high schools in the villages of Eshowe and Mbongolwane, reaching thousands of learners to date. Learn more about TB at https://bit.ly/3TF2GUe

title: MSF Live from Greece: A virtual visit with our migration projects
description:
We invite you to join us on a virtual tour of our projects and activities in Samos and Athens, Greece, on Wednesday, March 22, at 12:00 pm ET.   

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provides medical and humanitarian assistance to refugees, asylum seekers, and migrants in Greece. Our teams have been working in Greece since 2016 to treat the physical and mental wounds of people on the move. We see people who come to Europe searching for protection and instead are trapped in prison-like camps and detention centers with insufficient access to health care and other basic services.  

During this virtual project visit, we will take you to see MSF’s mobile clinic outside of the Vathy refugee camp on Samos. You will also visit the Athens Day Care Center, which provides mental health support, care for non-communicable diseases and sexual reproductive health (SRH), and access to social and legal services. Along the way you will hear from Ioanna Pertsinidou, project coordinator; Anna Karalia, SRH midwife; Sarah Massay, health promoter; and Nicholas Papachrysostomou, MSF head of mission in Greece. Nicholas will also join the live conversation to answer your questions and share more details about the medical needs in Greece. 

Join us for this rare glimpse inside MSF projects to learn more about our work and how our teams are adapting operations to respond to the growing challenges facing refugees in Greece.

title: Supporting Sex Workers' Health Without Judgement in Honduras
description:
"I have found this clinic where you can speak openly," says Nadia of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) health clinic in Pedro de Sula, Honduras. At other health facilities, she says, "they give you medical attention, but they also give you their point of view of what you should or should not do with your life, which is different. It’s totally different."

Supportive sexual and reproductive health care is important for everyone, but around the world, many people face damaging obstacles to accessing this care. For many women and girls, including cis and trans women, societal taboos and fears often prevent them from finding timely, appropriate information and services. Unmarried women, adolescents, sex workers, women in the LGBTQIA+ community, and others are often excluded from health care.

MSF is working to reduce the barriers to health care for marginalized and excluded people and people in crisis and to help them participate in their own health and well-being. Contraception, protection from sexually transmitted infections, safe abortion care, and counseling are some of the services that all women should have access to for an active, positive sexual life. Read more at https://bit.ly/3L2arRU

title: Caring for Survivors of Sexual Violence in Nairobi, Kenya
description:
Since 2008, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has provided comprehensive care for survivors of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) in the Eastlands area of Nairobi, Kenya. Along with supporting four government health centers, MSF runs Lavender House, a dedicated clinic offering specialized SGBV medical and mental health services.

 The clinic provides free, comprehensive care, including a 24-hour toll-free emergency hotline, ambulances to pick up or refer patients, and a community mobilization team to raise awareness and link people with vital services. With limited access to local SGBV care, Lavender House treats patients from the entire Eastlands area and parts of greater Nairobi county.

title: Day in the Life: Kira Working in Eastern Ukraine
description:
Follow a day in the life of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) outreach manager, Kira, and his team in eastern Ukraine as they distribute blankets, meet with the local community to help rehabilitate their shelters, and as they look for new locations to host mobile medical clinics.

title: Providing Mental Health Care in Ukraine
description:
In Ivano-Frankivsk, Ukraine, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) psychologist Ihor Ohdanskyi and his team provide mental health care to people displaced by the conflict, war-wounded people, and care providers. These are all people who may be "suffering from different mental health problems and disorders related with stress of the war, and with witnessing violence," he says.

One year after the escalation of war in Ukraine, eight million people have fled as refugees and around five million are displaced inside the country. People who live in areas under attack face incredible hardships, often living without electricity, medicine, food, or clean water. Even in the west of the country, in areas of relative calm like Ivano-Frankivsk, “everyone is affected by the war,” Ohdanskyi says. Read more at https://bit.ly/3StE28n

title: MSF Live from Ukraine
description:
We invite you to join us for a live online briefing with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff in Ukraine on Thursday, February 23, at 12:00 pm ET.

After the escalation of full-scale war in Ukraine one year ago, MSF expanded its medical humanitarian response to help meet the evolving needs of people caught in conflict. War has been simmering in eastern Ukraine since 2014, and many people living on the frontlines in this region have been suffering from physical and psychological wounds since then.

Today we have around 800 MSF staff—the vast majority of whom are from Ukraine—working with local organizations to deliver medical aid and support to the people who need it. It is important to note that Ukrainian health staff and civil society organizations are leading the humanitarian response. MSF's interventions focus on filling the gaps: our teams are treating patients near the frontlines, running mobile clinics, evacuating patients to safer areas, offering mental health care, and providing supplies and training to health facilities. The context remains extremely volatile, and we have had to step back in some regions. MSF is currently unable to access areas controlled by Russian forces, including areas in the east where we have been present since 2014.

Join us for a conversation with our colleagues Christopher Stokes, emergency coordinator for MSF in Kyiv, and Dr. Albina Zharkova, deputy project coordinator for MSF's medical evacuation train in Ukraine. Together they will discuss how MSF teams have adapted our operations over the past year and how we are preparing for the humanitarian challenges ahead. This live briefing will be moderated by MSF-USA Executive Director Avril Benoît.

Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit http://bit.ly/3XJziMS to RSVP.

title: How to Manage Stress, from a Psychologist in Ukraine
description:
“At the end of the day, find one thing which gave you satisfaction,” says Ihor Ohdanskyi, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) psychologist in Ivano-Frankivsk, Ukraine. "Every time you find something like pleasure, you do the work of supporting yourself.”
 
Ohdanskyi and his team work with members of the local community, people displaced by the conflict, war-wounded people, and care providers, all of whom may be "suffering from different mental health problems and disorders related with stress of the war, and with witnessing violence," he says.
 
One year after the escalation of war in Ukraine, eight million people have fled as refugees and around five million are displaced inside the country. People who live in areas under attack face incredible hardships, often living without electricity, medicine, food, or clean water. Even in the west of the country, in areas of relative calm like Ivano-Frankivsk, “everyone is affected by the war,” Ohdanskyi says. Read more at https://bit.ly/3StE28n

title: How MSF is Supporting Hospitals in Syria After the Earthquake
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has supported 38 hospitals and health facilities throughout northwestern Syria since the 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck on February 6. 

MSF teams have responded to a lack of adequate supplies by donating emergency kits, trauma kits, blankets, medicines, medical supplies, laboratory equipment, and medical consumables.

"We set up an emergency system so our ambulances could be at the disposal of any nearby hospital to bring the injured,” said Mohammad Darwish, MSF's deputy coordinator in Idlib governorate. "We also built a crew with previous  experience with earthquakes and other crises, along with doctors who headed to the neighboring hospitals to help treat the injured there." 

From February 6 to 12, MSF-supported facilities treated more than 7,600 people injured in the quake and recorded around 1,000 deaths. Read more at https://bit.ly/410CnLq

title: 3 Things to Know About the Syria Turkey Earthquake
description:
The earthquake in Syria and Turkey (renamed Türkiye) has killed over 36,000 and left tens of thousands of people injured and in need of medical care. Teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) were already working in northwest Syria, so we were able to start treating patients in the first hours of the disaster.  
 
Over the past week, we’ve been supporting medical facilities to care for the injured, providing ambulances to transport them, and getting urgent relief items to people in need. We also received the tragic news of the death of two of our colleagues who were found under the rubble. Some have lost their loved ones and their homes. We are in close touch with our colleagues inside northwestern Syria, providing them with psychological support and other services.   

Avril Benoît, the executive director of MSF-USA, discusses three things to know about the crisis: 
 
1. Hundreds of thousands of people are homeless in freezing temperatures. Houses and apartment buildings have been destroyed on a massive scale. We also must not forget about the impact of this disaster on peoples’ mental health. We are providing psychological first aid to our staff and to patients in the health facilities we support and across our mobile clinics in northwestern Syria. 

2. The earthquake compounded an existing crisis in northwestern Syria. War, a dire economic situation, the COVID-19 pandemic, and an outbreak of cholera had already plunged the region into a humanitarian crisis and pushed medical facilities to the brink. Nearly three-quarters of the entire population had already been forced from their homes by over a decade of war, with many people living in displacement camps in terrible conditions. 

3. This is a massive disaster that requires a massive international aid effort. More support must reach northwestern Syria as soon as possible. We must ensure that more access points into northwestern Syria are made available for international aid to reach the people who need it.

title: Saving New Lives in Taiz, Yemen
description:
In Taiz city, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) supports Al Jamhouri hospital, where pregnant people come from inside the city and the surrounding rural areas to receive care.

Throughout this region, there is a lack of prenatal and postnatal care, as well as high-risk delivery services and equipment. Patients in rural areas undergo a long and difficult journey through mountainous areas and destroyed roads to reach Al Jamhouri hospital, making it especially challenging to arrive in time for a safe delivery.

MSF began supporting the hospital in 2021, running the maternal and neonatal services and providing additional support to the ministry of health staff. Over one year, the rate of newborn deaths dropped from roughly 24 percent to 10 percent. 

MSF teams also supported more than 17,000 prenatal consultations and 3,000 postnatal consultations during the same period. Some of the patients were receiving their first prenatal consultations in the eighth or ninth month of pregnancy. Read more at https://bit.ly/3XHRB5n

title: Waking Up to an Earthquake in Syria: 'It felt like doomsday'
description:
Samar is a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) health educator in northwestern Syria. She and her family woke up on February 6 to feel the terrifying effects of the 7.8-magnitude earthquake. They managed to survive, but what they found outside was devastating.

"We could no longer feel anything other than fear,” she says, "terror, shivering in the cold under the rain. My children were shaking in front of me.” 

More than 22,000 people have been killed and more than 78,000 people have been injured across Syria and Turkey, according to latest estimates. The death toll is expected to rise in both Turkey and Syria, as many people are still trapped under rubble. Read about how MSF is responding https://bit.ly/3RPADR2

description:
Hasan, a logistician in northwestern Syria with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), awoke to a 7.8-magnitude earthquake on February 6. He is now participating in MSF's response to this disaster. As of February 8, MSF teams have seen more than 3,465 wounded patients in Syria and distributed essential items like blankets and hygiene kits to 2,500 families in Jinderis and Aleppo. title: Inside MSF’s Emergency Response to the Turkey-Syria Earthquake
description:
Ricardo Martínez, logistics coordinator of the emergency unit at Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), leads one of the first teams that the organization is sending from Spain to Turkey. The team will assess the situation and the humanitarian needs in some of the areas most affected by the earthquake. “The sooner we get in touch with the local authorities, the sooner we will understand what their most acute needs are,” said Martínez. “We will coordinate with them, what is our added value in the intervention.”

Other MSF teams were already present in northern Syria, treating the injured and carrying out distributions of emergency medical kits and relief items since the first hours after the earthquake. Read more at http://bit.ly/3I8duWX

title: MSF Responds Immediately After Earthquake Hits Syria and Turkey
description:
When the 7.8-magnitude earthquake hit southern Turkey (officially renamed Türkiye) and northwestern Syria on February 6, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), already present in Syria, was able to respond right away. In the first hours, MSF teams treated 200 injured people in Idlib province. Today, “MSF is supporting at least eight hospitals,” says Michel Lacharité, head of MSF’s emergency desk, “and we have a burn unit in Atme City and some medical staff from this hospital were detached to other hospitals which perform trauma surgery.” We are scaling up our response to meet the needs of people displaced by the earthquake in Syria, along with the International Blue Crescent. title: MSF is Responding to the Earthquakes in Turkey and Syria
description:
Following the powerful earthquakes that hit southern Turkey and northwestern Syria on February 6, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams working in northwestern Syria have mobilized with local partners to respond to the increasing needs in the area. The United Nations has confirmed that more than 9,000 people were wounded and 2,300 were killed, according to the first estimates from both countries.

Sadly, an MSF staff member was found dead under the rubble of his house in Idlib, and others lost members of their family.

MSF provided immediate support to 23 health facilities across Idlib and Aleppo governorates by donating emergency medical kits and supporting them with medical staff to reinforce their teams. MSF teams have donated blankets and essential life kits to displaced people in the region. The earthquakes destroyed hundreds of houses, leaving thousands homeless. People are staying outside despite the snow due to fear of aftershocks that have continued throughout the day.

title: The flooding continues to be a disaster in #southsudan #thingstoknow #news
description: As many countries in eastern Africa suffer the worst drought in four decades, South Sudan sits uneasily on the opposite end of the spectrum—saturated by years of intense flooding that has affected more than one million people in the country. The floods have displaced hundreds of thousands of people, killed millions of animals, and destroyed thousands of acres of crops, compounding an escalating food security crisis in the country. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is running outreach services and mobile clinics to ensure health care is available for the most vulnerable people in remote areas. Read more at http://bit.ly/3HSsJTy

title: Recovering from Cervical Cancer in Malawi
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs a comprehensive cervical cancer program in the southern African country of Malawi, which has the second-highest mortality rate from this cancer in the world. In collaboration with the Blantyre district health authorities, MSF teams have been working to improve access to screening, early diagnosis, and treatment for cervical cancer since 2018.  
 
A largely preventable disease, higher-income countries have made strong progress against cervical cancer by centering human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccinations and the early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions. The vast majority of deaths due to the disease affect women in low- and middle-income countries that lack those resources.  
 
“Cervical cancer screening shouldn’t be a one-off thing,” says Tifera Botomani Mapasa, MSF health promotion supervisor in Blantyre. “Women should embrace cervical cancer screening just like people have embraced HIV testing.” 
 
In 2021, MSF carried out more than 6,000 cervical cancer consultations at Queen Elisabeth Central Hospital in Blantyre district. Some 460 patients received surgery and 401 went through chemotherapy. 

Read more at http://bit.ly/40rldq4

title: Restoring Dignity: A journey with noma survivors
description:
Noma is an infection of the face that affects children, 90 percent of whom die within the first few weeks of developing symptoms. This neglected disease impacts people worldwide living in poverty without adequate access to health care.

‘Restoring Dignity’ follows the journey of noma survivors from different regions of Nigeria over the course of a year. The survivors are children, teenagers, and adults who have lived for decades with the physical and psychological consequences of this disease. 

Since 2014, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been supporting the Nigerian ministry of health, in the Noma Children's Hospital in Sokoto, the only hospital in the world entirely dedicated to noma patients. The program focuses on community outreach, active case finding in the region, health promotion, mental health support, and surgery. Four times a year, MSF sends experienced plastic and maxillofacial surgeons, nurses, and anesthesiologist to perform surgeries for noma survivors. 

This is a short version of the documentary 'Restoring Dignity,’ by filmmakers Claire Jeantet and Fabrice Catérini, produced by Inediz in collaboration with MSF. 

Find out more at https://noma.msf.org/

title: MSF Provides Life-changing Facial Surgeries for Noma Survivors
description:
Noma is an infection of the face that affects children, 90 percent of whom die within the first few weeks of developing symptoms. This neglected disease impacts people worldwide living in poverty without adequate access to health care.

Since 2014, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been supporting the Nigerian ministry of health, in the Noma Children's Hospital in Sokoto, the only hospital in the world entirely dedicated to noma patients. “We're giving people their self-esteem back,” said Mark Sherlock, an MSF health advisor, "so they can go on and live normal lives in their communities. And this is having a huge impact.”

When this video was made in 2021, COVID-19 travel restrictions limited MSF’s ability to provide services to noma survivors. Through a collaboration with the ministry of health, MSF supported a surgical team in Sokoto to carry out 20 surgeries.

Many more people need access to these life-changing services, so MSF is calling for three action points to be carried out by the international community:
- Put noma on the World Health Organization's list of neglected tropical diseases to shine a light on this disease and stimulate more research
- Include noma as an indicator for the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)—noma is linked to poverty and children’s access to health care and vaccinations, all components that the SDGs address
- And to integrate noma into routine health services so that children in endemic countries are screened for the early signs and symptoms of the disease, and more lives can be saved.

Watch the short version of MSF’s documentary on noma at https://youtu.be/2lBSROAH3K4
Learn more at https://noma.msf.org/

title: What is Plumpy'Nut? A Tool to Fight Malnutrition
description:
Plumpy’Nut is the brand name for a type of ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF) that Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams use in our nutrition programs around the world. Our staff will typically give a severely malnourished child packets of RUTF every day for several weeks to help them get healthy again. Plumpy’Nut ingredients are fortified peanut butter, milk, sugar, vitamins, and minerals. 
MSF is currently responding to nutrition emergencies in several countries around the world, including Nigeria, Somalia, Yemen, and Democratic Republic of Congo. Read more at https://bit.ly/2XiDvIJ

TRANSCRIPT
What is Plumpy’Nut?

[0:03] 
Tastes like chocolate. 

To me, it tastes like peanuts. 

Hmm, I think it tastes like milk. Yeah, it’s very delicious. 

[0:13] 
Here in northwestern Nigeria, we’re responding to a massive nutritional emergency brought on by violence and displacement, rising food prices, and climate change. We use this food to help severely malnourished children quickly gain weight and get healthy again. 

[0:29] 
It is highly effective because it’s rich in protein and nutrients and it packs a lot of calories. A  child can get a lot of energy from just small amounts. This is important because their stomachs have shrunk.  

[0:42] 
The packets can be stored at room temperature and no preparation is needed—it’s ready to eat. And importantly, children love the taste, so they want to eat it. 

[0:53] 
Nutrition emergencies like the one here in Nigeria are devastating for families and communities. And they are happening around the world right now, not only here in Nigeria. A tool like this can help us keep babies healthy and alive. 

END TRANSCRIPT

title: Ukraine: MSF Evacuates Psychiatric Patients from Kherson
description:
In November 2022, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) evacuated 400 psychiatric patients from a hospital in Kherson, in eastern Ukraine. The city had been recently retaken by Ukrainian forces, but heavy artillery fire was still being exchanged, and de-mining teams were in the process of detonating unexploded ordnance. Without power, and in close proximity to the fighting, the hospital was not a safe place. MSF teams worked with local partners to organize a plan to bring patients west from Kherson to other medical facilities in Mikolaiv and Odesa. 

The humanitarian needs in areas retaken by the Ukrainian military are high, especially for people with chronic diseases, the elderly, and those with conditions that affect their mobility. While reaching the most vulnerable in these areas is essential, it entails great risk for humanitarian workers. Read more at https://bit.ly/3iDS4ah

title: Pakistan: Major Health Concerns Remain Months After the Flooding
description:
It has been more than three months since devastating floods caused vast damage across Pakistan and displaced millions, but only in recent weeks have waters started to recede allowing people to return home. Those returning to their villages are finding destroyed houses and land, still surrounded by stagnant water. Meanwhile, those remaining in camps and informal shelters are faced with the threat of winter. The need for clean drinking water, food and health care remains at an all-time high.

Teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) are currently responding in three provinces, Balochistan, Sindh, and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. We have 10 mobile medical teams working in Balochistan and Sindh, where we are seeing high numbers of people with malaria, diarrhea, respiratory tract infections, and alarming numbers of people with malnutrition. In all three provinces we are also supporting water and sanitation services and the distribution of relief packages. Read more at https://bit.ly/3YnZvSV

title: Mozambique: Health Care in a Warming World
description:
With more than 1,600 miles of coastline, Mozambique is especially vulnerable to the effects of climate change. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has started a new planetary health project in Nampula province, an area prone to extreme weather events that are causing climate-sensitive diseases that used to appear seasonally to become prevalent year-round.
 
“Today, malaria is basically present throughout the year, which is very different from what happened in the past when malaria was seen mostly in the rainy season,” said MSF health promotion supervisor Adamo Armando Palame. Changing weather patterns over the last decade have resulted in shorter but heavier rainy seasons, resulting in the creation of lots of small lakes in which mosquitoes breed throughout the year. The heavy rains also wash away crops and impact agricultural yields, affecting food production and people’s income. Read more at https://bit.ly/3FBXFq7

title: Bringing Aid to Recently Occupied Villages in Ukraine
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing primary medical care in 30 villages that have recently been reclaimed by the Ukrainian military. People who remained in Kherson, Mykolaiv, and other regions that were taken by the Russian army have struggled without medical care and other essential services for months. MSF teams are bringing mobile medical trucks and containers to areas where medical facilities, pharmacies, homes, and infrastructure have been decimated. In addition to basic medical care and sexual and reproductive health services, MSF staff are also providing mental health care to survivors. Read more at https://bit.ly/3YfL0Ar

title: How MSF Treats Malnourished Children in Niger
description:
The West African country of Niger is currently experiencing a massive food security crisis and Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is responding by treating high numbers of malnourished children in different locations. In this video, MSF Hospital Director Bengaly Aboubacar and other Nigerien staff at MSF's Madarounfa project walk us through the process of caring for severely malnourished patients. 

When they first arrive at the MSF hospital in Madarounfa, patients go directly into triage where medical staff determine what care they need. From triage, severely malnourished children will be admitted to emergency care. These children often have other severe medical conditions and are sent to the intensive care unit where they might be treated for severe pneumonia, malaria, or anemia. After they’ve been stabilized, patients are ready to be treated for malnutrition and are moved into the ward where they are fed a nutritional therapeutic milk formula. Once they are out of harm’s way, patients move into the transition ward where treatment continues and the child's caregiver receives health education. At this point, some children are introduced to ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF); one brand MSF uses is Plumpy ’Nut, a blend of fortified peanut butter, milk, and sugar that contains essential vitamins and minerals.

Once the child is healthy, they are sent home and continue to receive regular care at the health center closest to where they live. They are usually given supplies of RUTF to cover them until their next appointment. Read more at https://bit.ly/2XiDvIJ

title: Why Are There So Many Cholera Outbreaks in 2022?
description:
In 2022, at least 30 countries have seen outbreaks of cholera or similar diseases and Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is now running cholera interventions in more than ten countries. The current number of outbreaks is unusual and worrying. 

Cholera is a deadly disease that spreads rapidly, even though it should be easy to prevent and treat. The risk factors for cholera outbreaks are always linked to access to safe drinking water and proper wastewater disposal. Lack of clean water can be the result of various causes: climate-related disasters like severe floods or droughts, armed conflict, political instability, and the displacement of people fleeing crises. 

Today MSF is running cholera response programs in Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Cameroon, Nigeria, Haiti, Lebanon, Syria, and Malawi. Our teams are involved in cholera prevention through health promotion, vaccination, and water and sanitation work. We also set up cholera units in hospitals and clinics, or open standalone cholera treatment centers in large outbreaks so we can treat hundreds of patients simultaneously.

title: How MSF Helps Migrants in Honduras on the Dangerous Route North
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) brings mobile medical clinics to the main crossing points between Nicaragua and Honduras in order to reach migrants on their way north. People often stop in the town of Trojes to apply for a temporary permit to legally cross through Honduras, and while they are waiting, MSF offers medical and mental health services, as well as social support. Health promoters provide information on where people can find safe lodging and other services in Central America and Mexico. Read more at https://bit.ly/3VYnkys

title: Treating HIV/AIDS in DRC: After 20 Years, MSF Sees Progress and Problems
description:
Two decades ago, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) was the first to provide free antiretroviral (ARV) treatment to people living with HIV in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The high price and scarcity of ARVs in 2002 were the equivalent of a death sentence for so many people at the time, the program was quickly overwhelmed. 

Since then, MSF has been a key player in the fight against HIV/AIDS in DRC, and much progress has been made. But an ongoing lack of funding, training for care providers, and ARVs has caused thousands of preventable deaths due to HIV/AIDS every year. “To realize today that we still have a long way to go,” says Dr. Maria Mashako, who has worked at MSF’s clinic in the capital Kinshasa for 20 years. “It’s very frustrating to see that patients still arrive in (severely ill) condition.” 

More than 500,000 people are living with HIV in DRC today, and one in five people still do not have access to treatment, according to the United Nations Program on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS). Only one-third of the children who need treatment are receiving it. Last year, HIV/AIDS caused nearly 14,000 deaths, and close to 20,000 people were newly infected. In 2015, United Nations (UN) member states committed to ending AIDS by 2030 as part of the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals. In DRC, MSF sees that unless donor countries make a much stronger effort to meet the needs, HIV/AIDS will not be a disease of the past any time soon. Read more at XXX

title: Liberia: MSF is Helping Children with Epilepsy Stay in School
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing care for people living with epilepsy in Liberia, in collaboration with the ministry of health, since 2017. More than 1,200 patients are enrolled in the program; a quarter of them are children like Mary who stopped going to school after she was bullied for having epilepsy.

Epilepsy is a common brain disorder that causes recurrent seizures. Although it has no cure, treatment can bring seizures under control in most people. In Liberia’s capital Monrovia, MSF teams use a holistic approach to caring for children with epilepsy with a focus on psychological and emotional well-being. A primary aim is to support their staying in or returning to school.

“Students will start bullying them and they will leave school,” says S. Wonka Reeder, Sr., a psychosocial worker with MSF in Monrovia. “If you don’t work on those things, those psychosocial problems, and they are taking medication, it doesn’t work.”

Today, Mary is back in school and thinking of becoming a doctor.

In five health centers across the county, MSF teams provide clinical treatment, mental health care, and education to people living with epilepsy. They also provide awareness-raising and other support in patients’ communities to help reduce the barriers to their being accepted in society.

Read more at https://bit.ly/3Xqa7QK

title: World Diabetes Day: How MSF Is Getting Insulin to People Who Need It
description:
Around the world, only half of the people living with type one diabetes have access to insulin. In the places where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is present, our teams work to make diabetes care accessible for everyone who needs it. In North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo, MSF doctor Grazia Caleo found that many children with diabetes could not get the care they needed. 

“They were not even going to visit the hospital because they couldn’t afford a boat, the transport to reach the hospital, or the treatment, access to insulin,” she said. "We have a duty, a responsibility to make sure that those patients are not left behind." MSF is calling for companies to make insulin pens and vials cheaper in low- and middle-income countries, and for countries to make public their prices for “diabetes bundles”—insulin, injection devices for insulin, and glucose monitoring devices—to help other governments and care providers with their price negotiations. #worlddiabetesday

title: Honduras: Responding to Dengue Fever, a Climate-Sensitive Disease
description:
In recent weeks, Honduras has seen a spike in dengue fever cases. Although dengue epidemics are common in the country, this increase is due to a lack of vector control during the COVID-19 pandemic. The changing climate also impacts the transmission of dengue. “It’s climate-sensitive because the mosquito that spreads it breeds in pools of water, which are more common after rainfall, and the mosquito breeding speeds up when it’s hotter and more humid,” said Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) planetary health advisor Lachlan McIver. 
 
Since July, MSF teams have been working to reduce and control dengue in Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras. In some of the most affected neighborhoods, people are forced to store water due to rationing in the area, which increases the number of places where mosquitos can breed. MSF teams visit people in their homes to share information on how they can prevent mosquitos from breeding and fumigate their homes to reduce the presence of adult mosquitoes. Read more at https://bit.ly/3tjgAPi

title: Climate Change Worsens Crises in Cameroon
description:
For several years, simultaneous humanitarian crises have affected the health and livelihood of people in Cameroon. Outbreaks of violence have limited access to health care and forced approximately 2.5 million people to flee their homes.     

Cameroon is in the Sahel region of Africa, an area particularly affected by climate disruptions that have further exacerbated existing issues such as food insecurity, malnutrition, and outbreaks of diseases like cholera and malaria. “In the past two or three years, the climate has changed considerably,” said farmer and Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mechanic, Abakar Mairou. “When the rain comes late, it means the harvest will be poor and we might miss the season.”

title: Syria: A Rare Glimpse into Al-Hol Camp
description:
Around 53,000 people—the majority of them women and children—live in Al-Hol camp in northeast Syria. Once a humanitarian camp for people displaced by conflicts in Syria and Iraq, Al-Hol has become more like a detention center for people with perceived affiliations with the Islamic State. People of more than 60 nationalities are held here, their home countries having failed to protect or find long-term solutions for them.

 "I see it as more of an outdoor prison,” said Ayla, a medical doctor who worked with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Al-Hol camp more than a year ago. She used her visual art skills to help process some of the disturbing things she was seeing—violence, intimidation, and people living in miserable conditions behind barbed wire fences. Outsiders are rarely allowed access to the camp and video and photos are not permitted, so Ayla's drawings offer a rare inside look. “Being able to produce this illustration felt a bit like letting go of certain things,” she said. Read more at https://bit.ly/3zQ2AjS

title: Moving Forward: Bearing Witness with Communities Caught in Crisis
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) invites you to a special online conversation about our work with people living in emergency conditions–from the war in Ukraine to the devastating floods in Pakistan. For more than 50 years, our teams have been providing direct medical aid while also bearing witness and speaking out about the problems driving emergency needs. Today, we are increasingly working with communities to help amplify local voices and calls to action. We’ll bring together aid workers and experts from our international medical programs to talk about how we’re adapting to meet the evolving challenges. title: MSF Responds to Cholera Outbreak in Lebanon
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working with Lebanon’s Ministry of Health and other humanitarian groups to respond to the country’s first outbreak in 30 years. People living in refugee camps and host communities have been impacted by the highly contagious waterborne disease, which causes profuse diarrhea and vomiting and can quickly lead to death left untreated. Lebanon’s current economic crisis has led to the breakdown of water and sanitation systems, creating the perfect conditions for a cholera outbreak, which can rapidly spread through contaminated water supplies. MSF outreach teams are raising awareness of the symptoms, treatment, and prevention of the disease in several parts of Lebanon, and our medical teams are preparing to open cholera treatment centers, training local medical staff, and adapting our hospital in the Bekaa region to treat cholera patients.

title: One Way MSF is Working to Reduce our Environmental Impact
description:
Hospitals and other health facilities generate a lot of waste. As Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works to reduce our carbon emissions, we are also working to improve our waste management practices. One promising initiative that we recently we piloted in Iraq is the Steriplus, a machine that turns infectious medical waste into domestic waste. Through a process of steaming and shredding, waste such as syringes, dirty bandages, and scalpels is sterilized before it is disposed of. Following the success of the pilot initiative in Iraq, we plan to roll out the machine in more of our projects soon. Read more at https://bit.ly/3TZXB7Z

title: 5 Facts about Venezuelan Migrants Stranded at the US-Mexico Border
description:
The Biden administration has announced that it will expand the use of the Title 42 policy that blocks migrants at the US-Mexico border from seeking asylum to include Venezuelans. Under this policy, tens of thousands of Venezuelans who have left their homes and embarked on a long, dangerous journey to reach the US will be stranded in Mexico or Central America—many with no resources, little aid, and nowhere to go. Title 42 is a public health order that was originally invoked by the Trump administration in 2020, using the COVID-19 pandemic as a pretext to effectively close the border to asylum seekers. MSF is calling on the Biden administration to end this harmful policy. Our teams along the migration route and the US-Mexico border will immediately work to expand their operations to try to meet the growing needs. Read more https://bit.ly/3DxfINh

title: “Now I’m back to life”: Mental Health Patients in Yemen Share Their Stories
description:
“I found the light at the end of the tunnel,” said Fatima*. “Before, I never felt alive, I was lost. Now I’m back to life,” said Abdul Karim. Fatima and Abdul Karim’s words sum up the long journey they underwent while receiving mental health treatment and support. They are both currently continuing treatment at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières’ (MSF) mental health clinic in Al-Gomhouri hospital in Hajjah city, northwest Yemen.
 
“Psychosis disorders are partly due to ongoing conflict in the country,” says mental health clinic supervisor Muaadh Abdul-Ghani. “Most people have lost their jobs and lost their loved ones as a result of the war.” At Al-Gomhouri, MSF offers psychological care, psychiatric treatment of severe mental health disorders, and psycho-education group sessions. Read more at https://bit.ly/3yDSodz
 
*Name changed for privacy. Abdul Karim preferred to use his real name.

title: Mental Health Day: Listening to Survivors of a Brutal Conflict in Mozambique
description:
In 2021, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams  provided almost 3,500 individual mental health consultations and facilitated group mental health activities for more than 64,000 people in Mozambique’s northern province of Cabo Delgado. This month marks five years of intense conflict between government forces and non-state armed groups in the region. An estimated one million people have been displaced from their homes due to the violence, often more than once, and more than 4,000 people have been killed. Five years of grief, fear, and instability has had profound consequences on people’s mental health. MSF’s mental health staff see patients suffering from acute stress, anxiety, and trauma. "Whenever we talk with the people here in Palma [a town in Cabo Delgado],” said MSF psychologist Josuel Moreira, "it is important to keep in mind that we may be talking with someone who has lost everything.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3SL9NZZ

title: MSF Evacuates Psychiatric Patients in Ukraine
description:
A psychiatric hospital in the Kharkiv region, near a frontline of Ukraine's war with Russia, was damaged by shelling in September. Some 600 patients were evacuated to another hospital in the region and the facility was quickly overwhelmed. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) accepted a request by Ukraine’s Ministry of Health to transfer more than 200 of these patients with neurological and psychiatric conditions to a less crowded facility in the country’s capital Kyiv. MSF has been using medicalized trains to evacuate people in need of medical care from areas in the east of the country to facilities further west with greater resources and capacity. MSF medical staff accompany patients and provide care during these long train journeys. On September 23-24, our teams transferred 210 patients from Kharkiv city to Kyiv in two trips over 36 hours. Read more at https://bit.ly/3UTQ0sE

title: Access to Clean Water Limits Disease Outbreaks in Harare, Zimbabwe
description:
For years, residents of Zimbabwe’s capital city of Harare and its surrounding suburbs have experienced recurrent outbreaks of waterborne diseases like typhoid and cholera due to bacterial contamination of local water sources. “People used to fetch water from unprotected wells,” said Precious Kapesa, a resident of Stoneridge suburb. ”They often had diarrheal diseases and some died […] as a result of drinking unclean water.”  

Since 2015, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has led an environmental health program to prevent future disease outbreaks by improving access to clean water in the area. MSF teams have rehabilitated and upgraded boreholes to better protect water at the source, and drilled new boreholes to reach fresh water supplies.

title: Pakistan Floods: Rising Cases of Waterborne Diseases
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has conducted more than 10,000 medical consultations in #Pakistan  following catastrophic flooding caused by exceptionally heavy monsoon rains that started in June. It is estimated that over 33 million people have been affected and that it could take months for the floodwaters to recede.

MSF launched mobile clinics in Charsadda district in three villages located next to riverbanks—including Miaonlay village. The houses in Miaonlay have been partially or completely destroyed, and communities are now facing outbreaks of waterborne diseases. In the last week, MSF medical teams have seen 983 patients in Charsadda district with respiratory tract infections, eye infections, acute diarrhea, severe skin infections, and chronic diseases. The teams have distributed non-food items, including hygiene and kitchen kits, mosquito nets, and insect repellent to more than 600 families in the three villages.

title: Moving Forward: Responding to the Climate Emergency
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) invites you to join us for a special conversation about how the climate emergency is affecting the communities we serve. From the Sahel and Horn of Africa to South Asia to Central America, we are providing medical care for people who are already suffering from the effects of climate change and environmental degradation. Our teams are responding to medical needs caused by cycles of drought, flooding, and extreme weather events. We are treating climate sensitive diseases such as malaria, dengue fever, and cholera. This year we are responding to a surge in malnutrition across multiple countries, with various political and economic issues compounded by environmental factors.

Join us for this online event to learn more about MSF’s evolving approach to planetary health, which recognizes that human health depends on the health of the planet. The event will be moderated by Avril Benoît, MSF-USA's executive director. Speakers include MSF deputy medical coordinator in Mozambique Dr. Ana Gabriela Gutierrez Zamudio and the country representative for MSF in Nigeria Dr. Simba Tirima.

title: Bringing Mobile Clinics to Ukraine Villages Affected by War
description:
In parts of Ukraine that are directly impacted by the war, many people are living without electricity, water, or gas supplies, often for months at a time. Many of these communities, including Nova Kaluha, a village in southern Ukraine’s Kherson region, also lack access to health care, so Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing basic medical and mental health services through mobile clinics. In Kherson, MSF has been responding to the need for chronic disease medications. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3qEOTPH

title: MSF Dr. Bilal showing the flooding aftermath in #Pakistan
description:
MSF teams saw villages completely underwater. Sometimes you can only spot the top of a house. Many people have lost everything and are sleeping in tents by the roadside. The floodwater they may drink is contaminated. Toilets have been destroyed or are filled with mud making them unusable, and floodwater is stagnant. All this will have consequences for people's health. 

MSF has been present for a long-time in Pakistan, specifically in the provinces of Balochistan, Sind, Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. Teams are on the ground providing primary health care, drinking water, and essential supplies.

title: Ukraine: MSF Helps Provide Physiotherapy for People with War Wounds
description:
Months of conflict in Ukraine have left thousands of people in need of physical rehabilitation, including treatment of war wounds, surgery, assistive devices, physiotherapy, and more. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are helping provide these services at public hospitals in Kyiv and Vinnytsia. "In Kyiv, it's a very big hospital where war-wounded patients arrive," said Dr. Diana Galindo, MSF medical coordinator. "They receive patients from the east and the south, where the first surgeries are done, and then they are sent to Kyiv to continue their care. We see that most of them are amputees, and they are presenting now with heavier handicaps than if they were treated properly with rehabilitation." Read more at https://bit.ly/3RBXqil

title: A Community Approach to Sexual and Reproductive Health Care in Honduras
description:
After providing sexual and reproductive health care for several years in Choloma, in the Cortés department of Honduras, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) this year launched a community-based project in the region. MSF teams of doctors, nurses, psychologists, and community educators visit vulnerable communities to offer maternal health consultations, mental health care, contraception, community education, and health promotion. Cortés department has some of the highest rates of sexual violence in the country, and teenage pregnancy is common there. MSF’s health promotion team is also holding talks and group counseling sessions with adolescents to answer their questions about sexual and reproductive health and address their mental health needs. Read more at https://bit.ly/3TXcl8k

title: South Sudan: Conflict Leads to a Mental Health Emergency
description:
A devastating conflict broke out last year in the community of Tambura, in South Sudan's Western Equatoria State. An estimated 80,000 people fled their homes and many people were killed or died from other causes related to the conflict. Many survivors living in displacement camps still haven’t found their loved ones, while others know their family members were killed but feel too unsafe to retrieve their bodies. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) identified mental health care services as a major need among traumatized survivors. MSF teams provided community-based mental health care in and around displacement camps, discussing the psychological problems many people were facing in order to normalize talking about them and to provide outlets of support for those who need it.

title: Rohingya Refugees in Bangladesh: “Help us live as humans”
description:
On August 25, 2017, the Rohingya people in Myanmar were the targets of a large-scale campaign of merciless violence. More than 700,000 people fled for their lives across the border into Bangladesh in a matter of weeks, joining thousands who had fled previous attacks. Today, nearly one million Rohingya still live in crowded, unsafe, and unsanitary conditions in what is now the largest refugee camp in the world in Cox's Bazar.

To mark five years of continued displacement with no solution in sight, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) gathered testimonies from several Rohingya refugees who share their hopes and fears. "We were born as humans and we wish to live a dignified life," said 65-year-old Rohingya refugee Mohamed Hussein. "We are requesting the world to help us live as humans." 

The Rohingya are especially vulnerable as stateless people, long denied citizenship in Myanmar. With no official refugee status in Bangladesh, the Rohingya have little access to employment or education and remain dependent on humanitarian aid. MSF teams see the impact of these conditions on patients' health—an increase in skin infections, waterborne diseases, and chronic illnesses like diabetes and high blood pressure. As the largest provider of mental health care in the camp, MSF also sees an increase in needs for psychological and psychiatric care. MSF will continue to provide care for the Rohingya and to advocate for greater international efforts to ensure that they have a chance for a better future. Read more at https://bit.ly/3cgkFPu

title: Mozambique: Inside MSF’s Relief Kits for Displaced People in Cabo Delgado
description:
Since June, it is estimated that violence has driven over 80,000 people out of their homes in the northern Mozambican province of Cabo Delgado, according to the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Doctors Without Borders/ Médecins Sans Frontiéres (MSF) is providing emergency assistance by distributing kits with essential relief items to displaced people. Since mid-June, over 4,000 families or over 20,000 people have received kits. 

“Displaced people need these objects, as well as food, because in their places [of origin], where they were settled, they ended up losing almost everything,” says MSF driver and logistician Jamal Gonçalves. “They need this type of help.” In this video, Gonçalves walks us through what’s in the three different types of relief kits we distribute, the food item kit, the travel kit, and the standard kit. Read more at https://bit.ly/3AAslWp

title: Haiti: Bringing health care to people trapped by violence in Port-au-Prince
description:
Haiti, still reeling from the power vacuum left after the assassination of its president last year, is dealing with surging violence by armed groups that has left hundreds dead and displaced tens of thousands of people in its capital, Port-au-Prince. The United Nations (UN) has documented a sharp increase in violence this year, with 934 killings, 684 injuries and 680 kidnappings in Port-au-Prince from January to the end of June. In recent months, armed clashes have again destroyed water networks and disrupted water truck deliveries in some neighborhoods. Doctors Without Borders/ Médecins Sans Frontiéres (MSF) teams are adapting to the rising insecurity by operating mobile medical teams and providing water and sanitation facilities.

Despite crippling violence and a humanitarian crisis in Haiti, the Biden administration continues a policy of expelling Haitians on deportation flights. Most Haitians have been expelled under Title 42, a health order invoked at the start of the COVID-19 pandemic that allows for the blocking and rapid expulsion of migrants, including people seeking protection at the US border. While deportation flights to Haiti have been paused since June, without a change in US policy, Haitians who arrive at the US border could still be expelled back to what has effectively become a conflict zone.

title: MSF Cares for People Arriving by Sea in Samos, Greece
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing emergency medical help to people arriving by boat on the Greek island of Samos. MSF teams have assisted more than 570 people over the last year in need of urgent medical care and psychological first aid, as well as food and water. Many of these new arrivals have told MSF staff about encountering violence while trying to cross into Europe from Türkiye [formerly Turkey], including beatings, theft, and sexual violence, and about violent interceptions on land and at sea, meant to discourage people from seeking asylum in Europe. MSF is asking the authorities to investigate each allegation of forced return and is calling for a humane and dignified reception for all people arriving on Samos.

title: Taking a Community-led Approach to Health Care in Chad
description:
In late 2021, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) co-designed a pilot project with the community of Sila in eastern Chad. The goal was to provide access to essential health care to the community while helping to develop the capacity to continue those services once MSF leaves. The community helped create a plan that includes training local health workers, establishing a fund to pay health staff once MSF leaves, and working with the authorities to build roads that make access to care more accessible for patients. title: Making Treatment for Sexual Violence More Accessible in Ukraine
description:
Survivors of sexual violence can face a number of obstacles preventing them from receiving the medical and psychological care they need—especially within the 72-hour window required to prevent sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancy.  In Holovanivsk, central Ukraine, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) led a two-day training for first responders and health staff working for the country’s health system on how to make this care more easily accessible. “It’s extremely important,” said Olha, a Ukrainian psychologist. “We often encounter instances of sexual violence. We want as many people as possible to be aware that this is happening." Read about MSF's work in Ukraine at https://bit.ly/3oG6aas

title: What is Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)?
description:
Every day, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams deliver emergency medical aid to people in crisis, with over 63,000 staff working in more than 70 countries around the world. Our teams of doctors, nurses, logisticians, and other frontline workers are often among the first on the scene when peoples’ lives are upended by conflict, disease outbreaks, or natural or human-made disasters. We respond based solely on medical needs, and we strive to be as open and transparent as possible when it comes to the work we do and the money we spend. Our financial independence ensures that the aid we provide is not used to further any government’s political or military goals. Learn more about our work at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org.

title: Palestinian Territories: Mental and Physical Toll of Living Under Israeli Control in the West Bank
description:
Hebron is the second-largest city in the West Bank and is divided into two areas: H1—governed by Palestine—and H2—under Israeli control. Home to about 42,000 Palestinians and 700 Israeli settlers, the area has become an epicenter of violence against Palestinian residents. It is also one of the most restricted areas in the West Bank: There are 21 permanent checkpoints operated by Israeli forces, and authorities impose harsh movement restrictions on Palestinian residents. This severely restricts access to health care, making it difficult for people to reach care and for health care providers to enter H2 to provide it. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is the only medical organization present in H2. Staffed by an all-female team, MSF’s clinic was established in August 2021, and provides consultations, sexual and reproductive health services, and mental health care—focusing on women and children. Between August 2021 and May 2022, MSF treated 5,135 patients, approximately half of whom were children under 15.

title: Ukraine: Partnering with Local Groups to Reach People in Need
description:
In Ukraine, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working closely with dozens of volunteer networks, non-profit organizations, and civil society groups to help meet the needs of communities impacted by the war. These groups have provided the vast majority of humanitarian aid in Ukraine since the beginning of the conflict. "They have done the bulk of the work," says Javid Abdelmoneim, an MSF doctor in Kharkiv. "They have shown dedication and capacity in getting humanitarian aid to the Ukrainian people." MSF relies on local groups' distribution capacity and their knowledge of and connections with communities while the organization supports their efforts with resources and expertise.

title: MSF Supports Traumatized Community in Ukraine’s Yahidne Village
description:
When the war came to Yahidne village in Ukraine from early March to early April 2022, people who were unwilling or unable to flee the fighting sheltered in basements for a month. There they endured both extreme physical discomfort and psychological trauma. “I’ve become nervous. When I hear a loud sound I'm afraid, and I want to cry all the time,” said Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) patient Nina Mikhailivna Modak. “And it's affected my body—my legs hurt, everything hurts.”
 
MSF is providing medical and mental health services in Yahidne and other areas affected by the conflict, including to more than 50 villages in Chernihiv oblast, north of the capital Kyiv. Read more at https://bit.ly/3ub5fC2

title: Iraq: Five Years After the Battle of Mosul
description:
It's been five years since the battle to retake the city of Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city, from the Islamic State group (ISg) was officially declared “over” on July 10, 2017. For the city’s people, life has slowly resumed, but rebuilding Mosul’s infrastructure is a slow and arduous process, and the health care system is no exception. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams provided medical humanitarian aid in and around Mosul throughout the fighting and have been supporting the recovery of the city’s shattered health system since the battle’s end.

title: Syria: Last Access Route to the Northwest at Risk of Closure
description:
After 11 years of war, 4.1 million people remain in need of humanitarian aid in northwestern Syria. Bab Al-Hawa crossing on the Syria-Turkey border is the last remaining humanitarian crossing point into the region. Now, this lifeline is at risk of closure if the United Nations (UN) Security Council does not renew the cross-border resolution, which is set to expire on July 10.

Closing the Bab Al-Hawa crossing will reduce access to basic food, water, and health care for millions of people, putting lives at risk. Most hospitals and health facilities would lack the necessary medical supplies to function, leading to preventable deaths. In 2021, 99 percent of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical supplies entered Syria through the Bab Al-Hawa crossing. MSF calls on the UN Security Council to renew the current cross-border resolution and keep Bab Al-Hawa crossing point open.

title: Providing Mental Health Support in Ukraine
description:
After more than 100 days of war in Ukraine, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mental health teams across the country are raising the alarm on the worrying psychological symptoms they are seeing. “I don’t feel heartache, it’s like a sore soul, and it immediately brings me to tears,” said Vira, an elderly woman who fled the fighting in Ukraine’s Donetsk region. “I’m worried about my relatives, who are still at home, my son who is still living where there is fighting.” 

From mid-April to mid-May, MSF teams conducted more than 1,000 individual and group mental health sessions in Ukraine. We have observed that people suffer from intense fear, constant stress, persistent worry, hopelessness, and panic attacks. Read more at https://bit.ly/3ub5fC2

title: Ukraine: Evacuating War Wounded by Train
description:
Since March 31, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has medically evacuated more than 650 patients from war-affected areas in eastern Ukraine to hospitals in safer parts of the country. The war in Ukraine is indiscriminately harming civilians who are struck by heavy weaponry in their homes, shelters, and evacuation routes, according to a report released by MSF, called “No Mercy for Civilians”, which is based on the experiences of patients that we’ve evacuated from eastern Ukraine by train.

Medical data and accounts from these patients and caretakers show that the war in Ukraine is being conducted with an outrageous disregard for civilian lives. This points to a lack of respect for civilian protection, which is a serious violation of international humanitarian law.

title: Surviving Libya: Janice’s Story
description:
“It didn’t matter what I had heard about people dying at sea […] I had to take the risk,” said Janice, a 23-year old mother from Cameroon who was rescued with her baby on May 9th from a boat in distress on the central Mediterranean Sea. Janice shares her story of escaping detention and abuse in Libya to seek safety with her baby son. 

Every year, thousands of people fleeing war, persecution, and poverty at home attempt the dangerous journey across the Mediterranean in hopes of reaching Europe. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is helping people trying to cross the Mediterranean Sea with our own search and rescue vessel, Geo Barents. We also provide assistance to people held in Libyan detention centers and those arriving in Europe.
