title: Ethiopia: More Aid Urgently Needed for Those Displaced in Afar
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is witnessing a deadly and escalating nutritional crisis in Ethiopia’s Afar region, requiring a major humanitarian response. Hundreds of thousands of people have fled conflict in Afar and are now facing drought, hunger, and an extreme lack of access to health care, along with the host communities. 

“This upscale of humanitarian assistance to Afar needs to happen now, should have happened yesterday,” said Raphael Veicht, MSF emergency coordinator in Addis Ababa. Since April, MSF has been increasing its support to Dupti Hospital, which serves a population of more than 1.1 million people including hundreds of thousands of displaced people. The number of severely malnourished children seen at the hospital has more than tripled this year. Read more at https://bit.ly/3aWD3Me

title: Moving Forward: A Humane Response to Migration
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) invites you to join us for a special conversation to mark World Refugee Day. We are now seeing record numbers of people forced from home—including a massive exodus of people fleeing the war in Ukraine. Governments from Europe to the United States are largely welcoming refugees from Ukraine, showing that it is possible to provide a humane response to people seeking safety.

We are calling for all refugees and asylum seekers to be treated with dignity and humanity—regardless of their race, ethnicity, or nationality. Learn more about the medical care we provide for people on the move, and the physical and mental health issues we witness firsthand.

The event will be moderated by Avril Benoît, MSF-USA's executive director. Speakers to be announced soon. Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit https://bit.ly/380II2N to learn more and RSVP.

title: South Africa: Communities Use Music To Cope After Devastating Floods
description:
After the devastating May 11 flash floods in South Africa’s KwaZulu-Natal Province, thousands of people who lost their homes remain in poorly equipped community shelters. With no plan in place to re-house them, their vulnerability to disease and mental health problems is at an all-time high. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is one of very few organizations providing medical and mental health services in the shelters, and with psychosocial support spread thin, we see that shelter residents are finding comfort in each other—and music. Taking our lead from the communities and working with shelter leaders and local musicians, MSF has been putting on musical programs in some of the largest shelters. This is just one facet of a mental health strategy that ultimately aims to empower shelter leaders to facilitate ongoing support groups for their communities.

title: Inside Out: People Reshaping Humanitarian Aid
description:
Across the aid world, humanitarian organizations are facing urgent calls to action to address systemic racism and dismantle colonial power structures. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and other organizations have pledged to reform and do more to uphold diversity, equity, and inclusion. But what does it mean to “decolonize aid”? How are we working to redistribute power and center the communities we serve? How do we build an anti-racist organization?

Join us on Thursday, June 2, at 1:00 PM EDT for an honest discussion about how to make meaningful change in the humanitarian aid sector. We’ll be in conversation with leaders and change makers from MSF, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), and Positive Vibes Trust.

title: US: Title 42 Continues, Keeping Asylum Seekers in a Dangerous Limbo
description:
For two years, under a policy known as Title 42, the US government has used the COVID-19 pandemic as an excuse to close its southern border to asylum seekers. Last week, a federal judge blocked the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) from terminating Title 42, which had been due to end on May 23rd. Title 42 leaves asylum seekers and migrants stranded in highly insecure conditions and often places them in situations of immediate danger. 

Title 42 has nothing to do with health or with the pandemic. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams witness the impacts of this cruel policy, which has severe and damaging consequences on the physical and mental health of people forced to flee. There is no excuse for continuing to misuse the order to turn away asylum seekers and block their right to seek protection. Title 42 should have been rescinded long ago.

title: War in Ukraine: “I’ll keep these pictures in my mind forever”
description:
Dr. Sasha Sholokov, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff member, shares his story of fleeing home with his wife and two-year-old son in Mariupol, Ukraine, in February. “I woke up at 6:30 a.m. because my house started to shake because of the shelling,” he said. “I realized ... I have to move right now.”

After making sure his family was safe, he returned with MSF to eastern Ukraine where he continues to help people like him who have found safety in Dnipro and Zaporizhzhia. Local communities and authorities have transformed every possible place – homes, schools, churches, sports complexes, offices, administrative buildings and hotels – into shelters to offer a safe place to stay. MSF teams run mobile clinics offering medical and psychological care to vulnerable people and are expanding activities to meet the growing needs in more than 70 shelters. title: Why is the number of kids with measles spiking? MSF epidemiologist explains #vaccination #measles
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is seeing a massive spike in the number of children who have measles worldwide. The World Health Organization (WHO) found that there were 23 million more babies under one year old who missed their routine vaccinations—including against measles—in 2020 than in 2019. That number hasn’t been this high since 2009.

There are various reasons for this; in places like Afghanistan, cases are high partly due to conflict and damaged health infrastructure. In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), inequitable access to preventive and basic health care services has fueled a cycle of measles outbreaks over the years. Some countries—Liberia, for example—may be feeling the direct effects of COVID-19's interruption of routine childhood vaccination campaigns.

The path forward is clear: Get vaccines into the arms of children who remain unprotected. Since 2006, MSF has vaccinated nearly 26 million children against measles. This year, MSF teams will continue their work to prevent and respond to measles outbreaks with reactive and proactive vaccinations and treatment. Read more at https://bit.ly/3yWVHxo

title: Providing Psychological First Aid to Ukrainians in Zaporizhzhia
description:
In the city of Zaporizhzhia, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are providing mental health care to people fleeing the fighting in southeastern Ukraine. People arrive in busses at a reception center located in a former shopping mall, and MSF mental health staff offer them psychological first aid. Patients often become very emotional due to the stress they've endured and the losses many have suffered. "My job is to help people safely express these emotions," said MSF psychologist Marina Popova, "and stabilize them until they can go to a safer place where they can relax." Read more about MSF's response to the conflict in Ukraine at https://bit.ly/3sn571m

title: Responding to Landslides in Eastern DRC
description:
Some 180 homes were buried by landslides in February when heavy rains hit the town of Ramba in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). People whose homes were destroyed have been left with nothing, seeking shelter with friends and relatives. The flash floods also damaged the local water supply system, burying established springs in mud, or contaminating them with floodwater. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provided 187 families with essential relief items, like cooking utensils, blankets, tarps, mosquito nets, and clothes.

title: Ensuring Access to Safe Water in South Sudan
description:
“We never used to know whether the water was clean or not, but we later found out that it was contaminated. The water gave us diarrhea,” said Roda James, a resident of Labarab, a remote area in eastern South Sudan. She and her community are not alone—across South Sudan, access to safe water remains a challenge.

Early this year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched a campaign to drill ten boreholes to provide safe water for drinking and cooking in the Maruwa, Labarab, and Boma areas in the east of the country. Drilling boreholes is an important health strategy to prevent waterborne diseases. Roda used to spend nearly an hour every day searching for water from the river before a hand pump was recently installed in her village. “We had a lot of sickness and having clean water has helped us a lot,” she said. “We now have access to clean water for cooking and drinking. Our life has changed.”

title: EU's Migration Double Standard
description:
As the war in Ukraine continues, European Union (EU) nations are mobilizing to welcome people fleeing the conflict. But not everyone seeking safety in Europe receives the same reception and assistance. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams continue to observe people being left to drown at sea, intercepted and pushed back at land and sea borders, denied assistance, and criminalized for seeking safety. The positive response to Ukrainian refugees shows that the EU has always had the tools to provide safe passage and humane reception for all those seeking safety. All they lacked was political will. Everyone seeking asylum, regardless of race, sex, or nationality should receive assistance and protection. Everyone should be treated with dignity.

title: Bringing Aid to Ukrainians Sheltering in Kharkiv’s Metro Stations
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are running mobile clinics in five metro stations in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv. Continuous fighting between Russian and Ukrainian forces has driven those who remain in the city—many elderly people among them—to seek safety underground. MSF's mobile clinic teams provide primary health care, including for chronic diseases such as hypertension or diabetes, as well as psychological support inside these stations. Teams are also working to support basic needs, including cleaning products and water filters. Find out more at https://bit.ly/3EeWEC5

title: Ukraine: Train Station Bombing Imperils Evacuation Efforts
description:
On April 6 and 7, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) helped evacuate 40 patients by train from Kramatorsk and other towns in Ukraine's Luhansk region. On April 8, Kramatorsk train station was hit by a missile attack. 

"I am horrified by reports of bombing or missile strike today on Kramatorsk station," said MSF emergency coordinator in Ukraine Christopher Stokes. "We were there yesterday, and we saw hundreds of people crowding the station, trying to leave. It is a big question whether we will be able to evacuate more people." Read more at https://bit.ly/3uZorCe

title: South Sudan: More Help Urgently Needed for Thousands Displaced by Clashes in Agok
description:
Recent fighting has displaced tens of thousands of people in Agok, a town in the contested territory at the border of South Sudan and Sudan. Thousands of people are living outside, without any shelter, food, or clean water. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is adapting activities in the region to better respond to the urgent needs. An MSF team has temporarily relocated to Abyei town, and we’re providing people displaced in South Sudan with food, clean water, and essential non-food items, like soap, mosquito nets, and blankets. We also support local health facilities and run mobile clinics in areas where there is no access to health care. But more humanitarian aid is urgently needed, and we are calling on other organizations to respond quickly to this crisis.

title: Ukraine: First Medical Train Transfer of Trauma Patients
description:
On the morning of Friday, April 1, nine people—including children—in serious but stable condition were transferred from a hospital in Zaporizhzhia, in southeastern Ukraine, to major referral hospitals in Lviv on a dedicated two-car medical train that Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) developed together with the Ukrainian Railways.

The patients, all of whom were suffering from blast injuries, were accompanied by a team of nine MSF medical staff. This first train is just the beginning, with a larger and more highly medicalized referral train being developed by the MSF team.

title: MSF Provides Urgently Needed Health Care for Women in Northwestern Syria
description:
After 11 years of war, northwestern Syria now hosts 2.7 million people, 80 percent of whom are women and children. With humanitarian needs growing, the region’s battered health system is facing dire challenges, including a lack of funding, making essential services like prenatal care and breastfeeding support increasingly difficult to access. “Every time we go to the hospital, I find that the services are unavailable,” said Fatima, a displaced person living in Idlib governorate. “They told me that the hospital where my daughter was born is now closed. It used to provide good services.” In response, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) stepped up activities to fill the gaps, assisting 50 percent more deliveries in three hospitals in Idlib governorate in 2021 and responding to a 200 percent increase in Caesarean sections. Read more at https://bit.ly/3KcySJf

title: Medical Supplies Arrive in Southern Ukraine
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) shipped 2,835 cubic feet of medical supplies to southern Ukraine. These medical supplies have arrived in Mohyliv-Podilskyi and are being distributed to Mykolaiv and other areas.

"We received ten medical kits, and each kit contains three parts: oral medications, injectable medications-infusions—and single-use items, namely medical supplies like catheters, tubes, etc.," said MSF pharmacist Arnaud Camilli. "All of these kits were designed specifically to respond to the needs that we have identified in the areas of Odessa and Mykolaiv." Read more at https://bit.ly/3L7ZOJZ

title: Displaced Again in Mozambique: “We are fleeing all the time"
description:
Cabo Delgado in northern Mozambique has been the target of violent attacks from non-state armed groups since 2017. Hundreds of thousands of people have been forced to flee their homes; most have been displaced multiple times, starting to rebuild their lives only to be driven away again by violence. The crisis appears to be far from over—a surge of attacks in January displaced thousands more people. Hundreds of houses were burned to the ground, crops were stolen, and the total number of people killed is still unknown. "I don't know when they'll stop chasing us," said Samuel, a displaced person in Cabo Delgado. "We're crying to be able to return home."

title: Providing Mental Health Care at the Moldova-Ukraine Border
description:
At the Palanca border crossing in Moldova, hundreds of Ukrainians are arriving every day to escape the fighting in the south of Ukraine. Those arriving in Palanca are mainly from Mykolaïv, a blockaded town 80 miles east of Odessa, and a target of intense bombing. 

“Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is here in Moldova to provide the first assistance to refugees,” said MSF emergency doctor Axel Andolfo. “Two days ago, we started medical activities divided into two parts. The main component is a mental health one … and we have a medical post here.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3uccjxp

title: Historias de una pandemia con trabajadores humanitarios de MSF
description:
Mientras conmemoramos el segundo aniversario de la declaración de la pandemia de COVID-19 el 11 de marzo, nos acercamos a los trabajadores humanitarios que han experimentado los dramáticos giros y vueltas de esta enfermedad. Médicos Sin Fronteras (MSF) en ascociarse con The Nocturnists, se complacen a presentarles una noche especial de narración en vivo y reflexión de trabajadores de la salud en todas las Américas que comparten sus experiencias personales en respuesta a COVID-19.

Únase a nosotros para rendir homenaje a los momentos de dolor y alegría, aislamiento y conexión, ansiedad y esperanza, y todo en el medio. Cómo fue enfrentar las amenazas en constante cambio de una nueva enfermedad infecciosa? Cómo aprendimos a cuidarnos mejor unos a otros y a nos mismos? Cómo nos sentimos ahora?

Lo invitamos a compartir este evento con su familia, amigos y colegas, cualquiera que haya sido parte de su grupo de soporte durante este tiempo sin precedentes.

Los Oradores:

El Dr. Michael Jaung es un médico de urgencias que ha trabajado con MSF desde 2019. Ha completado 7 asignaciones con MSF en 6 contextos diferentes, incluyendo Sierra Leona, Brasil, Líbano, Perú, Malawi y Palestina. Su asignación más reciente en Palestina fue como médico de la UCI en un proyecto de intervención en COVID.

La Dra. Mariana Gutiérrez ha trabajado como pediatra con MSF desde 2019 en lugares como Líbano, Irak, República Democrática del Congo y Afganistán. La Dra. Gutiérrez compartirá una historia de su tiempo de trabajo en una sala pediátrica en Irak al principio de la pandemia de COVID-19.

Tatiana Chiarella es enfermera de São Paulo, Brasil. Desde que se unió a MSF en 2014, ha completado numerosas asignaciones en varios roles. Antes del inicio del COVID-19, trabajó en Irak, Haití, Libia, Siria, Yemen, Malawi y Sudán del Sur. Luego respondió a la pandemia en su hogar en Brasil antes de su asignación más reciente en la Franja de Gaza.

La Moderadora:

El evento es presentado por la Dr. Emily Silverman, creadora de The Nocturnists, un aclamado programa en vivo y podcast de narración médica donde los trabajadores de la salud comparten historias personales de alegría, tristeza y autodescubrimiento. En marzo de 2020, The Nocturnists lanzó 'historias de una pandemia', una serie de podcasts documentales con diarios en audio enviados por cientos de trabajadores de primera línea en América del Norte.

title: Stories From a Pandemic with MSF Aid Workers
description:
As we mark the two-year anniversary of the declaration of the COVID-19 pandemic on March 11, we're reaching out to aid workers who have been through the dramatic twists and turns of this disease. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is excited to partner with The Nocturnists to bring you a special evening of live storytelling and reflection by healthcare workers from across the Americas sharing their personal experiences responding to COVID-19.

Join us in paying tribute to the moments of grief and joy, isolation and connection, anxiety and hope—and everything muddled in between. What was it like to face the morphing threat of a new infectious disease? How did we learn to take better care of each other, and ourselves? How are we feeling now?

The event is hosted by Dr. Emily Silverman, creator of The Nocturnists, an acclaimed medical storytelling live show and podcast where healthcare workers share personal stories of joy, sorrow, and self-discovery. In March of 2020, The Nocturnists launched Stories from a Pandemic, a documentary podcast series featuring audio diaries submitted by hundreds of frontline workers across North America.

We invite you to share this event with your family, friends, and colleagues—anyone who has been part of your support network during this unprecedented time. Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit https://bit.ly/3hJmvaT to learn more and RSVP.

title: Venezuela: “You end up going over all the things you could have done”
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Early on in the pandemic, our medical staff did not know how to prevent or treat this disease, which limited the care we could provide. Shortages of medical oxygen made it impossible to treat many severely ill people or provide appropriate end-of-life care so people could die with dignity. Staff had to deal with the unknown both at work and in their private lives. Their risk of contracting the disease was higher due to the lack of personal protective equipment.

Personally and professionally, having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.
To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face so we can develop the resources to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Dr. Koana Rojas is a pediatrician from Venezuela. When the pandemic hit in 2020, she decided to join MSF and support a COVID-19 ward in Caracas.

Video transcript:
Koana Rojas:
I do not think I was ever prepared to give so much bad news. It is overwhelming. Little by little, you get overwhelmed. First, it’s one loss, then another, then one more. You get home with all of this on your shoulders and it gets heavier and heavier. For seven years I had only seen pediatric patients. Now I am attending adults, which is completely outside of what I prepared for. 

In the pediatric field, you do not give much bad news. I had this patient—a 40-year-old-pediatrician—who had been admitted for COVID-19. From the beginning he had a lot of difficulties breathing. The only thing that could have helped him was to be in intensive care. But we did not have the physical space. 

It was impossible to transfer him to another hospital because they were all full. There was no other place where he would have received better care. Our last option was… palliative care. To put a 40-year-old patient on palliative care—it is not something I had ever seen before. 

The expression “palliative care” is a very strong one. It means that there is nothing else that we can do. Knowing that there is an intensive care ward where they can put me to sleep, attach me to a machine that will help me breath, and not understanding why they are not moving me to this area, why they are not putting me on a ventilator—Why don’t they help me even if I am still suffering? 

Not being able to give him the care he needed, it was inevitable for me to see myself reflected in him. To look at him draw in his last breaths and not even being able to hug him, because often you have this impulse to hug [the patient], touch him. You want him to see your face too and to make yourself felt, make yourself present. To have this last contact with someone, it is not something we can guarantee. We saw how his heart rate progressively slowed down. He was not conscious anymore and he passed away. 

It was really hard because… because it could have been me. I remember that his son, while crying and caught in desperation, kept repeating, “I know that you did all you could. Don’t worry doctor. I know you did all you could.” But it was hard for me to look him in the eye because deep inside I knew that there were things I could have done. There were other things we could have tried. We could have transferred him to intensive care for example. We could have put him on a ventilator. Medically speaking there were things we could have done. It was not like we did all that was humanly possible. 

But there are things that go beyond us. The fact that we did not have available beds in the intensive care unit, it is something that does not depend on me. If I could turn back time, I would spend more time with him. Obviously, I know that there are other patients, but… I think I would have liked to speak more with him, maybe comfort him because he was very anxious. I knew that he was not going to make it. He was aware of it himself. 

This is why I would have liked to share more with him, to try to understand him better. Maybe show him videos of his family. Try to accompany him in his last moment so that he wouldn’t have felt alone. 

Read the full transcript at https://bit.ly/3sQwfXa

title: Eswatini: “For me, it was quite painful”
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.

To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face so we can develop the resources to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Manqoba Sikhondze is a home care nurse with MSF in Eswatini.

Video transcript:
Manqoba Sikhondze:
You're going to receive three different calls from three different places in the region. These are people who are critical, with comorbidities, above sixty, seventy, seventy-five [years old]. As a medical person, you already know that if you're picking one person from these three, the other two that you have not picked, you already know that by the time you go there it's either they will have died or they'll be sick, their condition will have deteriorated. Even if you go there, you already know that even if you take them to hospital, you are not going to make it, you realize that the patient needs to be evacuated. Now we start making phone calls to all these different facilities that you actually work with, and they all tell you they do not have space, they do not have oxygen, they cannot take that particular patient. You have to explain to the family, you have to explain to the husband, you have to explain to the kids that their relative is in a situation where she needs to be taken to a facility, but there is no space in any of the facilities.

And as a result, you're just going to be sticking around just so that you are there, just so you are actually able to monitor and you'll keep on making those phone calls until a space avails itself somewhere. Then you have to take the patient, travel for eighty to one hundred kilometers to the nearest facility. I remember we did this for quite a number of times. Most of those patients did not actually survive.

The contact tracing team goes to the same homestead to find confirmed cases, new confirmed cases. They refer them to you. As a home care team, you have to go back to that particular homestead where you were there maybe three, four days ago with a critical patient and you already explained to the relatives that that patient needs a different level of care, but you are unable to provide it. And for them, they had the perception that you are unable to help them. So, we find that when we go back, now we are having issues of resistance. People are saying, "You are coming to us. We are maybe asymptomatic or we have mild symptoms, but you're coming here and you are unable to help our grandmother, you are unable to help our grandfather. We don't really find you to be a very effective and useful team." I remember one of them was working with the armed forces. Actually, he told me that he thinks I'm coming at this time of the hour because I want to earn a lot of money, because he knows that we health care workers when we are actually working at night, we get a lot of money. At that point, there was no monetary benefit whatsoever that we were getting. It was just our normal remuneration. So, for me, it was actually quite painful.

People were unable to understand that some of of these things were systematic. It was not the fault of us as a team. These were things that were beyond our control, but because we were the ones that people were seeing on the ground, we were the ones that people were actually venting out to with their anger, with their emotions and everything.

For those people we were unable to help, those people we were unable to save–even though it is painful, because there are still people that I actually look back, I do a personal review. I do personal introspection, I say, "maybe that person, is there something that maybe I would've differently to save that person? Is there something maybe I would have done differently to save that person?" But you find that if you look at all the different factors that were involved, you realize that at most it was not something that was within our power, it was something that was a systematic problem, systematic challenge that we had really very, very limited power to actually change or turn around.

title: Ukraine: “Each of us had to make choices in our lives”
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Early on in the pandemic, our medical staff did not know how to prevent or treat this disease, which limited the care we could provide. Shortages of medical oxygen made it impossible to treat many severely ill people or provide appropriate end-of-life care so people could die with dignity. Staff had to deal with the unknown both at work and in their private lives. Their risk of contracting the disease was higher due to the lack of personal protective equipment.

Personally and professionally, having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.
To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face. Such understanding is essential to developing the resources we need to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Kateryna Stephania works as a health promoter with MSF in Ukraine.

Video transcript:
Kateryna Stephanina:
There were moments when doctors, realizing that they could not do anything in this situation, were so worried that they experienced apathy and depression. There were moments when some of them wanted to leave the profession. We had to work with those people for a very long time in order to restore their emotional balance and help them get back to work. Because we understood they were on “the front lines.” 

A woman I know could be an example: she was thinking of leaving the profession. At that moment she was experiencing a lot of hardships. The death of her patients, the loss of a loved one. A person dear to her also died of COVID-19. At that time, things needed for effective assistance were not available. Personal protective equipment [PPE] was not available. 

[Healthcare workers] had to wear the same PPE for a long time not changing it, and thereby endangering their lives. The state system, unfortunately, could not fully provide comfortable conditions for their work. These people worked 24 hours a day. They had special clothing. It was a suit in which it was quite difficult to work. They were wearing diapers because they couldn’t take a break. 

Having visited a village that was in the red zone I could also become infected. [Instead,] I could simply drop out of the team. I could drop out, and eventually stop visiting those villages where people really needed help. I also heard from doctors that they had that very choice every day. 

After the shift, they often stayed at work so that they would not bring this virus home. They thought it would be better to stay there for a while. I think each of us has to make choices in our lives, especially during the COVID-19 period. I, personally, also had a period when I was wondering what was the best thing to do.

title: Venezuela: “I haven’t hugged my daughter for one year”
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Early on in the pandemic, our medical staff did not know how to prevent or treat this disease, which limited the care we could provide. Shortages of medical oxygen made it impossible to treat many severely ill people or provide appropriate end-of-life care so people could die with dignity. Staff had to deal with the unknown both at work and in their private lives. Their risk of contracting the disease was higher due to the lack of personal protective equipment.

Personally and professionally, having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.
To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face. Such understanding is essential to developing the resources we need to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Dr. Marisela Douaihy is an intensive care specialist in Venezuela.

Video transcript:
Dr. Marisela Douaihy:
The difference with this pandemic is that anyone will potentially need advanced life support. And you can’t. You can’t provide it because you have only a few beds for 30 million Venezuelan people. How do you choose between 15 people with the same condition? 

I was attending patients in my intensive care ward when I received an emergency call: “Doctor, we need your help in the respiratory triage,” which is where COVID-19 patients arrive. I remember arriving and seeing the emergency doctor with an expression of despair. He was unable to manage the situation. When I asked what was happening, I saw a lot of people who needed oxygen. Not being able to provide the oxygen that they needed brings you to a breaking point. 

It makes you think, “What if it were me on one of those stretchers and no one could help me?” It was… It is horrible. I felt I was suffocating at the sight of all those people who could not breathe. Obviously, your human side is touched when you see this disaster. You see people asking you for help but you can’t do anything about it. 

Why is this happening to me? Why do I have to choose? Why were some people lucky enough to arrive a bit earlier and get help, and others weren’t? 

In these moments—when you start asking yourself why—is when you collapse, if you have the human space. When I arrive home at night, all I can think about is, “I hope I made the right decisions.” It’s true that we [intensive care doctors] are used to death, but we are not used to seeing ten patients or more die in a single day.

I had to start seeing a psychologist to be able to mitigate a bit the pain of telling ten families a day, “I am sorry. We did everything we could, scientifically and according to our knowledge, but there is nothing else I can do for your relative.”

Intensive care doctors are not gods. We do not deserve the role of deciding who gets admitted and who doesn’t. Before, we were dealing with very sick patients who could or could not make it. But what is specific to this moment is that we have to say, “You can come in sir, and have the chance to survive. But you sir, no, unfortunately you are going to die.” 

It is hard. We are not God. We are human. It is not right that one person decides for others. As a doctor, I do not regret having chosen who to admit to the intensive care unit. What I regret is not being able to give a good death to those who had to die. Because when we die, we have the right to do it with dignity. 

Seeing myself as a risk factor for my family allowed me to establish rules. I come from a family where we always comforted each other in difficult moments. The hardest part is the lack of physical contact. I haven’t hugged my daughter for one year. 

Make sure you don’t miss weekly video updates and ongoing series about our work in crisis zones across the world. Subscribe to our channel here: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Moral Distress: When You Know What to Do, But It’s Beyond Your Control
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Early on in the pandemic, our medical staff did not know how to prevent or treat this disease, which limited the care we could provide. Shortages of medical oxygen made it impossible to treat many severely ill people or provide appropriate end-of-life care so people could die with dignity. Staff had to deal with the unknown both at work and in their private lives. Their risk of contracting the disease was higher due to the lack of personal protective equipment.

Personally and professionally, having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.
To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face. Such understanding is essential to developing the resources we need to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Monica Rull is a medical director with MSF.

Video transcript:
Monica Rull:
Silent Wounds tries to put words and express the feelings, experiences, distress, and the suffering that the humanitarian workers face that comes with sometimes a moral tool or a moral distress considering moral distress as the situation or the feeling that the individual has. When you do know what is the right choice when you do know what you need to be doing, but you can't because it's out of your own control.

We saw the moral distress that COVID-19 caused in high-income and high-performance health systems, and some of our staff that is used to confront these situations in the field, they were confronting the same situations in their home societies, which is not what we are used to. In MSF, we have kind of a filter when you are going to low-resource settings, when you do know that there are some things you will not be able to do. When you are back in your home society or in high-income countries, you are not expecting that so much. That also opened the question on how our own staff in their countries of intervention feel.

You could see the parallelism when we responded to Ebola, with our nationally recruited staff having the same questions than with COVID-19. It's like, "I'm responding to this. I'm going to be bringing it back home. Do I need to separate myself from my loved ones? I am being discriminated because I'm responding to this emergency." So, all these things that we have seen happen with COVID-19 in many countries are the things we are seeing in responding to epidemics. It happened with HIV-TB. It happened with Ebola. It's happening with any disease, with epidemic potential, high mortality, or high impact on the health system.

title: Iraq: “If you don’t get emotionally involved, you don’t care enough”
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.

To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face. Such understanding is essential to developing the resources we need to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Originally from Mexico, Dr. Mariana Gutierrez was working in a pediatric ward in Iraq during the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Video transcript:
Mariana Gutierrez:
There's always this idea that doctors should be somehow cold, or should be able to detach from their feelings, from their patients in order to give good attention.

He was a baby that was born in some other hospital. He had seizures and other signs that made us think he had meningitis. The treatment for neonatal meningitis is at least 28 days. That is the minimum of treatment that you can offer. On day 11 of treatment–so we were not even in half of the treatment–the mother started having some respiratory stress fever and cough. It was a big risk that she could indeed have COVID-19.

As we were not a COVID-19 center, we did not have the full PPE for treating patients with COVID-19. The COVID-19 center would probably not be able to take care of the baby and in a not COVID-19 center, they would not allow the baby in because the mother had COVID-19. So that's what we discussed with the mother, and we said, "the best option that we can come up with is that you bring another caretaker, your sister, your mother-in-law, your mother, whoever. We just need another caretaker to stay with your baby for a few days, until he completes the treatment." The mother and the father told us, “We have absolutely no one, but please let us stay in the hospital because we understand how important this is for the survival of our baby."

We were not able to keep a baby alone with no caretaker. That's just...you cannot do that. Mothers and babies should not be separated. Especially newborns. They should stay with their mothers. This mother was breastfeeding. So, this is definitely not an ideal choice for any patient, any sick patient. So, with no other choices, what we offered was, "okay, bring the baby every eight hours so we can give him the medication and we can check on him." The father came every eight hours. He came at 2:00 PM, he came at 10:00 PM, he received all the medication. The next day, he came again at 6:00 AM, received the medication, went home, and around 10:00 AM we received a call from the emergency room saying that this baby that had been hospitalized with us arrived dead to the ER. The baby had had seizures at home, probably went into apnea–which means he didn't breathe, he stopped breathing–and that's exactly when the baby died. By the time the parents arrived to the ER, there was nothing to be done. It was definitely a very difficult situation to deal with, especially...I mean, especially knowing that this baby could have survived if he had stayed with us in the hospital and received the full treatment.

It happens often in the humanitarian setting that you are confronted with the question, "do I save one patient, or do I save a bunch of patients?" So, when confronted with that question, it's always okay, numbers...I mean, more patients. It's better to give good quality of care to more patients. So that's why the decision was, "we cannot keep this mother and this baby because it represents a risk for the others."

Although of course you understand the pros and cons of keeping this baby or discharging him, you cannot help but feel guilty about it and think, "I should have done more. We should've looked for another possibility, another plan." It is also important to allow yourself to feel the sadness of the loss of a patient, to feel the anger. I don't fully agree with this idea of, "you should be completely detached from, from your patients. You should not get emotionally involved." If you don't get emotionally involved, then you don't care enough, and if you don't care enough, then you're certainly not going to change things for the better.

Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Italy: “The same incapacity to respond repeated over and over”
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Early on in the pandemic, our medical staff did not know how to prevent or treat this disease, which limited the care we could provide. Shortages of medical oxygen made it impossible to treat many severely ill people or provide appropriate end-of-life care so people could die with dignity. Staff had to deal with the unknown both at work and in their private lives. Their risk of contracting the disease was higher due to the lack of personal protective equipment.

Personally and professionally, having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.
To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face so we can develop resources to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

After many years of experience working with MSF, Dr. Chiara Lepora was tasked with setting up a team to respond to COVID-19 in her home country, Italy. 

Video transcript:
Chiara Lepora:
When we work with MSF all over the world, we are used to epidemics. We're used to crises. We're used to shortages. We're used to injustice that the health system somewhat perpetrates against its patients, its communities and its workforce. Aside from the fact that this was a new disease and a new epidemic, other than that, the characteristics of crises unfortunately look like each other all over the world.

The Italian health care system bases its actions on beautiful principles about quality of care and the universal right to care. This proved particularly problematic in a crisis context. When there are not enough hospital beds and there is not enough oxygen, there are not enough ambulances, there are not enough doctors and nurses, the simple fact of saying that everyone deserves care equally doesn't really help the doctor or the nurse in charge to make a decision, and decisions have to be made.

Medical staff were confronted with situations where each of them tried to use their own ethical principle–whether it was based on needs, or for instance, based on the possibility for that resource to be used more effectively, or whether it was somewhat of a sharing of resources equally among all patients–everyone had different principles that they were trying to apply, but of course there was not a coherence in those principles. That created a lot of tensions in between medical staff. So, two doctors making choices–both of them on sound medical reasons, but different ones–ended up giving contradictory information for instance, to patients or to their family members.

One aspect that was very frustrating for us and for all the doctors we worked with was the incapacity of the public health system and the ongoing political dynamics, to learn from what happened in the first wave of the epidemic. It would have been possible and necessary to adapt the system, to make it more resilient for the future waves. Unfortunately, what we have seen was a rigidity, and so just the same incapacity to respond repeated over and over again, not only in Italy, but in all the other countries around. I had an understanding and an expectation about the public health system in Italy. In these past 20 years, the region where COVID-19 had the highest level of transmission is one of the regions where public health has been somewhat dismantled more than elsewhere. And so it was very difficult to see how the privatization of care in a lot of different aspects of what a healthcare system should be, was having terrible consequences for patients and for the health system itself. Moral distress felt by workforce has been felt all over the world, by any doctor who had to make difficult decisions in a crisis.

It happens in basically all the settings where MSF works. The fact that we are talking about that now, just because it was more visible to European audiences, is a pity. It's an opportunity, and maybe it's time to talk about how difficult it is, not only in the COVID-19 epidemic, but how difficult it is every day when doctors do not have the necessary support from the health system they work in.

Learn more at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Humanitarian Aid Workers Are Not Unbreakable
description:
On the second anniversary of the COVID-19 pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières is releasing the “Silent Wounds” video series. We know that humanitarian aid workers experience moral dilemmas in their work; this is not new, nor is it specific to COVID-19. But the pandemic has brought to light what it means for aid workers to deliver medical assistance in sub-optimal conditions and to be presented with only poor choices.

Early on in the pandemic, our medical staff did not know how to prevent or treat this disease, which limited the care we could provide. Shortages of medical oxygen made it impossible to treat many severely ill people or provide appropriate end-of-life care so people could die with dignity. Staff had to deal with the unknown both at work and in their private lives. Their risk of contracting the disease was higher due to the lack of personal protective equipment.

Personally and professionally, having to make imperfect decisions, even knowing that those decisions led to the least harmful outcome, can generate feelings of inadequacy, meaninglessness, and frustration. Such feelings are symptoms of moral distress.
To shine a light on the direct and indirect impacts the pandemic has had on our staff and to offer a space for them to share their stories, MSF created “Silent Wounds,” a video project along with a research study of experiences that bring about moral distress. We did this to better understand the ethical challenges our staff face. Such understanding is essential to developing the resources we need to support them. 
Read more here https://arcg.is/1GiaaX  
See the full video series here: https://bit.ly/3sRG7je

Donatella Paioro is a psychologist with MSF, and Miriam Kasztura is a researcher.

Video transcript:
Donatella Pairo:
I think that we have a bit to demystify the fact that humanitarian workers are heroes and are untouchable or unbreakable. As an emergency medical organization, the humanitarian workers are exposed to the death of our patients, to the limitation of means and equipments that we can have, to the large scale of problems that we can face. This is part of our world. This is also part of what we choose to do. This doesn't mean that it is easy.

Miriam Kasztura:
When the first wave came, there was very little knowledge of the disease, of what COVID actually is, how it is transmitted. What kind of PPE do we need to protect ourselves and the healthcare workers? How can we treat it? There was a limited amount of knowledge. It was extremely difficult to move people across borders suddenly, or material. That confronted teams two situations where they've seen immense need to intervene because people had COVID-19 and were really sick and needed hospital care, sometimes intensive care, and we were not able to provide.

Donatella Pairo:
We had to adapt to this unknown. We had to adapt to the lack of control on our lives and on the choices that we were used to to make. We realized that it is not easy. There is still a lot of stigma, mental health. And I think that COVID helped to talk about the problems that people can face in their normal life.

Miriam Kasztura: 
If these situations, these experiences of moral distress are accumulated, one after one after one, they can, in that sense, lead to very strong frustration and burnout, and that is then a condition that would need psychological support. The accumulation of model distress in individuals and in teams has an impact on the quality of care we are able to provide, and that is a very clear link. So, the more we work in supporting individuals and people to deal positively with model distress, the better our quality of care will be as well.

title: Mariupol, Ukraine: Humanitarian Disaster Continues
description:
The situation in Mariupol city is growing more and more desperate as shelling and explosions continue. Most worryingly, there is no access to clean water—Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff report that people are melting snow and collecting rainwater to drink. There is no heating or electricity. Pharmacies have run out of medicine. The situation is especially dire for elderly people and people with disabilities, as they cannot find food or collect firewood in order to cook. Parents do not have access to adequate hygiene or supplies to care for their children. MSF is calling for safe passage for those willing and able to escape across war-affected areas inside Ukraine, regardless of the existence of humanitarian corridors or ceasefires that may temporarily be put in place. Warring parties must do all in their power to prevent harm to civilians at all times, in all places.

title: Mariupol, Ukraine: Extremely Dire Situation
description:
Mariupol city is currently surrounded and subject to heavy shelling. Our staff tell us that shops are no longer functioning, and most have been cleaned out by people looking for basics such as food. There is no heating or electricity. Pharmacies have run out of medicine. Most worryingly, there is no access to clean water—staff report that people are breaking open heating systems to wash their hands, and melting snow to drink. Over three days (March 5-7), a ceasefire was three times agreed to allow civilians to move out of the city safely. Each time the ceasefire failed. The situation in the city is growing more and more desperate. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is calling for safe passage for those willing and able to escape across war affected areas inside Ukraine, regardless of the existence of humanitarian corridors or ceasefires that may temporarily be put in be in place. Those who stay behind must not lose their civilian status: Warring parties must do all in their power to prevent harm to civilians at all times, in all places.

title: Blazing Her Own Path with Confidence in DRC
description:
To mark this year's International Women’s Day, we asked women around the world who are leaders and changemakers for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) to share their stories. "Leadership is all about charisma, being able to influence the team to make them move forward, to get them somewhere,” she said. description:

title: Moving Forward: The Future of COVID
description:
As the world prepares to enter a third year of the COVID-19 pandemic, many of us have questions about what our future will look like. What does it mean to learn to live with COVID? How much does that answer depend on where we live, and what kind of access we have to vaccines, tests, and treatments?  
 
Teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) have had to adapt constantly to confront the evolving challenges posed by COVID-19. We remain ready to respond to potential new waves of the disease, especially as vaccination rates remain dangerously low in many of the countries where we work. We also continue to push for global equitable access to COVID vaccines and other lifesaving medical tools.  

Join us for a conversation with MSF experts to find out what we’ve learned from our COVID response over the past two years, and why we’re calling for pandemic protection for everyone everywhere.  

Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit https://bit.ly/3JsTITH to learn more and RSVP.

title: Ukraine Crisis: MSF’s Emergency Response
description:
As hundreds of thousands of people are forced to escape the conflict in Ukraine, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to set up emergency response activities in the country and dispatching teams to Poland, Moldova, Hungary, Romania, and Slovakia. Teams are also ready to respond in Russia and Belarus.

“Our teams at the Ukraine-Poland border checkpoints are seeing people cross over on foot, in cars and on buses, many tired and exhausted, and some with children as young as 25 days old,” said MSF director of operations, Chrsitine Jamet. “Many of those crossing the Polish border told us they spent long hours waiting in lines in freezing temperatures. Some were dehydrated and others suffered from hypothermia.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3Hzn3uf

title: Using Artists to Drive COVID-19 Vaccinations in South Africa
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing COVID-19 vaccinations in the communities of Khayelitsha, South Africa, since July 2021. As part of a community-based approach, MSF teams work with the City of Cape Town to set up vaccination pop-up sites in areas where they've collected enough registrations. 

Since COVID-19 vaccination rates have been low among youth and males, MSF's health promotion team spearheaded a community mural project as a means of raising awareness about the vaccines. MSF invited three artists from Khayelitsha to develop pro-vaccination designs and paint them on community walls in the lead-up to vaccination drives. “I think it made a lot of impact on the community,” said Khayelitsha-based artist Noeleen Ndamane, “because as we were painting, a lot of people were asking as well where they can get vaccinated.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3HykAAe

title: Environmental Health: Lead Poisoning in Northern Nigeria
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) first responded to the lead poisoning crisis in northern Nigeria in 2010, when we were alerted to hundreds of children dying mysteriously in communities across Zamfara State. Acute lead poisoning can cause severe brain damage and death in children. The root cause of the lead poisoning was unsafe gold mining. In this part of Nigeria, the gold ore underground is mixed with lead. When the ore is dug up, crushed, and processed to extract gold, lead particles escape into the soil.

For the past twelve years, MSF has led a three-part approach to breaking this cycle of environmental pollution in Zamfara: medical treatment, remediation (removing lead from the environment), and introducing safer mining practices. Without remediation—removing the pollutants—children are continually re-exposed to lead toxins, rendering medical treatment useless. In turn, without safer mining practices, clean soil is quickly re-contaminated. From 2010 to 2021, MSF treated more than 3,500 children for lead poisoning, and cleaned the soil in affected villages. We also launched a pilot project promoting safer mining practices. Today, children are no longer dying of lead poisoning in Zamfara. MSF recently handed over our prevention and treatment program to state authorities.

title: Madagascar: MSF Responds to Cyclone Batsirai in Mananjary
description:
Cyclone Batsirai slammed into Madagascar’s eastern coast on February 5, causing widespread devastation. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical and logistics teams have been responding in the town of Mananjary and surrounding areas. The storm left the hospital and health centers damaged or destroyed, so MSF set up temporary facilities to treat people with medical needs. In addition to the challenges to accessing health care, MSF is also concerned that the loss of rice fields could mean food insecurity, and that access to safe drinking water could be a major problem. And as the country struggles with these challenges, a new storm—tropical cyclone Emnati—is headed towards Madagascar’s coast.

title: Lucky To Be Alive: Hunger and Violence in Northwestern Nigeria
description:
People in Katsina State, in northwestern Nigeria, are experiencing a major nutritional crisis along with an unprecedented wave of violence. Kidnappings for ransom, killings and assaults by armed men (commonly called bandits), have now become routine. This insecurity disrupts the lives of thousands, preventing farmers from growing crops and making it difficult for people to go to markets, schools, and hospitals. All this comes amidst a severe economic crisis, poor harvests, and a lack of water and arable land.
 
This documentary was shot by a group of Nigerian filmmakers from JB Multimedia Studios, led by Kachi Benson (Daughters of Chibok, 2019). "Lucky To Be Alive" tells the stories of mothers like Hadiza and Fatima who travel for miles along dangerous roads to get treatment for their malnourished children. It also sheds light on the many families struggling to feed themselves in a region where malnutrition is a problem at the best of times, and health workers and funding are woefully lacking.  
 
“The number of cases of malnutrition that we are seeing is increasing rather than decreasing, even though the annual peak has passed,” said Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Dr. Alibaba Nurudeen. “With the patients we have currently in the ward, I can say that it is just a tip of an iceberg.” MSF’s teams are working closely with the Nigerian Ministry of Health to improve treatment provided to children with malnutrition in therapeutic feeding centers across Katsina State but more help is urgently needed.

title: Love Without Borders: The Story of Yoeuth and Chamroeun Who Fell in Love After Working with MSF
description:
Yoeuth was just five years old when the Khmer Rouge seized power in Cambodia in 1975. During the turmoil that followed, she was separated from her family and alone. She joined others fleeing through the woods. “We ran away from the shells and couldn’t sleep at night,” she said. She eventually reached the refugee camps in Thailand. In 1987, when Yoeuth had just turned 17, she started studying everything she could on anatomy, basic health care, and midwifery at the hospital that Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) had set up in the Khao Dang refugee camp.

Around that time, Chamroeun Ros also fled Cambodia and ended up at the same camp. He was interested in becoming a health worker and was being trained to work as a pharmacist by MSF. “I worked in the same place as Yoeuth and was interested in her. I knew that she had been separated from her parents since the time of Pol Pot. I fell in love,” he said.

However, Yoeuth didn’t notice Chamroeun and longed to return to Cambodia. In 1991, when the war between Vietnam and Cambodia ended, she returned alone. A few years later, Chamroeun returned and started looking for her by reaching out to friends. “I eventually met her and took her out to eat. We have been together ever since,” he said. 

Together, they began working for MSF again in the Banteay Meanchey province to provide medical care for people living with HIV and AIDS. “We reached out especially to sex workers in the area and helped them make appointments for health check-ups at the clinic,” said Yoeuth. Chamroeun was again hired as a pharmacist and stock keeper. They worked with MSF until the early 2000s and have worked for other health care providers since then. They have now been married for 27 years and live with their three children in Cambodia. Read more at https://bit.ly/3sCfj5c

title: Epilepsy Care Changes Lives in Liberia
description:
Amuchin Nango struggled with epilepsy for years while growing up in Monrovia, Liberia. There was little awareness of epilepsy in the country and no treatment was available. The stigma he experienced drove him to drop out of school while he and his family searched for a cure. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a project for epilepsy treatment in Monrovia in 2017. A year later, Amuchin was finally receiving the care he needed. He was able to graduate from high school and start a career. "Now, I'm a classroom teacher,” he said. "Through the help of MSF, I can stand before students or before people. I'm imparting knowledge now.”

About 80 percent of people with epilepsy live in middle- and low-income countries and three-quarters of them do not receive the treatment they need. Epilepsy is the world’s most common chronic neurological disorder, yet in many places, it remains misunderstood. People living with the disease are often stigmatized and rejected by their communities. For many young people, this can mean forgoing education and participation in society. In Liberia, MSF is helping more than 1,200 patients access epilepsy treatment and overcome social stigma. As part of this effort, MSF staff are helping children return to school after social stigma caused them to drop out. Find out more at https://bit.ly/3gHPQSq

title: Providing Emergency Maternal Care in Afghanistan
description:
Gynecologist Tori Husum was working at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) maternity hospital in Khost, Afghanistan, when a pregnant woman came in with complications. Dr. Husum determined that the fetus was no longer alive and saw that the patient had some very distressing wounds. She performed a Cesarean section and treated the woman's internal and external injuries. She could carry out her professional duties, but she was profoundly affected by the experience. The following day, she went to visit the patient. “I was fighting tears. She was so strong,” said Dr. Husum, who usually works in her home country of Norway. “I’ve never experienced something like this.”

MSF is providing sexual and reproductive health care to women in Khost during a major political and economic crisis in Afghanistan; the country’s health system is on the brink of collapse, and access to medical care is challenging. MSF's hospital in Khost can be a lifeline for pregnant women. “[My experience with this patient] tells me that we are needed,” said Dr. Husum, “and that having access to free health care, no matter where you are in the world or who you are,  should be a human right.” Learn more about MSF's Khost hospital at https://bit.ly/3Ljw79P

title: Detained in Libya: “This is inhumanity”
description:
When they first met in 2019, Yonas was imprisoned in an overcrowded detention center in Libya, where Jérôme was working for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). More than two years later, the two reconnected in Belgium, where Yonas has claimed asylum after finally escaping Libya and crossing to Europe. “[I’m] divided—happiness [for] being here, and sadness that [I] left friends behind […] they are still there suffering. Especially at this moment, it’s very hard to cross through the Mediterranean Sea.” In recent years, there has been a significant rise in the number of refugees, migrants, and asylum-seekers intercepted at sea by the Libyan coastguard, funded by the European Union (E.U.). People are taken to overcrowded detention centers that do not have enough drinking water, food, latrines, or ventilation. “When they bring you back to the detention center, you know the consequences there. A lot of people have died there. I think this is inhumanity for the E.U.”

title: Faye's Breast Cancer Survival Story
description:
On the occasion of World Cancer Day, Faye Kadiatou Kanté Fonction shares her breast cancer survival story and advice. “I didn’t know anything about it, and I thought I was going to die,” said Faye. “It was because I didn’t know enough that I ended up having my breast removed.” Faye gathered with other cancer patients and created the association, Cancer Fighters, in Bamako Mali to share information on the disease and screening. They raise awareness on TV and the radio; during weddings, baptisms, and funerals; and by going door-to-door. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) partners with local organizations in Mali, like Cancer Fighters, to improve women’s access to screening, diagnosis, and treatments of cervical and breast cancer.

title: Yemen: Displaced People in Marib Struggle to Survive in the Desert
description:
Marib governorate is an active front line in the ongoing war in Yemen. In this harsh desert setting, around 150 informal camps serve as temporary homes for displaced Yemenis, African migrants, and others affected by the violence; some 13,000 families arrived at these sites in 2021. People taking refuge here lack water, food, adequate shelter, and access to health care. 

“The tents are not suitable. They cannot protect us from the rain,” said Mojahed, an internally displaced person (IDP). "They can’t protect us from the heat or the cold.” Eayad Selah, another IDP in Marib, said, "as the number of displaced people increases, there are not enough toilets for everyone. Toilets are very necessary." 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing essential medical services through eight mobile clinics and a primary health care center. Staff have seen an increasing number of patients with illnesses related to poor living conditions such as acute diarrhea and fever and a recent uptick in malnutrition. MSF is concerned that if conditions are not improved quickly in the camps, there could be outbreaks of measles, cholera, or COVID-19. Read more at https://bit.ly/3uuwCbh

title: We Answer Your Questions about Safe Abortion Care
description:
On the anniversary of the latest repeal of the Global Gag Rule, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Reproductive Health Specialist Maura Daly answers questions from our social media followers about abortion care. 

0:01 - How safe is abortion, really, in the contexts where you work?

0:14 - How accessible is safe abortion care?

0:28 - Why is it so important to you that MSF promotes safe abortion care?

The Global Gag Rule, implemented by every Republican president since 1984 and repealed by every Democratic president, is an extremely harmful policy that former President Trump made even more harmful. It already prohibited foreign organizations receiving US family planning funds from providing or even speaking about abortion to patients—even if they used non-US funds to support that part of their work.

Trump expanded the policy to apply to foreign organizations receiving any US global health assistance at all, not just family planning funds, including for HIV/AIDS, malaria, and TB programs. This affected a large number of organizations in more than 70 countries. 

Although the Global Gag Rule has been re-implemented time and again, it has not been shown to produce any positive health impacts. There is also no data to show it lowers the number of abortions. In fact, the data we do have shows that the GGR:
- Decreases access to safe abortion care, contraception, and information
- Interferes in patient-health care provider relationships
- Reduces outreach by community health workers

Even though the Biden administration rescinded the GGR on January 28, 2021, history tells us it might not be gone for good. Let's mark this important day and remember—safe abortion care is health care. Find out more at https://bit.ly/3u8WwRn

title: What’s Happening in Burkina Faso?
description:
Months of tension and protests in Burkina Faso culminated in a military takeover on Monday, January 24. The political crisis adds to an already fragile context characterized by an ongoing conflict. For more than a decade, the central Sahel region—principally Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso—has seen conflict between armed groups, government, and international forces. The fighting has created a serious humanitarian crisis with large-scale displacement and many people struggle to find food, water, shelter, and medical care.
 
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are providing food, clean water, maternity and child care, and malaria treatment but more help is needed. “People are living in very precarious situations,” said MSF coordinator Youssouf Dembélé. “[People are] often in camps exposed to bad weather, which increases waterborne diseases like malaria, diarrhea, and respiratory infections.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3G7GYzF

title: Philippines: Responding to Typhoon Rai
description:
On December 16, Typhoon Rai (locally known as Odette) battered the Philippines, leaving at least 405 people dead, 65 missing, and 1,261 injured, according to the National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council. Following assessments carried out by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Dr. Raul Salvador describes what his team saw on Dinagat Island. “Their hospital has been damaged, and they don’t have staff because all of them have been affected," said Salvador. "[People] are worried and they’re fearful of their health because their houses were blown off, and they don't have anywhere to stay.” 

MSF emergency teams will start providing medical and humanitarian assistance to communities on the remote islands of Dinagat, Siargao, and other outlying areas, which have an estimated combined population of over 240,000 people. In cooperation with the ongoing response from the Philippine authorities, we are focused on supporting health facilities, running mobile clinics in isolated areas, facilitating referrals of critical patients, distributing relief items, and donating essential medical materials. Read more at https://bit.ly/3qOdVN8

title: DRC: Renewed Violence Displaces Thousands, MSF Scales Up Response
description:
Since 2017, Ituri province in northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has been convulsed by conflict. In November 2021, rising tensions resulted in four attacks of unprecedented violence in the area. These latest clashes destroyed parts of Drodro town, and forced some 40,000 people into Rhoe displacement camp within two months. 

This new escalation of violence has pushed vulnerable people already displaced by the conflict to the brink. “The communities fighting in the area have been neglected for too long and we will not solve their problems with bandages and medicines. The Congolese state and its international partners need to take responsibility for reversing the dynamics of this vicious cycle that leads to more and more deaths, injuries, and displacement," said Davide Occhipinti, MSF’s project coordinator in Drodro. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is scaling up its response in the area to meet the massive and growing humanitarian needs. In the past few weeks, our teams carried out an average of more than 800 consultations per week, assisted 35 deliveries, and treated several dozen patients requiring mental health care. In addition, our health promotion teams have conducted health awareness sessions to detect cases of acute malnutrition, diseases with epidemic potential, and provide information on support services for potential victims of sexual violence. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3rJCLNH
