title: Greece: EU’s New Camp for Migrants on the Island of Samos is Like a Prison
description:
Refugees and asylum seekers are trapped in camps in miserable living conditions on the Greek islands, and, despite promises of change, the European Union (EU) is instead doubling down on its inhumane containment policies.

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) general director Stephen Cornish recently visited the new Multi-Purpose Reception and Identification Center that's being constructed for refugees on the Greek island of Samos. This new prison-like camp is intentionally more isolated than existing facilities, with increased security, surveillance, and segregation from the rest of society that will limit access to essential services and remove any agency or semblance of a “normal life.”
 
“This is the new approach to migration in Europe, where we are seeking to criminalize, to humiliate, and to punish the refugees and asylum seekers rather than to extend their rights,” said Cornish. “It's time for citizens to see what's happening with their taxpayer money and to instead of investing in this kind of criminalization, invest in a caring, dignified approach to asylum seekers and refugees arriving in Europe.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3gsrmMv

title: Kenya: A Painful but Triumphant Story about a Premature Birth
description:
Tracy, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) patient, shared the touching story of giving birth to her son Archie prematurely at the Mrima Health Center in Likoni, Kenya. Although he was born weighing only 2.8 pounds, she said, “I thank God now here he is, one year and almost 2 months [old].” Tracy is one of thousands of mothers who gave birth at the health center over the last five years. Before 2016, there were no emergency obstetric or neonatal care facilities in Likoni. Expectant mothers from the area had to cross a river to reach to Mombasa, where they could give birth in the city’s main hospital. But the ferry crossing would often cause life threatening delays for the women who needed emergency obstetric care. After six years of improving access to safe delivery in Likoni, MSF recently handed over its activities to the county health authorities. Today, Mrima Health Center is a first choice for deliveries, receiving expectant mothers from all over Mombasa county. Read more at https://bit.ly/2UPW5wp

title: 10 Years of Independence in South Sudan: Stories from MSF's South Sudanese Staff
description:
July 9, 2021, marked a decade since South Sudan gained its independence. In this short documentary, South Sudanese Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff members recount their personal experiences of the exuberance they felt at that moment—and the violence that followed. Over the last decade, the people of South Sudan have suffered through a civil war, intercommunal conflict, and insurgent fighting. MSF's South Sudanese staff have seen and felt this suffering first-hand while also responding to its consequences: the injuries and deaths from attacks on civilians and ethnically motivated violence, sexual violence, widespread displacement, and much more.

South Sudan is one of the most dangerous countries in the world for humanitarian workers. Since it gained independence, 176 aid workers have been killed and 334 injured. Workers of South Sudanese origin make up 94 percent of those deaths, and MSF has tragically lost 24 South Sudanese staff due to violence in the last ten years, five of whom were on duty at the time. Despite the urgent need for medical services in the country, little effort has been made to protect staff, patients, or humanitarian projects.

Peace accords in 2018 brought a ceasefire between the main warring parties in South Sudan, but fighting continues in some areas and the country remains in the grips of a prolonged humanitarian crisis. A new MSF report, "South Sudan at 10: An MSF record of the consequences of violence," provides an account of our experiences since July 9, 2011. Read the report at https://bit.ly/3zc885H

title: Surviving Sexual Violence in Democratic Republic of Congo: Victims Twice Over
description:
In this short documentary, survivors of sexual violence in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) share their stories about the twin impacts of rape and assault. These survivors suffer from physical and psychological wounds, as well as the social and economic impacts of being cast out of their homes and communities. Many women who have been attacked find themselves rejected by their loved ones instead of being supported after a traumatizing experience. The effects of social and familial exclusion combined with the loss of subsistence can lead some survivors into a downward spiral. "I didn’t keep it a secret from my husband because I hadn’t committed adultery,” said one woman. "In the end, he threw me out of the house and took the children. I was homeless. I didn’t know what to do.” 
Sexual violence is a major emergency throughout DRC, in areas affected by armed clashes and in relatively stable areas. MSF both provides and advocates for victims to receive free, high-quality, emergency medical care within 72 hours to prevent sexually transmitted diseases and unwanted pregnancies. Survivors need treatment for both physical and psychological trauma. We are also calling for greater national and international support for survivors to receive essential legal and socio-economic assistance. Read more at https://bit.ly/3rb8Xc9

title: MSF Responds to Severe Nutrition Crisis in Madagascar
description:
The southern region of Madagascar, a country off the southeastern coast of Africa, is facing a severe nutrition crisis, with some 74,000 children reported to be acutely malnourished. With the area’s health system overwhelmed, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been running mobile clinics to 17 different locations, and, in partnership with local authorities, teams have set up an inpatient center for children with acute malnutrition in Ambovombe hospital. More than 4,300 children have been treated since late March. The area is facing its worst drought in 30 years. Deforestation, sandstorms, and other environmental issues have resulted in failed crops and no source of income for many people. MSF is also providing food aid, but more is urgently needed. The COVID-19 pandemic has further complicated the situation, making it harder to transport personnel and supplies. “We suspect the crisis is going to last and that it might get worse during the year,” said MSF Head of Mission Ricardo Fernandez. “We’ll be staying a bit longer than we thought." Read more at https://bit.ly/2T0enKd

title: Responding to COVID-19 in Brazil’s Most Vulnerable Communities
description:
As Brazil faces a second winter of the pandemic, the COVID-19 situation in the country remains deeply concerning, with national and international experts warning of a devastating third wave. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams across the country are finding new ways to help vulnerable communities in the most disadvantaged areas of Brazil. In Fortaleza MSF staff are working in the communities of Prefeito José Walter and Grande Bom Jardim where people struggle to get the health care they need. “There are lots of communities like ours out there. People from other neighborhoods come to the mobile clinics here because it is a wonderful service,” said Katia, a resident of Prefeito José Walter neighborhood. “Since this pandemic started, getting health care has gotten even harder.” 

MSF’s two mobile clinics provide health care close to people’s homes and aim to increase the number of high-quality services for the community. Each day teams conduct rapid antigen testing for COVID-19, provide at-home follow-up for COVID-19 patients with comorbidities, offer mental health services, support the COVID-19 vaccination registration program, and run health promotion activities. Read more at https://bit.ly/2UQc6BR

title: MSF Responds to Humanitarian Crisis in Northwestern Nigeria
description:
There is a growing humanitarian crisis in northwestern Nigeria’s Zamfara state, where attacks by armed groups have pushed people from their homes or cut them off from lifesaving medical care and other essential services. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in the area are witnessing an alarming rise in the incidence of sexual violence and illnesses related to a lack of food, clean water, and vaccinations.

In and around Anka, where we manage a 150-bed pediatric ward in the town’s hospital and run outpatient malnutrition clinics, MSF is seeing an overwhelming number of malnourished children. The children’s weak immune systems have made them more susceptible to malaria, measles, and other diseases. “We’re having overflows in all of the wards,” said Dr. Godwin Emudanohwo, an MSF doctor at Anka General Hospital. “This is not the peak season. Things are not yet the worst, and this is how bad it is already.” Read more at https://bit.ly/35ZKZql

title: Migration: Moving Beyond Crisis
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have been responding to the needs of refugees throughout our 50-year history, but we are now facing an unprecedented global crisis. According to the United Nations refugee agency, there are now 79.5 million forcibly displaced people around the world—more than at any time in modern history. Millions more go uncounted and unprotected.   

The global refugee crisis is being made worse by government policies that only add to the suffering. In recent years, MSF teams have witnessed the terrible human costs of US and European policies to turn away vulnerable people looking for protection. We have repeatedly undertaken lifesaving search and rescue operations on the Mediterranean Sea, as governments in the region abandoned their responsibilities and left people to drown. We are providing aid to families in refugee camps that were never meant to become permanent homes—from Kenya’s Dadaab camp to the Kutupalong settlement in Bangladesh.   

MSF teams are constantly adapting our approach to provide medical and mental health services to people on the move. We also work with refugee communities to ensure they have a say over their future, and help amplify their stories and their demands.   

Join our conversation on Thursday, June 17, as we look ahead to World Refugee Day and the future of the global response to the growing humanitarian emergency. Our panel of experts will include Sergio Martín, head of mission for MSF in Mexico, and Aurélie Ponthieu, coordinator of MSF’s forced migration team based in Brussels. Kavita Menon, editorial director for MSF-USA, will moderate the discussion. 

Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit https://bit.ly/3ve6EWc to learn more and RSVP.

title: Responding to the Second Wave of COVID-19 in Yemen
description:
Yemen’s battered health system, decimated by years of conflict, is struggling to respond to a deadly second wave of COVID-19. Since the beginning of April, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been running a COVID-19 treatment center at Al Kuwait hospital in Sana’a. The center is one of very few places in Yemen where COVID-19 care is available for free, and its 64-bed ward and 15-bed intensive care unit have been full since it opened.
 
With little information about COVID-19 made available by the authorities in northern Yemen, people are left to decide for themselves how seriously to take the disease and what to do if they or one of their loved ones get sick. “My message to the public in Yemen is that COVID-19 exists, and they must take the precaution measures seriously,” says Mohammed Al Ghabri, MSF medical referent for the treatment center. “They should come early to the hospital, as soon as they show symptoms, before they get much worse. An early diagnosis of the disease helps us treat it.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3vx5J2Y

title: EU Must Stop Trapping People on the Greek Islands
description:
“Five years ago, the EU [European Union] decided to trap migrants and asylum seekers in five centers on the Greek islands to solve the so-called “migration crisis,” says Reem Mussa, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) humanitarian advisor on migration. “In fact, the EU created a crisis that they continue to recycle today.” The EU’s migration policies put the health, wellbeing, and safety of people trapped on the Greek islands in jeopardy. People who have survived violence and hardship are stuck in appalling conditions with a lack of information on their legal status and are subjected to harsh border and asylum procedures. 

MSF released a report on June 9, 2021 on the devastating impact of EU migration policies. We are calling on EU leaders to completely change their approach to migration instead of doubling down on their existing containment and deterrence policies. Read the report, Constructing Crisis at Europe’s Borders, at https://bit.ly/3cvWBVR

title: Lack of Water is a Growing Crisis in Burkina Faso
description:
Since 2018, the Sahel region of Burkina Faso has been at the center of a growing armed conflict that has spread across borders and into neighboring countries. More than 350,000 people are currently displaced there—around a third of the region's total population. The fighting—coupled with the effects of climate change—has left many people without access to safe water and at risk of disease outbreaks.
 
“Water is a big problem. We want help, we are very thirsty,” says Guènèba, a woman who was forced from her home by the fighting and is now living in a camp for displaced people. “Since we got here, this problem has gotten even worse.” Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is responding by bringing water to people in need and providing sanitation services, hygiene supplies, and basic health services, but more humanitarian assistance is urgently needed. Read more at https://bit.ly/3zgBsbL

title: Puerto Rico: Bringing COVID-19 Vaccines to Vulnerable Communities
description:
"Well, I wanted the vaccine because I know it’s good for me and my health,” said 79-year-old Candida Rosa Báez. "There are a lot of senior citizens who don’t have someone who can take them [to get vaccinated].” Báez is one of thousands of people in Puerto Rico who have received care in their communities during the COVID-19 pandemic from Puerto Rico Salud (PRS), an organization founded in 2020 by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff. “In Puerto Rico we have many bedridden people, we have many caregivers, many remote communities,” said Carla Gonzales, nurse and cofounder of PRS. "And for that person to make the arrangements or the contact to be transported to a hospital or to a vaccination area . . . It's a very difficult and complicated process.” Starting in April 2021, with MSF's support, PRS has been bringing COVID-19 vaccines to communities that might have fallen through the cracks of the health system's vaccine rollout, reaching people who are homeless, elderly, or living with disabilities. Learn about PRS at https://puertoricosalud.org or read more at https://bit.ly/2SWYXG5

title: Gaza: The Conflict is Over, but the Humanitarian Needs Remain
description:
From May 10 to 21, airstrikes and shelling from Israel killed more than 250 people and left close to 2,000 injured in the coastal enclave of the Gaza Strip. In the space of just 11 days, many Gazans saw their homes and their livelihoods destroyed and suffered long-lasting physical and psychological injuries. Many people were unable to access medical care as stocks of medications and medical supplies ran low due to the closure of the Erez entry point from Israel to Gaza.
 
“The biggest challenge I face is knowing that I have patients who need to follow up with me,” says Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) physiotherapy activity manager Abdulhameed Karadaya. “They call me for things that I cannot offer them due to the context.” These experiences come on top of lingering physical and mental trauma from previous rounds of violence, as well as the ongoing Israeli blockade of the Gaza Strip. Gazans require urgent humanitarian aid. Authorities in Israel, Egypt, and Gaza must facilitate humanitarian access to the Strip. Read more at https://bit.ly/3iaAwQj

title: MSF Clinic in Gaza Damaged by Airstrikes from Israel
description:
Gaza has been devastated by airstrikes launched by the Israeli military in response to rocket attacks fired by Palestinian armed groups based in the coastal enclave. The surge in fighting lasted for 11 days, ending with a ceasefire on May 21. A Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) clinic for providing trauma and burn care in Gaza was hit by airstrikes on May 16. Two doctors were among the 42 people killed in the airstrikes near the clinic. No one was injured at the MSF clinic itself, however the bombing destroyed a sterilization room, damaged a waiting area, and forced the facility to shut down temporarily. MSF was able to reopen the clinic for outpatient treatment a few days later. During the aerial bombardment, teams worked 24-hour shifts supporting medical staff at Al-Awda hospital, north of Gaza City, and donated medical supplies to other facilities throughout the Strip. The acute dangers made it extremely difficult for medical teams to move around, and for people to access treatment. Following the ceasefire, MSF is responding to the mounting humanitarian needs in Gaza, with more than 1,400 people injured and tens of thousands of people displaced. Read more at https://bit.ly/34bMdOd

title: 109-Year-Old Woman Recovers from COVID-19 in Brazil's Amazon Region
description:
Bonifácia de Oliveira celebrated her 109th birthday in the COVID-19 ward of Tefé Regional Hospital in Brazil's Amazonas state. The centenarian’s strong spirit and sense of humor made a deep impact on the team as they worked to respond to a devastating second wave of COVID-19 sweeping the region earlier this year. “The work of being a doctor, being a nurse, and being human in this whole process has been something that we focus on a lot,” said Dr. Carolina Kennedy, a physician with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). “We already know the patients by name . . . we follow them with the family.” Tefé was among the remote towns in the Amazon region affected by the collapse of the health system in the state capital, Manaus, in January. At the height of the emergency, even critically ill patients could not be referred to better-equipped hospitals in Manaus for treatment. The MSF team in Tefé helped staff at the regional hospital establish protocols that improved the quality of patient care, giving people like Bonifácia a better chance of survival. “I’m so happy!” Dr. Kennedy said when her patient was discharged. “She overcame something impossible...and survived one of the biggest struggles of her life.” Read more about MSF's work in Brazil at https://bit.ly/3vkveoS

FULL TRANSCRIPT
TEXT: February 2021, Tefé Regional Hospital, Amazonas, Brazil

Caroline Kennedy, MSF doctor: The work of being a doctor, being a nurse, and being human in this whole process has been something that we focus on a lot. We already know the patients by name, they are patients that we follow up with the family...

Júlia Queiroz, MSF doctor: A patient who really left a mark on me was Bonifácia. She is a 109-year-old patient who is not from Tefé, but arrived in Tefé when she was 14 with her sister.

Her sister fell in love with the only teacher in town and ran away with him, since it was a secret relationship and she couldn't stay in the city. Bonifácia didn’t go to school and soon after started to work in agriculture. She learned how to read and write at the age of 100. She is a patient with a beautiful story.

And she had her birthday here with us, now during COVID. It was really cool because she is very lucid. She said “Oh, since I'm not well I can't eat cake. But my dear, I have already eaten 108 cakes.”

She is always joking. It’s really something.

Taiane Alencar, hospital psychologist: She remains strong and is a very dear patient because she is very emotionally stable.

Taiane Alencar: How old were you when you got this tattoo?

Bonifácia de Oliveira: A few years ago...

Taiane Alencar: Were you young?

Bonifácia de Oliveira: I was only a girl... an irresponsible one.

Taiane Alencar: Irresponsible, huh? Stay strong and everything will be fine. You are our sweetheart. We want this moment to happen, okay?

Caroline Kennedy: So, the patient's hope helps a lot.

The more hopeful and the stronger the patient is, the easier it is for us to work with, manage, and heal that patient.

TEXT: After a few days, Bonifácia was discharged and went home with her family.

Carolina Kennedy: Dona Bonifácia went home. I’m so happy! 109-years-old, she overcame something impossible, went home, and lived through one of the biggest struggles of her life. She went home happy, laughing. It was such a happy moment,

TEXT: During the second wave of COVID-19 in Brazil’s Amazonas state, between November 2020 and March 2021, MSF supported Tefé Regional Hospital and helped provide better patient care and more comfort to those fighting the disease.

title: LIVE Reflections on a Decade of War in Syria
description:
Join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) for this critical discussion as we reflect on the last decade of war in Syria. Our teams have been responding to the humanitarian crisis in Syria from the start—from donating medical supplies, to setting up hospitals and clinics, to providing remote support to medical facilities and networks of doctors in areas that MSF could not access directly—often against daunting odds and great risk. But the situation is bleak, with no end in sight to the conflict.

Arwa Damon, award-winning senior international correspondent at CNN, will moderate this discussion. Panelists include Dr. Chenery Lim, medical coordinator for MSF in northwest Syria;  Will Turner, head of emergency operations for MSF in northeast Syria; and Dr. Aula Abbara, consultant and honorary clinical lecturer in infectious diseases and general internal medicine at Imperial College NHS Healthcare Trust in London. On May 20 at 1:00 PM EDT, this expert panel will answer your questions about MSF’s work with displaced Syrians in their home country and its neighbors.

Visit https://bit.ly/3fk0CNG to learn more and watch on livestream to watch from the start of the event: https://livestream.com/doctorswithoutborders/decadeofwarinsyria

title: A Pastor in East New York, Brooklyn, Shares His COVID-19 Vaccination Story
description:
The majority black and Hispanic communities in the East New York and Brownsville neighborhoods of New York City were among those hardest hit by the COVID-19 pandemic, and people here have also struggled to get access to lifesaving vaccines. These trends are emblematic of broader racial and economic disparities in access to health care in the United States. The legacy of systemic racism has also affected people's perceptions about the vaccines. In this video, Rev. David K. Brawley, lead pastor of the St. Paul Community Baptist Church in East New York, shares his journey to getting vaccinated against COVID-19. “I think I shared a lot of the concerns that many have had relative to the vaccination," Brawley said on the day he received his first shot of the vaccine. "I'm not certain about the vaccine, how it would affect our people, the history that our people have had in this nation relative to vaccinations. I shared some of those same concerns, but I'm glad I did this today.” Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) worked with BMS Family Health & Wellness Centers in Brownsville from February-April 2021 to expand access to COVID-19 vaccinations. BMS continues to provide free vaccinations in several locations in Brownsville and East New York. Find out more about their work at https://www.bmsfamilyhealth.org/

title: What Do You Look Forward to After Getting the COVID-19 Vaccine?
description:

[Our family needs] to get together and have fun,” said BMS nurse Oliver Rosario. “Hug each other, and love each other.” Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) worked with BMS from February-April 2021 to expand access to COVID-19 vaccinations in Brownsville and East New York, two neighborhoods that were particularly hard hit by the COVID-19 pandemic. title: More Medical Oxygen Urgently Needed to Fight COVID-19
description:
As COVID-19 continues to spread and vaccines remain unavailable in most countries, it’s critical that health systems have an adequate supply of oxygen to help treat severely ill people. “Oxygen is the single most important medicine for severe and critical COVID-19 patients, yet oxygen supply is often insufficient," says Dr. Marc Biot, director of operations for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). “Unstable oxygen supplies kill.” Oxygen production infrastructure has been neglected in low- and middle-income countries for decades, leading to more deaths from pneumonia, obstetric and neonatal conditions, and a host of other illnesses. The COVID-19 pandemic has brought the urgent need for oxygen into sharp focus. “This past week’s catastrophe in India has again highlighted just how critical oxygen is for COVID-19 patients,” says Dr. Biot. “Many other countries have already faced such disasters and many more may soon confront this same, deadly reality.” Learn more at https://bit.ly/3tH125U

title: Mozambique: Overwhelming Humanitarian Needs in Cabo Delgado
description:
Since 2017, nearly 700,000 people have been displaced by fighting between government forces and non-state armed groups in northern Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado province. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams continue to provide health care—including mental health care—by supporting health centers and running mobile clinics. As the fighting has intensified over the past year MSF teams have expanded capacity, but our response only addresses a fraction of the needs.

title: MSF Responds to Violence in Jerusalem
description:
On May 10, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams in Jerusalem treated hundreds of Palestinians injured by Israeli police. After days of confrontations, Israeli forces entered an area in the Old City where Palestinians were gathered and deployed rubber bullets, stun grenades, and tear gas. Many children were among those badly injured. “We’ve seen a 12-year-old with a femur injury, we’ve seen a 14-year-old with an eye injury,” said Dr. Natalie Thurtle, MSF medical coordinator. MSF is supporting the work of the Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) with teams of doctors and nurses in Jerusalem. Our teams are also ready to support health authorities in the Gaza Strip following the recent escalation of the conflict there. Read more at https://bit.ly/3o84qFA​

title: MSF Responds to India's Devastating COVID-19 Second Wave
description:
“India has just seen a surge of [COVID-19] cases beyond anyone’s imagination," says Gautam Harigovind, medical activity manager for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Mumbai, where the team has scaled up its response to the pandemic's second wave. COVID-19 has overwhelmed the city's health care system and its frontline workers. A 2,000-bed COVID treatment center where MSF is providing support has not been able to accommodate the high number of people who need care. Health staff are exhausted but continue to work in very difficult conditions. Harigovind urges people everywhere to see what's happening in India as a warning. "Please follow social distancing and please wear a mask," he says. MSF is particularly focused on caring for vulnerable people at greater risk due to the coronavirus, including those with chronic health conditions and HIV.

title: Let's Talk: The future of vaccines
description:
Join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) for the final event in our Let’s Talk Vaccines webinar series on Thursday, April 29. We'll have a conversation about current and future prospects for ensuring equitable global access to COVID-19 vaccines.

Right now, the world's richest countries, including the United States, have secured the vast majority of the world's total supply. Meanwhile, we're seeing health systems on the edge of collapse in several countries experiencing new waves of infection--including in Yemen, Iraq, and Papua New Guinea. Across much of the world, frontline health workers and vulnerable groups still have no access to COVID vaccines.  Dangerous new variants are spreading, making it harder to bring this pandemic to an end. We'll talk with public health experts and civil society activists about a range of solutions to get vaccines where they're needed most.

Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit https://bit.ly/2OOBBkx to learn more and RSVP.

title: Expanding Access to COVID-19 Vaccinations in Brooklyn
description:
Brooklyn’s Brownsville and East New York neighborhoods have been among the hardest hit by COVID-19 in New York City. Now these neighborhoods, and other areas with high numbers of low-income and predominantly Black or Hispanic communities, are also seeing comparatively lower vaccination rates—an outcome that is emblematic of broader racial and economic disparities in access to health care in the United States. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) partnered with the Brownsville Family Health and Wellness Center (BMS) to help expand access to COVID-19 vaccinations in Brownsville and East New York from February until April, 2021. While BMS had access to COVID-19 vaccines from government agencies, it requested administrative and logistical support from MSF to ensure as many people as possible could be vaccinated. After initially expanding vaccination activities in its existing health facilities, BMS has now opened a vaccination hub at St. Paul Community Baptist Church in East New York with the capacity to vaccinate at least 1,000 people per week. While MSF has finished its support for this effort, ongoing efforts are needed to help people in underserved communities access COVID-19 vaccinations. According to MSF's project coordinator, Dr. Kerry Dierberg, “these vaccinations are really going to only work if we can get them to the people most in need.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3t385FH

title: Call to Close Kenya's Dadaab Camp Threatens Refugees
description:
On March 23, the Kenyan government called for the closure of Dadaab and Kakuma refugee camps, which together host nearly half a million refugees. Dadaab is one of the biggest and oldest refugee camps in the world. Most of the people living in the Dadaab camp complex arrived from Somalia, or their parents or grandparents came from that country, which remains insecure. To force refugees to leave the camps, during the COVID-19 pandemic, and without any meaningful alternatives to guarantee their safety is inhumane and dangerous. “Somalia today is still very much affected by violence, by conflict, by drought, by floods, which makes survival quite tough,” says Adrian Guadarrama, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) program manager for Kenya. Even before the call for this closure, MSF was concerned about the mental health of refugees in Dadaab. In 2020, there were 20 attempted suicides and three deaths by suicide. “It’s very difficult for any human being to keep running at this level of uncertainty and with others card-playing your future,” says Guadarrama, “with your having very little to do or very little to say.”

title: Even During COVID-19, Routine Immunizations Must Not Be Neglected
description:
Immunizations save up to 3 million lives every year by protecting people, especially children, from vaccine-preventable diseases. Data from the World Health Organization show that since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, vaccination campaigns in many countries have been canceled or postponed while health resources are redirected to fighting the coronavirus. This is alarming news—not only does it mean that more children are immediately vulnerable to killer diseases like measles and polio, but it also creates opportunities for diseases that are under control in some areas to take hold once again. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is doing all we can to continue immunizations in our projects around the world while also protecting patients and staff against COVID-19. For example, in Vathy refugee camp on the Greek island of Samos, MSF vaccinated children under five against a range of childhood diseases including pneumonia, meningitis, and hepatitis B, all while observing infection prevention and control measures. “Our vaccination campaign was very challenging in COVID time, but we managed to vaccinate almost everyone inside the camp,” says MSF health promoter supervisor Ben Taleb Zied (Kira). Read more at https://bit.ly/3uD4WNY

title: Preventing Malaria in Burundi
description:
Malaria is a major health problem in Burundi, where it is the leading cause of death in young children. The same is true in many parts of sub-Saharan Africa. Of the estimated 400,000 malaria-related deaths each year worldwide, more than 90 percent are recorded in Africa.
 
Because there is no vaccine for the mosquito-borne disease, prevention is the best way to fight infection. One way to keep mosquitos from spreading malaria is indoor residual spraying, or IRS, in which homes are treated with long-lasting insecticide. Effective for months at a time, it drastically reduces the number of cases of malaria when combined with the use of mosquito nets. "Last year, spraying was a key factor in the 80 percent drop in malaria cases here," says Dr. Hippolyte Mboma, malaria project manager for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Burundi’s Kinyinya district.
 
“I worked as a nurse in the intensive care unit. I’ve seen too many people die from malaria,” says Jeanine Arakaza, who supervises an MSF spraying team in Burundi. “There are so many cases. I thought to myself, I have to switch to [working on] prevention.” In this video, we follow the work of Jeanine and her team as they travel by bicycle to different communities, helping thousands of people protect themselves against malaria. Read more at https://bit.ly/32D1XsV

title: Brazil: Failed COVID-19 Response Drives Humanitarian Catastrophe
description:
The COVID-19 pandemic is killing Brazilians by the thousands every day and overwhelming the country's health system. Last week, Brazilians accounted for more than a quarter of global COVID-19 deaths. Intensive care units (ICU) were full in 21 out of 27 of Brazil’s capitals. These staggering figures are clear evidence of the authorities’ failure to manage the health and humanitarian crises in the country and protect Brazilians, especially the most vulnerable, from the virus. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams working across Brazil report severe shortages of oxygen, medical supplies, and personal protective equipment. “Since the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, Brazil’s authorities have treated public health as a political game,” says Pierre Van Heddegem, emergency coordinator for MSF’s COVID-19 response in Brazil. “Masks are shunned, physical distancing is ignored, and few restrictions are put into place to protect the people.” We are calling on national authorities to act now to put in place an effective, centralized, coordinated public health response. Read more at https://bit.ly/3gqKIU3

title: 100 Years of Insulin
description:
This year marks the 100th anniversary of the discovery of insulin, the lifesaving drug for people living with diabetes. But a century later, insulin is still out of reach for half of the millions of people worldwide who need it. In most of the countries where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works, insulin is not available in public health facilities or private pharmacies. Three manufacturers—Novo Nordisk, Sanofi, and Eli Lilly—control 90 percent of the global market, keeping prices unreasonably high.
 
The scientists who discovered insulin sold the patent to the University of Toronto for $1, with the wish that the drug be accessible for all. To celebrate 100 years of insulin, let’s keep pushing to make affordable, effective diabetes treatment available to everyone who needs it. Read more at https://bit.ly/3e0tNo9

title: Sexual Violence Is a Public Health Crisis in Central African Republic
description:
In Bangui, the capital of Central African Republic, sexual violence is a public health crisis. With a long history of active conflict in the area, tensions here remain high and most of the sexual violence cases that Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) sees happen in the community and in the home. MSF opened the Tongolo support center in 2017 because survivors couldn’t access the medical and psychosocial services they needed. The center offers free, high-quality care, including for men, children, and adolescents. "Tongolo means ‘star’— something that shines, that gives hope,” says Sylvie Nadège, the center's supervisor. “The Tongolo center is special because we offer holistic care. We have all types of staff: health care workers, social workers, and mental health counselors, and we offer on-site health care.” Survivors of sexual violence also need services that MSF cannot provide, namely protection, emergency shelter, and economic and legal support. We are calling on donors and other organizations to make these services available in Bangui.

title: Mozambique: The Impact of Conflict in Cabo Delgado
description:
Since 2017 people in Cabo Delgado, a province in northern Mozambique, have been caught in a violent conflict between non-state armed groups and the government. Over the last year, this conflict has intensified, displacing more than half a million people. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been working in Cabo Delgado since February 2019 when teams responded to the consequences of Cyclone Kenneth. MSF Director of Analysis Jonathan Whittall provides insight into the conflict, its impact on people forced to flee, and the need for more humanitarian assistance. “What’s needed in Cabo Delgado are the basic necessities to sustain life,” says Whittall. “People need water, food, health care, shelter. We’re talking about emergency needs for a population that has been uprooted and displaced and found safety in extremely difficult conditions.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3rZLadJ

title: Fighting a Rise in Measles Cases in Democratic Republic of Congo
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is concerned about a recent surge in measles cases in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). This began just months after the country declared an end to its worst-ever measles outbreak, in which more than 460,000 children contracted the disease and some 8,000 died from 2018 to 2020. Measles is among the biggest causes of death for children worldwide, even though a safe and cost-effective vaccine is available. Since January 1, 2021, there have been more than 13,000 new cases in the region that includes North and South Ubangi provinces. In addition to treating sick patients, MSF teams have raced to vaccinate more than 130,000 children. They’ve also trained many local health workers in disease surveillance so they can recognize new outbreaks earlier. But more resources are urgently needed to keep this new surge from spiraling out of control. Read more at https://bit.ly/2PtkO6Q​

title: Let's Talk: COVID Vaccines for All
description:
Join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) for the next event in our Let’s Talk Vaccines webinar series on Thursday, April 1. As we mark one year of life defined by the COVID-19 pandemic, the global health community is focused on how to get vaccines to the people who need them most. Health workers and activists are calling for the fair and equitable distribution of vaccines around the world, and right here in the United States.  

Last year, MSF worked with local partners in projects across the US to support the COVID-19 response in underserved communities, including work with African American, Native American, and Latinx communities. This year, we are renewing our collaborations with community-based organizations in New York City and in Puerto Rico to ensure that COVID-19 vaccines reach some of those hardest hit by the virus.   

Racial and ethnic disparities in health and health care are not new, but the pandemic has exposed these harsh realities for all to see. Who is getting access to the new COVID-19 vaccines? What are the barriers? How can we expand the reach of these lifesaving tools? Answering these questions is critical to bringing this pandemic to an end. We know that no one will be safe from this disease until we’re all safe.

Ring the bell to be notified when we go live or visit https://bit.ly/3s0R2V1 to learn more and RSVP.

title: Meet Fanny, a Sex Worker and Community Health Worker in Malawi
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a medical project for sex workers in Malawi in 2014. The focus was on testing and treatment for HIV and tuberculosis and providing sexual and reproductive health care, including treatment for sexual violence. A key aspect of the program was using trained community health workers like Fanny—a fellow sex worker who could gain the trust of the people we wanted to reach and provide them with important health information and services. “What the girls go through, I go through the same,” says Fanny. “They look at me as their helper because we counsel and guide each other and share the problems we are facing.” Community health workers also offer direct services to beneficiaries, including contraception. “I distribute condoms, I give health talks. I distribute PEP (post-exposure prophylaxis to protect against HIV) and I am able to do pregnancy tests. I also accompany fellow sex workers to the hospital when they need to meet a doctor.”  Over seven years, the project reached more than 7,000 women and provided a successful model for reaching a neglected population and helping put the power of self-managed care into women’s hands. MSF’s project helped bring down the rates of HIV in the community and worked with local hospitals to improve their treatment of sex workers; it also addressed mistreatment of sex workers by police. “MSF changed the narrative. We are well informed,” Fanny says. “The trainings and groups have helped. We are now able to demand justice for ourselves.” In December 2020, MSF handed over the project to local community organizations and the Ministry of Health. Read more about MSF's work on treatment for sexual violence at https://bit.ly/3oNURLK.

title: Impact of the Tigray Conflict: “Our Home Was Destroyed”
description:
Fighting in Ethiopia’s Tigray region has displaced hundreds of thousands of people. Schools across the entire region, including towns and cities like Adwa, Axum, and Shire, are quickly filling with people fleeing violence. As they arrive, they join others who are already sheltering in poor and overcrowded conditions. “It’s an extremely concerning situation because we’re not seeing an adequate response from the humanitarian community […] for water, sanitation, food, or medical services,” says Esperanza Santos, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) emergency coordinator in Tigray. Many, like Ken Alew and his family, have already been displaced multiple times since the Tigray conflict began. In this video, Alew describes what they experienced after their house and all their possessions were destroyed in an attack on their hometown of Edaga Arbi.  

Find out more about the impact of violence from the Tigray crisis, and MSF’s response, at https://bit.ly/3tYaa6J

title: Treating Children with Tuberculosis in Tajikistan
description:
As challenging as it is to treat tuberculosis (TB) in adults, it is even harder in children, whose less robust immune systems make them especially vulnerable to developing TB. In Tajikistan, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) partnered with the Ministry of Health and Social Protection of the Population of Tajikistan to develop our pediatric TB program. We support both the children’s TB hospital, and children who are in outpatient treatment. In recognition of World TB Day, learn from MSF doctor, Zumrad Khamroeva, about the challenges of diagnosing and treating children with TB, MSF’s innovative family-based model of care, and our ambitious new plans for the Zero TB project. Read more at https://bit.ly/3d4Pvac

title: Yemen Urgently Needs Support to Fight Second Wave of COVID-19
description:
The health system in Yemen has deteriorated during six years of war, leaving it unprepared to respond to the urgent needs caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Currently, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Yemen are witnessing a dramatic second wave of severe COVID cases throughout the country, accompanied by a lack of oxygen and beds in intensive care units (ICUs). Our teams have launched an emergency COVID-19 project at Al Gamhouria hospital in the southern city of Aden to care for critically ill patients, but much more needs to be done. “Due to gravity of the situation, we call on all medical humanitarian organizations to immediately scale up their response to the COVID-19 outbreak in Yemen,” says MSF Head of Mission Raphael Veight. “And we call on institutional donors who cut their funding for the humanitarian response in Yemen to scale up and make sure that the necessary funds are available.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3sly1wE

title: Part 4: Life in Idlib | 10 Years of War in Syria
description:
In the final part of our documentary on the impact of a decade of conflict in Syria—"No way out"—we bring you into what is happening in Idlib and how the current situation is affecting  the lives of people currently living in the province. 

Over years of war and cycles of displacement, Syrians fleeing the violence have crowded into Idlib province, hemmed into the north by the Turkish border. Living conditions are disastrous. In a region where 2.8 million people already depend on humanitarian aid for their basic needs—food, water, shelter, health care, and education—every new military attack, every economic crisis affects a population left shattered by ten years of war. 

Amani Al Ali is a cartoonist who stayed on in Idlib city, even after it emptied out, in order to take care of her mother. "The war affected me psychologically," she says. "But it also gave me the motivation to keep drawing." Imad Youssef, a former construction worker, is unemployed and worries about the future in Idlib for his family and for other displaced people—especially those living in the camps and informal settlements. “They have paid heavily with their lives and livelihoods,” he says. Abu Alaa, a citizen journalist, asks how people in western countries would feel if they were forced from their homes and homelands. Ten years later, he still carries the key to the house he left behind.  

Read more about what is happening in Idlib and watch the full documentary at http://bit.ly/3lcujmb

title: Part 3: Attack on Raqqa | 10 Years of War in Syria
description:
In Part 3 of our documentary on the impact of a decade of conflict in Syria—"No way out"—we bring you into the lives of some of the people who were trapped in Raqqa, facing violence from all sides. None of the forces involved in the conflict—whether the Syrian government and its allies, the Islamic State group (IS), or the US-led international coalition—showed any mercy, leading to the destruction of Raqqa.

In June 2017, the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) backed by the US-led international coalition air force launched a major military offensive against the IS in Raqqa, making no distinction between combatants and civilians. People trapped in Raqqa endured persecution under IS control, followed by the coalition’s indiscriminate airstrikes. Khalaf Al Malla is a schoolteacher who fled after his home was raided by IS. During his last two months there, he describes living like a prisoner confined to his home. "Going out meant getting killed, either mentally or physically," he says. Fatima Al Ali and her family endured many hardships in Raqqa, but were not able to leave. She talks about living in constant fear during the coalition offensive, with airstrikes raining down and IS taking over people's homes. 

Read more about the situation in Raqqa as a result of the Syrian war  and watch the full documentary at http://bit.ly/3rDl7d7

title: Part 2: Airstrikes on Idlib Hospitals | 10 Years of War in Syria
description:
In Part 2 of our documentary on the impact of a decade of conflict in Syria—"No way out"—we bring you into the lives of some of the people who witnessed attacks on health facilities. These attacks have occurred throughout the conflict, depriving communities of vital services. People started avoiding hospitals for fear of being bombed, arrested, or tortured.  

On February 15, 2016, Syrian forces and their Russian allies bombed a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) supported hospital in Maarat Al Numan in Idlib in “double-tap” airstrikes. Dr. Mazen Al Saud describes arriving at the hospital to find his patients, colleagues, and friends buried under the rubble. "I was so shocked," he says.  

A few years later, in December 2019, despite Russia's announcement of a unilateral ceasefire, the Syrian government launched another massive offensive to take opposition-held territory. Over the next three months, more than 1.5 million people in Idlib and Aleppo provinces were forced to flee--the biggest internal displacement since the war began. Mustafa Ajaj, who runs a health care facility in Deir Hassan camp in Idlib, has been displaced six times and witnessed relentless and targeted attacks on health workers. “The bombing of medical facilities caused us enormous suffering,” says Mustafa. “Every medical center, in every free area, was bombed.” 
 
Read more about the impact of the airstrikes in Idlib and watch the full documentary at http://bit.ly/3liRcEH

1:06 Medical centers supported displaced people

title: Part 1: Siege of Homs & Attack on Ghouta | 10 Years of War in Syria
description:
In Part 1 of our documentary on the impact of a decade of conflict in Syria—"No way out"—we bring you into the lives of some of the people affected by the widening war. 

In the first section of Part 1, we take a look at the events and aftermath of the siege of Homs. In July 2011, the Syrian army deployed tanks in Homs, the third-largest city and an opposition stronghold. In February 2012, Syrian government forces began an all-out assault on Homs. A bloody siege lasted for nearly three years, with civilians trapped in the fighting. Abu Alaa, a citizen journalist, recalls his family's experience living under fire. Journalist and humanitarian aid worker Tarek Baderkhan, who was born in Homs, describes staying in the city for as long as he could. When his hometown fell to the Syrian army in 2015, he was evacuated by bus to the countryside north of the city. His body was scarred by shrapnel wounds.  

In the second section of Part 1, we reflect on the attacks in eastern Ghouta. On August 21, 2013, the Syrian government launched airstrikes and alleged chemical attacks in Ghouta. That morning, in less than three hours, three hospitals supported by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) treat 3,600 patients showing symptoms of exposure to a toxic agent. Imad Youssef is a former construction worker from Zamalka one of the areas that was hit. “It was a horrifying scene. Countless cars were evacuating thousands of victims from my hometown,” says Imad. “As I went from one medical facility to another, I found them overwhelmed with men, women, and children who were either choking, or had been killed.” 

Read more about what happened in Homs and Ghouta and watch the full documentary at http://bit.ly/3cvdX4a   

Timestamps:
0:02 Tarek recalls the Siege of Homs 
1:15 The attack on Homs in 2012

title: Intro: Syria Conflict Documentary | 10 Years of War in Syria
description:
While much of the world has turned away from the staggering scale of the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Syria, we wanted to look deeper. After a decade of conflict, 6.6 million people have been uprooted inside Syria—the largest number of internally displaced people anywhere in the world. Many families have been forced to flee repeated cycles of violence. Another 5.6 million Syrian refugees have fled to other countries for safety.  

Behind these terribly large numbers are, of course, individual human beings. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have been working in Syria throughout the long, brutal conflict. In this documentary about the war in Syria—"No way out"—we bring you into the lives of some of the people we’ve met along the way in Idlib, in overcrowded camps and settlements still vulnerable to airstrikes. These are the survivors. 

In this introduction to the documentary, we meet Mustafa Ajaj, who runs a health care facility in Deir Hassan camp in Idlib and has been displaced six times. A father of five, he has witnessed relentless and targeted attacks on medical workers and facilities since the beginning of the war in Syria. “Every year over these past ten years has seen fighting, war, battles and displacement,” says Mustafa. “You can live in a tent for a month or two, or even a year, but not for your entire life.” 

Read more and watch the full documentary at http://bit.ly/3ezi9m4

title: Urgent Need for Clean Water in Pulka, Nigeria
description:
Ongoing fighting in Nigeria’s Borno state has caused years of suffering for people in this northeastern region and pushed many to leave their homes in search of safety. Large numbers of displaced people are living in the town of Pulka, where access to clean water is a major problem. Water is particularly scarce now, during the dry, hot season that runs from November to May. “Most boreholes are not in working condition. You see a lot of people, sometimes over 1,000, [lining up] to get water, sometimes to get one bucketful of water,” says Mohammed U., who lives in Pulka. Many displaced people are forced to trade scarce food supplies for water with local residents. Some resort to drinking untreated water. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams running a hospital in Pulka say the most common disease they see, especially among children, is acute, non-bloody diarrhea—a direct result of the lack of access to clean water. MSF is calling on the organizations providing water and sanitation services here to act urgently to improve the supply of safe drinking water.

title: Syrian Conflict Timeline: 10 Years of War in Syria
description:
As depicted in this timeline of the Syrian crisis, Syria has been convulsed by war for 10 years. Back in 2011, what began as political protests quickly escalated to deadly conflict. A decade later, the humanitarian toll is devastating. Over this period, 12 million Syrian people—half the country’s population before the war—have been forced to flee and leave their homes behind, often multiple times. This is the biggest displacement crisis of the century. Many of those who have been uprooted are still displaced today. Years of conflict have also destroyed Syria’s infrastructure, especially its health system. Hundreds of medical facilities have been bombed, large numbers of medical staff have been killed or have fled, and there are still desperate shortages of medical supplies in many parts of the country. Today, the medical needs of the Syrian people are immense. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been responding to the crisis in Syria from the start, providing medical care and support to people in need across the country. We’ve donated medical supplies, set up hospitals and clinics, and provided remote support to medical facilities and networks of doctors in areas we couldn’t access directly. Today, MSF supports Syrians both within the country and in several neighboring nations that host Syrian refugees. Read more about the Syrian war timeline at https://bit.ly/38ztEq0

title: MSF Helps Provide Medical Care for People Displaced in Tigray Conflict
description:
Fighting in Ethiopia’s Tigray region has displaced hundreds of thousands of people. Most are staying with host families in the region, while tens of thousands of others have taken shelter at informal sites or are still hiding in the bush or the mountains. Most have been deprived of medical care for months and have received little humanitarian assistance. In the town of Shire, about 20,000 people live in precarious conditions in several schools and on the campus of Shire University. There is not enough food, and people with chronic diseases have not received medication for months. Children have not been vaccinated, and pregnant mothers are worried that they will give birth in the camps as the nightly curfew makes it impossible to reach the hospital. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams run primary health clinics in the displacement site and are supporting Shire hospital. Read more about MSF's efforts to help provide medical care for people displaced by the Tigray conflict at https://bit.ly/3cvOTKH

title: Wealthy Countries: ‘Stop Stonewalling’ on Action to Expand Access to COVID-19 Vaccines and Tools
description:
As we approach the one-year anniversary of the pandemic, governments are meeting to discuss a landmark proposal at the World Trade Organization for a waiver on intellectual property (IP) on COVID-19 vaccines, treatments, tests, and other medical tools. The temporary waiver would apply to IP on certain COVID-19 medical tools and technologies until herd immunity is reached. Yet the United States and 16 other countries are blocking the proposal by refusing to allow formal negotiations to begin. “The waiver proposal offers all governments opportunities to take action for better collaboration in the development, production, and supply of COVID medical tools without being restricted by private industry’s interests and actions," said Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) International President Dr. Christos Christou. "Crucially, it would give governments all available tools to ensure global access." Obstruction by wealthier countries continues despite the global challenges posed by highly infectious new variants of the disease spreading in some low- and middle-income countries. The US and others "must stop stonewalling and show the leadership required to deliver on the ‘global solidarity’ they have so often declared during this pandemic," said Dr. Christou. "It’s time to champion access to medical tools for everyone, wherever they live.” Read more at https://bit.ly/2OzOyOL

title: 1 Year On: Still Racing to Respond to COVID-19 Around the World
description:
One year into the pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are still racing to respond to COVID-19—and to the severe disruptions to other essential health services. MSF teams responded to the spread of the novel coronavirus in the more than 70 countries where we have existing medical projects, and launched emergency responses in many others—including unprecedented operations in Europe and the United States. 

Today, most COVID-19 activities have been integrated in our regular programs. However, we are maintaining some focused projects depending on the local needs. Teams have been caring for COVID-19 patients in treatment centers and hospitals, offering health education and mental health support, providing training for vital infection prevention and control measures in health facilities, and supporting response efforts by local authorities. A key priority is to keep our other lifesaving medical programs running amid this emergency. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3efkYsy

title: Self-testing for HIV Gives Patients Power Over their Health in Eswatini
description:
Eswatini has the highest prevalence of HIV of any country in the world. The fear and stigma around the disease is high, so Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) implemented home self-testing for HIV. "What I like about self-testing is that it gives you the freedom to know your HIV status without anyone else knowing and without going to the hospital," says Thoko, an MSF patient. People come for initial testing at our clinic and, if they test negative, they are given self-testing kits to use at home. "We really encourage women to continue testing for HIV so that they always know their status," says MSF counselor Nombulelo Ndlovu. "This will ensure that even if they are still HIV negative, they are able to continue to protect themselves and remain negative. If they happen to receive a positive result, we assure them that life goes on. All that they need to do is to go to the nearest clinic where they will get all the necessary assistance and be able to start ARV (antiretroviral) treatment." Read more about MSF's integration of self-care into our sexual and reproductive health projects at https://bit.ly/2MQy9Vq

title: Protecting Herself Against HIV Through Self-Care in Eswatini
description:
Mumcy Msibi lives in Eswatini, which has the world’s highest prevalence of HIV. When she learned that her husband was HIV positive, she went to a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) clinic and began pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), which prevents infection in people at risk of HIV. "I did not waste any time, I just rushed to MSF and I was given PrEP. I started taking it then," she says. "My entire family knows as well. I am doing very well with my PrEP." MSF is integrating self-care, including PrEP, as part of a patient-centered approach to health care by providing people with the knowledge, skills, and tools to participate in their own health care while still having access to formal health services when needed. Read more about the integration of self-care into our sexual and reproductive health projects at https://bit.ly/2MQy9Vq

title: International Women's Day 2021: What is Self-Care?
description:
The term "self-care" might conjure up images of yoga and bubble baths, but for women who face obstacles receiving the health care they need, self-care can be lifesaving. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is integrating self-care as part of a patient-centered approach to health care by providing people with the knowledge, skills, and tools to undertake self-care safely while still having access to formal health services when they need them. Self-care can include self-management, like administering a long-acting injectable contraceptive or managing your safe medication abortion at home. It can include self-testing, like self-swabbing for human papillomavirus, or oral home-testing for HIV. And it can include self-awareness, like accessing health information from a trusted peer or an app. Read more about how MSF is working to make self-care an option for more patients around the world at https://bit.ly/2MQy9Vq

title: Mozambique: More Aid is Needed as Violence Increases in Cabo Delgado
description:
The people of northern Mozambique’s Cabo Delgado province have been caught in the middle of a violent conflict since 2017. Over the last year fighting has become even more intense, forcing some 668,000 people to flee their homes. Many of these displaced people take shelter with host families, leading to overcrowded homes and increasing the risk of the spread of diseases like cholera. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are seeing cases of malaria and COVID-19 and many people have lost access to their treatment for HIV. The conflict has also taken a heavy psychological toll, and MSF is providing much-needed mental health care. People fleeing their homes “find people who have been tortured or horribly injured or who died of hunger and thirst in the jungle,” said MSF medical coordinator Patricia Postigo. “They tell us they cannot get these images out of their minds.”

title: Why Planetary Health Matters to All of Us
description:
At Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), we see how environmental changes impact human health. We know that the most vulnerable people will be the most affected--and we’re already seeing them in our waiting rooms. In this video, MSF medical director Dr. Monica Rull and planetary health coordinator Brian Willett talk about the health consequences of climate change and environmental degradation. "Our health depends upon the wellbeing of the planet, and the wellbeing of the planet depends on how we act," explains Willett. "It is all linked." MSF sees the climate crisis as a public health crisis. We are reaching out to help people who are most at risk, while also working to reduce the environmental impacts of our own aid efforts. Learn more at https://bit.ly/3uHWuhi

description:
At a time of intense global focus on COVID-19 vaccines, join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) for this first event in our three-part webinar series exploring our work on immunization.

title: Iraq: Inside a COVID-19 Ward in Baghdad
description:
Many years of war, beginning with the 2003 US invasion of Iraq, have prepared Baghdad’s hospitals for large influxes of wounded patients. But as COVID-19 began to spread through the city last summer, weaknesses in the overstretched health care system quickly became apparent. Even people with COVID-19 delayed coming in for treatment. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams supported the respiratory care unit of al-Kindi hospital throughout summer 2020. They saw first-hand the increasing needs and how the hospital was unable to cope with the flood of COVID-19 patients in need of close and consistent follow-up. MSF worked with health authorities to add its own COVID-19 treatment ward inside al-Kindi hospital, which opened in September with 24 beds. It has since grown to a 36-bed purpose-built facility. In this video, MSF nurse Amjad Ibrahim shows us a look inside the ward. Read more at https://bit.ly/3dHBRf8

title: Let's Talk Vaccines | Trailer
description:
At a time of intense global focus on COVID-19 vaccines, join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) this spring for a three-part webinar series exploring our work on immunization. We’ll discuss how our medical teams respond to epidemics, provide routine vaccinations amid crisis and conflict, and speak out for equitable access to vaccines. We’ll also look ahead to future opportunities for the development of vaccines that better meet the needs of our patients. MSF experts will draw on their experience to answer your questions about this urgent topic. 

MSF has nearly 50 years of experience delivering lifesaving vaccines in extreme conditions. Whether we’re vaccinating against common diseases like measles or pneumonia, or fighting newer threats like Ebola and COVID-19, we know that vaccines work. These are some of the most effective public health interventions available.

title: Caring for Civilians Wounded by Bombs and Bullets in Hodeidah, Yemen
description:
At Al Salakhanah hospital in Hodeidah, western Yemen, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs an emergency room and inpatient department and provides surgical care. Yemen has been mired in war for six years now and the population in and around Hodeidah has been severely impacted by fighting since 2018. Despite a ceasefire agreement, people continue to be injured and killed by bombings and bullets. “In the emergency room we receive all kinds of cases—Emergency cases like gunshots, accidental trauma and stray bullets, shrapnel from the blasts.” Read more about MSF's work in Yemen at https://bit.ly/37nNsMe​

title: Child Health Impacted by Ongoing Fighting in Hodeidah, Yemen
description:
At Ad Dahi rural hospital in Hodeidah, western Yemen, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provides a range of services including emergency and intensive care, inpatient treatment, and neonatal care. Yemen has been convulsed by war for six years now and the population in and around Hodeidah has been severely impacted by fighting since 2018. Despite a ceasefire agreement, people continue to be injured and killed by bombings and bullets. The health system has largely collapsed, and poverty and a lack transportation prevent many people from reaching the health services that remain functional. Pregnant women often receive no prenatal care and give birth at home to underweight babies who are particularly susceptible to disease. “Meningitis, diarrhea, and severe acute malnutrition with complications are causing the main morbidities [among children],” says Dr. Dhuha Shamsaddin, MSF’s medical activities manager. Read more about MSF's work in Yemen at https://bit.ly/37nNsMe

title: Responding to COVID-19 in Herat, Afghanistan
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has reopened our COVID-19 treatment center in Gazer Ga, in Afghanistan’s Herat province. Initially opened in June 2020, activities were paused when case numbers dropped in September. MSF reopened the treatment center in December, when numbers once again began to rise. Just over two months later admissions for COVID-19 have leveled off at around four per day, but we remain vigilant. After Kabul, Herat is the province most affected by the pandemic in Afghanistan, according to the Ministry of Health. In addition to running the treatment center, MSF also manages the COVID-19 triage unit at Herat Regional Hospital and screens patients for COVID-19 at an MSF clinic in a camp for internally displaced people in Kahdestan. Read more at https://bit.ly/2ZtsVlh

title: 'Catastrophic' Situation for COVID-19 Patients in Brazil's Amazonas State
description:
The health system in the city of Manaus is collapsing due to an overwhelming need for treatment of severe COVID-19 patients in Brazil’s Amazonas state. There are not enough beds, medicines, oxygen, or health staff to treat those needing care in the city or in the surrounding area which relies on Manaus for intensive care services. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières  (MSF) teams are boosting the treatment capacity of health facilities in Manaus and also in the town of Tefé despite a range of challenges. title: Central African Republic: A Healing Journey in Bangui
description:
In December 2020, in the wake of a presidential election, fighting broke out in Central African Republic (CAR) between the government, supported by UN military personnel and foreign troops, and a newly formed coalition of armed groups. Months later tensions continue to run high, and violence has spread to the outskirts of Bangui, the capital. Since mid-December 2020, more than 250 war-wounded people been treated by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Bangui and the provinces. On January 13, 2021, 31 year-old France Beldo became one of them after she was hit by a stray bullet in Bangui. In this video France tells her story of healing at MSF’s SICA hospital and describes how the violence has impacted her community. “If the fighting continues like this, we’ll keep on living in fear,” she says. “It has to stop so that the country can be peaceful again.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3jHhIXw

title: Migrants Abandoned at Italy's Borders: Issifi’s Story
description:
In recent months, the number of migrants and refugees at Italy's northern borders has sharply increased. Even through the winter, people head west across the snow-capped mountains towards France. Many tell stories of humiliation, violence, and harassment. People arrive on foot through the woods and along trails, where some report being beaten and turned back by police. The only thing that keeps them going, despite all they have suffered, is hope for what lies ahead. In mid-December, two teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams traveled to the main transit points along the border to speak with migrants and refugees on the move.

Issifi, originally from Niger, spent some time in Germany and Switzerland, but returned to Italy. He lived on the streets in Bolzano for more than a year until he met Reiner, a farmer who grows organic apples. Reiner invited him to stay on his farm, and Issifi remained there even after apple-picking season was over. “Getting to know his story was important,” says Reiner “It enriched me, and I was struck by his experiences during his journey. None of us can really imagine their suffering and the terrible things they have experienced in the course of their journeys. Yet despite having lived such a hard life, they always have smiles on their faces.”

Find out more at http://bit.ly/3cYVcrV

title: Alarming Mental Health Crisis Among Children Trapped in Greece
description:
More than 15,000 women, men, and children are still trapped in unsafe and humiliating conditions on the Greek islands. As this crisis continues, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mental health teams on Lesbos and Samos are seeing alarming levels of mental health distress among our patients. “Last year, MSF treated 50 children with severe suicidal ideation, or even suicide attempts” says MSF mental health activity manager Katrin Glatz-Brubakk. “It’s really really painful to see these children when they live in conditions where there is absolutely no hope for them.” We have warned repeatedly of the mental health emergency facing refugees and migrants trapped indefinitely in Greece. This emergency continues five months after the fires that destroyed Moria refugee camp on the island of Lesbos, and despite promises from the European Union (EU) that there will never be another Moria. Nevertheless, European states have maintained their harmful policy to contain people on these islands. MSF calls on the EU and Greek authorities to immediately move all asylum seekers, especially the most vulnerable, to safe accommodation. Read more at https://bit.ly/3roNSK2

title: Italy: Migrants Abandoned at the Borders
description:
In recent months, the number of migrants and refugees at Italy's northern borders has sharply increased. Even through the winter, people head west across the snow-capped mountains towards France; many tell stories of how they were repeatedly turned back by the French police. On Italy’s eastern border, people arrive on foot through woods and along trails after traveling the Balkan route, where some report being beaten by Bosnian or Croatian police.

While the overall number of migrants and refugees is lower than it was a few years ago, the humiliation, violence, and harassment continues to take place. The only thing that keeps them going, despite all they have suffered, is hope for what lies ahead.

Assistance from authorities is completely absent in the border cities, so it is left to activists and volunteers to receive people in transit and provide them with humanitarian assistance and medical care, with the support of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). In mid-December, two MSF teams traveled to the main transit points in Ventimiglia, Oulx, Bolzano, and Trieste to speak with migrants and refugees on the move, along with the people trying to help them.

Find out more at https://bit.ly/3aIKh2W

title: Responding to Urgent Medical Needs in South Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo
description:
In the last two years, the unrest in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo has forced thousands of people to flee their homes. Many have found refuge on the other side of the border between North and South Kivu. “We heard that there was peace in Katasomwa, so we decided to come here,” says Justin, a displaced person now living in this remote area of Kalehe Territory, South Kivu. “Since we got here in July, we have not been eating well … And this rain will end up killing us, we are homeless.” Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) sent an emergency team to respond to the most urgent needs. The team focused first on groups with the highest mortality rates, mostly children under 15 and pregnant women. Maternal mortality in the area is very high. MSF teams are also rehabilitating health centers in the area and organizing a vaccination campaign in collaboration with health authorities. Read more at http://bit.ly/3oNVDaH

title: 'Game Changer' Study Shows Insulin Can Remain Stable at Higher Temperatures
description:
A study carried out by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and the University of Geneva Pharmaceutical Department could have a huge impact on the lives of people with diabetes in low-resource settings. Product information for insulin requires that the drug be refrigerated up until the point of use, making access difficult for people living in  warmer parts of the world where having a refrigerator or electricity is not common. At MSF’s project in Dadaab refugee camp in Kenya, people with diabetes, who need at least two injections of insulin per day, need to go to a clinic to receive their shots. Since a curfew was implemented in the camp, people have not been able to receive a second shot in the evening—and hospital admissions have been rising. MSF used temperature data gathered in Dadaab camp for the study, which found that the drug remains stable up to 99 degrees  rather than required 77 degrees. This means that patients in Dadaab and elsewhere can now take their insulin home in cooling containers to self-inject and keep themselves healthy. “This is just giving [patients] back their entitlement in terms of the right to inject their own insulin and lead a more normal life with diabetes,” says Philippa Boule, MSF noncommunicable disease advisor. MSF is calling on the World Health Organization and pharmaceutical companies to adapt their recommendations for the use of insulin. Read more at https://bit.ly/3tp3rDh

title: Southern African Countries See COVID-19 Deaths Mount with No Vaccines in Sight
description:
Several southern African countries are seeing spikes in new COVID-19 cases and deaths, but their health systems have yet to receive any vaccines for the novel coronavirus. Health workers in this region are struggling to treat a surge of patients while a deadly new variant of COVID-19 continues to spread. Countries including Mozambique, Malawi, and Eswatini are completely overwhelmed--unable to immunize frontline health workers and those most vulnerable to the disease. “When vaccines are lacking, priority should be given to vaccinating health professionals and vulnerable people. That was the global agreement,” says Christine Jamet, MSF director of operations. “However, in practice, we see a small number of rich countries monopolizing vaccines, with no regard for lower-income countries that can’t even vaccinate their health care staff.” Hospitals are at capacity and oxygen supplies are low. MSF is calling for COVID-19 vaccines to be distributed equitably worldwide, and for frontline health workers and people at the highest risk of severe illness and death from the disease to be prioritized for immunization. Read more at https://bit.ly/3rthKoP
