title: MSF Supports Key Hospitals During Tigray Crisis
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) began working in key hospitals in eastern and central Tigray in mid-December, providing critical support to a health system shattered by violence since November. While fighting in this region of Ethiopia has driven some 60,000 people across the border into Sudan, hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced within Tigray. Most of them have moved into friends’ and relatives’ homes, creating households of 20-25 people. The impact on the health system has been acute. Before MSF arrived, many of the facilities our teams are now supporting were not functioning, lacking in medicines and staff. These Tigray hospitals are important for treating people in the cities where they are located, but also as referral hospitals for people in remote areas. Access to many remote places is still difficult, but MSF has been able to bring mobile clinics to the outskirts of some cities and even reopen health centers in some rural areas. During these visits, says Albert Viñas, MSF’s emergency coordinator, “it was striking to see a pregnant woman who had been in labor for seven days—we were able to refer her [for care]. People who arrived at the hospital on bicycles from 30 or 35 kilometers away, someone pushing the bicycle with the patient sitting on it.” When the health system stops working, says Viñas, “activities are stopped, such as disease detection or vaccinations. We fear that epidemics will appear.” Read more about MSF's efforts to support Tigray hospitals affected by the violence at https://bit.ly/3t9277u

0:46 Hospitals and health centers are found in poor condition

title: MSF Medical Staff Speak Out on the End of the Global Gag Rule
description:
On January 28, 2021, US President Joe Biden rescinded the Mexico City policy, better known as the Global Gag Rule. This brings to an end four years of this harmful policy that prevented US government funds from reaching any foreign nongovernmental organizations (NGOs) that even speak about abortion to their patients. Since the US is by far the biggest funder of global public health programs, many countries rely on US aid to support health care services. So US policies like the gag rule can have a devastating impact around the world. In fact, the gag rule, which has been implemented by every Republican president—then rescinded by every Democrat—since Ronald Reagan, has never been shown to reduce the number of abortions. By withholding health information and limiting access to essential care, the policy only pushed people with unwanted pregnancies to resort to unsafe abortion methods. The reversal of the Global Gag Rule is great news, but much more will need to be done to mitigate the damage it has caused and to expand access to safe abortion care.

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) does not accept US government funding, so our programs are not directly affected by the Global Gag Rule. However, we see the harmful impacts these types of policies have on limiting access to sexual and reproductive health care. In 2019, MSF treated more than 25,800 women and girls with abortion-related complications, many of which resulted from unsafe attempts to end a pregnancy.  Read more at https://bit.ly/3sZQoIt

title: Presentamos el Kit de Herramientas de PCI de Médicos Sin Fronteras
description:
El impacto devastador de la COVID-19 en los hogares para personas mayores y otros centros de atención colectiva ha evidenciado la necesidad de un mayor apoyo in situ y mejorar la adaptación de medidas de prevención y control de infecciones (PCI). 

Médicos sin Fronteras (MSF) ha respondido a la emergencia actual ofreciendo capacitación práctica en PCI y apoyo en salud mental al personal de los centros de cuidados prolongados en Michigan, Texas,la Nación Navajo y Pueblos. Para incrementar el alcance de estos proyectos, MSF ha creado un kit de material educativo de PCI, diseñado para integrarse fácilmente a los planes de estudio existentes en las escuelas de enfermería, salud pública y trabajo social. Este kit, que está disponible de forma pública, permite así a los estudiantes transmitir sus conocimientos sobre PCI a sus propias comunidades y ayudar al personal clínico y no clínico en los centros de cuidados prolongados a mantenerse seguro y protegido.

El kit de PCI contiene tanto archivos de texto como audiovisuales que enseñan cómo ingresar correctamente a las instalaciones; cómo llevar a cabo evaluaciones siguiendo el sistema de Evaluación de Control de Infecciones y Respuesta (ICAR, por sus siglas en inglés) del CDC; cómo realizar sesiones de capacitación o integrarse en el equipo de enfermería para introducir mejoras. Asimismo, contiene información relevante para mejorar la salud mental y el bienestar del personal que trabaja en primera línea. Una versión abreviada del programa de capacitación puede también utilizarse en hogares para personas mayores u otros espacios de convivencia.

Aprende más sobre el kit de herramientas para el bienestar y la prevención y control de infecciones de MSF en: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/IPCtoolkit-es

Si tiene preguntas o sugerencias, comuníquese con Marina Novack, coordinadora del proyecto de cuidados a largo plazo de MSF-USA: marina.novack@newyork.msf.org

title: Depleted Oxygen Supply in Brazil's Manaus Region Leads to COVID-19 Deaths
description:
Health workers including Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in Brazil’s Amazonas state are struggling to treat an increasing number of COVID-19 patients due to a breakdown in the oxygen supply. MSF is working in the remote towns of São Gabriel da Cachoeira and Tefé and normally refers severe patients to Manaus, the state capital and a regional hub. An overwhelming need for oxygen, however, has left the health system in Manaus unable to meet the demand. “Today we have patients in Tefé and we don’t know for how long we’ll be able to provide oxygen to them, ” says Pierre Van Heddegem, MSF's head of mission in Brazil. “Just this week, three patients died, patients that could have had a chance of survival if we would have been able to refer them to Manaus.” Read more at https://bit.ly/3sIuadS

title: More Aid Needed for Those Displaced in Ethiopia’s Tigray Region
description:
In November 2020, fighting broke out in the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, forcing hundreds of thousands of residents to flee their homes. While some 50,000 people have crossed the border into Sudan as refugees, others remain scattered throughout the Tigray region. Since December, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have been able to reach some of these displaced people with medical care, but we are very concerned for the fate of those we have not reached. “For a big part of the population in Tigray, they are still in areas where there has been hardly any humanitarian assistance provided,” says the head of MSF’s emergency department Karline Kleijer. Before the violence began in Tigray, she says, “there were at least 500,000 people already dependent on assistance in this region.” This is also an area that was hosting a number of refugees from neighboring Eritrea—the fate of those refugees is still unknown. “Our biggest worry for the population, the longer this situation lasts,” says Kleijer, “is how they can access food and what that means for their well-being.” Read more about MSF's efforts to help provide healthcare to thousands of Tigray refugees at https://bit.ly/3nLVjJ7

title: Integrarse en los Centros de Cuidados a Largo Plazo
description:
La práctica de integrarse en un centro de cuidados prolongados permite a los capacitadores ofrecer tutorías suplementarias al personal que requiere apoyo adicional para mejorar sus medidas de Prevención y Control de Infecciones (PCI). En este video, la Dra. Buffy Lloyd-Krejci repasa cómo determinar el cronograma y la escala de las iniciativas de integración. También revisa la importancia de la capacitación basada en evidencia, las evaluaciones a realizar tras el ICAR y porqué es necesario continuar desarrollando las prácticas de PCI por sus beneficios a largo plazo, más allá de su uso para enfrentar los desafíos actuales por la COVID-19.

Esta serie de videos se diseñó para ayudar a los estudiantes a navegar por el kit de protocolos y guías para la prevención y control de infecciones (PCI) creado por Médicos Sin Fronteras (MSF). Los efectos devastadores de la COVID-19 en los hogares para personas mayores y otras instalaciones donde esta grupo etario vive congregada, revelaron la enorme necesidad de un mayor apoyo in situ para poner en práctica de forma correcta las medidas de PCI en estos centros.

MSF ha respondido a esta necesidad brindando capacitaciones en PCI y apoyo para la salud y el bienestar mental del personal en las instalaciones de este tipo en todo Estados Unidos. Para mantener este trabajo, MSF diseñó un kit de herramientas sobre PCI para estudiantes en las escuelas de enfermería, salud pública y trabajo social que les orienta en promover capacitación en PCI en las instalaciones locales de cuidados prolongados. La Dra. Buffy Lloyd-Krejci, gestora de medidas de PCI en Michigan y que trabajó con MSF en hogares para personas mayores durante la pandemia de COVID-19, narra esta guía paso a paso.

Aprende más sobre el kit de herramientas para el bienestar y la prevención y control de infecciones de MSF en: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/IPCtoolkit-es

title: More than 55,000 Refugees from Tigray Seek Safety in Sudan
description:
In early November 2020, refugees from the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia began crossing into neighboring Sudan to seek safety. Now, more than 55,000 people have fled the fighting in Tigray and arrived in Sudan. Most of the refugees are living in official camps that lack adequate shelter, food, water, and other essentials. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing medical care in the camps in Kassala and Gedaref states and at one of the main crossing points into Sudan. Over time, people’s health conditions have deteriorated and MSF medical staff are currently seeing a lot of respiratory tract infections and acute watery diarrhea. We are also concerned about refugees from Tigray with chronic health conditions, such as diabetes and hypertension, who have little access to the medicines they need. On top of the medical concerns, the head of MSF’s emergency department Karline Kleijer says that many refugees are dealing with the psychological repercussions of the violence. “We heard a lot of stories of people being directly exposed to violence, or who witnessed violence of other people,” she says. In addition to having left their entire lives behind, they are also mourning family members and friends who were killed. “We consider mental health as one of the biggest needs in Sudan.” Read more about the assistance needed to address the needs of refugees from the Tigray region at https://bit.ly/3bydUGc

0:14 50,000 people fled from Tigray and are now in Sudan as refugees

title: To All Frontline Workers: We See You
description:
Health care workers across the globe have endured a year of unimaginable challenges. Each and every day, they have selflessly put aside their own exhaustion, grief, fear, or even anger, to serve on the front lines of the COVID-19 response. As 2020 comes to a close, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) doctors and nurses in the United States, Cameroon, and Sierra Leone share personal messages of solidarity to fellow medical staff around the world, speaking frankly about the emotional toll of losing patients, their shared worries and frustrations, and the things that bring them hope and motivation as they face the year ahead.

title: Conducting the ICAR Assessment & Completing the Report
description:
An effective IPC program requires a thorough assessment to help identify what a long-term care facility (LTC) is doing well and how it can make improvements. The CDC Infection Control Assessment and Response (ICAR) tool is a standardized framework used to help LTC facilities prepare and manage COVID-19. In this video, Dr. Buffy Lloyd-Krejci  goes over how to conduct the assessment, prepare a report, and how to share the findings with the LTC administration to establish next steps.  

This series was designed to help students navigate the resources in the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) infection prevention and control tool kit. The devastating effects of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other congregate adult living facilities revealed a long-standing need for increased on-site support to best implement IPC measures in these settings. MSF responded by providing IPC training and mental health and wellness support to facilities across the US. To sustain this work, MSF designed an IPC tool kit for students in schools of nursing, public health, and social work that provides direction on how students can implement IPC training initiatives in local long-term care facilities. Dr. Buffy Lloyd-Krejci, an IPC manager in Michigan who worked with MSF in nursing homes during the COVID-19 pandemic, narrates this step-by-step guide.

Learn more about MSF's IPC training toolkit at: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/IPCtoolkit

description:

title: Thank You for Supporting Health Care Workers in 2020
description:
COVID-19 has changed our lives. And while this pandemic has provoked deep uncertainty and fear, there are also reasons to stay hopeful. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams in more than 70 countries reacted quickly to prepare our medical projects for the threat of COVID-19, to respond directly to this new disease, and to keep other vital health services running despite the unprecedented challenges. We launched over 250 projects; distributed more than 2.3 million hygiene kits, masks, and PPE; offered mental health and wellness support; and provided training on infection prevention and control measures to essential workers. We could not have done this without our supporters.

Thank you for supporting us in 2020. And please continue to care for each other, and care for frontline workers in your communities and around the world by helping slow the spread of COVID-19. Learn more about our response to the pandemic at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/covid19

title: South Africa: Singing for Hope in the Time of COVID-19
description:
Doctors and nurses at Livingstone Hospital in Eastern Cape, South Africa, sang as they wheeled patients recovering from COVID-19 from the critical care ward to the general ward. The public health system in this area had been near the brink of collapse in November due to a shortage of medical staff. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provided support and helped them open a new COVID-19 ward. South Africa is currently facing a resurgence in cases due to the presence of a new variant of the COVID-19 disease. The MSF team in the Eastern Cape is preparing to travel to the Western Cape, where a sharp second wave of infections has filled hospitals in Cape Town to capacity. MSF doctors and nurses will support one of the province’s COVID-19 field hospitals.

title: Mexico-US Border: Migration Can Mean Life or Death
description:
No matter where you come from, seeking safety for yourself and your children is not a crime. However, after failing to protect people who are legally seeking asylum on our southern border for the last year, the US government is now using the COVID-19 pandemic to deny them any access to the asylum process at all. Some 2,200 asylum seekers were living in a makeshift camp in the Mexican city of Matamoros near the US border in March. These are people who have suffered from violence, extortion, or kidnapping and are seeking safety. Many of them had already been waiting for months in danger, living in tents outside with their children, to be called to their asylum hearings. This is due to the Migrant Protection Protocols (MPP), a US immigration program announced in January 2019 that requires many asylum seekers to remain in Mexico to await their hearings, rather than allowing them to wait in safety in the US. Soon after the COVID-19 pandemic arrived in the US, the border was closed and now some 60,000 people waiting in Matamoros and other cities along the border have no information about the status of their asylum requests and when or if they might be able to be heard. This video tells the story of Marcela and her children, asylum seekers running from armed men who have threatened to kidnap or kill them. They are now stranded at the border with no information and no hope. "If we’d stayed, they would have killed us a long time ago," she says. "I don’t want wealth—I want my daughters to be able to study, nothing more, and for us to be in a safe place, where we’re no longer afraid that they’re chasing us." Read more at https://bit.ly/38xnbv5

title: Syria: Displaced People Brace for Another Harsh Winter in Idlib
description:
More than two million displaced people living in northwestern Syria are bracing themselves for an impending winter that will make already harsh living conditions even more unbearable. In recent years, the region has seen multiple waves of mass displacement—between December 2019 and March 2020, fighting in the Idlib region forced one million people to flee, many of whom were already displaced. “As you can see, the situation’s bad,” says Nasr Al-Jaddouh. “You may well ask how I even live in this tent, but I don’t have another option. I fled Hama countryside because of heavy shelling and airstrikes.” To help improve living conditions during winter, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have started distributing winter kits containing warm clothes, tarps, mattresses, and blankets, to more than 14,500 families. Read more at https://bit.ly/2VU8jki

title: COVID-19 Is No Time For Profiteering
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is calling for no patents or profiteering on any tests, treatments, or vaccines used to fight COVID-19. MSF has seen first-hand the impact of scarce supplies and high prices of essential medical tools in our work caring for people with HIV, treating patients with tuberculosis, vaccinating children against pneumonia, and much more. Any patents on the medical tools needed to prevent and treat this new life-threatening disease will mean that only the wealthiest will have access to them. That means the coronavirus pandemic will take much longer to end, and many more people will get sick and die. Pharmaceutical and diagnostic companies must commit to not seek nor enforce patents. If they won’t do the right thing, then governments can take action. Please support the proposal to the World Trade Organization to say #NoCovidMonopolies. Let’s make sure that everyone, everywhere will have access to testing, treatment, and prevention of COVID-19. Learn more at https://www.MSFAccess.org/nopatents

title: Responding to Severe Flooding in South Sudan
description:
More than one million people have been affected by flooding in South Sudan this year, according to the United Nations. In Fangak county, located in the middle of the vast Sudd wetland, floodwaters began engulfing people's homes and farms in July and in some places the waters continue to rise. In late September, more than 3,000 people there were displaced from their homes by the flooding. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams distributed blankets, plastic sheeting and other essential items and are continuing to provide medical care to displaced people and residents of the community. “This year, water reached places that weren’t flooded last year,” says Nyabuok Lony Ruot, the relative of a patient at the MSF hospital in Old Fangak town. “All the crops are in the water. We came to the hospital by canoe.” A lack of roads in Fangak county means that most people travel by foot or by boat. In some places, the high waters make walking for medical care impossible and most people cannot afford to pay for a canoe, so MSF is using its boat as an ambulance. Read more at https://bit.ly/2I2SODk

title: Bringing Care to People Trapped by Violence in Guerrero, Mexico
description:
Pervasive violence in Mexico’s Guerrero state has pushed thousands of families to flee their homes and cut off many people from essential services, including access to medical care. Communities live in fear and isolation while more than 40 armed groups fight for control over territory all around them. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has provided mobile clinic services in Guerrero since 2016. In some places, MSF is the sole provider of health care. “Everyone is deprived of everything—of medicine, of teachers, of everything,” says Pablo Costilla, a community leader and farmer. Many people have seen their communities destroyed and lost loved ones to the fighting. MSF teams also offer mental health care, an essential service in this context. Read more at https://bit.ly/39Cdwpa

title: Caring for people living with HIV/AIDS in Central African Republic
description:
Some 38 million people are living with HIV/AIDS, over two-thirds of them in sub-Saharan Africa. The HIV crisis in Central African Republic (CAR) is particularly acute—fueled by extreme poverty, pervasive violence, a shortage of health facilities and staff, and major barriers to early testing and treatment. HIV remains a leading cause of death in the country. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams offer free medical care and psychological support for people living with HIV, including through community-based groups that make treatment more accessible even in remote areas. Few of the limited number of health facilities here offer HIV testing and care, and many people living with HIV have to make long and often dangerous journeys to find a clinic where services are available. Poor access to information about HIV/AIDS and stigma surrounding the disease add to the deadly obstacles to care. We’re calling for more action to bring free HIV testing and care within reach for everyone who needs it. Read more at https://bit.ly/3mvFCWz

title: COVID-19: More Nursing Home Staff Need IPC Training
description:
The essential workers who clean, cook, and do laundry for the residents of nursing homes in the United States play a critical role in stopping the spread of COVID-19. Yet these environmental services (EVS) staff rarely get the infection prevention and control (IPC) training they need to protect themselves and the vulnerable people they assist day in and day out. This a serious problem, especially during a pandemic that has devastated nursing homes across the country. In response, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) brought in-person IPC training as well as mental health and wellness support to more than 80 long-term care facilities in the US during COVID-19. “(We) do a one-on-one training with EVS staff,” says Kira Smith, MSF nurse manager for IPC who conducted site visits in Houston, Texas. “And that looks like going in and saying, ‘Okay, show me your cleaning practices. Why don't you show me how you clean a room?’ Then based on that, I'll clean the next room and show maybe some different techniques for a higher standard of IPC in cleaning. Then we'll go on to the following room, and she can show me what she learned. We can continue that way, practicing new skills. I can already see that it's making a difference and having an impact.” MSF is reaching out to nursing homes and nursing schools to share the IPC Toolkit, developed to strengthen capacity among frontline workers facing the pandemic. Learn more about MSF's IPC training resources at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/news-stories/story/covid-19-more-nursing-home-staff-need-training-prevent-spread

title: Nursing Home Staff Need Wellness Support During COVID-19 Pandemic
description:
"COVID has had a really huge effect on the personal life and work life of those individuals who work in nursing facilities,” says Perry McAfee, a health and wellness officer for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Houston, Texas. “Many of them have to work long hours—12-, 16-hour shifts, multiple days in a row. That has a huge effect on their wellbeing, their family life, and their work life.” The COVID-19 pandemic has taken a devastating toll on nursing homes in the United States. Elderly residents have been among those most vulnerable to the disease, as have the staff working closely with them. In addition to putting in long hours, staff in these facilities see residents and colleagues fall sick. The nursing staff face burnout and worry about bringing COVID home to their families, or bringing the disease to the residents. In order to support the mental health and wellness of these essential workers, MSF has brought mental health and wellness support to 59 long-term care facilities in the US during the pandemic. “I think mental health support is very much needed in this field altogether,” says Adelia Patterson, the wellness and life enrichment director at Focused Care at Beechnut, a nursing home in Houston. “Especially at times like that, because we're just caregivers at heart. We don't take the time to care for ourselves.” Learn more about MSF's efforts to support nursing home staff during the pandemic at https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/news-stories/story/us-nursing-home-staff-need-wellness-support-during-covid-19-pandemic

title: Let's Talk Access to Vaccines: A Call for Change in the Time of COVID-19
description:
For nearly a year we've been living with the new realities created by the COVID-19 pandemic. Even as scientists and medical professionals are uncovering new facts about the virus, we're still faced with many questions. Once we have an approved effective vaccine, who will have access to it? How much will it cost? How will we adapt to ensure the vaccine makes it to those most in need?  

For more than 20 years, the Access Campaign has worked to change government policies and  pharmaceutical industry practices to ensure that effective drugs, tests, and vaccines are available, affordable, and suitable for the people who need them most. In the time of COVID-19, the whole world is experiencing the consequences of a vaccine and medicines development system that places profits before people. The time for systemic reforms has never been more vital.  

Join Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) for this critical final discussion in our fall Let's Talk webinar series on November 12. We’ll be in conversation with Dana Gill, U.S. policy advisor on access to medicines for MSF-USA and the Access Campaign, and Manuel Martin, medical innovation & access policy advisor for the Access Campaign based in Geneva. Together with our host, MSF-USA executive director Avril Benoît, this expert panel will answer your questions about a COVID-19 vaccine and the road to ensuring access to essential medicines to all in need. 

Read more about MSF's Access Campaign at https://msfaccess.org

title: Racism is a Public Health Crisis
description:
As our Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams responded to COVID-19 in the United States, we saw the impact of longstanding racial disparities in health care. We saw that COVID-19 is disproportionately hurting black, Latinx, and Native American communities. In the US, black and Latinx people have been three times as likely to get COVID-19 as white people and twice as likely to die from it, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Racism is a public health crisis. We all need to work together to confront these challenges. 

Read more about our work responding to COVID-19 in the US at https://bit.ly/3mIpQYb

title: Vaccinating Against Measles in Timbuktu: “Prevention is better than a cure”
description:
Due to insecurity and displacement, vaccination coverage has been low in the region of Timbuktu in Mali for several years. Since February, a number of measles cases have been reported in the area. In September, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), alongside the Ministry of Health, decided to launch a vaccination campaign. The campaign reached over 50,000 children between six months and 14 years. “We say that prevention is better than a cure,” says Mariam Hammadoun Maïga, mother of 16-month-old Amadou, “so it’s better to vaccinate children than to treat them." Read more about MSF’s work in vaccinating against measles in Mali at https://bit.ly/3ouYZ3r

title: Introducing the Doctors Without Borders IPC Tool Kit
description:
In response to the challenges presented by COVID-19, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is reaching out to nursing homes and nursing schools in the United States to share our experience in epidemic response and infection prevention and control (IPC). From the start of the pandemic, MSF teams have worked with hundreds of long-term care facilities across Europe, as well as in Michigan and Texas. In this video, we introduce an adaptable training module available for nursing schools to integrate into their curricula. “Nursing schools are uniquely positioned to provide IPC expertise that can make a tremendous difference in their communities,” says Buffy Lloyd-Krejci, DrPH, who has worked with MSF as an infection prevention and control manager. The pandemic has taken a heavy toll on people living in nursing homes and long-term care centers, and on essential workers in these facilities. In the US, nearly 40 percent of coronavirus deaths have been linked to long-term care facilities—even though they accounted for only 7 percent of the total cases, according to an analysis by The New York Times. While the elderly and immunocompromised are particularly vulnerable to the virus, many long-term care facilities lack adequate training and support for staff on IPC.
 
The IPC Tool Kit is available for download here: https://bit.ly/3otaiJp
 
If you have questions or suggestions, contact Marina Novack, long-term care project coordinator for MSF-USA: marina.novack@newyork.msf.org.

title: Puerto Rico Community Leaders Respond to Larger Impacts of COVID-19
description:
In Puerto Rico, as in much of the world, COVID-19 is compounding the risks facing vulnerable groups. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams here worked with community-based organizations and local health providers to offer medical aid to those who need help the most. Our services included home-based primary care as well as monitoring for COVID-positive patients. At the end of September, MSF handed over medical activities to Puerto Rico Salud (PRS), a local organization formed by four members of our team seeking to carry on this vital work. Rolando Betancourt, who worked with MSF as a nurse and is a cofounder of the new organization, says working with MSF made him more aware of the medical needs among poor and marginalized communities. “We set out to find a way to continue the same work as Doctors Without Borders,” says Betancourt. “Who better than the same staff … who are already trained, and who know the quality of service required?” To find out more about our work in response to the impact of COVID-19 in Puerto Rico, click here https://bit.ly/37OjvX5. To find out more about Puerto Rico Salud, visit puertoricosalud.org/page/about-us

title: Burkina Faso: Mental Health Care for Survivors of Violence
description:
The world’s fastest-growing humanitarian crisis is unfolding in Burkina Faso. Over the past two years, escalating violence by armed groups in the north and east of the country has forced more than one million people to flee their homes. In addition to their physical injuries and ailments, many people also suffer from invisible wounds. Many have been victims of violence, have lost loved ones, or witnessed atrocities. “They may have fear or anxiety or are in permanent stress,” says Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) psychologist Issaka Dahila. To ease the psychological suffering of people affected by the conflict, MSF teams started mental health activities in Burkina Faso’s Eastern region at the end of 2019. This year, between July and September alone, 128 people attended individual consultations and 4,391 people participated in group mental health sessions with MSF. Read more at https://bit.ly/35hP34p

title: Nursing Home Staff Face Heightened Stress and Grief During COVID-19
description:
The impact of COVID-19 on nursing homes in the US has taken a significant toll on the dedicated staff who work in these facilities. “We were overworked, trying to do all the right things, trying to care for these residents to the best of your ability with the little strength you had at that time,” says Adelia Patterson, wellness and life enrichment director at Focused Care at Beechnut nursing home in Houston, Texas. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have provided training and support for overwhelmed nursing home staff in the US during a time of acute emotional stress and grief. Tiffany Bell, who works at a long-term care facility in Roseville, Michigan, says, “Even after COVID, we're going to need some type of therapy or counseling because it just has done so much damage to us emotionally.” MSF has provided mental health and wellness training to more than 59 long-term care facilities in the US this year in response to the pandemic. Read more about MSF's efforts to support nursing home staff who are dealing with stress management during the pandemic at https://bit.ly/2SVklZl

title: Welcome Back: A Documentary about Living in Liberia with Mental Illness and Epilepsy
description:
In Liberia, people living with mental illness or epilepsy face a dire lack of knowledge about the diseases, as well as resources for care. Many are stigmatized, and when spiritual interventions or traditional medicine don’t work, people can be rejected from family and society. “Imagine someone is coming down with mental condition in a family that has not heard about mental conditions before,” says Abraham Kollie, a psychosocial community worker for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). “Can you imagine that? They will go straight to seek solutions elsewhere, and not even think about coming to the clinic.“ 

Although epilepsy is classified as a neurological, rather than a mental health disorder, the two are treated within the same program in Liberia. “In our community and in Liberia, a lot of our people, even educated people, back the belief that epilepsy is contagious and that it can be transferred from one person to another,” says Kollie. “So we have a lot of work to do.”   

In the last 30 years, Liberians have endured two civil wars and an Ebola epidemic that claimed thousands of lives in the region, including a disproportionate number of health workers. Like many low-resource countries, Liberia has limited services for people with mental health disorders, with one psychiatric hospital and only two psychiatrists. However, the Ministry of Health has worked with MSF and other organizations to improve its strategy for delivering mental health care at the community level. Since this documentary was made, COVID-19 has caused some setbacks to this progress, socially isolating patients and disrupting treatment in some cases. MSF staff have had to start working differently to reach the most vulnerable patients and get them back on track.

This film introduces viewers to patients dealing with epilepsy and mental health conditions who are fighting to get their normal lives back. Find out more about what's happening in Liberia here: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/countries/liberia

title: Survivor of COVID-19 in Tamaulipas, Mexico, is Joyful
description:
When Juan José was admitted to the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) COVID-19 treatment center in Matamoros, in Mexico’s Tamaulipas state, he was in severe condition. “I was nervous, scared, and worried when I arrived,” he says. “One day here, two, three—being in a situation like this makes me think about my life.” As Juan José received medical treatment and started to recover, both he and his family also received psychosocial care from MSF psychologists to help them deal with fear and stress caused by the disease. “I want to tell you from the bottom of my heart that [MSF's] humanitarian work is very important,” says Juan José. “Thanks to that, I will change my life, my habits. I will improve as a person and as a human being.” MSF is now closing its activities in Matamoros and in Reynosa, also in Tamaulipas state, because the numbers of new cases are decreasing. In three-and-a-half months, our teams provided medical and mental health care to 194 COVID-19 patients and their families. Read more here: https://bit.ly/3lrW5tN

title: Cuidando a Las Comunidades Vulnerables al COVID-19 en Puerto Rico
description:
El 30 de septiembre, Médicos Sin Fronteras/ Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) completó sus actividades de respuesta ante la emergencia de COVID-19 en Puerto Rico, después de cuatro meses brindando asistencia medica humanitaria a algunas de las comunidades más vulnerables de la isla. “MSF logró impactar a comunidades que han sido marginadas en Puerto Rico por mucho tiempo, dijo la enfermera Carla, que dirigió el programa de monitoreo de MSF para pacientes positivos con COVID. Carla  es una de los cuatros miembros de el equipo de MSF en Puerto Rico que han comenzado su propia organización de ayuda médica, Puerto Rico Salud (PRS), para continuar brindando atención médica a personas que no tienen acceso a servicios medicos. En cuatros meses, el equipo médico de MSF atendió a más de 1.200 pacientes, principalmente adultos mayores padeciendo de condiciones crónicas como diabetes e hipertensión. Nosotros también ayudamos a distribuir casi 30.000 equipos de protección personal (EPP), proporcionamos  5.000 kits de higiene a personas sin hogar y otros personas que viven  en comunidades pobres o aisladas, y facilitamos formaciones acerca del control de prevencion de infecciones (CPI) para los trabajadores de la salud primera linea  en 22 instalaciones. Todo este trabajo fue hecho en  colaboración con organizaciones comunitarias y proveedores de salud locales. Leé más en https://bit.ly/3jRjBju

title: Caring for Communities Vulnerable to COVID-19 in Puerto Rico
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) completed its COVID-19 emergency response activities in Puerto Rico on September 30 after four months providing medical and humanitarian assistance to some of the most vulnerable communities on the island. “[MSF] managed to impact communities that have been marginalized in Puerto Rico for a long time,” says nurse Carla, who managed MSF’s monitoring program for patients who tested positive for the disease. Carla is one of four MSF staff who have started their own medical aid organization, Puerto Rico Salud (PRS), to continue providing health care to people who lack access to services. In the span of four months, the MSF medical team saw more than 1,200 patients, mostly older adults suffering from chronic conditions like diabetes and hypertension. We also helped distribute nearly 30,000 items of personal protective equipment, provided 5,000 hygiene kits to homeless people and others living in poor or isolated communities, and conducted infection prevention training to staff at 22 facilities. All of this work was done in close collaboration with community-based organizations and local health providers. Read more about MSF's efforts to combat the effects of COVID-19 in Puerto Rico at https://bit.ly/34zeePV

title: Indigenous Leader in Brazil Survives COVID-19, Recalls First Meeting MSF 30 Years Ago
description:
When Jacir de Souza, an indigenous Macuxi leader in Brazil's Roraima state, was treated for COVID-19, it was not his first encounter with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). In the early 1990s, MSF came to de Souza’s community in the Amazon region as part of the response to a malaria epidemic. “They said, ‘We're going to help. We invited indigenous people from all over Roraima to be trained as lab technicians and microscopists,’” de Souza remembers. Many of the people MSF trained some 30 years ago continue to work in their communities to this day. “There was malaria throughout the state, and then [with the work] it was gone. It was really over!” During the COVID-19 pandemic, MSF has focused on the most vulnerable people in Brazil, including those in indigenous communities which often lack access to medical care. Our teams worked in Roraima state's Boa Vista field hospital, where de Souza received treatment and recovered, from June to September this year. Unfortunately, others close to him did not survive. “I did not expect it would be such a tough disease,” he says. “I lost my younger brother, I lost my mother-in-law, I lost my aunt. I don't know when this disease will go away.“ Read more: https://bit.ly/2G4Lgza

title: On Safe Abortion Day, Let's Recognize that Safe Abortion is Health Care
description:
Right now, all over the world, our teams are seeing women and girls cut off from the essential health services they need due to the devastating secondary effects of the COVID-19 pandemic—including closures of health facilities, cuts in services, and supply shortages. Contraception and safe abortion care are rarely recognized as essential, even though they help prevent one of the biggest causes of maternal mortality: unsafe abortion. Every day, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams treat women and girls who've had to resort to unsafe methods to terminate pregnancy because they had no access to proper care. "During these extraordinary times, it's even more critical that women and girls have access to the health services that they need," says Dr. Manisha Kumar, head of MSF's task force for safe abortion care. Our teams around the world are working hard to keep essential programs for women and girls running. "In some places, this means giving women longer refills of their birth control pills to avoid unnecessary visits to the clinic. And in other places, this means working with community health workers and local women's groups to provide abortion medications in the community," says Dr. Kumar. Governments, health systems, and providers must ensure that these services remain open and accessible to women and girls. Contraception and safe abortion care are essential health care, during COVID-19 and always. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/safe-abortion

title: Responding to Surge of COVID-19 Cases in NW Syria
description:
The number of people with confirmed cases of COVID-19 is now ten times higher than it was just a month ago in northwest Syria. More than two million people in this area, which includes Idlib and Aleppo governates, have been displaced by the war in Syria. Most of them are living in overcrowded camps with limited access to water and poor sanitation. Their living conditions make infection prevention and control measures like physical distancing and handwashing extremely difficult. “Since the camps are considered to be high-risk areas, MSF launched an emergency intervention,” says Osama, a logistician with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). Our teams have helped distribute more than 63,000 hygiene kits to families staying in these camps since April while also helping health facilities to screen patients for suspected COVID-19. Read more: https://bit.ly/3kLPD0z

title: EU Migration Pact: No More Lies
description:
Today, the European Commission announced a new Migration Pact promising a “fresh start” to live up to European values while addressing the challenges facing migrants and refugees. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is saying loud and clear to European leaders that a fresh start on migration can only begin with radical change. No more containment camps at Europe’s borders. No more violence by security forces. No more abandoning people at sea. No more deals to send people fleeing violence back to unsafe countries. The announcement of the new migration pact comes soon after fires destroyed Greece’s Moria refugee camp, the largest refugee camp in Europe. The fires displaced thousands of migrants and asylum-seekers from an overcrowded and dangerous camp, making them homeless once again. MSF has repeatedly warned of the dangers in Moria camp, as almost five years of trapping people in these conditions can only lead to despair and tensions. We have been calling for these people to be evacuated to a safe place on the mainland or to other European countries. Instead, a new camp is under construction. Raise your voice and tell European leaders to stop these cruel policies: sign the petition at https://www.change.org/p/eu-commission-fire-moria-camp-call-for-urgent-evacuation-and-radical-change

title: Reaching Out to Indigenous People in Brazil Hit Hard by COVID-19
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are responding to COVID-19 in the central Brazilian state of Mato Grosso do Sul, home to indigenous communities that are disproportionately affected by the pandemic. “When it arrived, it arrived in full force,” says Alcery Marques Gabriel, a local indigenous leader from the Terena tribe, recalling the start of the coronavirus outbreak. “We lost elders who carried our history. Now what?” Indigenous communities are among the most vulnerable to the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil. They have historically been left out of the health care system and often must travel long distances to access basic services. They also suffer from a high prevalence of chronic diseases. MSF teams work in 11 indigenous villages in the Aquidauana region, provide support for the local hospital, and conduct mobile home visits focusing on prevention, diagnosis, and treatment for COVID-19. title: Thanking All Health Workers on World Patient Safety Day 2020
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is marking World Patient Safety Day with a big shout out to thank our staff and all health workers around the world who care for patients every day. The World Health Organization recognizes this day as an opportunity to highlight the need to provide safe, high-quality medical care as a global health priority. Providing care safely means taking steps to protect patients, as well as the staff who look after them. This is especially true during the COVID-19 pandemic. If we can’t keep health workers safe, then they and their patients will be at risk. Every day, MSF works hard to keep our staff protected. We ensure health workers have the personal protective equipment they need, such as gloves, masks, goggles and gowns. Rigorous infection prevention and control (IPC) measures also dramatically reduce risks. Read more at https://bit.ly/2E9IkQz

title: Refugees and Asylum Seekers Need to be Evacuated from Lesbos, Greece
description:
After a series of fires destroyed Moria refugee camp earlier this month, thousands of people have been forced to sleep in the streets with almost no humanitarian assistance. Greece and the European Union (EU) are trying to reinforce their dangerous containment policy, which would keep people trapped on Lesbos island in a new camp currently under construction. “What people need and [what] people demand is not to be put in another camp,” said Francisca Bohle Carbonell, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) nursing activity manager. “What people need and demand, and what we believe in too, is that people must be evacuated. People need to be put in a safe accommodation in Greece or in other European states.” MSF is calling on authorities in Greece and the EU to stop efforts to rebuild a new system of containment on Lesbos and to end the cycle of suffering on the Greek islands. MSF teams on the Greek islands have been treating people harmed by these inhumane policies for the past five years. Thousands of men, women, and children who fled extreme violence and poverty in search of safety have been pushed beyond their limits, with severe consequences for their physical and mental health. To sign a petition calling on European leaders to act now to evacuate these people whose lives and health are at risk, visit https://bit.ly/2ZLPuC2. To find out more about MSF’s work in Moria camp, visit https://bit.ly/2HaNNrD.

title: Fires Destroy Moria Refugee Camp in Greece
description:
Fires broke out and spread throughout Moria refugee camp on the Greek island of Lesbos on September 8. There were no reports of fatalities, but the camp, which was already overcrowded and dangerous, was almost completely burned down. The following day, more fires were ignited inside the camp, as we see in this video. The blazes again sent people running for safety in all directions, including many children. “People need to be evacuated right now,” said Faris Al-Jawad, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) communications manager, as he stood by the MSF clinic with the camp burning behind him. “This can’t go on any longer—evacuation of all people to safe accommodation on the mainland or other EU states.”  Some 12,000 people, most of them fleeing persecution and violence in their home countries and seeking safety in the EU, have been forced to remain for years in the camp, where hygiene conditions are abominable and, with COVID-19 cases now confirmed inside the camp, social distancing is impossible. Read more: https://bit.ly/2RfCf8h

title: Let's Talk COVID-19: The Road Ahead
description:
Six months after COVID-19 was declared a global pandemic, the crisis still rages on. There have been more than 24 million confirmed cases and over 821,000 deaths due to the coronavirus, and many more losses as health systems struggle to cope with the demands. In this final episode of our Let’s Talk COVID-19 summer event series, we’ll discuss where we go from here—what challenges and opportunities lie ahead.  

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are responding to COVID-19 in more than 70 countries, while maintaining other essential health services. We’re learning how to adapt to the evolving needs—from dealing with supply shortages to supporting essential workers to strengthening public health promotion. MSF teams have been working with local health authorities and community groups in the US and around the world to help slow the spread of the disease. We’re also taking action to ensure that any tests, treatments, and future vaccines for COVID-19 are safe, affordable, and available for all. 

Join us on Thursday, September 3, for the conclusion of our eight-part summer series. In this episode, we welcome back Kate White, medical technical lead for MSF’s COVID-19 response based in Amsterdam, and Dr. Matt Coldiron, MSF physician and epidemiologist. Together with our host, MSF-USA executive director Avril Benoît, this expert panel will answer your questions about the future of the pandemic.

title: After First COVID-19 Case in Moria Refugee Camp, Greece Imposes Dangerous Quarantine
description:
After the first case of COVID-19 was confirmed in Moria refugee camp on September 2, Greek officials have imposed a quarantine that prevents anyone from entering or leaving the camp. This effectively traps people in dangerous conditions. The site is extremely overcrowded, holding 13,000 people in a space designed for 3,000. For months, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and others have been calling for the evacuation of all residents of the camp, located on the island of Lesbos. “Absolutely no one can keep social distance,” says Caroline Willemen, MSF project coordinator. “There are not enough water and sanitation facilities for people to wash their hands on a regular basis.” Most of the people living in the camp are migrants, refugees, and asylum seekers trying to find safety in Europe. More than 200 of them have been identified as particularly at risk for COVID-19 due to their age or underlying medical conditions. Read more at https://bit.ly/31XXGB0

title: Puerto Rico: Fuertes Redes Comunitarias Apoyan La Respuesta a COVID-19
description:
Los equipos de Médicos Sin Fronteras (MSF) están respondiendo al COVID-19 en Puerto Rico, trabajando en colaboración con organizaciones comunitarias. Brindamos ayuda médica y información de salud a grupos de riesgo, incluyendo personas en situación de calle, personas con dependencia a drogas, y ancianos.

“La red en la isla ya es muy fuerte,” dice Yoruba Mitchell, gestora de actividades de promocion de la salud  para MSF. "Entonces, lo que hicimos fue básicamente venir y apoyar a esas redes existentes con las habilidades que pudimos contribuir, con nuestra experiencia trabajando en brotes y brindando capacitación y equipo." Debido a que los casos de coronavirus continúan aumentando, MSF ha ampliado su respuestaen la isla, brindando consultas de atención primaria en hogares y clínicas a personas sin acceso a servicios médicos, y realiza seguimiento de   síntomas a pacientes con COVID-19. title: MSF and Sea-Watch Launch Rescue Operations in the Mediterranean
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has relaunched lifesaving search and rescue operations in the Central Mediterranean Sea, in partnership with the nongovernmental organization Sea-Watch. During the first week of operations, our teams onboard the vessel Sea-Watch 4 rescued more than 200 people in a 48-hour period from August 22-24. As European Union governments have turned a blind eye to the tragedy that continues to unfold off the coast of Libya, organizations like MSF and Sea-Watch have become the only hope for survival for many migrants and refugees. Men, women, and children fleeing extreme violence, persecution, and poverty in their home countries are routinely caught and held in inhumane detention centers in Libya. If they can escape, many board dangerous, non-seaworthy vessels in an attempt to reach safety in Europe. For many, the likelihood of death at sea is preferable to the horrific conditions in Libya. "All of us, we are deciding to die in the Mediterranean rather than to live in Libya or to be in prison in Libya," says Kemo Kebbeh, a man who was rescued in a previous MSF search and rescue operation in 2019. EU governments are supporting the Libyan Coast Guard to intercept people fleeing for their lives and return them to Libya. More than 6,000 people have been returned so far this year—forced back to face an endless cycle of torture, detention, and abuse. Read more: https://bit.ly/3gtSDMn

title: Three Years after the Exodus, the Rohingya Face Even More Uncertainty
description:
Three years ago, starting on August 25, 2017, Myanmar security forces launched a campaign of targeted violence that ultimately drove more than 700,000 Rohingya people out of their homes in Rakhine state and across the border into neighboring Bangladesh. Many of these refugees lost family members and friends during the attacks, saw their homes burned, and witnessed unthinkable atrocities. When they arrived at the camps in Cox’s Bazar, the refugees joined some 200,000 others who had fled previous attacks and were still living in precarious conditions. After three years, conditions in the world’s largest refugee settlement have barely improved, and people are forced to live in overcrowded shelters. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) pediatrician Ferdyoli Porcel says poor living conditions in the camps makes this community more vulnerable to the spread of disease, including skin infections, parasite infections, respiratory infections, and severe pneumonia. Since COVID-19 arrived in the camps in May, the Rohingya have faced even more challenges: fewer medical personnel and services, restricted movements, and stigma in the community around the new disease, which makes people afraid to come for care. With no sense of when they will be able to safely return to their country, many Rohingya people feel like their lives are on hold. Read more: https://bit.ly/2QlGXAX

title: Puerto Rico COVID-19 Response Supported by Strong Community Networks
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are responding to COVID-19 in Puerto Rico by working in collaboration with community-based organizations. We’re providing medical aid and health information to at-risk groups, including homeless people, people who use drugs, and the elderly. “The network on the island is already so strong” says Yoruba Mitchell, MSF health promotion manager. “So what we did was basically come in and support those existing networks with the skills that we were able to contribute, with our experience working in outbreaks, and providing trainings and equipment.” As the number of COVID-19 cases is on the rise in Puerto Rico, MSF has expanded its activities on the island, providing primary care consultations in homes and clinics to people with no access to medical services and monitoring the symptoms of COVID-19 patients. Read more about MSF's response to the coronavirus in Puerto Rico at https://bit.ly/2CLC7cV

title: Misinformation & Coronavirus: Fighting Myths and Rumors About COVID-19
description:
In this episode of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) webcast series “Let’s Talk COVID-19,” we look at the impact of rumors and myths about COVID-19. Guest host Sandrine Tiller, lead for a new MSF project on misinformation and disinformation, talks with Luz Saavedra, head of mission for MSF in Haiti; Thiaba Anais Fame, MSF regional advisor for humanitarian anthropology, health promotion, and community engagement based in Senegal; and Sabrina Rubli, MSF health promotion manager in Democratic Republic of Congo. Our panelists discuss how MSF is working with communities around the world to stop the spread of coronavirus misinformation and protect public health.

title: "Housing is health care," How COVID-19 is Hurting Homeless New Yorkers
description:
When COVID-19 hit New York City, people were told to stay at home and practice social distancing, but homeless New Yorkers had few safe options. The COVID-19 mortality rate for people staying in homeless shelters is 67% higher than for New Yorkers citywide, according to Coalition for the Homeless, a direct action and advocacy organization. Many people living on the streets were afraid to go to a shelter, and there were suddenly more people who were homeless or housing insecure due to the economic impact of the pandemic. “There was a big surge in need on the streets,” says Dave Giffen, executive director of Coalition for the Homeless. “We just had to ramp up those operations very quickly. We really would not have been able to do so without the help of Doctors Without Borders because there were so many needs that we weren't prepared on our own to meet, like the need for showers and toilets and PPE [personal protective equipment].” Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontiéres (MSF) helped provide showers, portable toilets, handwashing stations, hygiene kits, clothing, and other essentials for people in Midtown Manhattan and Harlem. Giffen says that COVID-19 has exposed deep systemic problems in the way the city responds to homelessness. “We don't want to go back to normal. Normal was terrible,” he says. “Our only hope now is that seeing how this has played out adds more fuel to the fire to solve these problems on a systemic level.” To find out more about MSF's work supporting people who are homeless or housing insecure during COVID-19, visit https://bit.ly/320JCFJ.

title: Beirut Explosion Aftermath: "I have never witnessed something of this scale"
description:
In August 2020, Lebanon’s capital, Beirut, was rocked by a massive explosion that killed more than 150 people and left more than 5,000 injured. Krystel Moussalli, an epidemiologist with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontiéres (MSF), was inside the MSF building in Beirut when it happened. The walls were shaking, she said, “and the roof collapsing, and the voices of the people shouting in the streets, and the noise of broken glass. There were feelings of total shock, pain, loss, confusion.” Within days of the explosion, MSF teams were donating medical supplies to organizations including the Lebanese Red Cross and going to door to door to assess people's medical needs. We are currently investigating how best to provide support to the medical system during this extremely tumultuous time. “You hear of collapsed hospitals,” says Moussalli, “hospitals that were totally destroyed, that had to stop their activities, that had to evacuate their patients. And also, people's houses, partly or totally destroyed. People have their lives that have changed as of today, as of this minute.” Read more about the Beirut explosion aftermath: https://bit.ly/2PGqN4K​

title: Raising Awareness About COVID-19 in Ségou, Mali
description:
In Ségou, central Mali, people are contending with the COVID-19 pandemic on top of the effects of the armed conflict that has plagued the country since 2012. Although the number of infected people is relatively low—2,552 confirmed cases so far—the virus remains a threat. Dedicated staff like Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) infection prevention and control supervisor Souleymane Diarra are working to help people understand the importance of mask-wearing, social-distancing, and hand washing. “Sometimes we have patients who refuse to be hospitalized,” he says. “And there are patients who refuse to wear a mask when they’re in hospital. …But after explaining the illness, we have managed to raise awareness among most of the people.” Read more: https://bit.ly/33E9Ekb

title: Coronavirus in Michigan Nursing Homes: Supporting Staff and Residents
description:
The COVID-19 pandemic has taken a disproportionately heavy toll on elderly people living in long-term care facilities, with more than 40 percent of all coronavirus deaths in the US occurring in nursing homes. In Michigan, where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have worked for the past two months, nursing homes have experienced a significant impact from the effects of coronavirus. Essential staff in these facilities play a critical role in preventing the spread of COVID-19, but they’re at risk themselves—and the coronavirus is not the only threat. Nursing home residents and frontline workers alike face extremely high levels of stress and grief as they struggle to respond to the pandemic. “We were terrified, but we had 100 souls counting on us and we couldn't just walk away and lock ourselves in our home like everybody else was told to do,” said Connie Flanigan, director of nursing at Advantage Wayne in Michigan. “We had to figure out a way to get out here and take care of these souls.” MSF worked in Detroit to support and empower staff and residents at nursing homes and adult foster care facilities with on-site training, tailored guidance on improving infection prevention and control practices, and wellness workshops. Read more about MSF's work to curb the spread of coronvirus in Michigan at https://bit.ly/2DmYN3B

title: MSF Reaches Out After Massive Explosion in Beirut, Lebanon
description:
A massive explosion shook the Lebanese capital, Beirut, on August 4, killing more than 100 people and leaving more than 4,000 injured. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontiéres (MSF) teams stand in solidarity with colleagues in Lebanon who are responding to this emergency. title: Helping Seniors in New York During COVID-19: "It Takes a Village"
description:
Elderly and homeless people are among the most vulnerable to COVID-19 in New York City and around the world. During the pandemic, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has worked with Project FIND, an elder services agency in New York that provides housing and social services to older adults. MSF supported Project FIND’s efforts to keep their facilities safe from the coronavirus in New York. The organization runs three residential buildings and four senior centers in the city, manages a homeless in-reach program with shower services, and provides case management services, including psychiatric and medical care. These services have continued throughout the pandemic—and are now more important than ever. "We don't always know who is homeless. And part of that is because they have access to services like this," says Mark Jennings, associate executive director of Project FIND. "For them to have dignity and to have work. Being able to take a shower in the morning—so that when I do sit on the train, people don't run away from me. And people treat me as if I exist, that I'm not invisible. That's why they come here." Read more about MSF's COVID-19 activities in New York at https://bit.ly/2TPTsGJ

title: COVID-19: Supporting Nursing Homes in Michigan
description:
Older adults living in assisted living facilities, like nursing homes and adult foster care facilities, are accounting for the majority of deaths from COVID-19 because of their age and underlying medical conditions. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working in nursing homes in Michigan to help limit and stop the spread of the coronavirus in these facilities. MSF teams are offering in-person infection prevention and control training, technical support, and stress management care to staff and residents.
 
In this video we hear from MSF Infection Prevention and Control Manager, Dr. Buffy Lloyd-Krejci, “What’s different about what MSF is doing is, we’re actually going into the facilities. We’re going on-site. We’re spending time with the people.” Teams are also providing psychological support for nursing home staff. Read more at https://bit.ly/3jISfMR

description:

title: Asylum Seekers Stranded at the US Border Face COVID-19 in Matamoros, Mexico
description:
More than 2,000 asylum seekers sheltering in a camp in Matamoros, at the Mexican border with Texas, are now dealing with even more fear and uncertainty as the number of COVID-19 cases rises in Mexico and the government fails to take decisive action. These people are living in tents packed closely together, unable to practice social distancing and with little access to water and sanitation or routine medical care, let alone COVID-19 services. Meanwhile, the US closed its border with Mexico and cut off access to the asylum process in March. In response, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has increased activities in the Matamoros camp, providing mental health and medical services and health information about COVID-19. “People are responding positively to the advice and the infection prevention measures we bring,” says health promoter Ismael López. MSF is calling on the Mexican government to find safe solutions for vulnerable people at its border and the US to end its harmful practice of denying protection to people fleeing extreme violence in their countries. Read more: https://bit.ly/2CudgKA

title: Fighting COVID-19 in Brownsville, Brooklyn: A Community Based Approach
description:
Brownsville, Brooklyn is among the New York City neighborhoods hardest hit by the coronavirus. This comes as no surprise to local activists, who have long witnessed the disproportionately heavy toll of death and disease on communities of color. Black and Latino people make up about 95 percent of the population here. Nationwide, these communities have been three times as likely to get COVID-19 as white people and twice as likely to die from it, according to recent data from the US Centers for Disease Control. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) partnered with the Brownsville Multi-Service Family Health Center (BMS) to run a Brownsville, Brookyln, COVID-19 testing facility during the first wave of the pandemic. Providing access to testing has been crucial but came with serious obstacles. "Some of the challenges we face are perceptions that are historical," says Renee Muir, director of development and community relations at BMS, "that there's a deliberate infection plan that's happening, and it's population control, so don't go get tested." Infamous cases of abuse like the Tuskegee experiment, in which some 400 black men with syphilis were denied treatment for decades as part of a federally funded study, have eroded community trust in the medical system. BMS works at the grassroots level to address the questions people have about the coronavirus in Brownsville, Brooklyn, and eliminate barriers to care. They also respond to an array of related needs—from education to nutrition. Muir says that the pandemic is a wake-up call for health providers to address the underlying conditions that contribute to racial disparities in health care. Read more about COVID-19 here: https://bit.ly/2CudgKA Read more about Brownsville Multi-Service Family Health Center (BMS) here: http://bmsfhc.org

title: Refugees Evicted and Left Homeless in Athens, Greece
description:
Amid the chaos of the COVID-19 pandemic in Athens, Greece, refugees are being evicted from their homes with nowhere to go. As the Greek Ministry of Migration and Asylum began executing its plan to evict more than 11,000 recognized refugees, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is already seeing some of our most at-risk patients left homeless without any assistance. “We have a lot of vulnerable people with very severe health problems," says MSF's Dr. Luai Tayeh, "and they are in danger of being evicted from their homes without any shelter, without meals, without anything.” MSF is calling on the Greek government to identify housing solutions for refugees, to protect the most vulnerable people, and to stop evictions now. Read more at https://bit.ly/3enT4Hi

title: As COVID-19 Cases Climb in Yemen, Fear Keeps People from Care
description:
In June, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) began providing hands-on clinical support at a second COVID-19 treatment center in in Sana’a, Yemen, at Sheikh Zayed hospital. But despite indicators of a large number of cases in the area, relatively few people are coming to the hospital for care. Many Yemenis are not seeking treatment for COVID-19 symptoms because they fear contracting the virus in hospitals. Rumors about patient mistreatment at health facilities have also fostered fear and stigma. Some people wait at home until they become extremely ill, said Roger Gutiérrez, MSF’s head of emergency programs. “When they arrive here, it is very late and it is very difficult for us to intervene.” Read more at https://bit.ly/2OgOiAs

title: Let’s talk COVID-19: Protecting Women and Girls from the Worst Effects of the Pandemic
description:
In this video, Avril Benoît, executive director of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières in the US, talks with Dr. Manisha Kumar, a family medicine doctor and head of the MSF task force on safe abortion care; and Dr. Maura Emelina Lainez Vaquiz, a medical doctor working with MSF in Choloma, Honduras which has has been hit hard by COVID-19. Our project in Choloma includes support for a mother and child clinic, where we offer family planning, prenatal and postnatal consultations, psychosocial support for victims of violence, including sexual violence, as well as assist deliveries. The two discuss the potentially catastrophic secondary impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on the health of women and girls around the world.
 
This video was webcast live by MSF as part of our series “Let’s talk COVID-19: MSF responds to a pandemic.” This summer, join MSF aid workers and medical experts every other Thursday at 1:00 p.m. ET for answers to your questions about the humanitarian impacts of COVID-19. Tune in and join the live discussion at https://bit.ly/3802pDl

title: 10th Ebola Outbreak in DRC Declared Over (June 2020 Update)
description:
On June 25, 2020, the government of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) declared the country's tenth outbreak of Ebola over. With 3,470 cases and 2,287 deaths it was the country's largest ever and the second-largest on record anywhere, after the West Africa outbreak of 2014-2016. The last recovered Ebola patient was discharged from the Beni Ebola treatment center in North Kivu province on May 14, and, after no new reported cases for 42 consecutive days (which is twice the length of the disease's incubation period), the outbreak was officially declared over. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams had been working alongside the Ministry of Health to respond to the Ebola outbreak in the northeast of the country since 2018, and in this video our staff at projects across DRC celebrate the news. While we are hugely relieved, our teams remain vigilant—the virus is still present in western DRC’s Equateur province, and just one new case could trigger a new outbreak. Read more details about the tenth Ebola outbreak in DRC at https://bit.ly/3in8qik

title: COVID-19: Dealing with Oxygen Supply Challenges
description:
Patients who are seriously ill with COVID-19 cannot be treated without oxygen, but providing enough oxygen to meet the needs has been a major challenge from the beginning. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is responding to the coronavirus pandemic in more than 70 countries around the world and working to provide oxygen for our patients with COVID-19. At our COVID-19 project in Aden, Yemen, our teams use 250 bottles of oxygen a day, a huge but necessary expense for treating our patients. A more cost-effective and efficient alternative—oxygen plants—are in use or on the way to a number of MSF projects, including in Bangladesh, Burkina Faso, and Haiti. Our team in Aden is also awaiting delivery of an oxygen plant that can provide enough oxygen for 30 patients at a time. But COVID-19 has caused additional challenges: the machines are in high demand not readily available, and when they are sent from China, they must be quarantined at every stage of the shipping process. Providing oxygen will continue to be a major challenge for our COVID-19 projects around the world. Read more about MSF's global COVID-19 response at  https://bit.ly/3ghX4dO

title: Contraception and Safe Abortion Care Are Essential Health Care, During COVID-19 and Always
description:
Right now, all over the world, our teams are seeing women and girls cut off from the essential health services they need due to the devastating secondary effects of the COVID-19 pandemic—including closures of health facilities, cuts in services, and supply shortages. Contraception and safe abortion care are rarely recognized as essential, even though they help prevent one of the biggest causes of maternal mortality: unsafe abortion. Every day, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams treat women and girls who've had to resort to unsafe methods to terminate pregnancy because they had no access to proper care. "During these extraordinary times, it's even more critical that women and girls have access to the health services that they need," says Dr. Manisha Kumar, head of MSF's task force for safe abortion care. Our teams around the world are working hard to keep essential programs for women and girls running. "In some places, this means giving women longer refills of their birth control pills to avoid unnecessary visits to the clinic. And in other places, this means working with community health workers and local women's groups to provide abortion medications in the community," says Dr. Kumar. Governments, health systems, and providers must ensure that these services remain open and accessible to women and girls. Contraception and safe abortion care are essential health care, during COVID-19 and always. Read more here: https://bit.ly/2AkVtEy

title: COVID-19: Helping Farmworkers in Florida
description:
In the southwestern Florida community of Immokalee, tens of thousands of migrant farmworkers and other essential workers have had no choice but to stay on the job amid the coronavirus pandemic. Across the United States, farmworkers are at particularly high risk of contracting COVID-19 due to crowded living and transportation conditions, and limited ability to prevent infection at the workplace. Long workdays and language barriers often keep them from reaching the health services they need. To respond to these needs, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched a public health education campaign in collaboration with the Coalition of Immokalee Workers and ran free, mobile COVID-19 testing clinics with the Collier County Department of Health and the Healthcare Network of Southwest Florida. At-risk people like the community in Immokalee urgently need free COVID-19 testing at convenient times and locations, dedicated isolation facilities, and affordable and accessible health services. Read more at https://bit.ly/3idvIXR

title: Delivering Essential Medication in Jordan Amid the COVID-19 Pandemic
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs two clinics to treat non-communicable diseases (NCDs) like high blood pressure and diabetes in Irbid, Jordan. Since the coronavirus pandemic reached the country in March, our teams have had to adapt operations quickly in order to ensure continuity of care. NCDs are a major cause of death in Jordan and it is essential that patients continue to receive their medications during the pandemic. MSF adapted quickly to the strict and effective lockdown put in place by the Jordanian government by delivering medications to patients. “This required quite a big switch, we had to have a lot more drivers available, a lot more staff available to go out on delivery and pharmacy had to work very hard to prepare large numbers of medications all at once,” said MSF medical activity manager Rowena Neville. Once MSF implemented infection prevention measures, teams were able to deliver medications to 3,400 patients during the lockdown. Read more at https://bit.ly/3i9R1tA

description:

title: Rohingya Refugees Left to Starve at Sea
description:
On April 15, a boat carrying Rohingya refugees was denied disembarkation in Malaysia, leaving 500 people who had fled squalid, overcrowded refugee camps in Bangladesh stranded at sea for two months with little access to food or water. Citing concerns about the spread of COVID-19, Malaysian officials have tightened border controls and barred a number of boats from disembarking in recent months. After the boat was rescued by the Bangladeshi coastguard, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) sent medical teams to assess peoples’ needs and provide emergency medical care and mental health support. “They told us how their relatives had died before their eyes after drinking sea water, and how they had been mistreated,” said Muriel Boursier, MSF head of mission in Bangladesh. Other boats could still be stranded at sea, denied safe disembarkation by Malaysia and other countries in the region. On May 6, MSF wrote an open letter to Malaysian authorities expressing our support for safe disembarkation and urging them not to use the COVID-19 pandemic as an excuse to push vulnerable people back to sea. Read more at https://bit.ly/2YHhohy
