title: Combining Strengths at Sea: Rescues with Greenpeace
description:
Three Greenpeace boats, three ambulances to coordinate rescues: Medecins Sans Frontieres/Doctors Without Borders are collaborating with Greenpeace to utilize their strength at sea and ours in medicine for search and rescue operations in the Aegean Sea. MSF also has a medical team ready on the island of Lesvos to provide emergency care and refer and transport the most critical cases to local health facilities.

See also: This is Not a Game http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/boat-rescue-near-lesbos-not-game
Learn more: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org
Follow us on twitter: @MSF_USA

title: Boat Sinking Near Lesbos: This is Not a Game
description: A Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Greenpeace rescue team responded to a sinking rigid inflatable boat carrying 45 Afghan refugees crossing from Turkey to the north shore of Lesvos, Greece. On arrival to the scene the poor quality inflatable was taking on water. "We need to realize that this is not going to stop". Read more on the obstacles refugees face trying to reach Europe: http://bit.ly/1PosDxc

title: Ebola Outbreak Timeline Explained Animation
description:
April 2014: MSF described the Ebola outbreak as unprecedented. In this first year of the Ebola response, close to 500 health professionals, including 14 MSF workers, had lost their lives in the fight against the virus. Look back on MSF’s intervention in West Africa from the early days of the outbreak up until the end in this animation video which explains and visualizes the Ebola outbreak timeline.

Learn more about MSF's response to the Ebola outbreak: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/medical-issues/ebola

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

Follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/doctorswithoutborders/

Sign up for our newsletter: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/quick-signup-confirm

title: A Refugee Nurse in Northern France: 'Help these people'
description: Shakir, a registered nurse from Pakistan, helps care for his fellow refugees in northern France. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working alongside volunteers in the makeshift camps in Calais and Dunkirk to provide assistance.

title: Ben: Volunteers Help Refugees in France
description:
In northern France, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who arrive there after fleeing conflict in their home countries. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working alongside volunteers to provide assistance, helping to fill a void left by the government.

http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/
https://twitter.com/MSF_USA

title: Barnaby: Volunteers Help Refugees in France
description:
Barnaby is helping to build shelters for refugees in northern France. "There's no difference between the people living here and the people at home. That's what is so surprising when you arrive,
it's such a strange and half-obvious thing to try and grasp,
they're exactly the same." 
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working alongside volunteers to provide assistance to refugees.

title: Alain: Volunteers Help Refugees in France
description: In northern France, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who arrive there after fleeing conflict in their home countries. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works alongside volunteers to provide assistance.

title: A Refugee in France: 'No one knows what will happen to them tomorrow'
description: Ahmad fled Syria and crossed the sea to reach Europe. "I will not forget those four hours [on the boat]. It was like dying." Now he is living in miserable conditions in "The Jungle" camp in France while waiting to cross into the UK.

title: MSF's Month in Focus: December 2015
description: A look at some of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) activities this month: mental health care in the West Bank; the outpouring of volunteer assistance to refugees in Calais and Dunkirk, France; maternal and neonatal care in Kabul, Afghanistan; treating malaria in South Sudan; and continuing to provide medical care and assistance to refugees arriving in Europe as the winter begins.

title: Snapshot: South Sudan, Sick and Far from Care
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been treating patients for malaria in Aweil Hospital in South Sudan, but many people struggle to access treatment.

title: Mental Health is Affected as Violence Surges in West Bank
description: Social workers with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Nablus, the West Bank, see an increase in symptoms of extreme stress as violence surges.

title: Refugees in Greece: Same Path, Different Stories
description: Amber Alayyan, a doctor working with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) describes the similarities and contrasts between the refugees she met while working in Greece.

title: Volunteers Step Up to Help Refugees in France
description: Volunteers in northern France have stepped up to help fill the void in assistance for refugees arriving from Africa and elsewhere. Alongside these volunteers, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to provide aid for nearly 7,000 refugees living in Dunkirk and Calais.

title: Providing Emergency Maternity Care in Kabul
description: The Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Emergency Maternity unit in Kabul is providing free medical care to pregnant women and young children. The population here has surged and the center delivers 800 babies on average each month.

title: Refugees Face Miserable Conditions in 'The Jungle'
description:
"I never imagined that one day I would be living in a tent like this.
I had a good life in Syria." Abu Omar's search for safety led him across Europe to France, where he is now living in miserable conditions in a makeshift camp in Calais, France.

title: Tracey & Tamar: Volunteers Help Refugees in Calais, France
description: In Calais, France, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who arrive there after fleeing conflict in their home countries.

title: Iokasti: Volunteers Help Refugees in Samos, Greece
description: On the Greek island of Samos, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who arrive there after fleeing conflict in their home countries.

title: Gabi: Volunteers Help Refugees in Samos, Greece
description: On the Greek island of Samos, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who arrive there after fleeing conflict in their home countries.

title: Children Among the Refugees Arriving in Greece
description: Many of the refugees arriving on the Greek island of Samos are children. They have fled conflict in their home countries to seek safety. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing assistance.

title: Samos, Greece: "We are refugees, we are trying our best"
description: One refugee tells his story of arriving in Samos, Greece. There, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who are fleeing conflict in their home countries.

title: Bettina: Volunteers Help Refugees in Samos, Greece
description: On the Greek island of Samos, local and visiting volunteers are helping refugees who arrive there after fleeing conflict in their home countries.

title: 545,000 People Call for an Independent Investigation
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) delivered a petition signed by more than 547,000 people to the White House, calling for President Obama to consent to an independent investigation of the deadly U.S. airstrikes on MSF's trauma hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan. The airstrikes on October 3 killed at least 30 people, including 14 MSF staff members, and destroyed MSF’s hospital. The MSF petition calls for President Obama to consent to an investigation by the International Humanitarian Fact-Finding Commission (IHFFC), the one body established specifically to investigate potential violations of international humanitarian law under the Geneva Conventions. Read more: http://bit.ly/1Rts3US

title: Captain Madeleine: Why MSF is working in the Mediterranean Sea
description: Sea captain Madeleine Habib describes her experience at the helm of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) search and rescue ship the Dignity 1 on the Mediterranean Sea.

title: Thank You from MSF in 2015!
description: Thanks to your generosity, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams were able to respond to many crises in 2015. While you are watching this, our teams are saving lives in a crisis somewhere. On behalf of our patients and staff: Thank you!

title: Dramatic Rescue of Newborn Captured as Boat Capsizes
description:
During the first sea intervention by MSF and Greenpeace near the beach at Efthalou, a boat filled with families that travelled from Turkey ran aground and started capsizing. Those rescued include one newborn baby (about 2 months old) with his uncle (refugees from Iraq), and a young man from Syria. Everyone on the refugee boat was able to reach land while MSF reunited the family and friends after the arrival at port in Molyvos.

MSF and Greenpeace International have launched joint lifesaving operations in the Aegean Sea and will coordinate with the Greek coast guard. Learn more at: http://bit.ly/1Nwd71d

Music by Sergey Cheremisinnov - Sirius

title: Making #LifeBeyondHIV: Get Tested. Get Treated
description:
It’s World AIDS Day, and it’s time to prove HIV is in no way an automatic death sentence. The people of Khayelitsha in Cape Town, in creative collaboration with MSF, activists, artists and musicians, came together to urge young people to stand strong against the virus: "This mural is for us… It is made by the people of Khayelitsha"

Condomise. Get tested. Get treated. There’s ‪#‎LifeBeyondHIV‬

Music and lyrics by P'zho. Video produced by © MSF 2015 and MAKHULU.

title: MSF's Month in Focus: November 2015
description: Watch video clips from several Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) projects and activies in November 2015. Get reports from Greece, Syria, Central African Republic, Sierra Leone, and Pakistan, and learn why improved access to HIV treatment has not reached everyone who urgently needs it.

title: People With HIV Still Face Major Hurdles
description: The World Health Organization (WHO) now recommends putting everyone infected with HIV on treatment immediately. But some 20 million people living with HIV around the world remain without the care they need. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to simplify treatment and adapt it to individual needs to help everyone who needs care get access to it.

title: Snapshot: FATA, Pakistan
description:
Rarely do the people living in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas (FATA) in northwestern Pakistan get a chance to share their stories.
Confined to its reputation as a terrorist stronghold, the isolation and extreme hardship of the people living in the region are overlooked.
"It seemed like a far distant place, plagued by sectarian violence and internally displaced people. FATA for me is as much a part of Pakistan as Islamabad, Peshawar and Karachi and the spirit of FATA is as beautiful and captivating as it's people." - Sa’adia Khan, photgrapher

title: Ebola Survivors Now Face Different Challenges
description: Sierra Leone has finally been declared Ebola-free, but many of the 4,000 survivors of this deadly epidemic continue to suffer. They report having painful joints, chronic fatigue, vision or hearing impairment, as well as depression and post-traumatic stress. It is difficult for them to get treatment, and people still fear Ebola survivors. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to assist them.

title: Civilians Still in Syria Face Ever-Worsening Conditions
description: Sylvain Groulx was Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) head of mission for its Syria projects, based in Turkey. Here he describes the ever-worsening situation of civilians still living in Syria.

title: MSF and Locals on Greek Islands Work to Help Refugees
description:
Hundreds of thousands of refugees have crossed the Aegean Sea this year to get to one of the Greek islands close to Turkey. When they land on Samos island after a gruelling hours-long crossing in total darkness, they need to get warm and find out where they are. 
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works with local volunteers and asks them to let the team know when they see boats approaching so they can assist the refugees as quickly as possible.

title: Renewed Violence and Inadequate Assistance in CAR
description:
Renewed violence in September forced 40,000 people in Bangui, capital city of Central African Republic (CAR) to flee their homes. 
The situation remains unstable in Bagui; displaced people are sheltering at a camp at Mpoko airport and other sites such as Benzvi camp, shown here. The number of displaced people continues to rise and basic needs like hygiene and shelter are not being met. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is running mobile medical clinics here.

title: The Threat of Winter at Sea: Adapting the Bourbon Argos
description: Winter is coming, and the MSF search and rescue ship the Bourbon Argos has been adapting for the changing weather conditions in the Mediterranean Sea. A new set up on the back deck of the boat will protect those rescued from the wind, rain and waves. As Emergency Coordinator Sebastian Stein explains, "The most vulnerable are coming at the most dangerous time". http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/emergency-mediterranean

title: MSF Providing Logistical Services in "the Jungle" Makeshift Camp
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working in "the Jungle" makeshift camp in Calais, France, where some 6,000 people are sheltering after making the dangerous journey from Afghanistan, Syria, Iraq, Sudan or Eritrea. "We have a large team working on waste management, both raising awareness and collecting rubbish because rubbish has been accumulating for weeks and weeks, months even. We’re also working on providing shelters," said head of mission Pauline Busson.

title: Refugees in 'the Jungle' in Calais, France
description: An estimated 6,000 people are living in the makeshift camp called "the Jungle" in Calais, France. Most people have made the dangerous journey from Sudan, Eritrea, Afghanistan, Syria and Iraq to seek safety in Europe. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) head of mission Pauline Busson talks about their current situation.

title: Remembering Those Who Were Killed in Kunduz
description: Dr. Joanne Liu, the international president of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), travelled back to Kunduz, Afghanistan, to the site of the MSF trauma hospital that was destroyed by US missiles on October 3, killing 14 staff members and 30 people in total. Dr. Liu attended a commemoration along with the family and friends of those who were killed, and toured the ruined facility. Read more: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/kunduz-hospital-attack-msf-factsheet

title: MSF Delivers $17 Million to Pfizer
description: In New York on World Pneumonia Day, November 12, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) volunteers attempted to deliver more than $17 million of fake cash—the equivalent of one day of profits from the pneumonia vaccines for Pfizer globally—to Pfizer's CEO Ian Read. Help MSF put pressure on Pfizer and GSK to drop the price of vaccinating a child for pneumonia to $5. Sign the petition: http://www.afairshot.org/

title: At the Crossroads: That's Where We Operate
description: MSF is a neutral and impartial humanitarian organization that aims first and foremost to provide high-quality medical care to the people who need it the most. www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Kunduz One Month Later: A Commemoration
description: On the one-month anniversary of the bombing of the MSF trauma center in Kunduz, Afghanistan, MSF and supporters around the world came together to grieve and honor the colleagues and patients who were killed. "We continue to fight back for the respect of the Geneva Conventions," said Jason Cone, executive director of MSF-USA. "We are fighting back for the sake of our patients."

title: This Absurd Way of Doing Business is Actually a Reality...
description:
When prices are hidden, you can essentially set the price as high as you'd like. No one would know, right? It's absurd, but unfortunately, this is the way pharmaceutical companies set prices for their life-saving pneumonia vaccines.

Sign our petition to ask Pfizer & GSK to lower the price of the pneumonia vaccine to $5/child.
http://afairshot.org

title: Why Are Your Prices Covered?
description:
When prices are hidden, you can essentially set the price as high as you'd like. No one would know, right? It's absurd, but unfortunately, this is the way pharmaceutical companies set prices for their life-saving pneumonia vaccines.

Sign our petition to ask Pfizer & GSK to lower the price of the pneumonia vaccine to $5/child.
http://afairshot.org

description:
When prices are hidden, you can essentially set the price as high as you'd like. No one would know, right? It's absurd, but unfortunately, this is the way pharmaceutical companies set prices for their life-saving pneumonia vaccines.

Sign our petition to ask Pfizer & GSK to lower the price of the pneumonia vaccine to $5/child.
http://afairshot.org

title: Right Shot, Wrong Price
description:
When prices are hidden, you can essentially set the price as high as you'd like. No one would know, right? It's absurd, but unfortunately, this is the way pharmaceutical companies set prices for their life-saving pneumonia vaccines.

Sign our petition to ask Pfizer & GSK to lower the price of the pneumonia vaccine to $5/child.
http://afairshot.org

title: Highlights from MSF's Sexual Violence Webcast, Part 2
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  held a live panel discussion on the challenges of treating survivors of sexual violence. Watch the full recording: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sexual-violence-webcast

title: Highlights from MSF's Sexual Violence Webcast, Part 1
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  held a live panel discussion on the challenges of treating survivors of sexual violence. Watch the full recording: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/sexual-violence-webcast

title: MSF's A Month in Focus: October 2015
description: A look at some of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) activities this month: providing medical care to refugees in "The Jungle" makeshift camp in Calais, France; opening cholera centers in Borno State, Nigeria, where people have fled their homes due to violence caused by groups including Boko Haram; vaccinating children against measles in southern DRC during one of the biggest epidemic outbreaks this area has seen in recent years; continuing to provide care during the violent conflict in Yemen; working to address the challenges to providing vaccination campaigns where deadly diseases threaten children's lives; and dealing with the aftermath of MSF's trauma hospital being bombed by US forces in Kunduz, Afghanistan.

title: MSF Working in 'The Jungle' Makeshift Camp in Calais
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing medical to refugees sheltering in "The Jungle", a makeshift camp in Calais, France. The camp is has woefully inadequate waste management and sanitation conditions.

title: Displaced People in Nigeria Face Cholera Outbreaks
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened cholera treatment centers in response to outbreaks of the disease in displaced people's camps in Nigeria's Borno State. Some 1.6 million people have taken shelter in these camps, seeking safety from violence caused by groups including Boko Haram.

title: The Challenges of Vaccination Campaigns
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) conducts vaccination campaigns to prevent the spread of deadly diseases in the places where we work, where children are particularly vulnerable to diseases like pneumonia and measles. But these campaigns are extremely challenging. Read more: http://afairshot.org/

title: Responding to a Massive Measles Epidemic in DR Congo
description: The widespread measles epidemic has hit in the southern region of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been working to treat victims and contain the spread.

title: Snapshot: Yemen
description: Yemen has been in violent conflict since March 2015. Civilians have been the primary victims of deadly airstrikes and Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been working to provide urgently needed medical care.

title: An Expedition through PNG Jungles to Reach TB Patients
description:
An Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) team undertook an outreach expedition in late August, traversing the seas off the coast of Papua New Guinea’s Gulf Province and hiking for three days through mountainous terrain. The goal was to 
test out a largely overland route that would let medical workers reach more patients in rural areas and provide treatment to those suffering from tuberculosis.

title: Thousands of Refugees Exposed to Unnecessary Suffering Across the Balkans
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical coordinator Jota Echevarria and nurse Annlaug Selsto describe the situation in Serbia and Croatia, where MSF is providing care to thousands of migrants and refugees waiting to be transferred to Hungary.

title: The Refugee Journey Across the Mediterranean
description:
Four months since the Dignity I searchand rescue ship sailed from Barcelona to Sicily and then into a search and rescue zone 30 miles of the Libyan coast,  the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) team onboard have saved  more than 5,000 people from dying in the Mediterranean Sea. 

Every week, more people set off on this dangerous sea journey from Africa to Europe. All together the three MSF vessels—the Dignity I, the Bourbon Argos and MY Phoenix—which have been operating since as early as May, have assisted more than 17,000 people. 

Yet these numbers don’t explain what can push a person to make such a journey. The MSF team on board of Dignity I has been collecting stories and testimonies of those rescued in an attempt to see what lies beyond the numbers. 

This is what Laura Pasquero, an MSF humanitarian officer who has interviewed more than 100 people so far, says: 

“Through the people we talk to, we rescue the stories of their friends and family members who often don’t make it, for they die in the desert, or at sea, or in one of Libya’s prisons. When we talk to people about the boat trip on the sea to Europe, two things come out constantly from all the stories: that the boat trip was their only option to save their life, and that on the boat they were almost sure they were going to die. It looks like a contradiction. But it’s their reality.”

Read more about MSF's work with refugees in the Mediterranean: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/our-work/humanitarian-issues/refugees-and-idps

title: Dignity in the Mediterranean
description: "Being a humanitarian is much more than just giving people medicine. It's recognizing everybody as an individual with a story, with a life, with a right to a future," says the capitan of Dignity 1,  a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) rescue ship in the Mediterranean. Read more about MSF's work with refugees in the Mediterranean: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/our-work/humanitarian-issues/refugees-and-idps

title: Yemen: Aden, Then and Now
description: Bernard Leménager is a surgeon who has been to Aden, Yemen, several times in with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). When he returned to the country last summer, he saw how the city has changed after months of war.

title: Testimonies from the #YemenCrisis
description: In areas where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are working, health structures have been hit and damaged or destroyed by air strikes. As MSF emergency coordinator Natalie Roberts explains, these attacks severely limit the capacity of the Yemeni health care system to respond to medical needs.

title: Scenes From Kunduz Hospital in Afghanistan
description:
This is footage taken at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) trauma hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in 2011, 2014 and 2015. The hospital was the only facility of its kind in the northeastern region of the country. It provided cost-free, high level life- and limb-saving trauma care. In 2014, more than 22,000 patients received care at the hospital and more than 5,900 surgeries were performed. MSF treats all people according to their medical needs and does not make any distinctions based on a patient’s ethnicity, religious beliefs or political affiliation. 

At the time of the aerial attack on October 3, there were 105 patients and their caretakers in the hospital, alongside more than 80 international and Afghan MSF staff. MSF expresses its sincere condolences to the families and friends of its staff members and patients who have tragically lost their lives in this attack.

MSF calls for State activation of the International Humanitarian Fact-Finding Commission to investigate Afghanistan bombing. Read more: http://bit.ly/1hr5390

title: Unacceptable Conditions at Sea
description: On September 19, the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières' (MSF) search and rescue ship the Bourbon Argos rescued more than 900 people from four boats attempting to cross Mediterranean Sea and brought them to safety in Sicily. The ship has 26 people on board, including 14 MSF staff and an experienced search and rescue team. Read about MSF's search and rescue activities: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/emergency-mediterranean

title: PM Modi: Keep India the Pharmacy of the Developing World
description: On September 28, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières' (MSF) took advantage of Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi being in New York City to send him a message. Thanks to the country's patent laws, India is the pharmacy to the developing world; MSF sources 80% of its HIV drugs from India among other essential medicines. The U.S. is pressuring PM Modi to make India's patent laws more restrictive, which would benefit big pharma companies and cause millions of people to lose access to affordable medicines. MSF is urging PM Modi not to give in to U.S. pressure. Read more: http://handsoff.msf.org/

title: MSF Treats a Child Landmine Victim in Aden, Yemen
description: Landmines are increasingly becomin a problem in Aden, Yemen. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières' (MSF) is seeing more victims injured by the devices, including children like this boy. Read about MSF's work in Yemen: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/yemen

title: People Are Not Numbers: Refugees Need Safe Passage
description:
Lives continue to be lost at sea, in the back of trucks, and in make shift camps where people live in unacceptable conditions in the heart of the European Union. No matter the obstacles, people will continue to come as they have no other choice. Decisions adopted in EU summits have so far largely failed to improve the situation, and some measures have made the situation worse. Current policies are untenable in the face of this situation. The only way Europe can prevent a worsening crisis on its territory is to replace the smugglers by providing a safe, legal and free alternative to reach Europe. All forms of legal avenues allowing refugees to reach Europe must be put in place urgently. Efficient solutions to relocate asylum seekers from one EU member state to another must be found. Effective access to coherent asylum procedures and assistance should be provided at entry points, throughout Europe and along migratory routes. Swift registration and access to temporary protection should be provided upon arrival. Legal migration pathways must be created. Dignified reception conditions must be offered to all. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/emergency-mediterranean 
#SafePassage

title: SDGs: Is "Leave No One Behind" Just a Slogan?
description: The United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) promise, among other things, to end malnutrition and epidemics like HIV/AIDS, TB and malaria. Unfortunately, the SDGs are not rooted in the reality and health needs faced by the people today. The SDGs lack a clear plan on how they will be achieved, and their ambitions are out of step with current trends in development policies and funding. Read more: http://www.msf.org/topics/sustainable-development-goals

title: Pneumonia (mis)Spelling Bee
description:
Spelling pneumonia is hard. Paying for the vaccine is harder. #AskPharma to lower the price! 

This fall, we’re taking action to ask Pfizer and GSK to lower the price of the pneumonia vaccine to $5 a child. Learn more at: afairshot.org

title: Keeping Children Alive in Mali
description: Koutiala in southeast Mali has extremely high rates of infant mortality,  mainly due to malaria and malnutrition.  Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing lifesaving care.

title: Father and Son in Afghanistan
description: The trauma center run by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Kunduz is the only facility to provide care to trauma victims in the northeast Afghanistan. This man is visiting his son who has a shrapnel wound to his leg.

title: Hurdle After Hurdle for Refugees in Europe
description: More than 300,000 people seeking safety and a better life have crossed the Mediterranean Sea to Europe so far this year. For those who survive the dangerous crossing, the ordeal is by no means over. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing search and rescue assistance on the sea, as well as aid for those who make it to the other side.

title: A Month in Focus, September 2015
description: Watch A Month in Focus, a monthly video series that reports on some of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) current field activities. This month we look at: people on the migration route to Europe, an intervention in Mali, a hospital in Jordan for those caught in regional conflicts, MSF's work in Afghanistan, the evolution of MSF's logistics centers, and the situation for South Sudanese refugees in Ethiopia.

title: Relocated Refugees Still Vulnerable in Ethiopia
description: Until last month Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) worked in Leitchour camp in Ethiopia, where refugees were seeking shelter from the conflict in South Sudan. The condition of the camps were appalling - some 50,000 people living in the worst conditions. Deputy Head of Mission Brice Garnier describes MSF's role in moving these refugees to a different location and the concerns the organization has now about the conditions in the new camp.

title: MSF Logistics Pioneer Jacques Pinel
description: A driving force in pioneering humanitarian aid logistics, Jacques Pinel sadly passed away in August. He helped propel Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) to create what is now a constantly evolving logistics scheme.

title: Providing Mental Health Care for Those Affected by Violence in Rural Colombia
description:
In the Cauca mountains in Colombia, most of the population lives in rural communities that are affected by the conflict between the armed groups and the government forces which has plagued the area for the past 50 years.

Despite a decrease in the amount of harassment, attacks and fighting, people continue to live in fear, pain and silence. Access to mental health services in the isolated villages of the mountains is non-existent. MSF psychologists do both individual and group therapy sessions in municipal hospitals and villages.

title: In Jordan, a Hospital at the Crossroads of Conflict
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has just opened a newly upgraded reconstructive surgery hospital in Amman, Jordan, to provide improved treatment to war-wounded patients from across the region. MSF first established a specialized surgery project in Amman in 2006 to care for victims of the war in Iraq, which it later expanded to receive patients from Iraq, Gaza, Yemen, and Syria. The project is being ehanced and further expanded in its new building. Read more:  http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/jordan-reconstructive-surgery-hospital-war-victims-opens-amman

title: More Than Just a T-Shirt
description:
Wearing the MSF T-shirt means being part of a world-wide medical humanitarian organization that speaks out freely and acts with total independence. 
To apply to be a a Field Worker with MSF, go to: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/work-field

https://www.facebook.com/msf.english
https://twitter.com/MSF_USA

title: MSF Rescues 800 from Smugglers' Boats in the Mediterranean
description: On August 26, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) rescue ship, the Bourbon Argos, completed two rescue operations, saving some 800 refugees from smugglers' boats in the Mediterranean Sea. The first boat was a large wooden fishing boat in distress with approximately 650 people on board; the second was a rubber boat first spotted by a Tunisian fishing vessel, carrying about 150 people. After the rescues, the Bourbon Argos began its journey with around 800 people, most of them from Syria, along with people from  Ivory Coast, Mali, Cameroon, Nigeria, Sudan, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Bangladesh, and Pakistan, towards the port of Vibo Valentia in Italy. Read more: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/emergency-mediterranean

title: Ebola: A New Vaccine Brings Hope
description: In late July 2015, a study published in the medical journal "The Lancet" showed the positive results of a vaccine against Ebola, rVSV-EBOV. In Conakry, Guinea, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is taking part in the clinical trial, and has already vaccinated 1,200 people working on the frontline to fight the disease.

title: A Worrying Shortage of Antivenom Serum
description: It is estimated that up to 100,000 people die every year from snakebites, but the most effective antivenom used in Africa to prevent these deaths is set to run out. Manufacturer Sanofi has halted production of the serum after deeming it unprofitable. Another laboratory will take over production, but the serum will not be back in production until 2019. If production of the serum doesn’t start up again sooner, thousands of lives will be endangered. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) calls on Sanofi to provide a temporary solution.

title: Yemen: "You Come and Do the Work"
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) doctor Emmanuel Berbain describes the situation in Khamer, an area that has so far been spared the worst of the fighting convulsing much of Yemen.

title: Tanzania: Cholera, a New Threat to Burundian Refugees
description: In Tanzania's Nyarugusu camp, some 150,000 people are now crammed into an area initially planned to host some just 50,000. In response to a May cholera outbreak, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has vaccinated 130,000 people against the disease and are distributing clean water. Learn more at http://bit.ly/1UOQ7AA.

title: Lebanon: Lives Ruined by Conflict
description: Since the conflict in Syria began four years ago, more than one million people have fled to neighboring Lebanon in search of refuge.  In Abde, the clinic run by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is running at full capacity. To learn more about MSF's work in Syria and neighboring countries, visit http://bit.ly/1TNcDHF.

title: Teaser for War in Aden: Surviving the Everyday
description:
Watch the full, 23-minute documentary here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2UZQDDzGKpI
"They've killed us, scattered us. It's very hard," says a woman from Crater in southern Yemen. This film documents the high level of violence in and around the Yemeni city of Aden. The violence intensified in mid-July this year when the coalition took over the city of Sanaa and many Houthist rebels fled. In a single day, MSF received 206 war wounded patients. Today, the situation is improving but, uncertainty remains high.

title: War in Aden: Surviving the Everyday
description: "They've killed us, scattered us. It's very hard," says a woman from Crater in southern Yemen. This film documents the high level of violence in and around the Yemeni city of Aden. The violence intensified in mid-July this year when the coalition took over the city of Sanaa and many Houthist rebels fled. In a single day, MSF received 206 war wounded patients. Today, the situation is improving but, uncertainty remains high. Read more: http://bit.ly/1MVXYKq

title: Emergency Rescue at Sea
description: "We are seeing three boats...people swimming in the water," the project coordinator for the (MSF) search and rescue vessel the Dignity I reported on August 5, 2015. A boat holding an estimated 600 people had capsized off the coast of Libya. Among those people struggling to survive was a Palestinian family and their one-year-old daughter. Read more: http://bit.ly/1DwOWkF

title: MSF Rescuers Save Survivors of a Sunken Boat Near Libya
description: On August 5, 2015, a boat holding an estimated 600 people capsized off the coast of Libya. Rescuers from the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) search and rescue vessel the Dignity I picked up survivors from the waters of the Mediterranean Sea. They then transferred the survivors to the Dignity I, including the one-year-old daughter of Palestinian man who was also recued. Read more: http://bit.ly/1DwOWkF

title: MSF Rescuers Pull People Out of Mediterranean Sea
description: On August 5, 2015, a boat holding an estimated 600 people capsized off the coast of Libya. Rescuers from the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) search and rescue vessel the Dignity I picked up survivors from the waters of the Mediterranean Sea. Read more: http://bit.ly/1DwOWkF

title: Hands Off Our Meds- A Heartbeat
description: India is known as the ‘pharmacy of the developing world.’  Millions of people across the developing world are alive because of affordable medicines made in India, and now the progressive laws that make this possible are under threat. Join us and take action now at: http://handsoff.msf.org/

title: MSF in Syria: Working Under Tense Conditions
description: The abduction of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff members in January 2014 changed the guarantee of safety that staff once had. Hence, in August 2014, MSF pulled out its international staff and began running it’s operations in Turkey and in a few open facilities. One included the hospital located in Idlib Province that treated approximately 1,700 burn victims to the emergency room between May 2014 and April 2015. Read more: http://bit.ly/1fAJRVH

title: Vaccination: Challenges and Solutions
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) emphasizes the importance of vaccinations to reduce the possibility of future infectious diseases. Factors including cost and heat sensitivity create roadblocks in the implementation of these vaccines. Despite the challenges this year in Chad, MSF was able to vaccinate over 50% of children from 0-11 years of age.

title: Palestinian Territories: Support to Affected Civilians
description: In July of 2014 Israel launched Operation Protective Edge in the Palestinian Territories and many citizens were caught in the crossfire. The aftermath left 25 medical facilities damaged, over 10,000 people wounded and more than 2,000 killed. As the medical staff in Al Shifa hospital become overwhelmed with cases, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) was deployed to offer support. About a year later, violence and unrest continues in Gaza and the West Bank. MSF is providing mental health care to civilians living in these traumatic conditions.

title: MSF Aims for New TB Treatment
description: About 450,000 of the world’s population suffer from multi-resistant tuberculosis (TB), but in 2013 only a little under 100,000 people received treatment. This type of TB resists the main antibiotics used to treat the disease. Fortunately, two new TB drugs, bedaquilin and delamanide, give hope to drug-resistant patients. In April of 2015 Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and partners launched a project that aims to discover a precise treatment using these drugs. Read more: http://bit.ly/1KyZgLE

title: Ukraine: Troubles in the Health System
description: Following the aftermath of Russia’s annexation of Crimea, armed violence broke out in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions, including in the town of Debaltsève, located between the two areas. Consequently, the town's hospital was severely damaged and inhabitants were forced into cellars and underground shelters. In this part of Ukraine, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provided consultations to the people who were no longer covered by the local health service and those who could not leave their homes.

title: Nepal: Where are We Now?
description: On April 25, 2015 a 7.8 magnitude earthquake hit Nepal resulting in the 130,000 collapsed homes, 14,000 people wounded and 8,000 dead. Several days after the earthquake Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) deployed a team to aid in remote areas that were in need of immediate assistance. Shortly after, another earthquake hits and MSF was there to assist. In June, MSF Staff members Sandeep Mahat, Jessica Wilford, and Sher Bahadur Karki (Raj) lost their lives in Nepal. May they rest in peace. Now three months after, MSF prepares for the distribution of essential items in the mountain villages of Nepal for monsoon season.

title: Nigeria: Fleeing to Borno State
description: Civilians fleeing Boko Haram violence have sought refuge in Borno State in northeastern Nigeria. Many of the displaced people in this area are sheltering in Maiduguri camp, where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has treated people for respiratory infections and malaria, and treated 7,000 people for cholera. As the fighting and attacks continue in Nigeria, MSF sees the need to expand services.

title: South Sudanese Seek Asylum in Ethiopia
description: In 2014, 200,000 people from South Sudan fled to western Ethiopia in search for safety and asylum. The long journey from South Sudan to the Gambella region of Ethiopia left the arriving refugees in poor health. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) have been present in three camps located on the border of these countries to provide maternal care, treatment for malnutrition, and other health services. In the summer of 2014, in order to prevent a possible cholera outbreak, MSF began a cholera vaccination campaign that was administered to over 76,000 Sudanese children.

title: Challenges in Yemen: Violence and Embargo
description: Since March of this year violence and conflict have been occurring in Yemen as a result of the tensions between the Houthis rebels and President Hadi. Bombings in Aden have caused casualties on both sides, as well numerous injuries and deaths of innocent civilians. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has treated over a 1,000 casualties in the capital city of Aden. However,issues such as safe travel to and from the hospital and limited access to medical supplies has made this mission extremely challenging. Read more: http://bit.ly/1D9sLRO

title: Ebola: The Fight Is Not Yet Over
description:
In March 2014 , the death of patients and health workers in Guéckédou of the Guinea Forest region, was the first warning sign of what would later be identified as Ebola . Months later, this virus would take the lives of thousands of people in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. Over the past year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has faced many unexpected challenges in treating this virus. 


At the height of the epidemic MSF ran over 15 treatment centers leaving many health workers at risk. While Ebola has gone down tremendously, there are still select cases that are being treated. Read more: http://bit.ly/1oSVLVz

title: Persistent Violence in CAR
description: Beginning in 2013, violence and insecurity has created a tense situation in the Central African Republic. The conflict between the Anti-Balaka offensive and Seleka rebels in Bangui, CAR, resulted in violence against the Muslim population of the nation. Ninety percent of Muslims in the western part of CAR fled their home to Chad. In the city of Bangui, MSF has set up mobile services treating diarrhea, respiratory infections, and malaria. Also, in March of this year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched a vaccination campaign to  with the goal of treating 18,000 children with measles and polio. Read more: http://bit.ly/1x0L1cp

title: Antibiotic Resistance, A Major Setback
description: Over the past year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has continued to encountered many antibiotic resistance cases that have caused major setbacks in medical care. Haiti is one of the many areas affected by antibiotic resistance. Burn victims of Haiti carry germs that don’t respond to common antibiotics resulting in costly treatment or possible treatment failure. Practices such as routine monitoring of infections and information-sharing are a few strategies that could be of use for antibiotic-resistance programs.

title: Thank You For Your Support
description: A message from Jason Cone, our Executive Director at Doctors Without Borders.

title: Thank You For Becoming a Field Partner!
description: Thank you for stopping to speak with our representative on the street, and for becoming the newest Doctors Without Borders Field Partner. Your generous monthly support gives us the financial independence we need to deliver emergency medical care to people in more than 70 countries around the world. For more information about what your gifts are making possible, visit www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: MSF's Year in Focus 2014-2015
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) looks back on the last 12 months and brings you reports on: the Ebola response in West Africa; the increasing challenge of antibiotic resistance; the ongoing conflict in Yemen; the miserable situation for displaced people in Central African Republic; the exodus of refugees from South Sudan to Gambella camp in Ethiopia; people displaced by Boko Haram's violence in Nigeria; MSF's intervention after the Nepal earthquake; the needs of people affected by fighting in Ukraine; new hope for people with drug-resistant TB; the trauma of residents in the Palestinian territories; the challenges to and importance of providing vaccinations to displaced children; and the work of MSF's national staff to continue providing aid inside Syria after international staff had to relocate to Turkey due to security concerns.

title: Mama Agathe: The Lady in Pink
description: Agathe Farini Sena, otherwise known as Maman Agathe, is a counselor at the Village d’Accueil at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) -supported Masisi general hospital in North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo. Women with high-risk pregnancies stay at the facility as they wait to give birth. This way, when the time comes, they have access to high quality healthcare to ensure they give birth safely. Read more: http://bit.ly/1U2r6S9 #TomorrowNeedsHer #HerVoiceisMyVoice

title: Critical Situation in Yemen
description:
Due to the conflict, airstrikes, and fuel shortages, it remains extremely difficult to deliver medical care in Yemen. Aid is, however, desperately needed by the civilians caught up in the conflict.

Despite the dangers, Doctors Without Borders medical teams have performed more than 2,259 emergency surgeries at our independent hospital in Aden since the current conflict began. Learn more at: www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: A Treacherous Journey Across the Mediterranean
description: Eritreans, Somalis, Nigerians and others have been crossing the Mediterranean in hope for a better life. More than 100,000 migrants have crossed the sea since the beginning of the year. During this time Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  search-and-rescue ships have been able to aid migrants on this dangerous crossing.

title: Life in Luhansk, Ukraine
description: "It was really hard last winter." Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  field worker Amande Bazerolle spent four months as an emergency coordinator in Ukraine. She speaks about her experience working in the separatist controlled area of Luhansk.

title: Wonderwomen of Gaza
description: Photographer Ovidiu Tataru began the Wonderwomen of Gaza portrait project to "give a voice to the true heroines who live in extremely challenging conditions." Read more about these women here: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/wonderwomen-gaza

title: 20 Years Later, MSF Revisits Srebrenica and Bosnia
description: Despite being under UN protection, Srebrenica’s Muslim enclave fell into the hands of Bosnian Serb forces. Today, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières Borders (MSF) revisits its intervention in Bosnia from 1993 to 2003. Read more: http://www.speakingout.msf.org/en/srebrenica

title: The Gaza Strip: One Year After the Last Bombing
description: A year after Operation Protective Edge in Gaza, many of the thousands of homes destroyed have still not been rebuilt. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières Borders (MSF) has worked in Gaza for 15 years and has seen the impact of long-term violence and trauma.

title: A Month in Focus: July 2015
description: Take a look at just a few Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières Borders (MSF) projects around the world. This month we go to Gaza and highlight stories of women living there. We also focus on migrants and refugees crossing the Mediterranean; we revisit MSF's intervention in Bosnia between 1993 and 2003; warn about the implications of EU countries and the U.S. pushing company profits over people's health; and discuss the current situation in Ukraine.

title: #HandsOffOurMeds! Call to the Indian Parliament and PM Modi
description:
‪#‎HandsOffOurMeds‬! Tomorrow (July 21) marks the beginning of the “monsoon session” at the Indian Parliament. We want Prime Minister Modi reject any external proposal that undermines the production of affordable generic medicines in India, the ‘pharmacy of developing world.’ Learn what is at stake and take action here:
http://ow.ly/NU10k #‎monsoonsession‬

title: Helping Women Through Fistula Repair in Nigeria
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) field worker Bilkisu Aliyu works closely with women in MSF's fistula repair project in Jahun, Nigeria. She describes the difficult situations that many fistula patients face. Learn more about what women with fistulas face at Because Tomorrow Needs Her: http://womenshealth.msf.org/chapters/chapter-3/ 
#TomorrowNeedsHer

title: Working to Treat Malnourished Burundi Refugees in Tanzania
description: As people in Burundi continue to flee political unrest, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is responding to refugees' medical needs in Nyarugusu camp, just over the Tanzania border. Among the services teams are offering is treatment for severely malnourished children, but staff are being overwhelmed by the needs. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/tanzania-camp-burundian-refugees-breaking-point

title: Pregnant With Ebola: A Survivor's Tale
description: Around the time that the World Health Organization (WHO) finally declared the Ebola epidemic in West Africa an international public health emergency, a young woman named Adama Kargbo learned she was pregnant. A few months later, she contracted the virus and was admitted to an Ebola treatment center in Kissy, a suburb of Sierra Leone’s capital, Freetown. She lost her baby, but against all odds, she survived, overcoming the hemorrhagic fever which has killed more than 8,600 people in west Africa.

title: #HandsOffOurMeds
description: Millions of people are alive because of affordable medicines made in India. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) relies on medicines from India to do our medical work. LET’S NOT GO BACKWARD: Help us tell Indian Government and @PMOIndia  to protect the ‘pharmacy of the developing world.’ http://ow.ly/NU10k #HandsOffOurMeds

title: Keep the Pharmacy of the Developing World Open
description: Keeping the pharmacy of the developing world open is a matter of life and death. Millions of people in developing countries rely on Indian generics to stay alive. Treatment providers like Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) need these meds to do medical work around the world. Affordable generic medicines from India are under attack. Prime Minister Modi: PLS STAND STRONG! http://ow.ly/NU10k #HandsOffOurMeds

title: Let's Not Go Backwards
description: Millions of people rely on affordable medicines from India.  Progressive laws that have made India the ‘pharmacy of the developing world’ are now under threat. Learn what is at stake and take action: http://ow.ly/NU10k #HandsOffOurMeds

title: Tamim, 7 Years Old,  in Kunduz, Afghanistan
description: Tamim, 7, was injured when he fell from a roof while playing in his neighborhood in Afghanistan's Baghlan province. He received urgently needed treatment, free of cost, at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) 24-hour trauma center in Kunduz. Tamim and his father have just been told that the boy can go home soon. Read more about MSF's recent work in Kunduz: http://bit.ly/1CN123E

title: Mohammed, 14 Years Old, in Kunduz,  Afghanistan
description: Mohammed Youssouf, 14, was caught in the crossfire between government and armed opposition forces in Emama Saed, northern Afghanistan. He was brought first to the district hospital but they were unable to treat him, so he was brought by his brother to the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) free, 24-hour trauma center in the northern province of Kunduz. Read about MSF's recent work in Kunduz: http://bit.ly/1CN123E

title: From Eritrea to Mediterranean: "A Lot of Trouble"
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) rescued 345 people jammed into a small smuggler's boat crossing the Mediterranean on June 19. One man who escaped from Eritrea and risked his life to get from Libya to Italy tells his story. Read more about MSF's sea rescue operations: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-bolsters-mediterranean-search-and-rescue

title: Fistula Clip #3
description: A clip from the first "Because Tomorrow Needs Her" webcast in March, where panelist Catrin Schulte-Hillen spoke about the bringing hope to women with obstetric fistulas. The next webcast, on fistulas, takes place Thursday, June 25, at 8pm EDT: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/fistula-webcast

title: Fistula Clip #2
description: A clip from the first "Because Tomorrow Needs Her" webcast in March, where panelist Catrin Schulte-Hillen spoke about the challenges to treating women with obstetric fistulas. The next webcast, on fistulas, takes place Thursday, June 25, at 8pm EDT: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/fistula-webcast

title: MSF Fights to Aid Injured in Yemen
description: The recent coalition attacks on Yemen’s airport has made it even more difficult for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and other humanitarian groups to aid people suffering from the conflict.

title: Iraq: Hundreds Displaced in Kirkuk and Beyond
description: “I don’t think we’ll ever go back home. The situation is bad and day after day it will get worse.”  Here Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) take a glimpse into the lives of just a few families in Iraq who have been displaced by the many conflicts evoked by the Islamic State.

title: Post-Civil War Tensions Arise in South Sudan
description: South Sudan was experiencing a period of calm, but now tensions have risen again and South Sudanese civilians are feeling the effects. Many of these civilians get treated at Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières' (MSF) Bentiu hospital.

title: CAR Muslims Fear for Their Lives
description:
Snapshot: Five-hundred Central African Muslims take refuge in a church in Carnot.

Presented by : Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)

title: Could Antibiotic Resistance Threaten Public Health?
description:
“More than fifty years after the introduction of antibiotics on a large scale, could it become possible to die of simple pulmonary infection?”

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) discusses how antibiotic resistance can cause a threat to many.

title: Crisis in Nigeria: Boko Haram
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières' (MSF) Dr. Abubakr Bashir Bakri speaks about the lack of international acknowledgement to the acts of Boko Haram that has killed thousands and displaced millions of Nigerian people.

title: A Month in Focus: June 2015
description:
This month in Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF): attacks on Yemen airport challenges humanitarian assistance, advances from ISIS displaces many in northern and central Iraq, and --following the 2013 civil war-- tensions rise again in South Sudan.

Moreover, in the Central African Republic hundreds take refuge in Carnot Church , we learn how antibiotic resistance affects public health, and Dr. Abubakr Bashir Bakri speaks on the under-reported crisis of Boko Haram’s destruction in Nigeria.

title: Fistula Clip #1
description: A clip from the first "Because Tomorrow Needs Her" webcast in March, where panelist Catrin Shulte-Hillen spoke about the realties for women with an obstetric fistulas. The next webcast, on fistulas, takes place Thursday, June 25, at 8pm EDT: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/fistula-webcast

title: The Dangers of Unsafe Abortion
description: Abortion is illegal in Haiti, except to save the life of the mother. That leaves women and girls with unwanted pregnancies facing a difficult decision. Many of them seek abortions from fake doctors called “charlatans” or take pills purchased on the street. Of the estimated 44 million abortions performed every year worldwide, around half are considered unsafe. The vast majority of unsafe abortions occur in developing countries. Find out more about Because Tomorrow Needs Her at womenshealth.msf.org

title: A Story of Family Violence in PNG
description:
This is the story of a young woman in Tari, Papua New Guinea, who was attacked by her husband and sought treatment at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Family Support Center. MSF opened the center in 2009 to offer medical and mental health care to survivors of family and sexual violence, both of which are very common in PNG. Find out more about Because Tomorrow Needs Her at womenshealth.msf.org
Photos and video by Kate Geraghty

title: A Mother in Malawi Delivers HIV-Free
description:
Edna enrolled in MSF’s prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV (PMTCT) program in Malawi, where HIV-positive pregnant women are immediately put on lifelong antiretroviral treatment. ") I was afraid. I thought ‘How am I going to tell my husband about this? Do I tell him in person? What if he tells me this is the end of our marriage?’" When a pregnant mother is on effective treatment, the HIV transmission rate to her child drops from up to 40% to less than 5%. However, not all women have access to testing and treatment. MSF teams support more than 341,600 people on antiretroviral treatment in over 20 countries. In late 2013, MSF handed over the PMTCT program in Thyolo to Malawi’s health system. Find out more about Because Tomorrow Needs Her at womenshealth.msf.org
Video and photos by Sydelle Willow Smith

title: On Her Own But Not Alone in PMTCT
description:
Jennipher is a mother of four and a patient in the prevention-of-mother-to-child transmission of HIV (PMTCT) program in Thyolo, Malawi. "My husband was very supportive every time I was pregnant. When I got pregnant the last time, we went together as husband and wife to the first antenatal visit. We both got tested and they told us we were both HIV positive." When a pregnant mother is on effective treatment, the HIV transmission rate to her child drops from up to 40% to less than 5%. However, not all women have access to testing and treatment. MSF teams support more than 341,600 people on antiretroviral treatment in over 20 countries. In late 2013, MSF handed over the PMTCT program in Thyolo to Malawi’s health system. Find out more about Because Tomorrow Needs Her at womenshealth.msf.org
Video and photos by Sydelle Willow Smith

title: Safe Deliveries in Burundi
description:
"In July 2013, I started taking photographs of women in obstetrical emergencies in Kabezi, a small town in the northwest. On the first day, during an emergency call, I met Chantal, a 20-year-old woman who was in her thirty-second week of pregnancy." In Burundi, around 2,200 women die in childbirth every year. The high mortality is due to many factors. Transportation is one major issue: it is difficult to find a motorbike or a taxi at night in the countryside, so women often walk to the health center and arrive late. Find out more about Because Tomorrow Needs Her at womenshealth.msf.org
Photos and video by Martina Bacigalupo

title: Gurung Ram Bamadur: An Earthquake Survivor in Nepal
description: When the earthquake struck in Nepal on April 25, Gurung Ram Bamadur lost his flock and three of his fingers were crushed. When he was brought to the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospital, his fingers had to be amputated. He now faces an uncertain future. Read about MSF's response to the earthquake in Nepal: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-responds-second-earthquake-nepal

title: Sansar Ghale: An Earthquake Survivor in Nepal
description: Sansar Ghale has diabetes and high blood pressure. When an earthquake struck Nepal on April 25, his medication was lost. His friends carried him 5 hours to the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospital in critical condition. Read about MSF's response to the earthquake in Nepal: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-responds-second-earthquake-nepal

title: Evacuating Patients After Nepal Earthquake
description: After the 7.8-magnitude earthquake that hit Nepal on April 25, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) evacuated by helicopter seriously injured and ill people who had no access to medical care. Footage by Brian Sokol. Read about MSF's response in Nepal: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/nepal

title: Yemen: An MSF Doctor Gives an Update from Khameer
description: From Khameer, Yemen, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) doctor describes the situation for displaced families who've come there to escape the bombing and fighting where they live. Dr. Berbain is standing in an area where the population has jumped from three families to 85 familes. MSF is running mobile medical clinic and relief distribution there. Read more: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/yemen

title: A Day at MSF's Hospital in Aden, Yemen
description: In Aden, in southern Yemen, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is independently running a hospital that is now located in the middle of the fighting. Despite this, medical teams are still receiving and treating injured patients on a daily basis. About 1,000 patients have been treated since the beginning of the clashes on March 19. Movement in Aden has become extremely difficult due to fighting and fuel shortages. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-expecting-death-anywhere

title: Fistula: A Problem of Women Not Getting the Right Care
description:
Saturday, May 23, is the Int'l Day to End Obstetric Fistulas. "Let’s not forget that this is not an African problem, an Asian problem; this is a problem of women, mothers, not getting the right care." 
- MSF fistula surgeon Geert Morren 
Go to womenshealth.msf.org
#endFistula #TomorrowNeedsHer

title: MSF's Month in Focus: May 2015
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) reports on activities in May, 2015, in Nepal, Yemen, Chad, Haiti, Migrants in the Mediterranean, and Iran.

title: Nepal: Logistical Challenges to Earthquake Response
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been responding to the devastation of the two earthquakes that hit Nepal in April with medical care and water and sanitation services. The logistical restraints are difficult, but with helicopters MSF teams are able to reach remote villages where the needs are the greatest. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/nepal

title: Lack of Fuel in Yemen Prevents Access to Medical Care
description: A fuel blockade in Yemen is preventing people from accessing humanitarian aid. Displaced people continue to flee their homes for safety in the town of Khamer, where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is suporting the public hospital. But the lack of fuel means people cannot reach medical care and the consequences are disastrous. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/yemen

title: Survivors of Boko Haram in Nigeria Find Care in Chad
description: In neighboring Chad, survivors of violent attacks by Boko Haram in  Nigeria are finding shelter and treatment. Some 18,000 people have crossed Lake Chad and are living in camps and in the community. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is proividing medical and mental health care. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/thousands-nigerian-refugees-seek-safety-chad

title: Photo Story: A Long Recovery in Haiti
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs the only facility that specializes in treating patients with severe burns in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Five-year old Manette was badly burned over four months ago in a fire at her father’s workshop and has been slowly recovering.

title: Explainer: Migration Across the Mediterranean
description: The vast Mediterranean Sea is the world’s most treacherous passage for migrants. An estimated 20,000 people have died risking their lives to migrate from conflict ridden countries to Europe in the past 15 years. More than 1,750 have perished so far in 2015, most from Syria, Afghanistan, Eritrea and Somalia. Read about what Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is doing: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-and-moas-save-hundreds-people-mediterranean

title: Treating Iran's Invisible Women
description: Women excluded from health systems, such as sex workers and drug users, are often among those most in need of treatment. They are especially vulnerable to HIV and Hepitits C. In southern Tehran, Iran, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs a clinic to address their needs. Ernst Wissre was the project coordinator.

title: A Rescue Mission in the Mediterranean
description: Thousands of people fleeing violence, insecurity, and privation at home attempt a treacherous journey via North Africa and across the Mediterranean Sea to Europe every year. Countless lives are lost during the passage. So far this year, more than 1,500 people have been left to drown. In response to the urgent need for maritime search-and-rescue activities, MSF has partnered with the Migrant Offshore Aid Station (MOAS) to provide assistance to people fleeing crises and risking their lives to reach safe haven in Europe. Read more: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/emergency-mediterranean

title: MSF Treats 7-Year-Old and Father After Bomb Blast in Afghanistan
description:
Kunduz was previously considered one of the more stable provinces affected by the ongoing conflict in Afghanistan. Fighting has increased significantly in the northern province, however, since 2014. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provides surgical care for trauma patients, including 7-year old Feroz and his father. They were on their way to the market when they were hit by a bomb blast. They travelled more than 62 miles (100 km) to MSF's hospital, the only facility able to treat their injuries in their region. 

Read more about MSF's response to the current fighting in northeastern Afghanistan here: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/msf-treats-war-wounded-spring-offensive-rages-north-afghanistan

title: Interview with an MSF Nurse on the MY Phoenix
Nepal: MSF Establishes Emergency Field Hospital in Arughat
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is setting up an inflatable field hospital in Arughat, Nepal, a town in Gorkha district, approximately 83 miles northwest of the capital, Kathmandu. The 20-bed hospital will come equipped with operating facilities, as well as an obstetrics and maternity unit, and will provide critical health services in the wake of the April 25 earthquake. 

"This facility here is replacing the health center that was destroyed in the earthquake and which provides health care to the 10,000 inhabitants living here in Arughat, as well as the 40,000 people in the small, inaccessible villages in the surrounding health district," says Dr. Jean-Paul Delain.

title: MSF's Current Activities in Nepal
description: A cargo plane carrying 35 tons of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical and logistics supplies, including an inflatable field hospital, managed to land last night at Kathmandu’s overwhelmed airport. Soon, an MSF surgical team will be able to admit patients to the 20-bed hospital.

title: Help Us #AskPharma to Make Vaccines Affordable
description: This week Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched a global campaign—"A FAIR SHOT"— to call on pharmaceutical companies GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) and Pfizer to slash the price of the pneumococcal vaccine in developing countries to US$5 per child, so more children can be protected from this childhood killer, and to disclose what they currently charge countries for the vaccine. MSF led a protest in front of Pfizer's world headquarters in New York City and attended the company's shareholders' meeting in New Jersey. Read more: http://bit.ly/1Gfwnww or go to afairshot.org to help us #AskPharma to disclose and lower their vaccines prices.

title: A Month in Focus, April 2015
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) presents A Month in Focus for April 2015, including: 

Vaccinating 15,000 Children Against Measles in CAR

For Malaria Day, A Look at the Disease's Impact in Rutshuru, DRC

Jordan: War Wounds 

Vaccines - The Price Is (Not) Right

Evacuated from Northern Yemen

Millions of People Are Forced to Migrate

title: Millions of People Are Forced to Migrate
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have never seen so many people forced to flee their countries as they are seeing now. MSF has launched a campaign - #MillionSteps - to raise the public's awareness about the reality of this situation.

title: Evacuated from Northern Yemen
description: As the conflict in Yemen intensifies Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has had to evacuate some of its international teams. Christophe Garnier, a logistician has recently returned from Khamer in the North of Yemen and describes his experience there. Read about MSF's work in Yemen: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/country-region/yemen

title: Vaccines - The Price Is (Not) Right
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been campaigning for five years for Pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV), which are used to protect infants and young children against disease, to be made available at an affordable price. Now there is a call for more transparency about the manufacturing costs and the pricing policy in different places around the world. But most of all, MSF is demanding that PCV be made available at a maximum cost of $5 per child.

title: Jordan: War Wounds
description:
Omar, 29, was injured in a bomb blast in Daraa, in the south of Syria.
Treated at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospital in Amman, Jordan, for 5 months, he underwent multiple surgeries and received physiotherapy and psychological care. Lear more about Omar: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/traumatized-war-syria-and-recovering

title: For Malaria Day, A Look at the Disease's Impact in Rutshuru, DRC
description: World Malaria Day is April 25. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières’s (MSF) confronts this killer disease in many places where we work, including in Rutshuru, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, where people are subjected to two malaria peaks every year.

title: Vaccinating 15,000 Children Against Measles in CAR
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières’s (MSF) began a vaccination campaign against measles, targetting 15,000 children in the town of Bria, Central African Republic, at the end of March.  Without vaccination campaigns in places like this there could be deadly outbreaks. But such campaigns can be extremely challenging.

title: In Yemen, Moving Medical Supplies Is Now the Problem
description: Former head of mission for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Yemen, Himedan Mohammed Himedan, says getting supplies into Yemen has been difficult but now that MSF has suceeded in getting in shipments form sea and air, the challenge remains of getting the supplies everywhere they need to go. Read more: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/article/yemen-msf-plane-carrying-urgently-needed-medical-supplies-lands-sanaa

title: Doctors Without Borders' Vital Pact Campaign
description:
Learn More: http://www.VitalPact.org
Twitter: http://www.Twitter.com/VitalPact
Facebook: http://www.Facebook.com/VitalPact

Doctors Without Borders (MSF) recently launched, "Vital Pact: Fandom Where It’s Needed Most", a campaign that recognizes the power of devoted fans of games, comics, genre fiction, TV and films who champion MSF’s mission while pursuing their passions.

Through Vital Pact, fans can create fundraising projects that tap into the collective power of their communities. To help our supporters, we provide fundraising platforms, digital collateral and promo items, in addition to promoting fan-driven events via our Facebook and Twitter.

title: MSF's Month in Focus: March 2015
description: Take a glimpse at Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  activities in the past month. From Syria to West Africa to Afghanistan, MSF continues working to provide life-saving, impartial medical care to those who need it most.

title: A Look at Syrian Refugees, March 2015
description:
As the civil war in Syria continues to grind on, living conditions for civilians remain precarious. Many unable to leave the country flee to makeshift camps near the border, where a lack of medical care threatens the lives of inhabitants. Underground medical networks attempt to provide care to civilians, but their resources are limited.


Abou Hassan, displaced Syrian:
"There are 300 families here. We were given 60 tents during a first distribution, then a further 30, so 90 in all! People sold their furniture and whatever belongings they'd brought with them to buy a tent or build some form of shelter."

Since the beginning of the conflict, half of the Syrian population have had to flee from their homes.

"There are no medical facilities, no toilets, no drainage system. Each family gets 15 litres of water – that’s not even enough to drink. How can we wash or wash our clothes?"

Winter makes the lives of these families even harder.

Nathalie Roberts, medical coordinator, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF):
"When it snows there's a huge problem, when the snow melts it’s an even worse problem because everything’s muddy, everything gets wet, the blankets get wet and (...) you have to heat your tent or your home and the availability of fuel is difficult but the quality of fuel is even worse. So it’s kind of the risk balance – you can’t not heat the tent because everyone will get hypothermia but they’re using this fuel and there’s an explosion and the tent might catch fire."

Explosions caused by poor quality fuel have become so common that MSF’s hospital in Idlib Governorate now specialises in treating patients suffering from burns.

Abu Mohamad, supervisor:
"In one camp, there was a fire that then set fire to a whole group of tents. It happened early in the morning and there were children sleeping in those tents.
It’s not their fault, people are getting burned because they’re trying to keep warm or because barrel bombs explosions."

Since the beginning of the hostilities, medical facilities have been targeted, their personnel killed, abducted or forced to flee from the violence... and several months ago, some MSF centers were forced to close because of the risk of abduction. 

Doctors have set up networks in areas not controlled by the government, but they need help, help that MSF tries to provide.
The teams are only too aware from their contacts with Syrian doctors that thousands of people are in need of humanitarian aid... but their scope for action is woefully inadequate.

title: A Look at Ebola in West Africa in March 2015
description:
One year after the outbreak of Ebola in West Africa, the disease has claimed 10,000 lives and continues to spread in parts of Guinea and Sierra Leone. Health promotion teams work on spreading awareness throughout communities on infection prevention.

Timing is critical. Just one case of Ebola not detected in time can be enough to wipe out all the work put into containing the epidemic.
So, to ensure that people understand and integrate infection-prevention advice, health promotion teams like this one in Monrovia repeat the same messages time and time again. 

Elsie Siboe, health promotion supervisor, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF):  
"We have to ensure that people are aware that once there’s an outbreak, in future it's possible that we'll most likely to have another outbreak, and community burials or touching our dead bodies is one of the things that we have to think about and consider to do some behaviour change."

Once the epidemic is over, countries affected by the outbreak face the challenge of restoring their already fragile healthcare systems that have been reduced to a state of collapse.

title: Providing Care for Female Refugees in Ethiopia
description:
