description: MSF is vaccinating 68,000 children for measles in five camps in Bangui, Central African Republic (CAR) in order to prevent an outbreak. Hundreds of thousands of people are currently displaced in camps around Bangui as a result of violence since early December.

title: Thank You for Your Support in 2013
description: With your support we delivered emergency medical care in more than 70 countries in 2013. Watch the video to see some of the places where you've helped make a lifesaving difference.

title: MSF Assists Syrian Refugees in Northern Iraq
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a clinic inside this camp sheltering 12,400 Syrian refugees in northern Iraq in September. MSF teams provided nearly 4,000 consultations in October, a third of them for children.  As winter sets in MSF is even more concerned about the refugees' health.

title: In Gaza, MSF Delivers Post-Operative Care For Burn Patients
description: In Gaza, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) provides post-operative care to people injured in burn accidents. Generators and poor quality gas cylinders are the cause of many serious accidents in Gaza, and MSF's is the only clinic that provides comprehensive wound care, physiotherapy, and medical care for these types of injuries.

title: More Aid Needed Fast in Central African Republic
description: In Bouca, Central African Republic (CAR) Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has proven that despite the security restraints, it is possible to provide aid in CAR. Given the scale of the needs in the country, more humanitarian agencies must take action fast.

title: Providing Maternity Care for Syrian Refugees in Jordan
description: With more than 540,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan, the Jordanian health system has had problems meeting the needs of all these new patients. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has opened a maternity care clinic in Irbid and plans to scale up activities.

title: Decentralized HIV Care in Rural Malawi Works for 35K Patients
description: After 13 years in Malawi, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  has shown that HIV patients can be successfully managed in a rural setting with limited staff by the decentralization of care and shifting of tasks to staff with less medical training. Today MSF and the ministry of health treats 35,000 patients in Chiradzulu district.

title: MSF Working in Some of the Worst-Affected Areas in the Philippines
description: Three weeks after Typhoon Haiyan hit the Philippines, more than 200 Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff were working on the ground alongside several hundred Filipino colleagues. They have set up projects on the islands of Leyte, Panay and Samar, some of the worst affected areas, and continue to work in Tacloban.

title: MSF in the Philippines: "People Don't Stop Having Babies Because There is a Typhoon"
description: A month after Typhoon Haiyan, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) continues its work in the Philippines, including the remote area of Guiuan. The goal for MSF teams there is to fill in the gaps of medical care, including obstetric care, until the local health authorities can resume all normal activities.

title: MSF Working In Isolated Areas of  the Philippines
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are distributing essential items, such as plastic sheeting, hygiene kits and cooking kits, to people in isolated areas of the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan.

title: We See A Lack Of HIV Testing
description:
People on antiretroviral treatment are less likely to transmit HIV to others. To combat the epidemic, many more people need to be put on treatment. That is why testing people for HIV is crucial. Nelisiwe visits remote communities in Eshowe, South Africa, to help make testing available to all.

The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. 
The See What We See films reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: We See Children With HIV Being Neglected
description:
Amahle was born HIV-positive in Eshowe, South Africa. Her mother died from HIV/AIDS and Amahle now lives with her aunt. It is vital that Amahle understands why she needs to be on treatment for the rest of her life. 

The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. 
The See What We See films reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: We See Pregnant Women Dying From HIV
description:
Mamotsieleli is pregnant. She has just been diagnosed with HIV. If she receives regular treatment she can lead a normal life and the virus will not be passed on to her new baby.
But the nearest clinic where she lives in Lesotho is a five-hour walk away.
The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. 
The See What We See films reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: We See People Struggling To Continue HIV Treatment
description:
Although antiretroviral (ARV) drugs in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) are supposed to be free, patients have to pay for tests and consultations. For most people, these costs are unaffordable. To survive, Claudine in Kinshasa has to beg her friends for ARV pills.

The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. 
The See What We See films reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: We See People Starting HIV Treatment Too Late
description:
The health system in Democratic Republic of Congo is one of the weakest in the world.
Many people have no access to HIV treatment. In Kinshasa, Dr. Maria's hospital is among the very few in the country offering completely free HIV treatment. Each day new patients arrive desperate for help. One in four is too ill to be saved.

The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. 
The See What We See films reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: We See Discrimination Against HIV Patients
description:
People living with HIV often face stigma and discrimination.
Ko Tin Than lost everything when people found out he was HIV-positive. 
It even led to him stopping his treatment for a while. 

The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. The See What We See film series reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: Treating Wounds and Chronic Illnesses in Tacloban, Philippines
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has set up a 45-bed inflatable hospital in the city of Tacloban and working to provide medical care in collaboration with the Filipino Ministry of Health. Many of the medical facilities in the area were damaged or destroyed by Typhoon Haiyan, and as a result the MSF hospital has become the main referral center in the area.

title: See What We See: AIDS Is Not Over Yet
description:
The fight against HIV/AIDS has been hailed as one of the most successful public health projects in human history, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams that support HIV treatment for more than 280,000 people in 21 countries, see the revolution as unfulfilled for millions of people excluded from treatment. 

The See What We See films reveal what MSF medical staff witness and also highlight proven strategies for community-based care that puts more people on treatment earlier and helps them adhere to treatment in the long-term. Go to See.MSF.org to learn more.

title: Death And Displacement After Attack on Bouca, Central African Republic
description: An attack on the town of Bouca, northern Central African Republic (CAR), on September 9, 2013, spurred yet another wave of displaced people in the country. A military campaign by an alliance of rebel forces, Séléka, took a number of major towns and territory in eastern and central regions of CAR in 2012 and the fighting between armed groups has continued through 2013. An estimated 400,000 people are currently displaced in CAR.

title: Building a New Facility, Treating Patients in Tanauan, Philippines
description: The town of Tanauan, the Philippines, was nearly flattened by Typhoon Haiyan; of the 15 hospitals in the area, 14 were destroyed. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical staff had been seeing people inside a municipal building with no electricity while logistics staff built a five-tent facility next door. The facility is up and running now and MSF teams are seeing 230 consultations per day.

title: MSF Working to Meet Huge Medical Needs in Tanauan, Philippines
description: Tanauan, a small town of 50,000 inhabitants located 12 miles south of Tacloban, is one of the worst-affected areas in the Philippines. Some 95 percent of the houses were destroyed by Typhoon Haiyan and the population has only received minimal aid since. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) arrived in Tanauan Tuesday and is running a medical clinic.

title: MSF Treating Patients in the Philippines; Concerned About Remote Communities
description:
Logistical challenges have slowed the relief response in the Philippines, but Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is there and is treating patients. "Now we are more worried about communities that are farther away," said Dr. Natasha Reyes, MSF emergency coordinator.
CEBU, Philippines

title: Five Lessons to read X-rays
Paediatric TB Xrays (Part 2) - clues from the lateral film by Savvas Andronikou
description:
Paediatric TB remains an important and under-diagnosed cause of suffering and death in resource-poor settings. In this video, world-expert Savvas Andronikou will provide you with the radiology tools to guide your clinical decision-making, in making the diagnosis of TB.

See part 1 for approach to anterior Paeds TB here: vimeo.com/77954925

This series of short lectures is brought to you by:
SAMU - Medical Unit of MSF SA - samumsf.org
WFPI - World Federation Pediatric Imaging - pedrad.org/associations/5364/wfpi/

Produced by Aviro Health - avirohealth.com

title: Paediatric TB Xrays (part 1) - clues from the frontal film by Savvas Andronikou
description:
Paediatric TB remains an important and under-diagnosed cause of suffering and death in resource-poor settings. In this video, world-expert Savvas Andronikou will provide you with the radiology tools to guide your clinical decision-making, in making the diagnosis of TB.

See part 2 for the approach to the lateral xray here: vimeo.com/77954926

This series of short lectures is brought to you by:
SAMU - Medical Unit of MSF SA - samumsf.org
WFPI - World Federation Pediatric Imaging - pedrad.org/associations/5364/wfpi/

Produced by Aviro Health - avirohealth.com

title: 10 cargos planes filled with emergency supplies send to Philippines
In Syria, a Massive Exodus from Al Safira
description: In five days, fighting left 76 people dead in the town of Al Sarifa alone, and 450 others were wounded. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) was assisting the displaced before these violent attacks started. The area where people were sheltering is now empty, as families look for shelter elsewhere.

title: Living in Fear in Central African Republic
description: Tens of thousands of people had to flee their villages in the north of Central African Republic (CAR) in October. Violence is all too common in CAR: homes are burned down and many people must take shelter in the bush. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) helps to provide medical aid, including for 28,000 people in Bossangoa town who have sought refuge at the Catholic Mission Compound.

title: Treating Burn Injuries in Haiti
description: Droulliard hospital, one of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical facilities in Port-au-Prince, is the only referral unit in the city providing care for burn patients. Completely refurbished in 2013, the unit is constantly full. Many children are victims of domestic accidents; many other patients are burned due to makeshift living conditions, such as fallen electrical wires.

title: Children Are Going Without Vaccinations; MSF Asks for Access to Lower Prices
description: The GAVI Alliance provides vaccines at reduced prices to the world's poorest countries. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) insists that GAVI prices should be available to non-governmental organizations. More than 22 million children still have no access to routine immunization and the cost of fully vaccinating a child has spiked.

title: Finding a Quicker Diagnosis for TB in Colombia
description: Colombia MSF's tuberculosis team in Buenaventura is facing a major challenge... How to deliver effective treatment when the diagnostic process is inadequate? The number of people with tuberculosis in Buenaventura on Columbia's Pacific coast is three times higher than in the rest of the country. And many of them suffer from resistant or multi-resistant forms of the disease. To facilitate earlier diagnosis, MSF is supporting the municipal laboratory, which uses several tools including microscopy, microbiological culture and innovative and more advanced technology Genexpert.

title: An Effective Treatment for Kala Azar in Remote Areas
description: Kala azar is one of the names for visceral leishmaniasis, a parasitic disease spread through the bite of sand flies. Left untreated, it is fatal. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing treatment for kala azar at community level in Bihar, one of India's most populous and impoverished states, for five years.

title: How Many Pills Does It Take? We Need Better TB Treatment
description:
How many pills does it take to treat one person with drug-resistant TB? 14,600! We need better treatment now. 
The two-year regimen for treating DR-TB is extremely arduous and can cause patients to become blind or deaf and can cause organ failure. MSF is calling for better diagnosis and treatment for DR-TB. Support the Test Me, Treat Me DR-TB Manifesto. Sign now at http://msfaccess.org/TBmanifesto/

title: Distant Voices: Drug-Resistant TB Patients in Nagaland, India
description: In the mountainous region of Nagaland, northeast India, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working with local groups and health authorities to treat people with drug-resistant tuberculosis (DR-TB), a form of the disease that does not respond to the two main drugs used to treat TB. The two-year regimen for treating DR-TB is extremely arduous and can cause patients to become blind or deaf and can cause organ failure. MSF is calling for better diagnosis and treatment for DR-TB. Support the Test Me, Treat Me DR-TB Manifesto. Sign now at http://msfaccess.org/TBmanifesto/

title: How Can We Vaccinate More Children?
description:
The Serum Institute of India became the first company to re-license a vaccine for use outside of the cold chain - the cold chain is a method of constant refrigeration that is required for most vaccines to keep their potency but which is completely unrealistic for many rural areas in developing countries. 
The Meningitis A vaccine can now be kept outside of refrigeration at temperatures up to 104 F (40C) for up to 4 days. As a result, many more children will have access to this life-saving vaccine. So what incentives do pharmaceutical companies need to produce more better adapted vaccines for developing countries?

title: Waiting for the Harvest: The fight against malnutrition and malaria in Niger
description:
In Niger, the months before the October harvest are very difficult. Many families have already used up their food stocks, and the rainy season, from June to September, brings more cases of malaria. If a malnourished child also has malaria, he or she often will not want to eat, and treatment becomes complicated. 
To fight the double threat of malnutrition and malaria in Niger, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works at the community level, providing home care with so-called "malaria agents", people from the villages trained to diagnose and treat simple malaria. They also examine the child's nutritional status and vaccination coverage. MSF has also set up seasonal malaria chemoprevention, a preventive strategy that consists of administering antimalarial treatment to children between three months and five years of age each month from July to October, the period of greatest transmission of the disease.

title: Displaced Again in Democratic Republic of Congo
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working in the Mugunga 3 refugee camp in Democratic Republic of Congo's North Kivu Province providing health care to people who have displaced time and time again by violence.

title: Providing Specialized Surgery in Haiti
description: Some 50 people come to the emergency room at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Drouillard Hospital in the Cité Soleil district of Port-au-Prince every day, and half require surgery. In addition to road accidents, people are often injured by violent crime. MSF provides care treatment free of charge; patients also receive psychological support and physiotherapy to give them the best quality of life possible when they leave.

title: Born Free of HIV in Swaziland
description: The HIV/AIDS epidemic has torn apart many families in Swaziland. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has launched a prevention of mother-to-child transmission program, a prevention and treatment pathway for pregnant and breastfeeding women and newborns.

title: A Call to Lift the Humanitarian Blockade in Syria
description: While the chemical weapon attack on a Damascus suburb in August took the horror of what is happening in Syria to a new level, recent diplomatic negotiations barely touched on the issue of aid for the Syrian people. A Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) project coordinator working in Syria and the president of the French section of MSF wrote an open letter entitled "Lift the Humanitarian Blockade" which was published in French newspaper Le Monde in September.

title: MSF Launches Website Revealing Insights to Its Decisions to Speak Out on Crises
description: On October 3, 2013, the international medical humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched an educational website (speakingout.msf.org) that provides unprecedented insight into its decisions during key humanitarian crises of the past 40 years.

title: Four Million Vaccinated for Measles in DR Congo So Far
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins San Frontières (MSF) responds to a recurring measles epidemic in northern Democratic Republic of Congo by ramping up vaccinations and treatment in target areas. In two years, four million people have been vaccinated through the joint efforts of MSF and local health authorities.

title: Filling the Gaps in War-Torn Orientale Province, DR Congo
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) started working in Geti, in Democratic Republic of Congo's Orientale Province, in 2006, bringing medical and mental health care to people who had fled fighting between the army and militias. Today MSF supports both the health center there as well as the General Hospital of Geti.

title: MSF Ramps Up Medical Activities in Northeastern DR Congo After Fighting Breaks Out
description: Several tens of thousands of displaced people have been living in precarious conditions in the region of Ituri, in the northeast Democratic Republic of Congo, for the last two weeks. Fighting broke out between the Congolese armed forces and the militia group, Force de Résistance Patriotique de Ituri (FRPI) on August 22, a battle for control over the southern zones of Ituri. Thousands of people have fled their homes to avoid the fighting. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has strengthened its medical activities in Geti, Orientale Province, to bring medical and mental health care to displaced people.

title: Treatment For Survivors of Sexual Violence in Haiti
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has treated 128 survivors of sexual violence at its Drouillard Hospital in Port-au-Prince so far this year; one third of these patients have been younger than 15 years old. MSF provides immediate medical care for the patients, including prophylaxis for HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases. Counselors provide mental health care, and the project gives patients a certificate in the event they decide to take legal action.

title: Providing Aid In an Overwhelmed Uganda Transit Camp
description: Tens of thousands of refugees have fled violence in North Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of Congo, and come to Bubukwanga transit camp in Uganda. The camp currently hosts twice as many inhabitants as it is built for. The upcoming rainy season is likely to make conditions even worse for the refugees. "We're having to share plastic sheeting, there are no rooms, no roof... And when it rains, we spend the whole night in water," said one refugee. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams are handling the provision of clean water and building latrines, as well as providing healthcare, vaccinations and treatment for malnutrition.

title: Central African Republic Abandoned; MSF Provides Health Care
description: Abandoned by the international community, Central African Republic (CAR) is in the grips of violence perpetrated by armed groups. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a pediatric program in the district hospital of Bria in August; every day some 200 children under 15 arrive. It's the rainy season and 75 percent of them have malaria. Others suffer from respiratory tract infections, diarrhea and malnutrition. Most health facilities no longer function here.

title: MSF Leaves Somalia After 22 Years
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) closed all its medical projects in Somalia after 22 years of negotiating with countless authorities, armed groups and civilian leaders to be able to work there. But these same authorities have tolerated, or even participated in two recent events that triggered MSF's decision to withdraw from the country: the assassination of two MSF staff in Mogadishu at the end of 2011, and the kidnapping of another two who were freed this summer after 21 months of captivity.

title: Thousands of People With Neurotoxic Symptoms Treated in Syria at MSF-Supported Hospitals
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) operates six hospital inside Syria and provides many other Syrian health facilities with technical support and medical supplies. At the end of August, three of these facilities reported to us that they had treated patients displaying neurotoxic symptoms. On August 21, three hospitals in the suburbs of Damascus, where MSF donates supplies, informed MSF that they had treated 3,600 patients displaying neurotoxic symptoms. Syrian doctors had treated them with Atropine supplied by MSF; 355 of the patients died.

title: Cured of Extensively Drug Resistant TB in South Africa
description: With one last, brave gulp, Phumeza Tisile, 23-years-old, put an end to her daily ritual of the last two years and swallowed the last of the 20,000 pills she had taken to cure one of the most severe forms of tuberculosis (TB): extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB). She is the first person in South Africa to be cured of this form of the disease.

title: Thank You for Your Support
description: A message from Melissa Bieri, a Doctors Without Borders logistician in Yida refugee camp, South Sudan.

title: Bringing Blood Testing for HIV Patients Closer in Malawi
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is proving two local health centers in Chiradzulu district, Malawi, with machines that test the blood of HIV patients. The machines will allow health workers to see how effective treatment has been and to make decisions based on those results. Up to now only large regional facilities could provide results like this.

title: Migrants in Yemen Tell of Horrific Experiences
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing mental health care in a detention center in Sana'a, Yemen. Migrants have told counselors of horrific experiences with traffickers; many are trying to return home.

title: MSF Organizes Training For Doctors in Gaza
description: Since doctors in Gaza cannot leave to receive specialized medical training, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) organized an accredited training course for them in Gaza.

title: Lifesaving Vaccinations for Refugees Delayed Due to Price Negotiations
description: In order to prevent the diseases that killed many refugees in Yida camp, South Sudan, in 2012, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has launched a water and sanitation program and begun a vaccination campaign for children. The campaign was pushed back to start now, during the logistically difficult rainy season, because MSF had to engage in lengthy negotiations to get the vaccine at an affordable price.

title: "Now There is No Health Care At All" in Parts of Central African Republic
description: Residents of a village in Central African Republic have no access to medical care due to recent violence. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has arrived there to provide medical care but is worried about levels of malaria, a potential nutrition crisis, and the lack of antiretrovirals for people living with HIV.

title: MSF Forced to Withdraw from Somalia; An In-Depth Interview
description: An in-depth interview on the decision by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) to withdraw completely from Somalia. An MSF General Director, Arjan Hehenkamp, speaks to Somali journalist Hamza Mohamed.

title: On the Road to Growth, Pediatric Project in Konseguela
description:
In Mali, one in five children don't live to see their fifth birthday.

Acute malnutrition affects around 10% of children under the age of five. Malaria is still the leading cause of child mortality in the country, with pneumonia a close second.

Yet there are now straightforward measures for preventing and treating these diseases. 

In the health zone of Konseguela, Médecins Sans Frontières is running a paediatric programme in partnership with the Ministry of Health that incorporates these measures into a comprehensive health care programme targeting the main causes of child mortality.

title: Just Back From Port-au-Prince, Haiti
description: Tracey Hansel, a U.S. doctor, just returned from her first assignment with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), at Drouillard hospital in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Part of her time was spent in the hospital's burn unit, the only free burn care available in the country. She spoke about the one of the best moments of her months there.

title: Vaccination Campaign in Refugee Camp Shows Limits of Access
description:
"Today we'e on the verge of starting a vaccination campaign against pneumococcal disease in Yida refugee camp (in South Sudan). What we would like to do is actually vaccinate all the children under five against pneumococcal disease but we simply can't afford to do that at the prices we're being made to pay for the pneumococcal vaccine." -Dr. Greg Elder, Deputy Director of MSF Operations
Children in crisis need access to newer vaccines to protect them from life-threatening illnesses. To learn more go to http://bit.ly/1cNfgqn

title: Just Back From Yida Refugee Camp, South Sudan
description: Elizabeth Elliott was in charge of human resources and finance at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) project in Yida refugee camp, in South Sudan. Some 75,000 people are living in the camp after having fled from Sudan due to bombings and armed fighting. Read more about Yida here: http://bit.ly/15HwO1C

title: A Syrian Refugee Arrives in Greece
description: One Syrian refugee tells his story of getting to Europe. In 2012, almost 8,000 Syrians arrived in Greece through Turkey, according to Ioanna Kotsioni, a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) migration expert. "First of all, in the very very beginning, people are happy that they have safely reached Europe. They also expect that in Greece, and in Europe in general, they will be received with dignity, that they will receive some basic services, some support, that they will be recognized as refugees. And then they very quickly get disillusioned."

title: In Turkey, A Syrian Refugee Struggles to Get By
description: Kilis, a city on the Turkish side of the border, is the first stop for many Syrians fleeing the conflict; Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is trying to meet the medical needs. One refugee with a badly injured foot tells his story of leaving and surviving.

title: "When the war is over...I want to go back to Syria"
description: Many Syrians risk their lives fleeing the war in their country; they pay smugglers to get them to Turkey or Lebanon and then many continue on to Greece. Without jobs or access to medical care, many refugees are living in bad conditions and with serious health needs. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to assist them.

title: Chronic Health Problems on the Rise in Syria as Health System Crumbles
description: Syrian doctor Jamal describes working with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in a converted school that now serves as an outpatient clinic. As the conflict in Syria wears on and people are forced to live in increasingly difficult conditions. Without adequate access to health care, health problems like diabetes, hypertension, and mental health conditions have increased exponentially.

title: A U.S. Surgeon in Syria: "From Birth to Death"
description: Surgeon Steve Rubin from the U.S. describes his work in one of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospitals in northern Syria. Before the war began, Syrians had access to good quality health care. Now that the country's health system has collapsed, MSF is one of very few remaining actors offering health care for chronic conditions and obstetrics in addition to care for war casualties.

title: Diabetes, Shrapnel Wounds, and Newborn Twins: An MSF Hospital in Syria
description: The conflict in Syria shows no sign of abating, and the number of people in need of urgent medical care increases day by day. In addition to those injured by war there are countless people affected by common health problems that would be entirely manageable in a normal setting. Treatable health issues like diabetes, hypertension, and maternal health can quickly become deadly without access to medical care. As the number of people in need of urgent medical care in Syria continues to rise, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is running six hospitals, four health centers, and several mobile clinic programs inside the country.

title: Trans-Pacific Trade Pact: Hands Off Our Medicines
description: Have you heard about the Trans-Pacific Trade Pact (TPP)? No? You're not alone. Negotiations are being conducted in secret, behind closed doors. But it's slated to become the most harmful trade agreement ever for access to medicines. It's not too late to act. Ask countries negotiating the TPP to protect people in developing countries. Click here for details: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/take-action/tpp/

title: Abandoned HIV Patients in Central African Republic Need Treatment
description: A coup d'état in March in Central African Republic resulted in mass displacement; homes were burned and clinics looted. Some 11,000 HIV patients were cut off from antiretroviral treatment, leaving them at risk of developing resistance to medication, or worse, getting sick and dying. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has resumed medical activities and is trying to get as many people back on treatment as possible.

title: MSF Working to Respond to Rising Medical Needs in Syria
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is running six health structures in northern Syria, where many hospital and clinics were shuttered due to the war; teams are also assisting 7,500 people living in a transit camp near the Turkish border, and running vaccination campaigns in the north of the country.

title: HIV/AIDS Patients Spurned in Yemen
description: People living with HIV/AIDS in Yemen suffer from a severe lack of access to treatment and face strong discrimination from their communities and even their healthcare providers. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working with one hospital and with activist groups to raise awareness of the disease and improve access to treatment.

title: MSF Brings Urgently Needed Care to TB Patients in Colombia
description: Tuberculosis (TB) is more prevalent in Buenaventura, one of Columbia's biggest port cities, than anywhere else in the country. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working there because many people in urgent need of TB treatment have difficulty accessing the healthcare system. More than 300 TB and drug-resistant TB patients were admitted to the program in 2012.

title: New Drug Could Eradicate Sleeping Sickness By 2020
description:
A new drug for the neglected disease sleeping sickness is currently in clinical trials; if the trials are conclusive, Fexinidazole could be registered within two years and sleeping sickness could be eradicated around 2020. This drug would be a vast improvement over current treatment as it's much simpler to administer and thus accessible to many more people.
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and other partner organizations established Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative (DNDi) in 2003 to develop new treatments for neglected diseases, including sleeping sickness.

title: A Village Without Health Care in Malaria Season
description: A coup d'état in March drives all existing health workers out of Benzambe village; clinics are looted, and the community is left with no health care during malaria season. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works to test and treat everyone in this remote part of Central African Republic.

title: "Some Already Died": Violence Cuts Off HIV Patients From Treatment
description:
"Many are still at home without treatment, and some already died," - HIV patient in Bossangoa 
A coup d'état in March in Central African Republic resulted in mass displacement; homes were burned and clinics looted. Some 11,000 HIV patients were cut off from antiretroviral treatment, leaving them at risk of developing resistance to medication, or worse, getting sick and dying.  Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has resumed medical activities and is trying to get as many people back on treatment as possible.

title: Peter, A Refugee's Story in Maban, South Sudan
description: Peter has grown up as a refugee - he first fled Sudan for Ethiopia when he was a child. Today, he lives in a refugee camp in South Sudan where he works for Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) as a translator. He does not believe his dreams will ever be realized, but he has hope for the next generation.

title: Nasrin, A Refugee's Story in Greece
description:
Please click on CC button for English subtitles.
A Greek woman narrates the story of Nasrin, a 23 year-old refugee from Syria. Nasrin told MSF her story earlier this year when she arrived at the island of Lesvos after a harrowing journey from her war-torn homeland into an uncertain future.

title: Lebanon: Syrian Refugees In Harsh Living Conditions, With Growing Health Needs
description: For many Syrian refugees in Lebanon, just getting a roof over their heads and keeping their families fed is a struggle. On World Refugee Day, June 20, Doctors Without Borders /Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) warns that these dire living conditions are affecting people's health.

title: Jawaher, A Refugee's Story in Maban, South Sudan
description: When Jawaher fled the bombing in her native Sudan and crossed the border into South Sudan, she only took three of her children and the clothes on their backs. She was forced to leave her eldest child and embark on a month-long journey to a refugee camp where she and the other children would be safe. She is now being trained as a midwife assistant by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), but she really wants to go home.

title: Anesthesiologist Julia Sobol: Modifying Your Practice in the Field
description: Julia Sobol is an anesthesiologist from New York City, whose first MSF assignment took her to Jahun, Nigeria for 2 months. Here she describes the set-up of the program in Jahun, where MSF provides obstetric care and offers surgery for women with vesicovaginal fistulas. When a piece of equipment she relies on in the United States wasn't available in the field, Julia learned to modify her practice.

title: Anesthesiologist Julia Sobol: One Aid Worker's Workload
description: MSF aid worker Julia Sobol is an anesthesiologist from New York City. Here she talks about her typical workload during a 2 month MSF field assignment in Jahun, Nigeria, where MSF provides obstetric care and offers surgery for women with vesicovaginal fistulas.

title: Anesthesiologist Julia Sobol: Young and Healthy
description: Julia Sobol is an anesthesiologist from New York City. For two months she worked in a maternal health care program in Jahun, Nigeria, where MSF responds to obstetric emergencies and offers surgery for women with vesicovaginal fistulas. While her practice in the United States prepared her for dealing with the death of a patient, she wasn't prepared for how young and healthy her patients would be in her first MSF assignment. Here Julia remembers one of her patients -- a 15-year-old girl who died after delivering a stillborn.

title: Ob-Gyn Veronica Ades: On Mission in South Sudan
description:
Veronica Ades is an ob-gyn in New York City. While working with MSF on a one-month obstetric mission in South Sudan she learned to identify teaching opportunities and to make decisions without the team of ob-gyn colleagues she was used to having. She also had to perform some difficult procedures and diagnose medical conditions she was encountering for the first time.

The MSF reference books Veronica refers to in this video can be downloaded for free from the MSF Reference Books site: http://www.refbooks.msf.org/MSF_Docs/En/MSFdocMenu_en.htm.

TRANSCRIPT
My name is Veronica Ades, I'm an OB/GYN in New York City, and I was in South Sudan doing a one-month obstetric mission.

So most of what we did was take care of the GYN and obstetrical patients, most of the disease that we saw was diarrhea, and urinary tract infection, and then a lot of labor -- a lot of obstructed labor, from either bad pelvises or the usual causes. The national staff really could do the labor and delivery themselves. The midwives were there to round on patients and then to handle complications, um, and then they called me for any complications they couldn't handle themselves -- operative deliveries, C-sections, or just really anything that seemed kind of over their heads.

I think that the biggest difference was that the national staff was not very skilled. They were really eager, but just because of the -- really the lack of available medical education in the country, their skills levels were lower. Teaching was very well-received and was very much needed, but you couldn't necessarily take for granted that they were going to understand what you meant, even if it was a fairly basic nursing skill. For example, they didn't really know how to read a urine dipstick and brought it up to me and I arranged a teaching session around that. But for a long time I was assuming that they were diagnosing UTIs correctly when they weren't. So that was a challenge. I think they were extremely receptive to teaching and critique and so that made it a lot easier. But it certainly made me realize how much I had to be careful about what I was recommending and how much they understood. 

Then I think the other thing is having no other obstetrician around. I'm used to working among lots of other obstetricians and having other people's opinions, especially surgically. When I had to do these really complicated cases I literally had no one else's opinion who had ever seen the situation before, other than the anesthesiologist. And I think that's really daunting because you're worried you're going cut a ureter or you know, hit a vessel and you're the only one who can decide that, so. It's nerve-wracking.

I think the most obvious thing that I hadn't really ever seen before was destructive deliveries -- having to remove a full-term infant vaginally by destroying it I think is something you hear about but never do. It's pretty gruesome. Other than that, I think a lot of the medical conditions -- one was either just conditions I'd never seen before, or two was trying to figure out what these conditions were without the benefit of diagnostic tools. The things I'd never seen before would be -- certainly typhoid and cholera were in the environment, and we didn't know if anyone specifically had it. It was really hard to get testing and you had to go symptomatically. I'd heard a lot about cholera and had learned about it in medical school, but to actually diagnose it myself, I had no idea. And so I really relied on my hospital supervisor to help me with that, and typhoid especially I thought was really challenging diagnosis because you know, the diarrhea is not particularly specific and how would I know that someone had typhoid as opposed to some other form of diarrhea? Everyone had diarrhea. So, I had to call my hospital supervisor and really talk about it and then, you know, MSF has some books in the field that you can look it up in. And then thankfully there was the Internet and you can Google it. 

Besides that, I think it was conditions that maybe I had seen before but I couldn't figure out which condition it was from the symptomotology I had. I had a pregnancy that I couldn't work up because I couldn't do liver function tests or a kidney test or anything. I had a hematuria patient that was really dangerous -- she was very, very anemic and just had red blood in her urine and no way to work it up. So things like that, where you just had to treat empirically, and the patient could easily die if you didn't get it right.

title: Ob-Gyn Veronica Ades: Working with National Staff
description:
Veronica Ades is an ob-gyn and MSF aid worker from New York City. For one month she was the only ob-gyn in MSF's obstetric project in Aweil, South Sudan. Here she talks about the challenges that came with this assignment and the team of midwives and other staff who supported her.

TRANSCRIPT
Before I left, I was warned that I might be put in, like, surgical situations that I'd never had to do before. That didn't necessarily happen to me. I think it came close -- things like an appendectomy or just have someone with a surgical abdomen that might not be obstetrical. Luckily we did have a surgical program a few hours away that we could send people to, so I didn't encounter that particular problem, but I do think that just in general, surgically, not having access to other obstetricians was very different for me. For example I had to do a C-hyst and the patient was already very sick. To open her abdomen and she's continually bleeding, and I had no one to check in with, when usually you would call for help -- I think that to me was a new experience. It wasn't a different surgery from what I'd been trained to do, but it's very different when you're alone. 

I think working with midwives is something I've always done here, but working with midwives who were placed in a different position than they have been. At home, most midwives are trained to do labor really well and delivery very well, but not really medical management of patients, and I think that's a big challenge for them. So for me, I had to become sort of a teacher of midwives who were very well trained in obstetrics to actually become, in some ways, partial doctors. And that was actually really fun for me, it was certainly a challenge. But for them it was the challenge.

Being on call 24/7 is very different from home. I mean, and at home you'll work an entire 24-hour shift, and that's pretty routine. But then you go home and you'll sleep and you'll know that you're not going to be called because someone else is on. But there, for an entire month, I was the only OBE and if something came in, it was all me. And I'd have periods where I was barely called, and I would just round and come home; and I would have periods where I just thought it was never going to end. I think I did eight C-sections in three days, and just round-the-clock, pretty much. I had another time when I had a C-hyst over all night, and then the next day I had to stay really late doing a rape evaluation, and some -- I forgot, something else that required only me. And it was -- you know, those things weren't surgical, but I had to be the person, and it was so tiring. I just thought, if something comes in tonight, I don't know what I'm going to do, I'm so tired. And thankfully nothing did, and the midwives that I worked with were great about trying to help me out and make sure that I was -- actually the whole team was great about trying to make sure that I was rested enough, but that's something that was new and challenging, was being on 24/7 when not your entire team was, just you.

title: Ob-Gyn Veronica Ades: Story of a Patient Who Died
description:
Veronica Ades is an ob-gyn in New York City. During a one-month obstetric mission with MSF in South Sudan, she witnessed the largely preventable tragedies that occur in areas lacking access to maternal health care.

TRANSCRIPT
So, pretty early on when I got to South Sudan, we had a really difficult case and this was my hardest experience there. It was actually my first day and the OB who I was taking over from was still there. I was getting oriented or whatever, and she called me over into the OR and said I'm doing a vacuum, you should come and see how it goes. 

I ended up participating because it was so difficult. And the situation was an 18-year-old girl who was having her first baby and had come in with a stillbirth after laboring for four days at home. And she was already septic, blood pressure was low, pulse was really high, and she was getting antibiotics and actually pressers in the OR. They needed a vacuum to get the baby out. And it was really tough, and I actually ended up scrubbing in with the other OB and we really needed the force of two of us to get that baby out, but we didn't want to have to open her abdomen because that would just make her so much sicker. But we got it out, it actually went okay, and we examined her afterward and tried to see if anything was necrotic but it looked okay. And then we sent her to the ward and in the beginning she was doing ok: she was weak and infected, but talking and her parents were there taking care of her and then um but still very infected, and over the course of the next day, her blood pressure started dropping, and we knew this was probably from sepsis. We made her antibiotics more aggressive, and briefly the anesthesiologist thought it would be a good idea to put her on pressers, because her blood pressure was so low, and we talked that over after a few hours and the hospital supervisor really weighed in, I think, very importantly here and said, "You know, we can't put everyone on pressers, we can't run an ICU, we don't have that capability, and if she isn't better, and isn't supporting her blood pressure after 24 hours, she really needs to do it on her own, because we can't, we can't support this for long." 

She was right. And so we stopped the pressers and she just continued to be very infected, um, and over the next two days, she really decompensated. I don't think the pressers would've saved her -- I think she was just too sick -- but it was really, really hard to watch her die. She just became unconscious and then she -- I think we had to put an NG tube. And her parents just stayed, like, literally sitting in her bed. And by the end her breathing was so labored and it was painful -- like it looked very painful even though she was unconscious -- and I wanted to do something to help her and I could've here, you know? I could've intubated her. I could've sedated her. but you can't -- you can't do anything there, so you just have to watch her die. And her parents at the end were sitting on her bed, each one holding a hand, and just watching her. And when I knew she was going to die, I told them that and I said, "It's really, really likely she's going to die," and we had a translator explain to the parents. And they were accepting; they understood at that point and they said, "You know, it's in God's hands," but to me that was tough. An 18-year-old shouldn't be dying having a baby. So that was hard. I think, you know, you rethink, "What could I have done differently?" and I don't know. I know that she would've lived if she'd given birth in New York, but, I don't know that in that setting that we could've done anything differently. 

It's tough. Maternal mortality really boils my blood because it's entirely preventable, almost entirely preventable. That's a perfect example: she's a young, healthy woman, and if she'd come in after one day of labor instead of four, she'd be alive. I don't know that you ever make it go away. The hospital supervisor actually said something I think that's really true: she said, "Every doctor has their own personal graveyard in their mind," and it's true. Like, you hold them with you forever and you think about them and nobody else knows it's there, but you, you carry it.

title: Ob-Gyn Veronica Ades: Rising to New Challenges
description:
Ob-Gyn Veronica Ades was surprised at what she was able to do on her first assignment with MSF. Here she talks about performing a hysterectomy during a C-section in MSF's obstetric project in Aweil, South Sudan.

TRANSCRIPT
I think there were two situations where I surprised myself in what I was able to do. I think the first was the C-hyst that I had to do. I hadn't done one in residency, and of course I've done hysterectomies, but they're so much more challenging during a C-section. And this woman just clearly needed it. She had a ruptured uterus and she was bleeding to death, and I was super-nervous, you know? I knew I had pieces of the skills, but I'd never put it together in that one situation. But there was -- she only had me, and I was there and I just kept thinking about what my teachers had told me of things like, you know, do what you can do until you're done, you know? Or, establish normal anatomy, or, just take it one step at a time, and things like that really, really helped. And so I was there, with her abdomen open, and the anesthesiologist going, "When is she going to stop bleeding...?" and I just said "Okay, I can do this, so let me do this right now. And I can do this next, and let me do it right now." And I kept going until I think the most nerve-wracking part was when I was at the point where I had to transect the uterine arteries. I was nervous about her ureters; I couldn't see them. And I had used all the techniques I knew to try to identify them and I couldn't find them, and yet if she continued bleeding she wasn't going to need them because she was going to be dead. 

So I said okay, you know, I have these skills, I've done all of these things that I know how to do, and I just need to go ahead and do this. And it was hard; my heart was really beating as I clamped her uterines, but it's fine, she has two intact ureters and that's great, and I think it was -- it just took me saying, I really do know how to do this. Maybe I've never done this particular situation, but I've done all the pieces that are required, and I did it. Alone, with no other obstetricians, and that's amazing.

title: Ob-Gyn Veronica Ades: Caregiving in a Conflict Zone
description:
Veronica Ades is an ob-gyn in New York City. While on a one-month obstetric mission with MSF in South Sudan, she sought to earn the trust of patients affected by years of conflict.

TRANSCRIPT
I don't know if this is a direct effect of conflict, but I think that women's empowerment was quite strikingly low. It was sometimes hard to even get women to be willing to consent for themselves, um, which is difficult, coming from New York, where we expect the women to consent for herself, and her family can be involved, but she actually has to make the decision. And often, she herself was not really willing to do that, um, and often deferred to her husband, and for me ethically, it was important that she understand what was happening. 

And then, you know, I think another thing was that, I realized how connected I was to this nonverbal communication, obviously I don't speak Dinka, but when you don't speak the language at least you can make eye contact and smile. And I would assume that this was a result of chronic conflict, but people are very, very stoic and there's not a reflexive smile. And I realized that to connect with someone nonverbally, it's hard to do that when they don't smile as they're shaking your hand or immediately smile in response to your smile. And I think it's just cultural, but that was sort of striking when I got there. And it made it harder for me, or much more challenging, to find a way to get my patients to trust me without me being able to say anything to them, and I don't know that this is a result of war -- maybe it's just cultural -- but it seemed very striking, and more so than other places that I've been that are stoic and that are suffering, but not in active conflict.

title: Physician Marc Levin: Encountering New Diseases
description:
Marc Levin, a family physician in New York City, has completed MSF missions in Chad, Niger, and the Central African Republic. His assignments with MSF brought him into contact with diseases he had never before treated in the United States, such as rabies, measles, and sleeping sickness.

TRANSCRIPT
So, there were a number of diseases that I treated during my missions with MSF that I hadn't seen in the U.S. and I learned a lot about.  Some things I had certainly heard about or learned about in school, but never actually treated.  Things like rabies, measles -- there always seemed to be measles outbreaks where I was working, both in Niger and the Central African Republic -- meningitis, and in the Central African Republic, part of our project was to address the high prevalence of African sleeping sickness.  

The African sleeping sickness project was really interesting because obviously that's not something we see here.  What we were doing was going into villages that had high prevalence.  Some of the villages had 15 percent prevalence of African sleeping sickness and we would go in and do a mass screening of everyone.  So they would get a finger prick blood test.  It is spread by the tsetse fly, so if anyone in village has it and they get bit by a fly, it can be spread to anyone in the village.  So really the goal is to check everyone on the village, because if you eradicate it from everyone, then no matter how many times the tsetse fly bites, it won't spread the disease.  So the treatment started with mass screening of villages across a huge area in the northern Central African Republic.  If people were positive, then they had further workup, often lumbar punctures.  They would often get ganglion cysts that we would feel and they would get biopsied and then they would be admitted for a week for inpatient IV treatment. 

After that they would need surveillance over two years.  So at six months, 12 months and then two years, they would have lumbar punctures.  So we would go back into the villages and really track these patients and repeat their lumbar punctures to see how they were feeling.  There were a fair number where there was a recurrence and then we would bring them to be retreated.  We reduced the prevalence from about 15 percent in some of the villages to less than 0.5 percent since 2008, I think the project started.  So it was an incredibly successful project.  For me as a physician to really learn and feel comfortable about a new disease that I had never seen was really interesting.

title: Physician Marc Levin: Doing the Best With What You Have
description:
Marc Levin, a family physician in New York City, has completed MSF missions in Chad, Niger, and the Central African Republic. Here he talks about the challenge of diagnosing and treating patients in the field, and how he coped with sometimes limited equipment and diagnostic tests.

TRANSCRIPT
I think that a lot of the things that you see with MSF are often things that you see here, in the U.S., just overseas they can often be fatal.  So things like upper respiratory infections and diarrhea in children.  You probably see more meningitis, tuberculosis, things like that.  But generally I felt I had what I needed.  There were often cases where I just wasn't clear on the diagnosis, where someone was confused.  There was one case in Chad of a teenage girl who just couldn't walk and just had pain in her legs, but the exam was normal and we had no idea why.  Children with severe respiratory illness where it would certainly be helpful to have an x-ray or a CAT scan or an EBG to figure that out.  I had another case that was in Chad where a woman came in just completely confused and we had no idea why.  Certainly something like a head CT or an MRI would be helpful in those cases, but I do feel like the vast majority of cases I had what I needed.  The common diagnoses were very common.  So malnutrition, malaria, during an epidemic, meningitis, respiratory infections, diarrhea.  I think those were the big things that I saw.  

I think that there are cases that I will always remember that I wonder, Did I make the right call and did I treat for the right things?  I think often what happens with those cases is you sort of have your differential and you treat for the top three things.  So people might be on multiple antibiotics or multiple medicines where you are really trying to cover your bases.  

We had a patient, a 14-year-old girl in southeastern Chad and she just came in and she had leg pain and I think it was one-sided, unilateral leg pain.  She had trouble walking and moving her leg.  Her exam was completely normal.  Actually I got a second opinion because my supervising doctor had come from the capitol that week, so I had her look at the leg as well and do an exam and she could actually do a more extensive exam as a woman, because culturally there were parts of the exam that I couldn't do on a 14-year-old girl.  So she did a more extensive exam and everything was normal, everything was fine except the patient said she couldn't walk and she had pain in her leg.  In the U.S. she would have had an x-ray and blood cultures and maybe an MRI to look for acute fractures or osteomyelitus.  Of course, in a displaced persons camp in Chad we didn't have any of that.  We made our best guess and we treated her for osteomyelitus, a bone infection, and we gave her antibiotics IV and about a week later she was better and she went home.  I don't think we'll ever know what that was, but that is often how you have to practice medicine with MSF when you're stumped.

title: Physician Marc Levin: Working Outside Your Comfort Zone
description:
Marc Levin, a family physician in New York City, has completed MSF missions in Chad, Niger, and the Central African Republic. Here he talks about the added responsibilities he took on while working with MSF and the way he got more accustomed to the workload with each successive mission.

TRANSCRIPT
So I think with MSF I can speak as my role as a physician like all people with MSF you feel, you always feel you are a little stretched beyond what you're used to and you are always going to be asked to do more than you are used to in the U.S. and probably do things outside your comfort zone to some degree.  I think as a physician, I was certainly asked to do some things that I would never be asked to do here.  For example, in Chad I was the only physician for 35,000 people, so I was on call all the time, which here in the U.S., I don't think anyone would really ask me to do.  I think in southeastern Chad there wasn't an obstetrician.  I'm a family doctor, so the midwife would do most of the deliveries, but if there were complications, she would call me and so I often had to make decisions about obstetrical care that I would never be asked to do here in the U.S.  Decisions about interventions or assisted deliveries or decisions about C-sections -- things that here in the U.S. I would always have an obstetrician to call upon, but there the nearest surgeon was five hours away by car, so I was sort of the most qualified person in that environment.  

I think non-medically, you have a lot more responsibilities as a physician.  Often you are overseeing the projects or really ensuring quality of care.  Making decisions about staff, about disciplinary actions, about staffing issues, about sort of the direction that a project is going to go in.  Often you are the person who's making those big decisions. 

I think in the U.S. we rely on more administrators or CEOs of health centers to make those decisions, and really with MSF, you're often the person who's making large decisions for the project, at least the medical piece of the project.  

I actually really liked it.  I like being in charge.  Part of me, I felt like this is crazy.  You know I was on call all the time.  I arrived and I had, sort of training.  I overlapped with the doctor that was there previously, so we overlapped for about three days or five days or something, so that was my real training and orientation to the project in Chad.  I was really running the medical project after that.  Part of me thought it was insane to be on call all the time, but part of me really liked it.  I felt like I came to MSF wanting to work and wanting the experience and wanting to be really engaged in the project, so in that sense it was really useful.  I think after two or three months I was pretty exhausted, though.  But like I said before, I think you are always going to be stretched with MSF.  I think that it really pushes you and you come out a better person, a better physician after you go through that experience.  

I think with each mission it got easier, because I understand what is expected.  I think even before it was clear that I would work hard.  It was clear, my responsibilities.  It was clear from my orientations in the New York office as well as meeting with people at the desk in Paris, as well as meeting with people in the capitol.  Really I was clear what the job description was, so I don't think that was really a surprise.  I felt like I got used to it.  I feel like I liked it.  I came back for more missions.  I feel each one was easier because I understood.

title: Physician Marc Levin: How to Make MSF Work With Your Career
description:
MSF aid worker, Marc Levin, has completed several missions with MSF while also maintaining his job as a family physician in New York City. Here he explains how careful planning -- both professionally and financially -- allows him to balance his work with MSF with his career in the United States.

TRANSCRIPT
It was always my dream to work for MSF, and so it was important for me to find ways to make MSF work with my career.  I think the way that I most make it work is planning ahead, really speaking to my employer and finding times when it will work for both of us, when I can go away for periods.  I think financially it is often a challenge because certainly I get paid much less when I work with MSF than when I work in the U.S.  But I think in terms of making choices in my life and living pretty frugally so that I can go on a mission for six months where I don't make a lot of money and still cover my costs here.  

I live in a small apartment here in New York; I sublet my apartment when I go away.  I'm careful about how I spend my money when I'm here so that I can have the MSF experience.  I think the biggest thing is finding an employer or finding a place that will be supportive of your work if it is something that you want to build into your career.  I think that's probably the biggest trick.  And it takes a lot of planning. 

I might want to go tomorrow, but it's just not feasible and I have to wait six months or a year or two years before it's the right time.  But for me, that's what's worked in terms of me maintaining a career here and also maintaining a career with MSF.

title: A New Tuberculosis Drug Under Trial
description: While Bedaquiline, a new drug for the treatment of tuberculosis, is still in the clinical evaluation stage, it shows promising results. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) admitted 29,000 people suffering from tuberculosis on first-line treatment in 2012. Long neglected by research efforts, these patients may soon enjoy the benefits of recent innovation.

title: A Trauma Center in Northeast Syria
description: In a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) trauma center in northeast Syria, surgeons must adapt procedures to the complex and challenging setting. In a country at war, patient care takes on a very different meaning.

title: Lebanon: Tension in Tripoli
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) supports a hospital for some 42,000 Syrian refugees who have fled to the Lebanese city of Tripoli. However, the conflict in Syria has exacerbated the violence that already existed between Sunni and Alawite communities.

title: Iran: Tehran's Neglected Women
description: In Darvazeh Ghar, one of Tehran's most deprived neighborhoods, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams work with city hospitals and a network of local organizations to assist the most disadvantaged families.

title: HIV/AIDS in Yemen
description: HIV is not a major epidemic in Yemen; prevalence is estimated at about 0.2 per cent of the population. However, people living with HIV face stigma and discrimination almost everywhere, even in some health facilities. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to provide treatment and help fight the stigma.

title: Kala Azar: Forgotten Patients
description: Take a look inside a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) project in South Sudan focused on kala azar, a neglected disease that is fatal if not treated; despite the fact that it kills some 50,000 people globally each year, according to the World Health Organization, treatment options are limited by the scarcity of affordable drugs and effective diagnostics.

title: Trans-Pacific Trade Pact: Hands Off Our Medicines
description:
Have you heard about the Trans-Pacific Trade Pact (TPP)? No? You're not alone. Negotiations are being conducted in secret, behind closed doors. But it's slated to become the most harmful trade agreement ever for access to medicines. It's not too late to act. Ask countries negotiating the TPP to protect people in developing countries. Click here for details:
http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/help-us-fix-tpp

title: South Sudan: Preparing for the Rainy Season
description: At the Yida refugee camp in South Sudan, where the population has increased five-fold in the past year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is treating growing numbers of patients and preparing for the additional hardships that will come with the approaching rainy season.

title: Malawi: A Clearer Picture of the AIDS Epidemic
description: In Malawi, where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is now treating 36,000 people living with HIV/AIDS, teams are taking part in an ambitious survey designed to measure the incidence of the disease, seeking to learn if HIV/AIDS is still spreading as rapidly as it was, or if transmission rates have decreased.

title: Jordan: Shattered Lives in the Middle East
description: In Jordan, where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) treats patients who need specialized surgical and rehabilitative care, a project originally designed for Iraqis now also includes people from several other nations, including Yemen, Libya, and Syria.

title: Livesaving Care for Mothers and Children in the Ethiopian Mountains
description: MSF is providing care to mothers in the remote Ethiopian region of Aroressa, where health centers and qualified medical personnel are scarce.

title: A Young Syrian Woman Shot By A Sniper Gets Assistance As A Refugee
description: Salwah, 18 years old, was shot by a sniper in Aleppo, and now she cannot walk. After seeking treatment in several hospitals in Syria, she became a refugee in Turkey where she is now receiving assistance. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing her with mental health care. Photographs by Anna Surinyach.

title: Meet 2-Year-Old Nyota, a Malaria Survivor in Congo
description: When she saw that her two-year-old daughter was ill, Nyota's mother brought her to the MSF clinic in Nyasi, Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), where she was diagnosed with and treated for malaria. Malaria is the leading cause of illness and death in DRC. Last year, MSF treated half a million people in DRC suffering from the deadly disease. Read more at www.doctorswithoutborders.org and follow MSF's work in the Democratic Republic of Congo on Twitter @MSFCongo

title: Tackling the Deadly Combination of Malaria and Malnutrition
description: In southern Niger, malaria and malnutrition together are taking a toll on the population, especially its children. Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontiers (MSF) is pioneering innovative ways to tackle this deadly combination.

title: Dear GAVI, Please Let Us Access Your Discounted Vaccine Prices
description:
The price to vaccinate a child has risen by 2,700 percent over the last decade. Countries where Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works will lose their donor support to pay for vaccines soon, and will have to decide which killer diseases they can and can't afford to protect their children against.
MSF is asking the GAVI Alliance to open up their discounted vaccine pricing to humanitarian actors that are often best placed to respond to vaccinating people in crisis.
Read more here - http://bit.ly/117Wxy0
The GAVI Alliance is an international public-private partnership whose stated mission is to increase access to immunization for children in poor countries. GAVI co-finances the cost of vaccines with qualifying countries. Participants include governments of developing and donor countries, the World Health Organization, UNICEF, the World Bank, the vaccine industry, research and technical agencies, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and other philanthropic organizations.

title: Vaccines: We Need Better Tools to Save Lives
description: To protect children right now, we have to use vaccines that aren't well suited to the job they have to do. Vaccines can't take the heat -- they have to be kept at between 35 and 46 degrees at all times. But we need to use them in some of the hottest places on earth. For this and other reasons, we need better-adapted vaccines to protect children from life-saving illnesses. For more information, go to www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Vaccines: How Much Is Enough?
description:
Children are now protected with 11 vaccines; up from six vaccines a decade ago. The price of vaccinating a child has sky-rocketed. It cost $1.37 to vaccinate a child 10 years ago, now it's $38.80. That's a whopping 2,700 percent increase. So how do we decide how many vaccines children need? Is it based on how much money you can make, or on how many children's lives can be saved?
Bring down vaccine prices and protect more children from life-threatening illnesses. Read more here - http://bit.ly/117Wxy0

title: Syrian Refugees in Need in Iraq
description: The high number of Syrians registering as refugees at the Domeez camp, near the city of Dohuk in the Kurdish region of Iraq, has overstretched the camp's capacity. Domeez camp was established in April 2012 and was initially designed to host 1,000 families. The population in the camp has now risen above 35,000 people, however. Despite the efforts of the local authorities, the level of assistance is clearly insufficient, and aid workers are struggling to keep up with the needs of all the residents. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing thousands of medical consultations every day, has supplied families with water and hygiene kits, and is planning a measles vaccination campaign.

title: Malian Refugees Find Safety, Health Risks in Mauritania Camp
description:
Malian refugees began arriving in Mauritania in February 2012; today, almost 70,000 people are living in Mbera camp alone. There, they are far from the conflict, but living conditions are difficult and many children are becoming malnourished. 



Though the camp is far from the conflict, living conditions here are precarious. Since the start of the year, the number of malnourished children has more than doubled. 

Close to 170,000 refugees now live in the countries bordering Mali. They hear the stories of the continuing violence back in Mali. They will not return home any time soon.

title: Affordable Access to Generic Drugs Is Safe - For Now
description:
On April 1, 2013, a landmark ruling by India's Supreme Court ensured continued access to affordable HIV medication for the millions affected by this disease, including the 220,000 patients that Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) treats with generic HIV/AIDS medication. 

This access has been under threat for the past seven years by pharmaceutical company Novartis, which challenged a section of India's Patents Act that prevented the practice of "evergreening," or extending the patent of an existing medicine by modifying it slightly. By extending patents, pharmaceutical companies prevent the manufacture of generic drugs. The ruling by India's Supreme Court is a victory for those fighting for access to affordable medicine -- at least, for the time being.

title: Migrants Trapped and Often Abused in Morocco
description:
The report "Trapped at the Gates of Europe" raises the alarm about the situation of Sub-Saharan migrants in Morocco. Sub-Saharan migrants making their way to Europe often find themselves trapped in this country, and as EU border nations step up their combat against illegal immigration, the migrants' living conditions worsen.
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff observed an escalation in intentional violence, and increased numbers of patients abused by Moroccan security forces and sometimes by Spanish security forces. The report also looks at sexual violence endured by female migrants. In the past two years, MSF has treated 700 victims who receive no assistance or protection from the authorities.  



In spite of the violence, migrants' access to healthcare has somewhat improved, notes the report. With human rights now the number one priority among advocates, MSF has handed over its activities to specialist organizations.

title: Starting New Lives Safely in Papua New Guinea
description:
The autonomous island of Bougainville is slowly emerging from decades of conflict. 
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) set up medical facilities in Buin, a remote village in the south of the island, in June 2011. Admissions to the maternity unit, have steadily increased since the project's inception. 

Expectant mothers are referred by small clinics in the area. They spend several days here before giving birth to avoid traveling on rough roads during labor. MSF is also supporting an awareness-raising campaign to teach women about a new program for victims of sexual violence. Up until now, there has been no such treatment available in Bougainville.

title: Chechens Get New Cardiology Equipment and a New Lease on Life
description:
After years of war, Chechnya's health system is failing. Its citizens are falling victim to noncommunicable diseases antagonized by bad habits, such as smoking and poor diet, not to mention the stress of living in a war zone. As a result, two thirds of deaths in the country are caused by cardiovascular disease.
