Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works in Grozny's Republican Emergency Hospital, where today there is hope: in the hospital's cardiology unit, new equipment is helping to improve the health of Chechens. 

Oxygen concentrators, defibrillators and electro cardiographs have reduced the unit's mortality rate by over 75 percent, according to staff there, who treated more than 1,500 patients in just one year.

title: Women in Somalia Look For A Safe Delivery
description:
Life is difficult in Mogadishu, despite recent improvements. More than 370,000 displaced people live in the city with limited access to health care, food and water. Pregnant women in particular are suffering: They give birth in difficult conditions, at the mercy of the slightest complication. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a hospital in Mogadishu in 2011, and the maternity unit has been full ever since.
However in the Xadaar district of the city, MSF was recently forced to close its clinic, as security there is tenuous.

title: 'Evergreening' Is What Drug Companies Do To Increase Their Profits
description: Drug companies are awarded patents on a new drug for 20 years. After 20 years they have to allow for the generic manufacture of these drugs. Evergreening is when a company makes minor change to the drug to receive another 20-year patent. This leaves people in developing countries forever unable to get the medicines they need. India has a law that stops evergreening. Novartis has been fighting this law for 6 years. If they win, people all over the world will lose - they will lose a lot more than just a court case. Go to www.msfaccess.org/STOPnovartis

title: Afghanistan: Mobile Medical Care in Kabul
description: The population of Kabul has tripled over the last 10 years. Some people arrive after fleeing conflict-torn areas for the relative safety of the capital, while others, pushed by poverty, are simply trying to make a living. Returnees from Pakistan and other provinces of Afghanistan have also made their way back to the city. For those living in makeshift settlements and camps, the harsh winter makes an already difficult situation even harder. In January 2013, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) started running mobile clinics and nutritional screenings in six locations where hundreds of Afghans have settled.

title: Women Rendered Incontinent In Childbirth Get Transformative Surgery
description: Another group of women are cured of fistulas at the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Jahun, Nigeria. The program helps women who sustain injuries during obstructed childbirth and are rendered incontinent. An estimated 800,000 women are effected by fistula in Nigeria.

title: Much-Needed Hospital in Somalia Reopens After 6 Months
description: Daynile Hospital in Somalia's Mogadishu suburbs is open again after a six-month closure due to security concerns. There is very limited health care in Somalia and people from far and wide rely on this Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospital. Many patients receive surgical treatment for injuries during sporatic fighting; the team also sees chronic health problems such as diabetes and high blood pressure.

title: Syrian Refugees in Host Countries Wait For Aid, Suffer Illnesses
description: Refugees who have made it out of Syria are pouring into camps in neighboring countries, and international aid is not keeping up. In one camp in Lebanon families must wait weeks or months to be registered, meanwhile having to share tents with other families outside the camp and receiving no food aid. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is treating people suffering from illnesses often related to the living conditions.

title: Living Conditions Inside Syria Getting Worse; Leading To More Health Problems
description: Drug manufacturing in Syria has halted and getting medicine from outside is extremely difficult. Available medical care gives priority to those injured in the conflict. Women and children suffering from chronic health problems or domestic injuries - including burns - are not getting care. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has responded to the need for medical care by opening three hospitals in Syria.

title: "A Humiliating Situation," Syrian Refugees in Lebanon
description: Meet some of the more than 120,000 Syrian refugees living in the Bekaa Valley in Lebanon while their country is at war. Families are living in camps, unfinished houses, and abandoned buildings. They are not getting adequate aid.

title: Restarting Health Care in Konna, Mali
description: A physician with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in the town of Konna, Mali, describes how MSF teams are treating patients and helping to restart the healthcare system there after fighting there caused many health workers to flee the area. MSF also continues to work in the regions of Mopti, Gao, and Timbuktu.

title: Bringing Much-Needed Medical Care to Timbuktu
description: Liberian project coordinator Toe Jackson describes how his Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) team brought much-needed medical care to conflict-ridden Timbuktu, Mali.

title: MSF Trains Syrians To Give First Aid at Front Line, Denounces Imbalanced Distribution of Aid
description: The majority of international humanitarian aid is being implemented from the capital city of Damascus and distributed to areas under government control. Aid remains minimal for some seven million Syrians living in opposition-held regions, where conditions continue to worsen. During a donor conference held in late January, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) spoke out about the imbalanced distribution of international aid provided to Syria. MSF teams are providing care for patients in neglected areas and training Syrians to give first aid near the front line.

title: Fighting Neglected Disease Sleeping Sickness in South Sudan
description: Sleeping sickness has been a major health problem in South Sudan for the last century. Transmitted by the tse tse fly, it can be fatal if left untreated. Over a ten-week period, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mobile teams based in Kajo Keji traveled to remote villages where patients have little access to medical care, screening over 37,000 people for the disease and providing treatment to those in need.

title: Treating Those Caught In Mali's Armed Conflict
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have remained in northern Mali throughout the recent crisis in order provide medical care to the local population. MSF has treated 35 wounded patients in Timbuktu over the past few weeks and is running programs in Mauritania, Niger, and Burkina Faso to assist those fleeing the conflict.

title: In Helmand, Trying To Save Critically Ill Patients
description: In Afghanistan's southern province of Helmand, few hospitals continue to function. People embark on long and dangerous journeys to reach the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hospital in the province's capital, Lashkargah. The MSF's team challenge is to try to save the lives of patients who often arrive near death.

title: Access to the Danger Zone [trailer]
description:
Directed by Peter Casaer and narrated by Daniel Day-Lewis, this documentary provides a harrowing look at the challenges of delivering humanitarian aid in armed conflicts. "Access to the Danger Zone" explores the strategies that Doctors Without Borders uses to save lives in the world's worst war zones, including Afghanistan, Somalia and eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.

More info: http://bit.ly/12EuDte

title: Many Syrian Refugees In Lebanon Live In Desperate Conditions
description: The conflict in Syria has forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their country for neighboring Lebanon. According to a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) study conducted in May 2012, over half of the refugees are living in unsanitary conditions with no access to desperately needed medical care. MSF teams working in Tripoli and the Bekaa Valley are providing refugees with free health care and distributing supplies, but the medical facilities are often overwhelmed. MSF continues to ramp up its activities in the country.

title: Battling a Measles Epidemic in Northeast Congo
description: Following a recent malaria epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a measles outbreak has spread through some 20 health zones in the the country's Orientale Province. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has deployed major logistical support to treat 16,000 patients and vaccinate close to 340,000 children in the affected regions.

title: Afghanistan: A Hospital in Helmand
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is supporting the regional Boost Hospital in Lashkargah, the capital of Afghanistan's Helmand Province. Our aim is to provide free, life-saving medical care in all areas, including maternity, pediatrics, surgery and emergency room service.

title: Lives in the Balance conference - Day 1 Welcome & Keynote Address
Lives in the Balance conference - Day 1 - Dr Kim Address
Lives in the Balance conference - Panel 1.1
Lives in the Balance conference - Panel 1.2
Lives in the Balance conference - Roundtable 1.3
Lives in the Balance conference - Roundtable 1.4
Lives in the Balance conference - Day 1 Closing
Lives in the Balance conference - Day 2 Welcome
Lives in the Balance conference - Tech Session 2.1 DR TB
Lives in the Balance conference - Tech Session 2.2 Chagas
Lives in the Balance conference - Tech Session 2.3 Vaccines
Lives in the Balance conference - Day 2 Closing
In War-Ravaged Syria, MSF Works To Get People Access To Medical Care
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is supporting a secret healthcare facility in Idlib Province and continues to try to improve access to medical care in war-ravaged areas.

title: Pushing For More Research And Development For Neglected Diseases
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) hosted a conference in New York that brought researchers, global health experts and donors together to discuss research and development initiatives in the field of neglected diseases. Since these diseases usually affect poor populations, research for finding better drugs and diagnostics for them is scarce.

title: Vaccinating To Prevent a Measles Epidemic in DRC Camps
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is vaccinating children in displaced persons camps in the Democratic Republic of Congo to prevent an epidemic.

title: A Month In Focus: January 2013
description: The January 2013 Month In Focus features brief reports on the following Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) activities: assisting destitute civilians in Syria; a positive report on treatment of tuberculosis; an international conference in New York on fatally neglected diseases; monitoring the situation in Yida refugee camp in South Sudan; and preventing a measles epidemic among displaced children in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: The First New TB Drug Since 1963 Approved
description: The first new drug approved to treat tuberculosis (TB) since 1963 could result in shorter treatment with less side effects and the opportunity to treat more people. For people with drug-resistant TB, it could present a new lifeline.

title: MSF Monitors the Situation in Yida Camp, South Sudan
description: The end of the rainy season and continued conflict have pushed a new wave of people to Yida refugee camp in South Sudan. The high mortality rate Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) saw in July has stabilized, but levels of malnutrition among displaced children remain high.

title: HR and Finance Coordinator Ann Kane: Software Programs Used in the Field
description: HR and Finance Coordinator Ann Kane describes the computer programs MSF typically uses in the field.

title: HR and Finance Coordinator Ann Kane: Learning It In The Field
description: As an HR and finance coordinator at MSF projects, Ann Kane is responsible for many things she would never deal with in the US.

title: Midwife Rebecca Ullman: Managing a French-Speaking Team In Limited French
description: Language issues add another layer to the challenges of managing an international team.

title: Midwife Rebecca Ullman: How I Made MSF Work in My Life
description: Rebecca Ullman is a midwife who worked with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Ivory Coast.

title: Midwife Rebecca Ullman: Living With An International Team
description: There are advantages and disadvantages to living and working shoulder to shoulder with a group of people from all over the world, at different ages and with language skills. MSF midwife Rebecca Ullman describes her experiences and what she's learned.

title: Midwife Rebecca Ullman: Stepping On Toes, Developing Awareness
description: Midwife Rebecca Ullman learned the hard way that at an international project lines of communication can get crossed and sometimes you have to dig a little deeper to find out what your role really is.

title: HR and Finance Coordinator Ann Kane: Know Your Cultural Norms
description: Dealing with your staff, as well as with government personnel and others, requires you to find out what the cultural and social expectations are in that country.

title: Midwife Rebecca Ullman: Learning From National Staff
description: Midwife Rebecca Ullman learned how to treat patients better by learning from experienced national staff midwives.

title: Physician Amitha Sampath: An Exchange of Ideas in the Field
description: Amitha Sampath is a physician with MSF. She is from New York City and is trained as a pediatrician. She has worked with MSF in Nigeria and in Sierra Leone. Here she talks about how working in the field differs from working in the US and what she gained from working with her national staff colleagues.

title: Physician Amitha Sampath: Treating Unfamiliar Diseases
description: Amitha Sampath is a physician with MSF. She is from New York City and is trained as a pediatrician. Working with MSF in Nigeria and in Sierra Leone, she learned a lot about diseases she rarely or never saw in her US practice. The books Amitha refers to in this video are MSF Clinical Guidelines: Diagnostic and Treatment Manual and Essential Drugs: Practical Guidelines. They can be ordered from the MSF-USA bookstore here - http://www.refbooks.msf.org/MSF_Docs/En/MSFdocMenu_en.htm

title: Physician Amitha Sampath: A Surprising Recovery
description: Amitha Sampath is a physician with MSF. She is from New York City and is trained as a pediatrician. Working with MSF in northern Nigeria, she helped treat a very sick child with TB who made an amazing recovery.

title: Physician Amitha Sampath: Cultural Factors Come Into Play in Medicine
description: Amitha Sampath is a physician with MSF. She is from New York City and is trained as a pediatrician. Working with MSF in Nigeria and in Sierra Leone, she encountered cultural issues with patients that had great impact on their treatment and lives.

title: MSF in Honduras: Violence in the Streets of Tegucigalpa
description:
In Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing medical assistance to vulnerable people facing extreme  violence and a lack of access to health care. Many of these patients are young people who live on the streets and suffer the most from what MSF staff call an "epidemic of violence". Photographs and voiceover by Spencer Platt.

Learn more about Doctors Without Borders's lifesaving efforts in Honduras: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/what-we-do/countries/honduras

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières helps people worldwide where the need is greatest, delivering emergency medical aid to people affected by conflict, epidemics, disasters, or exclusion from health care. Learn more at http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org

SUBSCRIBE: https://goo.gl/BtzdsR

Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/doctorswithoutborders
Follow us on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/doctorswithoutborders/
Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/MSF_USA
Connect with us on LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/medecins-sans-frontieres-msf
Sign up for our newsletter: https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/quick-signup-confirm

title: 24 Hours In Burco Hospital, Part 2: The Maternity Ward
description:
The town of Burco (also written as 'Burao'), in Somaliland, has the largest public hospital in the area and serves at least 350,000 people.

Last year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams joined Ministry of Health staff at this eight-ward hospital to start providing high-quality, free medical services. Now, Somali staff work alongside MSF staff from as far away as China and Denmark so that patients with medical emergencies receive quality health care. 

Maternal mortality rates in Somaliland are among the worst in the world, and the hospital's maternity ward is by far the busiest department in the hospital. A team of experienced midwives and doctors run this busy unit, which has seen a substantial increase in the number of admissions over the last year.

title: 24 Hours In Burco Hospital, Part 3: The Surgery Ward
description:
The town of Burco (also written as 'Burao'), in Somaliland, has the largest public hospital in the area and serves at least 350,000 people.

Last year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams joined Ministry of Health staff at this eight-ward hospital to start providing high-quality, free medical services. Now, Somali staff work alongside MSF staff from as far away as China and Norway so that patients with medical emergencies receive quality health care. 

Trained surgeons are available 24 hours a day at Burco Hospital, whether for trauma or obstetric operations. Many patients choose to visit local healers before coming to the hospital, which can cause dangerous delays or even additional medical problems.

title: 24 Hours In Burco Hospital, Part 1: The Emergency Room
description:
The town of Burco (also written as 'Burao'), in Somaliland, has the largest public hospital in the area and serves at least 350,000 people.

Last year, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical teams joined Ministry of Health staff at this eight-ward hospital to start providing high-quality, free medical services. Now, Somali staff work alongside MSF staff from as far away as China and Denmark so that patients with medical emergencies receive quality health care. 

The hospital's emergency room is the point of entry for many patients. More than 4,500 people were seen there during the first nine months of 2012. This first video in a series of three looks at the emergency room.

title: MSF USA Executive Director Thanks Reddit Atheists
description: MSF USA Executive Director, Sophie Delaunay, thanks reddit atheists for their continued generous support.

title: Coming To Terms With TB In Chechnya
description: After years of conflict, a large number of tuberculosis (TB) cases are now being diagnosed in Chechnya. Half are drug-resistant cases. To help ensure that patients adhere to treatment, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has set up a counseling program which is an integral part of the treatment.

title: The Plight of Displaced People in DRC
description:
The M23 rebels' advance on Goma left hundreds of casualties and hundreds of thousands of displaced people in its wake.
In addition to its activities in several large hospitals, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has set up mobile clinics inside the camp and continues consultations at the health center.

title: A Hidden Crisis in South Sudan
description: In South Sudan's Jonglei State, civilians are caught up in inter-communal clashes. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has published a report which describes the devastating consequences of the fighting on the health of displaced people.

title: Eradicating Yaws in Congo
description:
For over two months, on foot, by car, and in dug-out canoes, three Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams scoured the tropical forest of the Republic of Congo to reach the Aka Pygmies, a marginalized people with no access to health care. 
The teams' goal was to eradicate from the community an infectious disease called Yaws.  They organized a mass treatment campaign where everyone was given a single dose of antibiotic, enough to cure the disease.
More than 17,000 people were treated for yaws, of whom nearly 7,000 were children under the age of 15.
Now it is time for MSF to pass on the baton.

title: After Sandy, Haiti Hit With More Cholera
description:
Hurricane Sandy hit Haiti in late October, bringing with it a rise in cholera cases. Even though the Ministry of Health's response to cholera remains inadequate, many aid organizations are leaving the country. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) runs five cholera treatment centers to respond to the epidemic and teams have increased the number of beds in order to deal with the influx of patients.
At the treatment centers, patients receive oral or intravenous rehydration and the most severe cases receive antibiotics.

title: Conflict Creates Dire Medical Needs In Syria
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is doing what it can to address the serious lack of medical care for civilians in northern Syria. 

Women who would ordinarily give birth in hospital now don't have medical facilities where they can deliver in a safe environment. People with chronic diseases still need medical assistance, but it is hard to find. Medical staff in Syria face the huge challenge of how to work in an insecure and extremely volatile environment. Numerous hospitals and health centers stand in ruins—living proof of the desperate health situation there. 

MSF is trying to meet these needs, as well as the emergency needs of people with war-related injuries. MSF field hospitals in the north of the country are treating people with  gunshot wounds, shrapnel wounds, open fractures, and injuries caused by bombs.

title: MSF USA Executive Director Thanks Reddit Atheists
description:
MSF USA Executive Director, Sophie Delaunay, thanks reddit atheists for their generous support.  

The community has raised over $210,000 for MSF since 2011.

title: At Any Price? The Price of Refusal
description: Sudan, 1997

title: At Any Price? The Price of Security
description: Rutshuru, North Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of Congo, 2007

title: Month in Focus: December 2012
description: This month, we focus on treating tuberculosis in Chechnya, fighting Yaws in Congo, civilians displaced by conflict in DRC and South Sudan's Jonglei State, and a rise in cholera cases in Haiti in the wake of Hurricane Sandy.

title: Doctors Without Borders
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) works in nearly 70 countries providing medical aid to those most in need regardless of their race, religion, or political affiliation.

http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/donate

title: Join the Club (2)
description:
Piloted by Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) in Khayelitsha, the award-winning ART Adherence Club model focuses on patient participation and peer support, for improved treatment adherence. This simple model allows patient groups to collect pre-packed, two-month supplies of treatment from lay health workers either at the clinic or outside of the clinic - whether at a local library or at a fellow patients home.

ART Adherence Clubs give stable adherent HIV patients easier access to their treatment, while unclogging clinics and freeing up scarce nurses and doctors to manage new or at-risk HIV patients.

Today, the Cape Town Metro is home to more than 400 of these clubs as part of a partnership between MSF, the Western Cape Department of Health, Cape Town's City Health and the Institute for Healthcare Improvement.

Due to growing interest in replicating the model, MSF has produced a report and practical toolkit which includes a step-by-step, 'How-to' guide, two short films and additional information on tailoring the model to various contexts.
[15:17 minutes]

title: Join the Club
description:
Piloted by Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders (MSF) in Khayelitsha, the award-winning ART Adherence Club model focuses on patient participation and peer support, for improved treatment adherence. This simple model allows patient groups to collect pre-packed, two-month supplies of treatment from lay health workers either at the clinic or outside of the clinic - whether at a local library or at a fellow patients home.

ART Adherence Clubs give stable adherent HIV patients easier access to their treatment, while unclogging clinics and freeing up scarce nurses and doctors to manage new or at-risk HIV patients.

Today, the Cape Town Metro is home to more than 400 of these clubs as part of a partnership between MSF, the Western Cape Department of Health, Cape Town's City Health and the Institute for Healthcare Improvement.

Due to growing interest in replicating the model, MSF has produced a report and practical toolkit which includes a step-by-step, 'How-to' guide, two short films and additional information on tailoring the model to various contexts.
[06:42 minutes]

title: Surgery in Syria
description: The conflict in Syria is escalating. Civilians are bearing the brunt of indiscriminate violence. Over the past four months, MSF has opened four field hospitals in northern Syria, and is providing emergency medical treatment, including surgery. MSF medical teams have treated more than 2,500 patients and carried out around 550 surgical procedures, and MSF is looking to expand its relief activities.

title: Surgery in Syria, Part 1: Building An Operating Theater In A Cave
description: British surgeon Paul McMaster recently returned from Syria, where he treated the wounded first in an operating theater set up in a cave and then on a farm. Though McMaster has experience working in war zones, in Syria he found a "more oppressive type of danger." Here, he reflects on his experiences.

title: Malaria: Offering Children a Chance
description: For the first time, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been employing seasonal malaria chemoprevention (SMC) in Chad and Mali.170,000 children aged between three months and five years received anti-malaria medicines during the peak transmission season. This treatment, recommended by the World Health Organization, will not eradicate malaria definitively. But in countries like Chad and Mali, where malaria is the first cause of infant and child mortality, it does have an important role to play in emergency situations.

title: Sri Lanka: End of Mission
description: Twenty-six years after first working in the country in 1986, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams have handed over the last remaining projects in Sri Lanka and MSF has left the country.

title: Congo: Yaws in the Forest
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) heads into Congo's tropical forest to treat the Pygmy population for yaws.

title: Novartis: Court Case in India Begins
description: The lawsuit brought against the Indian Government by Swiss pharmaceutical company Novartis began in New Delhi on September 11. This new offensive follows the failure of a previous court case six years ago. Novartis is contesting part of Indian law on patents that enables Indian manufacturers to produce affordable generic drugs. Learn more at http://www.msfaccess.org/STOPnovartis/.

title: Niger: Malaria and Malnutrition, the Double Sentence
description: The pediatric unit in Niger's Guidan Roumji hospital is overwhelmed. Since the beginning of the year, MSF has treated close to 69,000 malnourished children and 175,000 cases of malaria. Southern Niger is still rife with malnutrition. In July, torrential rains destroyed crops and grain reserves. During the rainy season, malaria-transmitting mosquitoes proliferate. And malnourished children, already weak, run a higher risk of developing a severe form of malaria.

title: Swaziland - MDRTB HIV Coinfection
description:
In Swaziland, high rates of HIV and TB co-infection have fuelled a rise in multi-drug resistant TB (MDR-TB). Resistant to both of the most common TB drugs, MDR-TB treatment lasts about two years. 
 
In this film, Briget Tuwala speaks about losing her daughter to MDR-TB after confirmatory tests took too long to come back from the lab. Sibusiso Dlamini, an MDR-TB patient, describes the painful injections that comprise at least eight months of MDR-TB treatment. These injections can lead to hearing loss, loss of feeling in the legs and depression in patients.
 
Only about 60 percent of MDR-TB patients will successfully complete treatment, leading MSF to call for shorter, better and more easily tolerated treatment.

title: Month in Focus: September 2012
description: This month, we focus on Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)'s efforts to improve the situation in South Sudan's Yida refugee camp, a makeshift hospital in Syria, aid to victims of flooding in the Philippines, displaced Sudanese refugees in Ethiopia, fighting cholera in Guinea and Sierra Leone, and the successful containment of an Ebola outbreak in Uganda.

title: In Syria, MSF Works In A Makeshift Hospital
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been working in Syria in cooperation with an association of Syrian doctors, the UOSSM, since June.

title: An Improved Situation in Yida Camp, South Sudan
description: After Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) scaled up its operations in Yida refugee camp in South Sudan, the mortality rate fell sharply in just one month.

title: Philippines: MSF Aids Victims of Torrential Rains
description: In response to torrential rains in the Philippines, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has distributed 2,600 hygiene kits in the province of Bucalan and are assisting with outreach and clean-up.

title: Ethiopia: MSF Treats Displaced Sudanese Refugees
description: Ethiopian authorities denied Sudanese refugees access to humanitarian aid when they refused to leave the camp where they were staying. When many of them did arrive at a new camp site, a quarter of under-five-year olds were acutely malnourished. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a therapeutic feeding center at the new camp and offered vaccination services.

title: Fighting A Cholera Outbreak In Guinea And Sierra Leone
description: A cholera epidemic in the capitals of Guinea and Sierra Leone was declared in February. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has treated nearly 8,000 people in the two countries.

title: MSF Helps Contain Ebola in Uganda
description: An Ebola outbreak occurred in the Ugandan area of Kibaalé at the end of July. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) launched an emergency intervention to contain the spread of the virus, which has killed 16 people.

title: Swat Sleeping Sickness: A Call to Action
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been actively engaged in controlling and treating sleeping sickness for the past 25 years, screening three million people and treating more than fifty thousand.

To date, MSF's mobile sleeping sickness team has worked in Central African Republic, Chad, and Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), and are soon to work in South Sudan. 

MSF also runs ongoing sleeping sickness programs in South Sudan, Central African republic, and DRC.

title: Fighting Double Impact of Malnutrition and Malaria in Niger
description: A food crisis is affecting an estimated 18 million people across Africa's Sahel region right now, including in Niger, where four million children are projected to suffer from acute malnutrition, with at least one million at risk of developing severe acute malnutrition. At the same time, 80 percent of children who come to Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) clinics in Niger test positive for malaria. MSF is trying to reach those who need help the most. Go to www.doctorswithoutborders.org for more information.

title: Fulbright Awards Ceremony - In Honor of Doctors Without Borders
description:
On September 8, 2012, the Fulbright Association presented its 2012 J. William Fulbright Prize for International Understanding to Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)at the Library of Congress in Washington, DC.

The award, a $50,000 prize, was received with a speech by Dr. Unni Karunakara, international president of MSF.  MSF will utilize the funds from the Fulbright Prize to support its efforts in pioneering a more patient-friendly treatment regimen for people living with drug-resistant TB.

Mark Harrington, executive director of the Treatment Action Group, provided a short tribute to MSF prior to the presentation of the award.

title: Violence in Eastern DRC: Patient Testimonies
description:
Fleeing one's home to escape violence has become a fact of life for ordinary people in the east of Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), where a conflict is raging between multiple armed groups in the provinces of North and South Kivu. The area around Lake Kivu, with its lush vegetation, has a complex history of inter-ethnic violence and battles for the control of mineral wealth. 

These are some of the human stories behind the conflict in the Kivus, where civilians suffer from a lack of resources and difficulties accessing health care. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing medical and humanitarian aid to the victims of war in DRC since 1996, and is currently providing high-quality medical care in North and South Kivu in 10 referral hospitals, 31 health centers, nine health posts, and a number of cholera treatment centers.

title: Novartis's 6-Year Legal Challenge Against India's Pro-Health Law Heads to Supreme Court
description: Swiss pharmaceutical company Novartis heads to the Indian Supreme Court today in New Delhi, in a final bid to undermine a key public health safeguard in Indian patent law specifically designed to prevent drug companies from abusive patenting practices that keep medicine prices high. If successful, the move would have a devastating impact on access to essential medicines across the developing world, according to the international medical humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), which relies on affordable generic drugs produced in India to carry out its work in 68 countries.

title: The Patient Becomes the Healer
description:
Francis Gatluak was one of the first people Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) ever treated for kala azar, a neglected disease also known as visceral leishmaniasis. Francis came from a small village in South Sudan's Unity State, still a conflict area today. When he was young, the men and boys fled the village to avoid being killed by fighters from either side of the conflict. As the war continued through the late 1980s, famine struck. And people became victims of an epidemic outbreak of kala azar, a rare and neglected tropical disease, transmitted by the bite of the sandfly. Left untreated, it's deadly 95 percent of the time. When people began dying in the MSF health clinic in Leer - including Francis's brother -  no one knew what was killing them. By the time Francis got sick, they had diagnosed the disease as kala azar. When Francis became better, he stayed at the hospital and began working with MSF, first as a translator, and then he began to learn how to provide treatment. He also offered valuable information to the MSF team. He knew that the majority of patients were coming from a famine-stricken area of Unity State called Duar. Nearly all the patients in Leer, and hundreds more other displaced people treated by MSF, had all come from the area around Duar. He urged MSF to go to Duar and provide treatment there. His persistence paid off. MSF established a clinic in Duar in 1990. Because of Francis's far-reaching
initiative, around 10,000 people were treated for kala azar, in the project's first year alone. Francis now works as a nurse. He's currently in his 23rd year with MSF. 
This video was screened at the Fulbright Prize ceremony on September 8, 2012, when MSF was given this prestigious award. Go to www.doctorswithoutborders.org for more.

title: Situation Critical: South Sudan
description:
Over the past eight months, more than 170,000 refugees have fled into South Sudan, yet this escalating emergency has received scant media attention compared to the scale of the crisis.

More info: http://bit.ly/RHFwVf

title: Putting Our Best Foot Forward Satellite
description: MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Intellectual Property Workshop
description: MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Young People, HIV & Reproductive Health Services
description: MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Antiretroviral Therapy in Resource-Limited Settings
description:
Participants will leave this workshop with a better understanding on use of second-line ART in RLS, including the complex intersections between chronic HIV infection, long-term antiretroviral drug exposure and chronic-degenerative co-morbidities, and the latest scientific evidence on the use of ART as HIV prevention.

MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Proposals for a Global Innovation System
description:
The challenges but also promising initiatives that could facilitate the development of affordable medical tools adapted to the needs of patients in resource-limited settings.

MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: HIV Responses in the Context of Migration
description: Addressing HIV vulnerability of irregular Zimbabwean cross-border migrants in South Africa. MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Beyond the Clinics: Novel Approaches to HIV Testing
description: MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Press Conference: The Battle for Access
description:
Middle-income countries are increasingly taking measures to overcome the patents that price drugs out of reach.

MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Press Conference: The Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement
description:
Encompassing eleven countries and slated for further expansion across the Asia Pacific region, the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement (TPP) is a regional trade agreement that will "set the standard for 21st-century trade agreements going forward."

MSF at the 2012 International AIDS Conference. http://aids2012.msf.org

title: Month in Focus: August 2012
description: This month, we focus on the MSF clinics treating AIDS and opportunistic infection in Zimbabwe, fighting malaria in a remote region of DRC, providing aid to Congolese refugees in Uganda, treating child malnutrition in Burkina Faso, and the ongoing humanitarian crisis in South Sudan's refugee camps.

title: Improving Adherence Among Migrants, Teenagers, and Children
description: Programme data from Zimbabwe, Mozambique and South Africa released by the international medical humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) at the International AIDS Conference shows good adherence outcomes for antiretroviral treatment (ART) strategies that target specific groups—migrants, teenagers and children—that are either hard to reach or retain in care.

title: Impact of the Global Fund Crisis
description: http://aids2012.msf.org/2012/where-will-the-money-come-from-challenges-and-approaches-to-sustainability-moae03/

title: Virological Monitoring: Bridging the North-South Divide
description: Despite the fact that the benefits of virological treatment monitoring are well established and that routine viral load testing is the standard of care in rich countries, access to viral load testing in resource-limited settings remains limited or non-existent. A number of cost-reducing strategies and implementation challenges must now be addressed so that virological monitoring can become the norm for all patients on ART. This will be important to prevent the development of drug resistance and preserve the use of first-line ART. This session presents the challenges and promise of scale-up of virological monitoring from a patient, health system, and market perspective. The session will be of interest to donors, policy makers, civil society representatives, and implementing organizations.

title: Measuring Viral Load Not a Luxury
description: As HIV treatment is scaled up in developing countries, the lack of access to viral load monitoring—routine in wealthy countries—must be addressed. Increased access to viral load monitoring can help people stay on antiretroviral combinations as long as possible, and help stave off resistance.

title: Getting to 15 Million
description:
A first-of-its-kind study released today by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) maps progress across 23 countries on HIV treatment strategies, tools and policies needed to increase treatment scale-up. The results show that governments have made improvements to get better antiretroviral treatment (ART) to more people, but implementation of innovative community-based strategies is lagging in some countries.

More info: http://aids2012.msf.org/2012/webcast-getting-to-15-million/

title: Trauma Care in Afghanistan: Filling a Void in the North
description: In August 2011, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened a 70-bed emergency trauma center in Kunduz, a city of 250,000 people in the north of Afghanistan. It's the only hospital of its kind in the region, and, like all MSF hospitals, no guns are allowed, and treatment is free. Patients arrive here every day, and with a variety of injuries.

title: Protest at the International AIDS Conference (HQ)
Mortality Rates Rising for Sudanese Refugees in Yida Camp, South Sudan
description: Some 170,000 refugees have fled conflict and food insecurity in Sudan's Blue Nile and South Kordofan states. After a harrowing journey, they arrive in camps in South Sudan where aid is severely lacking. Around 55,000 refugees are now in Yida camp, a site initially intended to host 15,000 people. Every day, new families arrive, tired and weakened by their journey to escape Sudan. Despite the increasing aid, the situation in the camp is a major humanitarian disaster. According to a survey by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), since June, at least five children have been dying every day.

title: MSF Fights Malaria in Orientale Province, DRC
description:
An outbreak of malaria has struck several parts of Orientale Province, Democratic Republic of Congo. Since June, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing care to people throughout the Ganga-Dingila health zone, where an unusual number of people have been suffering from malaria and severe anemia and exceptionally high mortality rates have been recorded. 

MSF is the only medical humanitarian organization in the area, working with the Ministry of Health to make treatment available in the most isolated, hard-to-reach communities. Between June and July, MSF treated more than 7,000 people on an outpatient basis and hospitalized over 740, including 180 who received transfusions for severe anemia. MSF continues to expand its activities to reach the most isolated and affected communities.

title: Testimonies from Syrian Refugees Seeking Medical Care in Jordan
description:
Since the uprising began in March 2011, some 120,000 Syrians have fled from conflict in their country, seeking safety and reliable medical care in neighboring countries. These three Syrians fled from violence in Derah and Damascus to a hospital in Amman, Jordan. One man was shot in the leg as he and his friends carried injured people off the streets. Another was shot in the shoulder during a protest, severing the nerves. The third man suffered a gunshot injury that left him in a coma for four days. 

Without official authorization to operate inside Syria, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) continues to support networks of Syrian doctors in Homs, Derah, Hama, Damascus and Idlib with supplies and medicines from neighboring countries. MSF doctors treat those who were wounded or tortured in Syria at a surgical hospital in Amman. Teams also provide primary health care and psychological support to Syrian refugees in Lebanon.

May 2012 © MSF
For more information, visit www.doctorswithoutborders.org.

title: My Life With HIV: Veena
description: Veena Panchal is a mother in Mumbai who found out in 2002 that she was HIV positive. She is one of eight million people whose lives have been transformed by HIV/AIDS treatment. Treating people who have HIV saves lives and prevents the virus from spreading.

title: Music Opens Doors To A Girl's Recovery in Haiti
description: Music "animators" play a part in Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mental healthcare services at Drouillard Hospital in Port-au-Prince. See more Insight videos and learn more about MSF's work in Haiti at www.doctorswithoutborders.org.

title: Dattchina's Story: The Only Free Burn Unit In Haiti
description:
A young girl is brought by her mother to the only free burn care unit in Port-au-Prince, run by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). 
See more Insight videos and learn more about MSF's work in Haiti at www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: A Young Survivor of Haiti's Earthquake Tells Her Story
description:
Twelve-year-old Mirlanda lost one of her legs due to the 2010 earthquake. Her strength and family support have made her a survivor and Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) medical care has been crucial to her pulling through. Today she is a bright and upbeat young girl who looks ahead to the future, but she and her family must live with the effects of the past.
See more Insight videos and learn more about MSF's work in Haiti at www.doctorswithoutborders.org

title: Protest at the International AIDS Conference
description: MSF joined thousands of protesters at the International AIDS Conference in Washington DC, calling for governments and pharmaceutical companies to halt policies and practices that hamper access to medicines.

title: Global Fund Protest at the International AIDS Conference
description: AIDS activists, such as HealthGAP, Global Fund Advocates Network, and Stop AIDS Campaign UK, and treatment providers, including MSF, took over a panel discussion on the future of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, TB, and Malaria at the International AIDS Conference. The groups protested against efforts to cap funding for countries rather than continue to accept ambitious grant proposals from countries hit hardest by the AIDS epidemic.

title: HIV/AIDS in Democratic Republic of Congo
description: The number of HIV-positive people in DRC is currently estimated at more than one million, 350,000 of whom could benefit from antiretroviral (ARV) treatment. However, only 44,000 people are currently receiving treatment, translating into a 15 percent ARV coverage rate, one of the lowest in the world.

title: My Life With HIV: Carmen
description:
Carmen Jose-Panti is HIV-positive. Her husband, Victorino, is HIV-negative. "She's a part of me," says Victorino, who loves his wife deeply and encouraged her to get tested for HIV when she started to show symptoms. 

Carmen is one of eight million people whose lives have been transformed by HIV/AIDS treatment. Treating people who have HIV saves lives and prevents the virus from spreading.

title: My Life With HIV: Ivone
description: Ivonne is a mother looking after four kids and a husband, in a village in northern Mozambique. Baking is the way she has chosen to push the family fortunes forward. "Don't be afraid if you have HIV. We are all brothers and sisters together."

title: Malnutrition in the Sahel Strip
description:
Malnutrition has always been a severe and wide-reaching problem in the Sahelian countries, which face a yearly hunger gap between harvests, weak to nonexistent infrastructure and perennial flooding, but this year's situation has been complicated by security problems in Mali and an unusually poor harvest. In order to establish better treatment for the tens of thousands of children affected by severe acute malnutrition yearly, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is switching gears from emergency responses to an integrative approach that treats monitoring and early detection of potentially malnourished patients as part of basic healthcare, just like vaccines.

July 2012 © MSF
For more, visit https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/

title: Walking For Days To Escape Violence: One Refugee's Crossing Into South Sudan
description: Amal is 28 years old and a mother of three. She and around 35,000 other refugees escaped violence in Sudan's Blue Nile State by crossing the border into South Sudan in May and June. On June 12, Amal was brought to a Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) mobile clinic at a refugee transit site called 'Kilometer 18' in Upper Nile State. She was thin, weak and coughing, and she could barely walk. Amal was immediately examined, an IV drip was inserted into her arm, and she was transferred to MSF's hospital in the Jamam refugee camp. MSF health staff suspect that she has tuberculosis and will start her on TB treatment soon. Amal weighs just 32 kilograms, or 80 pounds, and she is too weak to speak, so her cousin Hassan told her story on her behalf.

title: MSF Performs Triage For Truckloads of Refugees
description:
Doctor Erna Rijnierse talks to us from a new MSF transit camp clinic in Upper Nile State, South Sudan, where MSF is doing everything it can to identify and treat the sickest refugees before they are taken to a new camp in Batil.

Video shot June 28, 2012
© Corinne Baker/MSF

title: Fighting Neglect: Kala azar
description: Kala Azar is a neglected tropical disease responsible for 50,000 deaths every year.

title: Fighting Neglect: Chagas
description: Chagas is a parasitic disease found on the American continent, where it affects an estimated 8 to 10 million people and claims up to 12,500 lives every year.

title: Fighting Neglect: Sleeping Sickness
description: Sleeping sickness is a fatal and much neglected disease that plagues parts of Africa.

title: Midwife Rebecca Ullman: Having To Make Difficult Decisions
description: Working with a limited blood bank and in an area with few treatment options present difficult problems in treating women with high-risk pregnancies.

title: Scarce Water and Aid for 100,000 Refugees in South Sudan
description: MSF will be able to supply Sudanese refugees at one camp with about a sixth of the amount of water they need. More humanitarian organizations need to step up and provide assistance.

title: Nick Lawson thanks AP Government class at Cosby HS.MOV
description: Nick Lawson, Director of Field Human Resources, congratulates the AP Government class of Cosby High School on their exam scores and thanks them for their dedication to fundraising on behalf of Doctors Without Borders.

title: MSF "Doing Everything We Can" For Sudan Refugees in Jamam
description: Tens of thousands of refugees who have fled from fighting in Sudan are gathered in a camp near the town of Jamam in northern South Sudan. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing medical care, water and relief items, but there are more people in need than our staff can assist. MSF continues to call on other organizations to immediately step up their assistance to the refugees in the northern parts of South Sudan.

title: Refugees Dying From Lack of Water in South Sudan
description:
Tens of thousands of refugees fleeing fighting in Sudan are facing a full-blown humanitarian crisis, with people dying from a lack of water, adequate medical care, and shelter as they seek refuge in already-overcrowded camps in South Sudan. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Medical Team Leader Dr. Erna Rijnierse described the situation in Maban on June 14. 

TRANSCRIPT: "We are here at the clinic at kilometer 18. People have moved here since yesterday. As you can see there is a lot of patients at the moment. There is also a measles vaccination campaign going on which increases even more the number of people. 

"People are in a very bad state. They have been walking for seven hours yesterday withot any water or nothing. Shelters have not been done yet. Water is being provided by MSF at the moment, but a lot of people still drink water from shallow places. We see a lot of diarrheal diseases, both bloody and not-bloody diarrhea. The other thing we see is malnutrition. A lot of kids haven't had proper food because they have been on the road for almost a month, up to six weeks.

"We are facing challenges in every single direction. Everything is not easy here. We are trying to increase our capacity to see as much people as we can. We are doing health promotion to stop people from drinking the bad water. We're doing everything that we can."

title: Dadaab 20 Years On: Shadows of Lives
description:
Dadaab, Kenya, hosts the largest refugee camp in the world. Originally conceived as a temporary solution to shelter refugees of Somalia's civil war, the three neighboring sites that are referred to collectively as one refugee camp are now 20 years old, and have become a permanent home for the majority of people who have sought shelter there. 

With a new influx of refugees last year due to increased fighting and hunger in Somalia, conditions for people inside and stranded outside the camps deteriorated to a shocking level before obstacles to increasing aid were resolved. 

While the numbers of deaths and malnutrition levels have dropped since then, living conditions in the camp remain precarious. The safety of those living in the camps and those assisting them have deteriorated dramatically with regular outbreaks of violence and attacks on refugees and aid workers, including the kidnapping of two Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff. MSF continues to do everything possible to achieve the safe release of Montserrat Serra and Blanca Thiebaut.

title: Guinea: A New Approach to Fight Cholera
description: More than 170,000 people in the Boffa region of Guinea recently became the first in Africa to receive a new two-dose oral vaccine for cholera. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), in collaboration with the Guinea Ministry of Health, led the vaccination campaign.

title: Chad: Malnutrition Rates Soar
description: The difficult lean season in Chad has already begun, and MSF is working to treat malnutrition as quickly as possible. MSF teams screen for cases of severe malnutrition and distribute ready-to-use therapeutic food to malnourished children.

title: South Sudan: Aid Needed Before the Rains Start
description: Conflict with Sudan has forced 90,000 people to flee to Upper Nile State. They have taken refuge in the camps of Jamam and Doro. More and more people continue to arrive, and aid is desperately needed before the rainy season complicates access to the camps.

title: Burkina Faso: A Constant Flow of Refugees
description: 56,000 Malians have taken refuge in Burkina Faso after fleeing fighting that began in Mali in mid-January. They are living in makeshift shelters in camps where the sun beats down relentlessly and where aid is severely lacking.

title: International Aid Remains Insufficient for 160,000 Malian Refugees
description: Since late January, nearly 160,000 Malians have fled their country for camps in Burkina Faso, Mauritania, and Niger. While instability persists in Mali, leaving little hope that the refugees can return to their country soon, another imminent threat is looming: the rainy season, which will further complicate the deployment of aid.

title: Pediatrician Kerstin Hanson: The Best and Worst Experiences
description: Kerstin Hanson is an American pediatrician working with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF).

title: Pediatrician Kerstin Hanson: How Working in the Field is Different
description: Kerstin Hanson is an American pediatrician working with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF).

title: Pediatrician Kerstin Hanson: Going to the Field After Residency
description: Kerstin Hanson is an American pediatrician working with Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF).

title: Meet MSF Nurse John Fiddler: Nurse Practitioners in MSF
description: John Fiddler is a nurse practitioner and works in the field as a nurse for Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF).

title: Nurse John Fiddler: A Story About Malaria
description: John Fiddler is a nurse practitioner and works in the field as a nurse for Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF).

title: Burkina Faso: The Forgotten Malian Refugees
description: Nearly 50,000 Malians have taken refuge in Burkina Faso after fleeing the fighting that began in Mali in January. International aid has been slow and insufficient; there is not enough food or water. Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) is providing medical care to the refugees, and to the residents of the area who are also affected by drought.

title: Surge in Patients with Malaria in DRC
description: Medical teams from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in the Democratic Republic of Congo respond to a spike in the number of patients with malaria.

title: DRC: Massive Surge in Malaria Needs Urgent Response
description: Doctors Without Borders/Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) health workers are seeing a 250% increase in the number of patients with malaria over the last three years in Democratic Republic of Congo. MSF teams are currently responding to outbreaks of the disease in six provinces.

title: CAR: MSF Offers Women Freedom From Fistula
description: In January 2012, 50 women from northwest Central African Republic traveled to a hospital run by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), to undergo surgery that would change their lives forever. One of those women was 17-year-old Awa, who made the journey to Boguila to be treated for a fistula she developed two years ago, during the birth of her first child.  Obstetric fistulas are devastating injuries that affect more than two million women around the world, mostly in Africa.

title: Haiti: Building Emergency Services
description: On January 12, 2010, the earthquake in Haiti destroyed 60 percent of the hospitals in the country. In February 2012, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) opened Nap Kenbé in the Tabarre neighborhood of Port-au-Prince, the fourth hospital MSF has opened in Haiti since the disaster. Nap Kenbé is a reference center for specialized surgery, offering high quality internal and orthopedic surgery to Haitians free of charge.

title: Chad: On the Brink of a Peak in Malnutrition
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working to treat malnourished children in Chad and elsewhere in the Sahel region as a nutritional crisis looms.

title: Chagas in Paraguay: The Scourge of the Vinchuca
description: In Paraguay, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is covering the rural Chaco region, encouraging people to be tested and treated for Chagas, a widespread but little known and potentially fatal disease.

title: Haiti: Medical Certificates for Cholera Patients
description: Since it was disclosed that the cholera epidemic that struck Haiti in 2010 was inadvertently brought to the island by a United Nations (UN) battalion from Nepal, many of the 500,000 people affected by the disease have requested certificates proving they were treated, in hopes of receiving compensation from the UN. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing thousands of former patients with medical certificates.

title: Uzbekistan: Tuberculosis Shows Resistance
description: In northwestern Uzbekistan, drug-resistant forms of tuberculosis (TB) are spreading while only one in 10 people with TB receives treatment. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has treated more than 2,000 people with drug-resistant TB in Uzbekistan over the last 10 years.

title: DRC: An Alarming Surge in Malaria
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has recorded a three-fold increase in patients with malaria in parts of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) since 2009. MSF teams are seeing alarming numbers of malaria patients this year as well, and have launched an emergency response.

title: South Sudan: Time Is Running Out
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working in Doro and Jamam refugee camps in South Sudan. About 80,000 refugees have fled to the camps to escape ongoing violence in Blue Nile state, and MSF -- working against the clock -- is trying to help as many as possible before seasonal rains at the end of the month make the area inaccessible. Dr. Kirrily de Polnay talks about her work in the camps and warns that aid organizations need to urgently accelerate their activities if disaster is to be avoided

title: Chechnya TB slideshow-ENGLISH
description: Photos by Lana Abramova

title: Phumeza's TB&ME Video Blog: Where I Live
description: Phumeza is an XDR-TB patient and a blogger for the TB&ME project. This is her first video blog from her home at a TB patient facility in South Africa. To read Phumeza's TB&ME blog, visit http://msf.me/GCWOPQ

title: Athong's TB&ME Video Blog: Stigma
description: Multidrug-resistant tuberculosis patient and TB&ME blogger Athong talks from India about the stigma he faces living with the disease. To read his blog visit http://msf.me/GPjFre

title: Insight: Uzbekistan - A Mother With MDR-TB
description: She had all but given up, thinking her TB was going to end her life. Her coffin had already been built. But then Rohatay Abdullaeva, a former nurse living in northwest Uzbekistan, learned she could get help, that she could heal. As World TB Day approaches, MSF celebrates her good health as a sign of what's possible, but also remembers the huge and growing numbers of people with TB and drug resistant TB who cannot get the help they need.

title: Maternal Health
description: MSF is providing maternal and emergency obstetric care in more than 30 countries worldwide, but in places where woman cannot access care, some 1,000 die every day due to complications in pregnancy and delivery.

title: Dadaab
description: Though the international spotlight has moved on, hundreds of thousands of Somali refugees in the Dadaab camps in northwestern Kenya, the largest refugee camps in the world, continue to struggle amid harsh conditions and pervasive malnutrition, particularly among children. Aid has been too slow in coming, however, and longer-term solutions are nowhere to be found.

title: Novartis
description: The pharmaceutical company Novartis continues to put profits above people by challenging a seven-year old Indian court ruling that, if overturned, would have a devastating effect on access to generic forms of essential medicines, including HIV medications, in the developing world.

title: Sleeping Sickness
description: An MSF team is traveling around isolated villages and regions in central African countries in order to offer treatment and screening for sleeping sickness, a parasitic disease spread by the tsetse fly that can be fatal if it is not treated.

title: Tuberculosis:
description: Though the number of TB patients is on the rise worldwide—MSF treated some 25,000 cases in 2010 alone—there is still too little access to care and too few new diagnostic tools and medicines.

title: Insight: DRC - "I got on the motorbike with the midwife "
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) makes it a priority to provide life-saving, emergency obstetric care in both acute and chronic humanitarian crises. Fifteen percent of all pregnancies worldwide will experience a life-threatening complication. The most critical moment is delivery: the majority of maternal deaths occur just before, during, or just after delivery, often from complications that cannot be predicted. It is at this point that the provision of quality obstetric care is vital to save women's lives. The majority of maternal deaths are avoidable when access to emergency obstetric care is ensured.

title: Insight: South Sudan - Dodging a Double Risk
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) makes it a priority to provide life-saving, emergency obstetric care in both acute and chronic humanitarian crises. Fifteen percent of all pregnancies worldwide will experience a life-threatening complication. The most critical moment is delivery: the majority of maternal deaths occur just before, during, or just after delivery, often from complications that cannot be predicted. It is at this point that the provision of quality obstetric care is vital to save women's lives. The majority of maternal deaths are avoidable when access to emergency obstetric care is ensured.

title: Insight: Pakistan - Delivering in the Dark
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) makes it a priority to provide life-saving, emergency obstetric care in both acute and chronic humanitarian crises. Fifteen percent of all pregnancies worldwide will experience a life-threatening complication. The most critical moment is delivery: the majority of maternal deaths occur just before, during, or just after delivery, often from complications that cannot be predicted. It is at this point that the provision of quality obstetric care is vital to save women's lives. The majority of maternal deaths are avoidable when access to emergency obstetric care is ensured.

title: Insight: Haiti - "Madame, here is your baby"
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) makes it a priority to provide life-saving, emergency obstetric care in both acute and chronic humanitarian crises. title: MSF Protests Novartis' Assault on Access to Medicines
description:
In 2006 the drug company Novartis took the Indian government to court over its patent law, in a move that threatened access to affordable medicines produced in India for millions of people across the developing world. The company wanted to get the law changed so that they could more easily extend the patents on their products, and stop generic companies from producing the same medicines at a fraction of the price.

MSF's Drop the Case campaign, launched in response to this move, gathered nearly half a million signatures calling on the company to drop its case. But six years later, the legal battle continues. India's Supreme Court is now due to give the final judgement on the case in March.

This week, MSF joined with activists from Health GAP, Act Up, and others to protest the Novartis lawsuit at the company's headquarters in New York. 


Learn more about the case and MSF's efforts to protect access to essential medicines: http://www.msfaccess.org/STOPnovartis/

title: "At Any Price?" Event in New York - Part 2
description:
February 9, 2012
New School, Tishman Auditorium

Medical humanitarian organizations and human rights groups often operate in the same crisis zones but have different aims and approaches to negotiating access.  Join panelists from Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), Human Rights Watch (HRW), and the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia University (SIPA) for a discussion of the dilemmas faced by both humanitarian and human rights organizations trying to work in crisis zones. How different are the two approaches? Are they compatible on the ground? How are decisions made about establishing projects? And what compromises are acceptable when negotiating access to populations in immediate danger?

title: Syria: Medicine as a Weapon of Persecution
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is treating injured Syrians who have crossed the border into Jordan, Lebanon, and Turkey. Teams are also providing doctors inside Syria with medicines and medical materials.

title: Swaziland: Community Takes Part in HIV Treatment
description: With 25 percent of the country's population HIV-positive, and so few doctors to initiate treatment, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF)  has implemented task-shifting along with Swaziland's Ministry of Health. Now, lower-level trained health workers can get more people on lifesaving treatment.

title: Libya: MSF Suspends Work in Misrata Detention Centers
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff treating patients in Misrata detention centers suspended medical activities when it became clear that the patients were being tortured.

title: Papua New Guinea: Back to Bougainville
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is working again on Bougainville Island, east of mainland Papua New Guinea, after a 10-year absence. The comprehensive care project features a maternal health program and a specialized tuberculosis ward. Teams work along side the health authorities to help build the island's local healthcare capacity.

title: Pakistan: Providing Medical Care in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
description:
At a hospital in Hangu district, in Pakistan's Khyber Pakhtunkhwa Province, the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) 
team treats a large number of patients for trauma caused by road accidents and shootings. Health workers are also trying to bring down the high rate of maternal mortality in the area. MSF treated 20,000 patients in Hangu, including many mothers, in 2011.

title: At Any Price? Event at Boston Public Library, Part 1

At Any Price?
