Time To Act - Afghanistan: Healthcare in Helmand
Health Held Hostage to Politics
description:
September 2008
Health care workers have been on strike since August 30 2008, following Hamas' firing on medical workers, resulting in a reduction of 50-80% of medical services, including the suspension of specialized surgeries and external referrals.

title: Haiti: Water and Sanitation, an Essential Role to Fulfill
description: In the Cité Soleil area of Port-au-Prince, MSF distributes 300,000  liters of water every day to more than 15,000 people. Here, MSF water and sanitation specialist Katelijne Van Eyck conducts much-needed water testing.

title: Put Your Ideals into Practice - Medical staff needed for global emergencies.
MSF Frontline Reports podcast Ep. 70 - Giving Children with HIV the Support They Need
description:
MSF began treating adults living with HIV in developing countries in the 1990s. Ten years ago - in December of 2000 -- MSF teams also began treating children with antiretrovirals, or ARVs. Over the past decade, however, there has been little, or no, progress in key areas such as developing diagnostics for children under 18 months or creating medicines better adapted for children. In addition to these urgent medical needs, another side of providing care to child patients has been neglected as well. That's patient support -- it's a combination of mental health care, education about the disease, and help to get basic needs met, so the patient understands his disease, has what he needs to fight it, and will continue to fight it for the rest of his life. For children, this kind of support is crucial and it needs to be specific to each individual.

Welcome to the November 30th, 2010, MSF Frontline Reports podcast. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization.

For more information on this story and to learn more about MSF or Doctors Without Borders, please visit msf.org to find the MSF web site in your home country. You can read the entire Eneza Ujumbe at doctorswithoutborders.org. Please send any comments and questions for the podcast to msfpodcast@msf.org. MSF is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization that delivers emergency assistance to people affected by wars, epidemics, and natural or man-made disasters in more than 60 countries around the world.

title: Starved for Attention Event at Boston Public Library - Audience Q&A
description:
A recent Starved for Attention event at the Boston Public Library featured health experts, aid workers, and photojournalists discussing the causes and potential solutions to combating childhood malnutrition.  
The panel was hosted by WBUR reporter Martha Bebinger and included VII photojournalist and Starved for Attention contributor Jessica Dimmock, MSF aid worker Dr. Marc Levin, Tufts University nutrition expert Patrick Webb, and Boston Medical Center pediatrician Dr. Caroline Kistin.

title: Starved for Attention Event at Boston Public Library - Panel Discussion
description:
A recent Starved for Attention event at the Boston Public Library featured health experts, aid workers, and photojournalists discussing the causes and potential solutions to combating childhood malnutrition.  
The panel was hosted by WBUR reporter Martha Bebinger and included VII photojournalist and Starved for Attention contributor Jessica Dimmock, MSF aid worker Dr. Marc Levin, Tufts University nutrition expert Patrick Webb, and Boston Medical Center pediatrician Dr. Caroline Kistin.

title: Month in Focus: November 2010
description: Reports from MSF projects in Haiti and Gaza, as well as on efforts to battle HIV/AIDS and to help patients gain access to essential medicines.

title: Préservez la vie. Préservez les traitements vitaux.
Generic Drugs: Hands off Our Medicine
description: With the "Hands off Our Medicine" campaign, MSF is attempting to counteract policies that could restrict access to generic medicines in the developing world, medicines that are crucial to MSF's work and the short- and long-term health of patients.

title: Haiti: Cholera, another emergency
description: Since cholera began to spread in Haiti, MSF has treated more than 18,000 patients in 27 Cholera Treatment Centers (CTCs) throughout the country and is anticipating treating many more in the coming days.

title: Gaza: Healthcare system crippled by the embargo
description: Shortages of medical supplies and electricity, along with restrictions on both the import of materials and the provision of permits for expat personnel, continue to limit the people of Gaza's ability to receive appropriate medical care.

title: Pas le moment d'abandonner
description: Le manque de traitements pour le VIH/SIDA s'aggrave en Afrique.

title: La décentralisation : des traitements au plus près des patients
Keep HIV Treatment Alive!
description: On World AIDS Day there are five million reasons to be cheerful. So let's celebrate the five million people in developing countries who now live full and healthy lives because of HIV/AIDS medicines... while we can. HIV/AIDS treatment in developing countries is facing a double blow: funding for AIDS if falling short, and drug prices are set to go through the roof. Take action now against this double blow. Tell rich countries to take their hands off our medicines, and help keep AIDS treatment alive. Take action now: https://action.msf.org/en_CH

title: Decentralizing Treatment - Care Closer To Home
description: As the number of individuals living with HIV grows worldwide, MSF is looking for techniques that will simplify treatment without sacrificing care. By utilizing a single dose antiretroviral drug in many of its HIV projects, MSF is pursuing a "task shifting" approach designed to lessen the human resource burden and to decentralize treatment, bringing it closer to patients.

title: VIH/Sida - Simplifier le suivi médical
description:
Chaque jour, de nouvelles personnes sont infectées par le virus du Sida. Et les malades sous traitement le restent toute leur vie. En conséquence, le nombre de personnes qui ont besoin de soins ne cesse d'augmenter.

A l'occasion de la journée mondiale contre le VIH Sida, le 1er décembre, Médecins Sans Frontières alerte sur cette situation.

title: Afghanistan : Soins de santé à Helmand
description:
Dans la province de Helmand, de graves conflits ont laissé près d'un million de personnes privées de soins de santé essentiels. 

En 2009, Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) a commencé son travail à l'hôpital Boost, situé à Lashkargah, la capitale de la province.

title: Simplifying HIV/AIDS Patient Care
description: As the number of people with HIV continue to grow in the developing world, MSF is working to meet the needs by simplifying treatment and patient care while maintaining a high quality. See how MSF is managing care at its Blue House clinic in the Mathare area of Nairobi, Kenya.

title: Providing Health Care in Helmand, Afghanistan
description: Photojournalist Ton Koene traveled to Helmand Province, Afghanistan, in June 2010 to visit the MSF project in the capital, Lashkargah. Intense conflict in the province has left around one million people without access to the health care they need. Here, Koene documents how each member of the MSF team there is working to save lives and provide free medical care in Lashkargah.

title: MSF Frontline Reports podcast Ep. 69: Preventing Mother-to-Child HIV in Rural Kenya
description:
In Kenya, more than 22,000 children were infected with HIV in 2009. The district of Homa Bay,  in rural western Kenya, has the country's highest HIV prevalence rate. MSF is working to stop the spread of the disease in Homa Bay with its prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) program.

Welcome to the November 23th, 2010, MSF Frontline Reports podcast. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization. 

For more information on this story and to learn more about MSF or Doctors Without Borders, please visit msf.org to find the MSF web site in your home country. Please send any comments and questions for the podcast to msfpodcast@msf.org. MSF is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization that delivers emergency assistance to people affected by wars, epidemics, and natural or man-made disasters in more than 60 countries around the world.

title: Afghanistan: Healthcare in Helmand
Cholera Treatment Ongoing in Petite Riviere
description: Nearly a month after the first cases of cholera appeared in the Artibonite region in Haiti, MSF continues to treat as many patients as possible while also trying to stop further spread of the disease.

title: Haiti: A New Cholera Treatment Center in the North
description: As cholera continues to affect the people of Haiti MSF teams are working to open additional treatment centers. In the northern-most part of Haiti, the Port-de-Paix region, MSF has opened a large treatment center and a small treatment unit to increase access to treatment. In the treatment unit, a small team of three, two international staff and a Haitian nurse, have been able to offer treatment to people unable to travel to the larger treatment facilities.

title: Haïti : L'épidémie de choléra gagne du terrain
description: Le choléra continue à se propager en Haïti tandis que la population s'efforce de trouver de l'eau potable et de comprendre une maladie à laquelle ils n'avaient jamais été confrontés jusqu'alors. Les équipes MSF ont lancé des interventions à Port-au-Prince, dans le centre du pays et sur la côte nord. Toutefois, il est essentiel que d'autres intervenants viennent renforcer leurs efforts en vue de répondre aux besoins des patients dans les prochains jours.

title: MSF Frontline Reports podcast Ep. 68: Fighting Cholera in Haiti
description:
More than 1,150 MSF staff are responding to the massive cholera outbreak throughout Haiti right now, a daunting task given the quickly rising numbers of cases throughout the country. 
Welcome to the MSF Frontline Report podcast for the 15th of November, 2010. Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization. For more information on this story and to learn more about MSF or Doctors Without Borders, please visit msf.org to find the MSF web site in your home country. MSF is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization that delivers emergency assistance to people affected by wars, epidemics, and natural or man-made disasters in more than 60 countries around the world.
If you have questions or comments, send them to msfpodcast@msf.org

title: Haiti: Cholera Epidemic Gains Ground
description: Cholera continues to spread in Haiti as people struggle to access clean water and understand a disease they've never encountered before. MSF teams are responding to the outbreak in Port-au-Prince, in the center of the country, and on the northern coast, but other actors will need to get more involved to meet all the patient needs in the coming days.

title: MSF Protests EU-India Trade Talks
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff and supporters rallied outside the offices of the European Commission on November 8, before delivering an open letter of protest against ongoing trade talks between the European Union and India that could damage access to affordable medicines. 

The provisions in the free trade agreement under discussion could seriously impede generic medicines producers in India from delivering more affordable and quality generic versions of medicines for people in developing countries. MSF itself could not carry out much of its medical humanitarian work without access to these drugs. Support MSF's campaign 'Europe! Hands Off Our Medicine!' Go to action.msf.org

title: MSF Frontline Reports podcast, Ep. 67: 'Europe! HANDS OFF Our Medicine'
description:
Generic versions of antiretrovirals, or ARVs, that cost a fraction of the price of brand medicines make it possible for MSF to treat 160,000 people living with HIV around the world. Eighty percent of the ARVs we use come from India, and millions of others in developing countries depend on India-made generics as well. But the European Commission has begun directing its trade policies in a way that could stamp out the production of lifesaving generics in India. MSF has launched a global public campaign to tell Europe to back off, and to honor its commitments to global health. 
Welcome to the MSF Frontline Report podcast. Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization. Please send any comments and questions for the podcast to msfpodcast@msf.org.

title: Don't Let Europe Cut Off  Millions in the Developing World From Livesaving Generic Medicines
description:
Anand Grover, UN Special Rapporteur on the Right to Health, explains why he backs MSF's campaign - "Europe! HANDS OFF Our Medicine".

The international medical humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is launching a global campaign to stop Europe's multiple attempts to restrict access to these medicines for patients across the developing world. "We depend on access to affordable generic medicines like those produced in India to treat all kinds of diseases," said Dr. Unni Karunakara, president of MSF's international council. "We buy 80 percent of our AIDS medicines from India—medicines that keep 160,000 people alive today.  On their behalf, we cannot remain silent as Europe works to close the door on every aspect of drug supply: the production of a generic medicine; its registration; and its transportation to patients in other parts of the world. So today we are launching a campaign demanding 'Europe! HANDS OFF our medicine.'" For more information about the campaign go to: action.msf.org

title: MSF Frontline Report podcast - Ep. 66: Domestic and sexual violence in Papua New Guinea
description:
70% of women in Papua New Guinea say they've been physically abused by their husbands, and in some parts of the country that number reaches 100 % -- according to the PNG Law Reform Commission. When this kind of violence is so widespread, what kind of a difference can a small MSF project for victims of domestic and sexual violence make? 
This is MSF's Frontline Report podcast for the November 2, 2010.
Find out more by going to MSF.org to find the website in your home country. Please send any comments and questions for the podcast to msfpodcast@msf.org.
Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization that delivers emergency assistance to people affected by wars, epidemics, and natural or man-made disasters in more than 60 countries around the world.

title: GAZA pallier le besoins en chirurgie (Francais)
description:
Dans le hall du dispensaire de soins post-opératoires de Médecins sans frontières, à Gaza, Zainab attend son rendez-vous. 
Le 24 juillet dernier, une bougie allumée lors d'une des coupures quotidiennes d'électricité a mis le feu au matelas sur lequel elle dormait.
A sept ans, les deux jambes brûlées, Zainab ne peut plus marcher.
Admise dans le service des grands brûlés de l'hôpital Al Shifa, dans la ville de Gaza, elle a ensuite été référée au dispensaire MSF. 
Trois fois par semaine, une infirmière change ses pansements. 
ITW Nariman Pal, infirmière (en anglais)
"Je refais ses pansements pour éviter toute infection. Pour protéger ses plaies des microbes"
Parmi nos patients, 20 % des personnes brûlées sont des victimes d'accidents domestiques. Comme Zainab, la plupart ont besoin d'une opération de chirurgie réparatrice. 
Nous sommes à l'hôpital Nasser de Khan Younis, la deuxième ville de la bande de Gaza. C'est là que Zainab a bénéficié d'une greffe de peau.
MSF travaille ici en collaboration avec les autorités locales de santé. L'objectif est de diminuer le nombre de patients sur la liste d'attente. A Gaza, plus de 500 personnes doivent attendre pendant au moins un an l'opération dont elles ont besoin.
Le Dr Hassan Hamdan est le chirurgien référent en chirurgie réparatrice de l'hôpital Nasser. Pour lui, le programme chirurgical de MSF permet aussi un transfert de compétences entre médecins. 
Hassan Hamdan, chirurgien plasiticien (en arabe) 
"Notre équipe rencontre beaucoup de difficultés, à cause de l'embargo qui nous empêche de quitter Gaza. Et donc nous ne pouvons pas avoir de nouvelles experiences, ni échanger des informations. La visite de ces equipes nous aide beaucoup."
Malgré un récent allègement, l'embargo sur la bande de Gaza continue d'affecter le système de santé et la population gazaouite.

title: Communauté de brevets -- premier brevet enfant cédé (Francais)
description:
En décembre 2009, Médecins sans frontières saluait le principe de la mise en place d'une communauté de Brevets. Un pas important vient d'être franchi, puisqu'une première molécule va être déposée dans ce mécanisme. 
Pierre Chirac, Pharmacien, MSF (en français)
« Il y a une institution tout à fait importante, le National Institute of Health - donc c'est le principal, c'est le gros organisme de recherche publique aux Etats Unis - qui a offert à cette communauté de brevet, le brevet qu'il possédait sur l'anti-retroviral Darunavir. 
C'est un premier pas -- même s'il n'est pas suffisant - vers la production de médicament à bas coût pour les pays en développement.
Pierre Chirac, Pharmacien, MSF (en français)
Pour l'instant ça permet rien parce qu'en fait, sur le Darunavir, il y a d'autres brevets possédés en particulier par Tibotec, du groupe américain Johnson and Johnson. Mais de toute façon on va être très souvent dans ce cas là, c'est à dire des médicaments pour lesquels il y a plusieurs brevets. Donc il est important que les autres titulaires de brevet mettent leurs droits dans ce patent pool. 
C'est malgré tout une avancée importante. Car si d'autres suivent l'exemple, cela permettra de mettre au point de nouvelles combinaisons de médicaments et rendre plus accessibles les traitements contre le VIH/Sida.
Pierre Chirac, Pharmacien, MSF (en français)
MSF a salué cette annonce, (...) parce que c'est vraiment un geste très important et à encourager qu'un organisme public cède ses droits à cette communauté de brevets. Et puis ça incite aussi, ça met une pression plus forte sur les firmes pharmaceutiques pour qu'elles mettent à disposition aussi leurs brevets. 
MSF traite actuellement plus de 160 000 personnes atteintes du VIH/Sida. 80% des médicaments ARV utilisés dans les projets de l'ONG sont produits par des compagnies génériques indiennes.

title: Malnutrition -- 195 millions d'histoires (Francais)
description:
Oublier les images d'enfants au ventre gonflé et aux yeux dans le vide... Proposer un regard nouveau sur la malnutrition. Un regard débarrassé des clichés.
En partenariat avec MSF, Sept photographes de l'agence Seven ont parcouru trois continents pour raconter les histoires de la malnutrition en 2010. 
La campagne, baptisé Starved for attention, s'accompagne d'une pétition.
Starved for Attention - DRC  (sous-titres français)
Au Burkina Faso, une mère se bat pour ses enfants...
Dans le nord de l'Inde, la malnutrition dure depuis des générations, et plus personne ne s'en étonne. 
Au Mexique, un ambitieux programme national a changé la donne.
Sujet Mexique : sous-titré en français (sous-titres français)
Aux Etats-Unis, c'est un double standard qui prévaut. 
D'un côté, les familles américaines démunies reçoivent de l'aide pour acheter des œufs et du lait à leurs enfants. 
De l'autre, l'aide alimentaire publique n'offre aux pays pauvres qu'un mélange de farine de maïs et de soja, inefficace pour lutter contre la malnutrition. 
Starved for Attention - US (sous-titres français)
Aujourd'hui, des produits nutritionnels adaptés existent. Avec une volonté politique forte, ils pourraient parvenir jusqu'aux 195 millions d'enfants malnourris. Starved For Attention demande aux principaux pays donateurs de l'aide alimentaire un engagement dans ce sens.
Marie Pierre Allié, Présidente de MSF
Cette exposition circule aujourd'hui en France et dans d'autres pays pour montrer ces enjeux liés à cette question et pour demander aux gens de signer une pétition qui sera envoyé aux dirigeants des principaux pays donateurs
La campagne a déjà été présentée à New York, Milan, Toronto, Abidjan, Rome et Paris. 
Le travail des photographes est toujours visible sur Internet. La pétition, elle aussi en ligne, sera présentée au printemps 2011 aux dirigeants du sommet du G8 en France.

title: MSF Frontline Reports podcast - Episode 65: MSF closes a long-running hospital in DRC
description:
Welcome to the MSF Frontline Report podcast for October 26, 2010. Médecins Sans Frontières/Doctors Without Borders, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization. The Bon Marche Hospital in Bunia, eastern Democratic Republic of Congo, was started by MSF in 2003 after years of conflict and instability had rendered the national health services almost non-existent. Now, although violence between armed groups in the Congo is still a huge concern, the situation in Bunia itself is significantly calmer. This year MSF handed over medical activites back to the country's ministry of health. 
Hear about how and why MSF leaves a project.

title: Patent Pool: First Patent Rights Offered
description: In December 2009, MSF welcomed the idea of a patent pool to help lower the costs of HIV medicines in developing countries. An important milestone has just been reached; the first patent has been offered by The National Institute of Health.

title: Malnutrition: 195 Million Stories
description:
MSF and VII Photography launched the Starved for Attention campaign in early 2010. In an effort to rewrite the story of malnutrition, the campaign seeks to reform the double standard of international food aid.

Sign the Starved for Attention petition to rewrite the story malnutrition: http://www.starvedforattention.org/take-action.php

Watch the videos from the project here: 
http://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p=5B29001261012A20

title: Gaza Strip: MSF Opens a New Surgical Program
description: With a new surgical program in Gaza, MSF and local health authorities are trying to reduce the time patients spend waiting for the surgeries they need.

title: Haiti: An Extraordinary Patient
description: Mirlanda, a young MSF patient in Haiti who lost her mother and a leg to the earthquake, is a source of inspiration to the MSF staff, her fellow patients, and the photographer who captured her spirit in these images. Photographs by Nicola Vigilanti.

title: MSF Frontline Reports podcast #64 - MSF's Kashmir radio soap opera
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières or MSF's radio soap opera "Alaw Baya Alaw" - Kashmiri for "Hello Brother, Hello" - has been on the air in the Kashmir Valley since 2005. Its purpose is to raise awareness of mental health issues in an entertaining way.

title: MSF Frontline Reports Podcast #63: In Kashmir, mental health during a surge of violence (photos)
description: The Kashmir Valley has been in the midst of increasing civil unrest since June. Violent, deadly clashes between protesters and security forces have led to strict 24-hour curfews and an even more pronounced military presence on the streets, the combination of which has kept people from accessing much-needed mental health care. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been providing psychological care in Kashmir since 2002 and since June the team has had to adjust its strategy to in order to reach those who need help the most.

title: Europe! HANDS OFF Our Medicine
description:
Patient and other voices from MSF's Mathare AIDS clinic in Kenya about how they rely on affordable generic antiretrovirals produced in India for their survival.

To learn more about the impact the EU-India Free Trade Agreement, visit msfaccess.org/​main/​access-patents/​free-trade-agreements/​

Join our "EUROPE! Hands off our medicine" campaign & tell Europe to stop pushing policies that will deny medicine to millions of patients in the developing world action.msf.org

title: MSF's Dr. Susan Shepherd on World Food Day Advocacy
description: Dr. Susan Shepherd, MSF's Nutrition Coordinator, has been in Washington D.C. this week in advance of World Food Day, bringing her experience from the field treating patients in Niger.  In this interview she talks about her frustrations and hopes of securing better resources for malnourished children.

title: Starved for Attention - World Food Day Advocacy in Washington DC
description: Emi Maclean, US Manager of MSF's Access to Essential Medicines Campaign, talks about her upcoming meetings around World Food Day to advocate for greater resources in the fight against malnutrition. We can't do it alone! SIGN and SHARE our petition to tell world leaders they need to rewrite the story of malnutrition: http://bit.ly/195strvd

title: MSF Frontline Reports Podcast #62: Difficulties of Treating Children with TB
description:
In Mathare, a poor area on the outskirts of Nairobi, MSF treats children with TB, but just diagnosing them is extremely challenging. Results of the lack of research into TB means the main diagnostic tool for the adult form of the disease is 130 years old and not at all adapted for use with children.

Welcome to the October 5th, 2010, MSF Frontline Reports podcast. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières, or MSF, is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization. This week: the challenges of diagnosing and treating tuberculosis - or TB - in children.

For more information on this story and to learn more about MSF or Doctors Without Borders, please visit msf.org to find the MSF web site in your home country. For more information on MSF's Campaign for Access to Essential Medicines, go to msfaccess.org. MSF is an independent medical humanitarian aid organization that delivers emergency assistance to people affected by wars, epidemics, and natural or man-made disasters in more than 60 countries around the world.

title: Pakistan: New Medical Activities
description: Emergency aid continues to be deployed in Pakistan following the floods that swept through the country at the end of July. MSF teams are treating patients for pathologies resulting from poor living conditions and lack of food, particularly in the south of the country. To date MSF teams have provided more than 40,000 consultations.

title: Yemen: Supporting Health Facilities
description: MSF is supporting health facilities in northern Yemen by providing free emergency and inpatient services along with medical supplies and medicines for the roughly 28,000 civilians who were displaced by fighting this past March.

title: Niger: Breaking the Vicious Circle of Malnutrition
description: In July MSF implemented a new preventative strategy to help fight the nutrition crisis facing Niger. Through the monthly distribution of ready-to-use food supplements MSF is hoping to reduce the number of cases of acute malnutrition.

title: Honduras: Dengue Fever
description: In Honduras, more than 50,000 cases of Dengue Fever have been reported. MSF has set up an emergency ward for children to help local health efforts combat the outbreak. Special attention has also been paid to prevention efforts and education about the disease.

title: Pakistan: Providing Clean Water in the Flood Zone
description: In Pakistan's Balochistan province, MSF is working to provide clean drinking water and to prevent outbreaks of waterborne diseases.

title: Community Model for HIV Treatment
description: In Mozambique's Tete province, MSF is working with an innovative model for HIV/AIDS treatment that depends on the patients themselves to help facilitate the use of antiretrovial (ARV) drugs. The patients form small groups to support each other, nominating one member to pick up their ARVs and collectively helping each other adhere to the treatment program. This creates a support network for the patients and alleviates strain on Mozambique's under-resourced health system. It also provides a model for scaling up ARV treatment in developing countries with high HIV/AIDS burdens.

title: Assisting Malnourished Children Displaced by Floods in Pakistan
description: Living conditions for people displaced by floods in Pakistan have intensified malnutrition. Malnourished children are more suceptible to potentially deadly illnesses, such as acute watery diarrhea and pneumonia.

title: Pakistan: MSF Works to Aid Displaced People in Sindh Province
description: Displaced people living under makeshift tents are in need of medical assistance, water, and shelter.

title: Pakistan: MSF Working to Reduce Risk of Epidemics
description: Cholera is endemic in Pakistan, and conditions created by the recent floods greatly compound the possibility of an epidemic outbreak. MSF is taking every precaution to prevent such an outbreak from happening while preparing for a large scale response if it does.

title: Pakistan: Providing Water in Mingora, Swat Valley
description: Water sources have been lost or contaminated in Mingora, leaving this population at risk of rapidly spreading diseases. MSF is now providing 200,000 liters of fresh water there every day.

title: Meningitis: A New, More Efficient Vaccine
Pakistan: Delivering Clean Water to Charsadda
description: In Charsadda, MSF is delivering safe water to areas where people affected by the floods have gathered.

title: Pakistan: Distributing Essential Items to People Affected by Floods
description: An MSF team distributes essential goods, such as jerry cans for water, cooking kits, tarps and blankets, in flood-ravaged northwest Pakistan.

title: Beat the Bulldozers: Separating Fake from Life-Saving Generic Medicines
description: This video explains one of the fatal confusions at the heart of this matter between legitimate generic medicines....and illegal fakes.

title: Malnutrition: Hundreds of Thousands of Children Under Threat in Sahel
description: Throughout Africa's Sahel region, MSF works to treat and prevent malnutrition during a particularly extreme food and nutrition crisis.

title: Kyrgyzstan: Tension Remains High
description: In Kyrgyzstan, MSF treats both medical and psychological needs after June's violent confrontations.

title: Haiti Six Months On
description: Six months after the earthquake in Haiti, MSF is looking to the future while continuing to attend to current needs.

title: Interview with Photojournalist John Stanmeyer
description: VII photographer John Stanmeyer traveled to rural areas of Oaxaca State in Mexico to shoot  "A Solution from Within", which documents the area's successful Progresa/Oportunidades nutrition safety net program for the Starved for Attention project.

title: Teaser MSF medical Spanish
Teaser_MSF_medical_Eng.mp4
Haiti Six Months Later
description:
http://maps.msf.at/Haiti-Six-Months-Later/

On the evening of January 12, 2010, a massive earthquake hit Haiti, destroying large chunks of the country and its capital, Port-au-Prince, killing hundreds of thousands of Haitians, injuring hundreds of thousands more, and leaving millions homeless. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) had been working in Haiti since 1991 and was thus already on the ground. Moments after the earth shook, in fact, MSF staff was treating patients.

And, in the time since, MSF's efforts in Haiti have not let up. Here, we both look back and look forward at the medical and humanitarian needs in Haiti and MSF's activities in the country, focusing in particular on surgery and post-operative care, access to primary care, access to specialized care, and living conditions. Our staff and donors have made possible a response unprecedented in MSF's history of responding to medical emergencies. But we proceed knowing that a great deal of work remains to be done.

title: Teaser_Haitiens_Spanish.mp4
Teaser_Haitiens_Fr.mp4
MSF EN HAITI, UN MOIS APRES LES OURAGANS AUX GONAÏVES
description: En 2008, suite aux passages de plusieurs tempetes tropicales et de l'ouragan Ike, la ville des Gonaives a ete en grande partie innondee. Ici les equipes de MSF ont rapidement pris en charge les blesses, tout en restaurant l'acces a l'eau potable

title: MSF EN HAITI, LES BESOINS EN CHIRURGIE REPARATRICE
description: Plusieurs mois après le séisme, un grand nombre de patients nécessitent encore des interventions chirurgicales pour pouvoir restaurer leur mobilité.

title: MSF EN HAITI, TROIS MOIS APRES
MSF EN HAITI, S'ADAPTER AUX BESOINS
description: des les premieres semaines, il a ete necessaire pour Medecins Sans Frontieres de pouvoir identifier l'ensemble des besoins et y repondre rapidement. L'organisation a ainsi developpe un vaste champs d'activites

title: MSF EN HAITI, OPERATION TOUJOURS PLUS
description: Depuis le seisme, MSF a redouble ses efforts pour restaures les capacites en terme de prise en charge chirurgicale et augmenter la capacite.

title: MSF EN HAITI, AIDER MALGRE TOUT
description: Alors que les membres du personnel haitien ont meme ete sinistre et victimes du seisme, ils sont determines a porter secours

title: MSF EN HAITI, SIX AVIONS EMPECHES D'ATTERRIR A PORT AU PRINCE
description: Alors que les besoins sont immenses, six avions de Medecins Sans Frontieres transportant du materiel

title: MSF EN HAITI, GAGNER DU TEMPS ET DES VIES
description: Quelques minutes apres le tremblement de terre du 12 janvier, les equipes de MSF sur place se sont mise a pied d'oeuvre pour pouvoir prendre en charge l'afflux de blesses. Tres vites d'autres equipes sont arrivees en renfort.

title: MSF EN HAITI, AUPRES DES SINISTRES A PACOT
description: A Pacot, ancien centre de rehabilitation fonctionnelle, les equipes de MSF ont pris en charge les blesses affluant des environs des les premieres minutes apres le tremblement de terre.

title: MSF EN HAITI, ENVOI DE MATERIEL VERS HAITI
description: Des les premieres heures apres le seisme, les equipes de Medecins Sans Frontieres se sont mobilisees pour pouvoir envoyer le plus rapidement possible du materiel en Haiti

title: MSF EN HAITI, CONFERENCE DE PRESSE DU 13 JANVIER 2010, TORONTO
description: Premiere conference de Presse organisee par Medecins Sans Frontieres, au lendemain du tremblement de terre

title: Interview with Photojournalist Franco Pagetti
description: VII photojournalist Franco Pagetti traveled to North Kivu Province, Democratic Republic of Congo, to capture images for "The Malnutrition That Shouldn't Be".

title: MSF EN HAITI, CLINIQUE MOBILE DANS LE CAMP D'AVIATION
description:
Le camp d'aviation situe pres de l'aeroport est l'un des plus importants de la capitale haitienne. Ici pres de 50 000 personnes vivent dans des conditions extremement precaires. Ici, MSF organise des cliniques mobiles dans un ancien bus scolaire reconverti en salle de consultation. Dans ce meme camp, l'organisation a construit des latrines et organise l'approvisionnement en eau

 In addition to providing water and sanitation here, MSF has set up a mobile clinic in a former school bus.

title: MSF IN HAITI, MOBILE CLINIC IN AVIATION CAMP
description: Aviation camp is one of the biggest camps in Port au Prince. It is estimated that 50 000 people live in precarious conditions. In addition to providing water and sanitation here, MSF has set up a mobile clinic in a former school bus.

title: MSF IN HAITI, PHYSIOTHERAPY, PSYCHOTHERAPY AND REHABILITATION
description: In Tabarre post operative Center, MSF is providing physiotherapy and psychological support to the victims of the earthquake. By attending physiotherapy and psychotherapy, Day after day, patient learn how to deal with their body. Some will be able to walk again with prosthesis. Tabarre post op center has become a small community where everybody support each other

title: MSF IN HAITI, RECONSTRUCTIVE SURGERY IN ST LOUIS HOSPITAL
description: Manouchka was wounded on January 12th. Since then she has undergone multiple surgery to be able to use her arm again. In St Louis Hospital, MSF is performing reconstructive surgery to restore patient mobility

title: Inpatient Services in Jacmel's Saint Michel Hospital
description:
http://maps.msf.at/Haiti-Six-Months-Later/

Jacmel St Michel hospital was seriously damaged during the January 12th earthquake. Several months after, MSF is providing healthcare in semi permanent structures

title: Primary Health Care in Léogâne
description:
http://maps.msf.at/Haiti-Six-Months-Later/

While victims of earthquake are still being treated in MSF facilities, needs are evolving toward access to primary health care for a large part of the population. In Leogane, more than 220 patients come everyday for outpatient consultations. Here, in addition to general consultations, MSF provides mental health support



Alors que MSF continue de prendre en charge les victimes directed du seisme du 12 janvier, les besoins en matiere d'acces aux soins de sante primaire resurgissent. A Leogane, plus de 220 personnes se rendent chaque jour au dispensaire de Medecins Sans Frontieres. Ici en plus des consultations generales, MSF apporte un soutien psycho social pour estomper les blessures invisibles

title: MSF IN HAITI, DANIELLE LEAVES THE HOSPITAL AFTER FIVE MONTHS
description: Danielle who has been hospitalized for more than 5 months, finally leaves the hospital today. She receives support from the psycho social team to be able to cope with the outside reality

title: Psycho-social Support for Children in Sarthe
description:
http://msf.org/haiti-after-the-earthquake

While their physical wounds are recovering, children need support before they leave the hospital. In Sarthe Post Operative care center, MSF provides psycho social support to the children

title: Living Conditions in the Petionville Golf Club Camp
description:
http://maps.msf.at/Haiti-Six-Months-Later/

6 months after the earthquake, living conditions have hardly improved for a large of Port au Prince population. Here MSF provides access to primary health care in a tented outpatient department clinic. Most serious cases are referred to other MSF facilities in town

title: MSF IN HAITI, MOBILE CLINIC IN AVIATION CAMP
MSF EN HAÏTI, SOINS DE SUITE ET REHABILITATION A TABARRE
description: Au centre de soins de suite de Tabarre, MSF a mis en place un service de kinesitherapie et de support psycho social pour les victimes du seisme. Grace a des exercices physiques et a l'apport de la psychotherapie, les patients reprennent progressivement contact avec leur corps. Certains pourront marcher de nouveau grace a la mise en place protheses. Un veritable sentiment communautaire s'est developpe dans le centre

title: MSF en Haiti, acces aux soins de sante primaires et sante mentale a Leogane
description: Alors que MSF continue de prendre en charge les victimes directed du seisme du 12 janvier, les besoins en matiere d'acces aux soins de sante primaire resurgissent. A Leogane, plus de 220 personnes se rendent chaque jour au dispensaire de Medecins Sans Frontieres. Ici en plus des consultations generales, MSF apporte un soutien psycho social pour estomper les blessures invisibles

title: MSF in Haiti: Six Months After
description: July 6, 2010 - Six months after the January 12 earthquake that devastated Haiti, people still struggle to live. MSF continues to provide a wide range of medical, mental health, and hygiene assistance.

title: MSF en Haiti, Danielle sort de l'hopital 5 mois apres le tremblement de terre
description: Danielle, hospitalisee depuis plus de 5 mois dans une structure de Medecins Sans Frontieres, sort finalement aujourd'hui.

title: MSF en Haiti, accompagnement psycho social des enfants apres le tremblement de terre
description: Alors les blessures physiques se referment, il est necessaire de pouvoir accompagner les enfants avant leur sortie de l'hopital. Dans le centre de rehabilitation post operatoire de Sarthe, MSF a mis en place un systeme de prise en charge psycho social des enfants.

title: Haiti: A Family in the Ruins, Part 2
description: July 6, 2010 - Six months after the earthquake that devastated Haiti, the Clerger family has had to divide up. There is no work to be found, and they still have received no help beyond MSF's medical assistance.

title: We Couldn't Just Sit By: 20 Years in Liberia
description: Through the voices of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) Liberian staff -  20 years of providing emergency aid. After two decades, MSF turns over management of hospitals and reduces its presence in Liberia. Staff revisit intensely personal memories of the brutal civil war and carry us with them on their nation's journey from horror to hope.

title: Liberia Healthcare 20 Years
description: After 20 years of emergency aid, Médecins Sans Frontières reduces activities in Liberia, handing its hospital services over to the Liberian Ministry of Health and Social Welfare - a sign of the health systems progress just seven years after the end of 14 years of brutal civil war. As Liberia reconstructs and develops, many challenges lie ahead. Here the children of Liberia express worries for healthcare and share hopes for the future.

title: India: Invisible - starvedforattention.org
description:
http://www.starvedforattention.org

Photojournalist Stephanie Sinclair turned her lens on an MSF program in Bihar State which treats children at the epicenter of one of the world's malnutrition hotspots. These children descend from generations of a chronically under-nourished population, making malnutrition more difficult for MSF workers to spot. Malnutrition in India is so pervasive it is almost invisible.

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and VII Photo present Starved for Attention, a multimedia campaign to uncover the hidden crisis of childhood malnutrition. Watch 7 of the 195 million stories of malnutrition from prolific and award-winning photojournalists.

Sign the "Starved for Attention" online petition and be part of the campaign to rewrite the story of malnutrition and demand that the 195 million malnourished children get the attention they need and deserve to escape the deadly cycle of malnutrition.

TAKE ACTION NOW: http://www.starvedforattention.org

Photos: India 2009 © Stephanie Sinclair/VII

title: Burkina Faso: A Mother's Devotion - starvedforattention.org
description:
http://www.starvedforattention.org

Jessica Dimmock tenderly captures the heartbreaking emotional strains experienced by a young, hard working mother, Natasha, simply trying to feed her children. Alone at 24, she scavenges firewood to sell in the market.  Her meager earnings force an impossible choice: between buying food or medicine for her three children.  

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and VII Photo present Starved for Attention, a multimedia campaign to uncover the hidden crisis of childhood malnutrition.  Watch 7 of the 195 million stories of malnutrition from prolific and award-winning photojournalists.

title: Bangladesh: Terrifying Normalcy - starvedforattention.org
description:
http://www.starvedforattention.org

Photojournalist Ron Haviv traveled to the island of Bhola in southern Bangladesh to document the challenges of food insecurity, rapid climate change and poverty which make malnutrition so pervasive on this densely-populated island. In his intimate portraits, Haviv captures the resignation with which Bhola's malnourished mothers and children accept a chronically meager food supply.

title: The US Standard and A Double Standard - starvedforattention.org
description:
http://www.starvedforattention.org

Antonin Kratochvil's bold landscape images lay bare the (mis)use of land and resources in the American midwest. The US Government Accountability Office has found that the current system of sending domestically produced blended flour overseas costs as much as 34 percent more than buying food products locally. Kratochvil maps the food-aid pipeline from the corn fields of Iowa to the ports of Africa, exposing the inefficiency of the current system and its failure to deliver nutritious foods to young children.  

Jessica Dimmock's intimate portraits of families benefitting from the US government-funded Women, Infants and Children nutrition program (WIC) reveal the other half of the US food aid story. WIC supports a quarter of all American children from birth to age four and has been shown to have dramatically reduced anemia and the rate of low birth weight. The access to nutritious, enriching foods that WIC provides to young American children is a stark contrast to the nutritionally devoid blend of fortified flour dumped on starving children outside the country.  

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and VII Photo present Starved for Attention, a multimedia campaign to uncover the hidden crisis of childhood malnutrition. Watch 7 of the 195 million stories of malnutrition from prolific and award-winning photojournalists.

Sign the "Starved for Attention" online petition and be part of the campaign to rewrite the story of malnutrition and demand that the 195 million malnourished children get the attention they need and deserve to escape the deadly cycle of malnutrition.

TAKE ACTION NOW: http://www.starvedforattention.org

Part 1 photos: USA 2009 © Jessica Dimmock/VII
Part 2 photos: USA 2009 © Antonin Kratochvil/VII

title: Djibouti: Frustration - starvedforattention.org
description:
http://www.starvedforattention.org

At MSF's clinic in the Balabala district of Djibouti, doctors and nurses scramble to treat a never-ending influx of young malnourished patients. Last year, the clinic treated nearly 1,730 malnourished children under five years old. In this multimedia reportage shot by photojournalist Marcus Bleasdale, hear clinic workers speak about the successes and frustrations of their work. 

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and VII Photo present Starved for Attention, a multimedia campaign to uncover the hidden crisis of childhood malnutrition.  Watch 7 of the 195 million stories of malnutrition from prolific and award-winning photojournalists.

title: Treating TB/HIV Co-Infection in Kenya 2007
Unacceptable Conditions in Guinea Prisons 2008
description: In September 2008, MSF began an emergency intervention in the civilian prison of Guéckédou in southeastern Republic of Guinea. Upon arrival, MSF found malnutrition in one in three adult male prisoners, one in five of whom suffered severe acute malnutrition. Appalling hygienic conditions had led to dehydration and rampant skin and respiratory infections. Overcrowded cells mixed both minors together with adults and prisoners with tuberculosis (TB) together with other inmates. Health care was only infrequently available.

title: Papua New Guinea: Cholera Epidemic
description: The first cholera epidemic in 50 years has broken out in Morobe province of Papua New Guinea.  Working in partnership with the Ministry of Health, MSF has set up a treatment center in front of the Angau hospital. The number of cases is now falling. Since the epidemic began in mid-August, 138 people have received treatment. Six patients have died.

No Time to Quit
description: New therapies have had great benefits for people living with HIV/AIDS, but looming funding cuts could undo many of the gains.

Ethiopia 1984
Thai Border 1979
Beirut 1976
MSF's Emergency Feeding in Niger 2005
Mitwaba, Democratic Republic of Congo 2005
Liberia: Fragile Peace 2005
Treating Children With HIV/AIDS 2005
TB Treatment in Akuem, Sudan 2005
Daily Life in Kalma Camp, Darfur, Sudan April 2006
Report from Northern Darfur, Sudan 2006
Cholera Outbreak in Luanda, Angola 2006
Malawi: Living With HIV/AIDS 2006
The Challenges of Treating Tuberculosis 2006
Civilians Face Attacks on Chad-Sudan Border 2007
Sexual Violence in DR Congo 2006
Rwanda 1994
Interview Paul McMaster, Vavuniya, Sri Lanka 2009
description: Between April 20 - May 8, 2009, Sri Lanka's Ministry of Health and MSF surgical teams in Vavuniya hospital performed 963 surgeries, over 90 percent for injuries related to the conflict. MSF Surgical Advisor Paul McMaster describes the situation.

title: Congo: The Malnutrition That Shouldn't Be
description:
http://www.starvedforattention.org

In a somber, yet bold, reportage, photographer Franco Pagetti reveals the daily struggle to survive in North Kivus forbidding bush and teeming, fetid displaced persons camps, where food is scarce and the people are on edge, ready to run at a moments notice.

Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and VII Photo present Starved for Attention, a multimedia campaign to uncover the hidden crisis of childhood malnutrition. Watch 7 of the 195 million stories of malnutrition from prolific and award-winning photojournalists.

Sign the "Starved for Attention" online petition and be part of the campaign to rewrite the story of malnutrition and demand that the 195 million malnourished children get the attention they need and deserve to escape the deadly cycle of malnutrition.

TAKE ACTION NOW: http://www.starvedforattention.org

Photos: DRC 2009 © Franco Pagetti

title: A Vulnerable Existence: Migrants in South Africa
description: Their reality is grim  the thousands of migrants and refugees existing on the margins in South Africa. They lack access to proper health care and shelter and face physical and verbal abuse, police harassment and xenophobic attacks. For these migrants, proper legal status is often difficult to obtain, if not impossible. Gangs prey on them when they cross the border into South Africa and in the derelict buildings where they find temporary housing. As a result, many face further threats living in dangerous conditions, particularly in Johannesburg. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is providing health care to these vulnerable people in Musina, a town on the border with Zimbabwe, and in Johannesburg.

title: Kenya: From Discrimination to Positive Living with HIV
description: When Victor learned that he was co-infected with HIV and TB in 2003, he faced enormous societal stigma and challenges to getting treatment. Today, thanks to better treatment opportunities and training, he is living healthy and helping others with HIV.

title: Migrants Detained in Greece on Their Way West
description: Many migrants who leave war-torn homelands thinking better days await in Europe make a perilous journey westward only to wind up detained for months in Greece and other countries.

title: No Refuge, Access Denied: Zimbabweans in South Africa Struggle to Survive
description: June 2nd, 2009

title: Indonesia: Parts of Sumatra Island Devastated by Earthquake; MSF Responds
description:
In Indonesia, many people have disappeared and any hope of finding survivors has almost vanished. Bodies are still trapped under the rubble and relatives are waiting. Marlene Lee, an MSF psychologist, provides support to some families in the most affected areas.
October 9, 2009

title: NECT: An Improved Therapy for Sleeping Sickness
description: Sleeping sickness is a major health problem in sub-Saharan Africa. With existing medicines either cumbersome to administer or a cause of intense side effects, a new and cheaper therapy, NECT, holds great promise of benefiting thousands of vulnerable patients.

title: South Africa: Violence Without Borders
description: Violence and turmoil have followed Zimbabwean migrants across the border into South Africa.

title: Morocco: Sexual Violence and Migration
description: MSF responds to the widespread sexual abuse of women from sub-Saharan Africa trying to reach Europe to find work or asylum.

title: Mayotte: Reaching Isolated Migrants
description: MSF teams are assessing health needs among undocumented migrants who have arrived on the island, off the coast of Mozambique, looking for work

title: AIDS: Non-Negotiable Lives
description: A free-trade agreement between the EU and India could threaten to restrict the access patients and care-givers in the developing world have to affordable generic drugs.

title: Haiti: Three Months After the Earthquake
description: Three months after the January 12 earthquake, MSF continues to develop and expand their services in response to still immense and evolving needs.

title: Writing On The Edge - Morocco
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Rizzoli International Publications, Inc., proudly present Writing on the Edge, a collection of 14 first-hand accounts of life inside conflict zones where the international medical humanitarian organization provides emergency medical care. The book takes readers on a harrowing tour of countries in crisis, profiling people struggling to cope with war, disease, and lack of access to basic health care.

Award-winning photographer Tom Craig teamed up with MSF and an international roster of 14 highly-esteemed, widely-traveled writers, directors, and actors, and visited various MSF projects, returning with poignant accounts of their experiences. Here, Craig talks about Sub-Saharan migrants who live in hiding in Morocco.

title: Writing On The Edge - Cambodia
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Rizzoli International Publications, Inc., proudly present Writing on the Edge, a collection of 14 first-hand accounts of life inside conflict zones where the international medical humanitarian organization provides emergency medical care. The book takes readers on a harrowing tour of countries in crisis, profiling people struggling to cope with war, disease, and lack of access to basic health care.

Award-winning photographer Tom Craig teamed up with MSF and an international roster of 14 highly-esteemed, widely-traveled writers, directors, and actors, and visited various MSF projects, returning with poignant accounts of their experiences. 

Here, Craig discusses his experience in Cambodia with award-winning author Jim Crace.

title: Writing On The Edge - Burundi
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Rizzoli International Publications, Inc., proudly present Writing on the Edge, a collection of 14 first-hand accounts of life inside conflict zones where the international medical humanitarian organization provides emergency medical care. The book takes readers on a harrowing tour of countries in crisis, profiling people struggling to cope with war, disease, and lack of access to basic health care.

Award-winning photographer Tom Craig teamed up with MSF and New York Times best-selling author Tracy Chevalier. Their story focuses on the abuse of women in Burundi.

More information:
http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/events/public/2010-writingontheedge/

title: Writing on the Edge: Great Contemporary Writers on the Frontline of Crisis
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Rizzoli International Publications, Inc., proudly present Writing on the Edge, a collection of 14 first-hand accounts of life inside conflict zones where the international medical humanitarian organization provides emergency medical care. The book takes readers on a harrowing tour of countries in crisis, profiling people struggling to cope with war, disease, and lack of access to basic health care.

title: Living In Emergency - Doctors Without Borders [trailer]
description:
http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/livinginemergency

For the first time ever, MSF gave a documentary crew uncensored access to its field operations. Set in war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) and post-conflict Liberia, "Living in Emergency" interweaves the stories of four doctors as they struggle to provide emergency medical care under extreme conditions.

Living in Emergency is screening online for live audiences starting September 17, 2010. More information here:
http://www.constellation.tv/filmSpecific?film_id=15&trailer=true

title: Haiti: How They Live
description:
This slideshow is narrated by an MSF communications officer, who also took the photographs during a two-week visit to Haiti in March, 2010. He accompanied MSF field staff on assessments of living conditions in makeshift camps where people had been living without basic assistance.

All photos © Michael Goldfarb/MSF

title: DRC: Condition:Critical - Messages of Support Delivered
description:
On the 24th November 2009, MSF launched the last installment of the Condition: Critical project. You heard stories from Francoise, Mishoko, Bahati and children that have been abducted during the conflict. Since then, nearly two thousand of you have left messages of support for the people of Eastern Congo on the Condition: Critical message map. The first of these messages have already arrived in Congo and more are to follow. This video shows messages being delivered by MSF staff and the reaction of local people to them.

Learn more: http://www.condition-critical.org

title: World TB Day: Rolandi in Georgia
description: Rolandi Mamulia came to the TB hospital in Zugdidi, Georgia, after a previous TB treatment failed to cure him.  The doctors suspect he has drug-resistant TB and are awaiting the results of a culture test (to establish the presence of drug-resistant TB) carried out in a Belgian laboratory on the patient's sputum.  Right now, Rolandi is on standard TB drugs to stabilize his condition. However his health in deteriorating rapidly.

title: World TB Day: India
description: Sayeed Shabir Khan and his wife Rayeesa Khan have been married for 15 years.  Sayeed was working as a private driver in Mumbai, India when he was diagnosed with HIV.  His health deteriorated rapidly and his wife supported him in getting further tests.  These tests finally revealed he was also infected with drug-resistant TB.  Sayeed is now being treated by MSF for both illnesses.

title: World TB Day: Georgia
description: Shorana Konjaria's husband thought his drug-resistant TB was cured in the summer of 2008.  But his illness returned later in the year.  He returned to Zugdidi TB hospital in Georgia and was started on treatment again.  He is now awaiting the results of a culture test which will reveal if his treatment is actually working.

title: Mali: the Koutiala Pediatric Project
description: MSF is running a pediatric program at a hospital in Koutiala, in a region where one in four children dies before the age of five, and conducting mobile clinics that are helping to make healthcare available to many who previously had no access to it.

title: Tuberculosis: A Troubling Resurgence
description: It was supposed to be a thing of the past, but Tuberculosis is still with us, claiming lives, growing more virulent, and demanding much more attention. On March 24, World TB Day, MSF will present a selection of stories and images detailing the work its doing around the globe to counteract this deadly disease.

title: Haiti: Rebuilding Lives
description: In order to tend to the longer-term needs of Haitians wounded and displaced by the January 12 earthquake, MSF has set up centers for specialized services such as physical therapy, psychological care, and plastic surgery, and has also been distributing items such as tents, soap, and blankets.

title: Kenya: The Forgotten Camps of Dadaab
description: Hundreds of thousands of Somalis who fled fighting in their homeland are stranded in overcrowded refugee camps just over the border, in Kenya, where MSF has been offering medical and psychological care.

title: Sri Lanka: Reviewing 9 Months of Activity
description: At the end of January, MSF closed its program in northern Sri Lanka, which was established last May when intensified fighting between the Tamil Tigers and the military drove tens of thousands of people from their homes and left many others in a state of pronounced medical distress.

title: The Difficulty Diagnosing TB: Charity, 4 years old (Kenya)
description: Charity Achieng is four years old and lives in Mathare, a large slum in Nairobi, Kenya. She is suspected of having TB because her mother already has the disease. To rule out active TB, she needs to cough up some sputum for testing. But Charity, like most young children, cant cough up the sputum from deep in her chest, producing saliva instead. Here caregivers try to induce sputum from her.

title: Tuberculosis Today: Where We Stand
description: It's still with us and still deadly, but for far too long, in far too many places, tuberculosis has been neglected. On March 24, MSF will join in the recognition of World TB Day by telling stories from its frontline battles against a disease that kills two million people every year.

title: Tuberculosis Today: Names
description: It's still with us and still deadly, but for far too long, in far too many places, tuberculosis has been neglected. On March 24, MSF will join in the recognition of World TB Day by telling stories from its frontline battles against a disease that kills two million people every year.

title: Tuberculosis Today: Dates
description: It's still with us and still deadly, but for far too long, in far too many places, tuberculosis has been neglected. On March 24, MSF will join in the recognition of World TB Day by telling stories from its frontline battles against a disease that kills two million people every year.

title: Haiti: MSF Projects Enter a New Phase of Care
description: Two months after a devastating earthquake, and with the rainy season fast approaching, MSF continues to expand both its medical and non-medical services in Haiti.

title: Zimbabwean Migrants in South Africa Face Abuse on Both Sides of the Border
description: Zimbabweans have been crossing the border seeking refuge in South Africa for years. They are fleeing an economic and humanitarian crisis, trying to survive. But many risk their lives by making the journey; on both sides of the border they are preyed upon by violent gangs and others.

title: Chagas: Grecia's Story
description:
Grecia is 18 and is in her first year of medicine at the Cochabamba University. She and her mother have been treated for Chagas.

More on MSF's work with Chagas and other neglected diseases: http://bit.ly/akBQqH

title: Haiti: One Month After the Earthquake
description: One month after a devastating earthquake, MSF continues to work diligently to respond to the needs of the Haitian people.

title: Inauguration of the European Parliament Working Group on Innovation & Access
description:
With support from the MSF Access Campaign, a new group has been set up at the European Parliament that aims to both raise the profile of poverty-related diseases and influence EU institutions so as to improve access to medicines for people in developing countries.  

The Working Group on Innovation, Access to Medicines and Poverty Related Diseases, is being established to serve as a discussion forum with Members of the European Parliament, the European Commission and civil society so as to better integrate the European Unions response on health related issues, specifically on HIV/AIDS, TB, malaria and other neglected diseases, as well as to ensure coherent policies on these topics.

title: Khayelitsha: Patient & Doctor Testimonies on the desperate need for improved access to AIDS meds
description:
Many people living with HIV in developing countries are not able to get hold of the medicines they need.

The UNITAID patent pool for HIV medicines could change this.  Join MSF in pushing drug companies to put their patents in the pool.

Hear directly from patients and doctors in Khayelitsha, South Africa on why they are supporting the creation of UNITAID's patent pool. 

To learn more about the patent pool and other innovative mechanisms for improving access to medicines, visit http://www.msfaccess.org

title: Migrants Struggle in Mayote
description: MSF delivers medical services to migrants who have traveled to Mayotte, one of the islands of the Comoros archipelago.

title: Fleeing Violence in the DRC
description: Tens of thousands of residents in the Democratic Republic of Congo's northwest flee into Congo-Brazzaville to escape continuing fighting.

title: Gaza, One Year On
description: In Gaza, the effects of last years Operation Cast Lead is still being felt

title: Chagas Disease: Break the Silence - Time to Treat - Matthew Spitzer
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative (DNDi) had this panel discussion on Chagas disease, a forgotten illness that threatens over 100 million people throughout the Americas, on October 1, 2009.

The discussion is moderated by award-winning journalist Julio Cesar Ortiz, Univision 34 News Reporter. On stage are three experts in the field; Dr. Tom Ellman, a physician who heads MSFs Chagas treatment and prevention program in Bolivia; Dr. Sheba Meymandi, Director, Center of Excellence for Chagas Disease, Olive View-UCLA Medical Center, the only treatment program for Chagas disease in the United States; and Dr. Bernard Pecoul, Executive Director of DNDi, a non-profit pharmaceutical research and development organization working to develop new and improved treatments for some of the worlds most neglected illnesses, including Chagas.

title: Chagas Disease: Break the Silence - Time to Treat - Maria Gutierrez
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and the Drugs for Neglected Diseases Initiative (DNDi) had this panel discussion on Chagas disease, a forgotten illness that threatens over 100 million people throughout the Americas, on October 1, 2009.

The discussion is moderated by award-winning journalist Julio Cesar Ortiz, Univision 34 News Reporter. On stage are three experts in the field; Dr. Tom Ellman, a physician who heads MSFs Chagas treatment and prevention program in Bolivia; Dr. Sheba Meymandi, Director, Center of Excellence for Chagas Disease, Olive View-UCLA Medical Center, the only treatment program for Chagas disease in the United States; and Dr. Bernard Pecoul, Executive Director of DNDi, a non-profit pharmaceutical research and development organization working to develop new and improved treatments for some of the worlds most neglected illnesses, including Chagas.

description:
