title: The Photographer Gallery Talk
description: MSF and First Second Books presented a unique opportunity to hear from some of the key people involved in the creation of The Photographer during a panel discussion at the VII Gallery in Brooklyn, New York, moderated by award-winning VII photographer Ron Haviv. The panel included graphic novelist Emmanuel Guibert, editorial director at First Second Books Mark Siegel, and Doctors Without Borders-USA Executive Director Sophie Delaunay.

title: Starved for Attention: The Neglected Crisis of Malnutrition - Part 1 of 2
description:
This is a recording of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Columbia Universitys Institute for Human Nutrition (IHN) panel discussion about addressing the global crisis of malnutrition, which took place September 10, 2008 at the Riverside Church in New York City. 

The program was moderated by Dr. Ron Waldman, Professor of Public Health at Columbia Universitys Mailman School of Public Health and Team Leader for Pandemic Preparedness and Response at the United States Agency for International Development. The panelists included Biraj Patnaik, Principle Advisor, Office of the Commissioners to Indias Supreme Court; Dr. Milton Tectonidis, MSF nutrition advisor; and Dan Maxwell, Tufts University. 

The discussion is preceded by a brief introduction by Richard Deckelbaum, Director, Institute of Human Nutrition, and Susan Shepherd, Medical Advisor, MSF Campaign for Access to Essential Medicines.

title: Starved for Attention: The Neglected Crisis of Malnutrition - Part 2 of 2
description:
This is a recording of the Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and Columbia Universitys Institute for Human Nutrition (IHN) panel discussion about addressing the global crisis of malnutrition, which took place September 10, 2008 at the Riverside Church in New York City. 

The program was moderated by Dr. Ron Waldman, Professor of Public Health at Columbia Universitys Mailman School of Public Health and Team Leader for Pandemic Preparedness and Response at the United States Agency for International Development. The panelists included Biraj Patnaik, Principle Advisor, Office of the Commissioners to Indias Supreme Court; Dr. Milton Tectonidis, MSF nutrition advisor; and Dan Maxwell, Tufts University. 

The discussion is preceded by a brief introduction by Richard Deckelbaum, Director, Institute of Human Nutrition, and Susan Shepherd, Medical Advisor, MSF Campaign for Access to Essential Medicines.

title: Inside MSF's Inflatable Hospital
description: Take a tour of one part of the inflatable hospital Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) will set up in Haiti.

title: Haiti: Conditions for Staff, Patients Improve
description: After enduring delays in receiving urgent medical supplies and equipment, as well as continuous aftershocks that threatened already-damaged facilities, MSF staff are now treating patients inside an inflatable hospital.

title: Haiti: Two Weeks After the Earthquake, Needs Are Changing
description: In some locations, the needs for amputations are decreasing while needs for post-operative care are rising. MSF teams are diversifying activities to include mental health care, as well as mobile units that travel into areas surrounding current MSF operations, looking for people in need of medical treatment.

title: Haitian Staff Determined to Help
description: Despite enduring profound losses of their own, Haitian members of MSF's staff have continued to do everything they can to provide emergency medical care to the countrymen and women in the aftermath of the January 12 earthquake.

title: MSF Haiti Inflatable Hospital Tent Setup
Six MSF Planes Carrying Vital Medical Supplies Are Rerouted
description: Six MSF cargo planes loaded with vital medical material like antibiotics have been redirected to Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. This will delay MSF staff's ability to treat patients who urgently need it.

title: MSF Works to Save Lives After Haiti Earthquake
description: More than 700 Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff are working to provide emergency medical care to earthquake survivors in and around Port-au-Prince. Surgical priorities are amputations and caesarean sections. Experienced staff say they have never seen so many severe injuries.

title: Haiti: MSF Teams Overwhelmed by Needs
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) staff work 24 hours a day to treat as many patients injured in the January 12 earthquake as possible, but the needs are huge and there are delays in receiving crucial supplies.

title: MSF's Inflatable Hospital Increases Medical Aid in Pakistan
description: See how MSF used inflatable hospitals after the 2005 earthquake in Pakistan. MSF uses inflatable hospitals to provide critical medical care in disaster areas. Portable operating theaters, they can be readied in enormous crates and quickly loaded onto planes. These kits comprise beds, rolling trays, respirators - all the equipment and medicines required to provide effective lifesaving surgery.

title: MSF Press Conference on Haiti Earthquake
description: Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) teams already working on medical projects Haiti have treated hundreds of people injured in the quake and have been setting up clinics in tents to replace their own damaged medical facilities. Paul McPhun, MSFs operations manager for Haiti, described the current situation for MSF teams on the ground during a press conference on January 13.

title: About Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières
description: This video offers a complete overview of the activities, philosophy and structure of the international humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières  (MSF).

title: MSF Offers Tribute to Staff Killed in Pakistan
description: Two medical staff from Doctors Without Borders were killed this month while driving to assist people affected by fighting in Swat district, northwestern Pakistan on Sunday, February 1, 2009.

title: Southern Sudan: Facing Up to Reality
description: In January 2005, Sudan signed a peace agreement marking the end of 21 years of violent war between the North and South. This year, there was a sharp deterioration in the humanitarian and security situation for the population of the semi-autonomous South. MSF medical teams witnessed the most severe escalation of violence in Southern Sudan since the signing of the peace agreement.

title: Condition:Critical - Francoise's Story
description:
Francoise's story is one of the last pieces to be released from Condition: Critical, a year-long MSF project aiming to give a voice to the people living through the war in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Please watch the video, then visit the Condition: Critical website to leave a message of support for the people of eastern DRC. Your message may be selected to be shared with our patients.

http://www.condition-critical.org

title: Munich: MSF pushes for 9 pharma companies to put patents in the pool
description:
MSF asks pharma companies to put their AIDS patents in the patent pool.

Please sign our petition: https://www.actionformsfaccess.org

For more information, www.msfaccess.org

title: MSF Jumps in Lake Geneva for the Patent Pool
description:
Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is calling upon nine of the biggest pharmaceutical companies to quickly make available new treatments for millions of people living with AIDS. One possible solution: a patent pool would allow the prices of those treatments to be reduced.

Make it Happen!

WHEN: Wednesday 28 October, from 5.30 P.M.

WHERE: Bains de Pâquis, Genève

MSF, Groupe SIDA Genève, Dialogai, the Bern Declaration other NGOs and associations will be present to jump in the lake of Geneva to catch a giant pill, unreachable for those who need it the most.

title: HIV/AIDS Support Groups in Khayelitshsa, South Africa
Natasha's Story: World AIDS Day 2009
Support Groups
description: Support Groups provide HIV/AIDS and TB patients with coping strategies.

title: Integrated Care at Ubuntu Clinic
description: Integrated HIV and TB care is available at the Ubuntu clinic in Khayelitsha township

title: HIV/AIDS and TB Coinfection
description: Nondumiso was co-infected with HIV and TB. Now she runs support groups for other patients.

title: Nandipah's Story
description: Nandipah was kicked out by her family when they learned of her HIV status. She prays every day for reconciliation

title: Abungile's Story
description: Abungile is 14 years-old and, a few months ago, asked his mother if he was HIV positive. When she told him the truth, that both of them were HIV positive, Abungile was initially very scared. Now he takes care of both of them, is determined to eat well and live a healthy lifestyle as a preventative measure.

title: Access to Medicines
description: Nomafu fears failing her 2nd line HIV treatment, and worries what will happen to her with no other treatment options

title: Condition:Critical - Drawing the War
description: Watch the all too common story of a child, forced to become a soldier, through his pictures and words. Then go to Condition: Critical to leave a message of support for him and all the children like him who have been forced to grow up in such a horrific way. MSF will take a selection of these messages to Congo (DRC) as a show of support and solidarity.

title: Condition:Critical - Bahati's Story
description:
Bahati's story is the third of four to be released from the last chapter of Condition:Critical, a year long MSF project aiming to give a voice to the people living through the war in Eastern Congo (DRC).

Please watch the video, then visit the Condition: Critical website to leave a message of support for Bahati and the people of Eastern Congo.

http://www.condition-critical.org

title: Cod iyo Muqaal: Wax-qabadyada MSF ee Isbitaalka Jamaame ee Soomaalia.
description:
Isbitaalka  Jamaame oo taqriiban 20  Mayl dhinaca waqooyi ka xigta magaalada weyn ee Kismaayo, waxaa la furay sanadkii 2007. Goobtan MSF waxay ku bixisaa nafaqayn,daryeelka dalmada, caafimaadka guud, daryeelka deg-degga ah.Haviyee Roldan oo ah Kal-kaaliye caafimaad ayaa ka soo shaqeeyay Jamame  toddoba bilood sanadkan gudahiis asagoo ahaa isu-duwaha goobta.   

Asaga oo adeegsanayo Sawira  iyo waraysiya Roldan uu la yeeshay shaqaalaha caafimaad ee Soomaaliyeed  ayuu u yeelay/u huwiyay waji amba dareen bini'aadminimo xaalada Soomaaliya.

English version available here: 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFmQCxeVw70

title: Condition:Critical - Mishoka's Story
description:
Mishoka's story is the second of four to be released from the last chapter of Condition: Critical, a year long MSF project aiming to give a voice to the people living through the war in Eastern Congo (DRC). 

Please watch the video, then visit the Condition: Critical website to leave a message of support for Mishoka and the people of Eastern Congo.

http://www.condition-critical.org

title: Sierra Leone: Patient Fees Put Lifesaving Medical Care Out of Reach
description: In Sierra Leone, a simple  medical consultation may cost as much as 25 days of income. These fees are a major obstacle to life-saving health care in a country with some of the highest maternal and child mortality rates in the world. On November 18 and 19, 2009, international donors will meet in London at the Sierra Leone Investment and Donor Conference. MSF wants donors to realize the urgency of this user fee problem and take steps to address it.

title: MSF Frontline Reports: October 2009
description: This month we bring you a story about malnutrition in a land rich for cultivation: in the Democratic Republic of Congo, many children suffer from severe malnutrition even though food is abundant where they live. And in Uganda, a community-based movement of HIV-positive patients helps MSF provide care. Plus, this month's Emergency Updates.

title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders LIVE December 14
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and NCM Fathom present a unique, one-night only LIVE documentary and panel discussion event. 

For the first time ever, MSF gave a documentary crew uncensored access to its field operations. The critically acclaimed, Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders, gives a rare inside look into the organization through the eyes of four doctors pushed to the edge and forced to confront the limits of their idealism in the face of overwhelming medical needs.

Following the documentary, a live panel discussion will be hosted and moderated by Elizabeth Vargas, anchor of ABC News 20/20. 

Panelists will include: 
-- Dr. Tom Krueger, an MSF surgeon featured in the documentary
-- Sebastian Junger, best-selling author of The Perfect Storm and contributing editor of Vanity Fair
-- Sophie Delaunay, Executive Director of MSF-USA, plus other specials guests

BUY TICKETS:  (This event is only in the U.S.)
http://www.ncm.com/Fathom/OriginalPrograms/LivingInEmergency.aspx?utm_source=DoctorswithoutBorders_LIE&utm_medium=Microsite&utm_campaign=LivinginEmergency_FathomPage

title: DRC: Violence Continues Against Civilians
description: Louis finds one of his two sons, kidnapped four months previously. Attacks, rapes and kidnappings occur frequently here. We are in the northern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo, in the Upper and Lower Uélé. The region has been in the grip of violence since 2008, with clashes continuing between members of the Lord's Resistance Army, a Ugandan rebel group, and Congolese and Ugandan armed forces.  Aid remains inadequate in this hard-to-reach area. In some places, MSF is the only NGO in the field. Other humanitarian organizations must mobilize to work with this isolated population, trapped in a conflict that is spreading here, in the northern Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Central African Republic: Nutritional Emergency in the Southwest
description: This child is suffering from kwashiorkor, a form of severe malnutrition. MSF teams have set up four nutritional treatment projects, including this one in a hospital in Boda. A food crisis has increased the number of malnutrition cases here in the southwest region of the Central African Republic. The people who live here are already poor and are experiencing the full brunt of an economic crisis, specifically in the mining sector.  MSF has treated 1,800 patients in two months. In addition to malnutrition, many suffer from other health problems including malaria, diarrhea and tuberculosis. Beyond the nutritional emergency, people here have other health needs that require a broader response.

title: Iraq: MSF Authorized to Continue Its Activities
description: MSF's partnership agreement with Iraqi authorities has been renewed and the Ministry of Health has authorized MSF to continue its activities. Patients are sent from Iraq to Amman, Jordan. The seriousness of their wounds often requires long periods of hospitalization and, sometimes, multiple surgeries.

title: Southern Asia and the South Pacific
description:
Natural Catastrophe in Indonesia, the Philippines and the Samoan islands 

In Indonesia, MSF has focused its efforts on the country's isolated areas and, specifically, in the area north of Pariaman, where several earthquakes and landslides have occurred. Nearly 90 percent of homes have been destroyed. 

Based on the latest estimates, more than 700 people have died and nearly 3,000 are missing. 

In the Philippines, official reports estimate that 300 people have died in the floods and another 32,000 have been displaced.

title: HIV-TB: A Double Epidemic in Southern Africa
description: Swaziland in Southern Africa is on the brink of a major health crisis due to the killer twin epidemic of HIV-AIDS and TB.

title: Living in Emergency: Stories of Doctors Without Borders
description: Living in Emergency is a film that takes place in war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo and post-conflict Liberia, and follows four Doctors Without Borders aid workers as they struggle to provide emergency medical care under extreme conditions. With different levels of experience, these medical humanitarians must find their own ways to face the challenges, the tough choices, and the limits of their idealism.

title: Connecting the DOTS, Coughing up for TB
description:
Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), the International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease, and Global Health Advocates/ACTION hosted a symposium in Sweden, 21 October 2009. 

Hear from Dr Christophe Fournier (President of MSF), Dr Pehrolov Pehrson (MSF Sweden), Dr Frauke Jochims (MSF Geneva) and Dr Nils Billo (International Union Against Tuberculosis and Lung Disease) on the importance of increased funding for TB research and development. 

More info: http://www.msfaccess.org/main/tuberculosis/stockholm-tb-symposium/

title: Indonesia: MSF's Post-Earthquake Intervention Continues
description: Nearly three weeks after the earthquake hit, the emergency phase is winding down, but MSF is still finding small populations in need of help and continues to provide medical and mental health assistance, as well as relief supplies.

title: Philippines: MSF Intervenes After Flooding
description: As the water begins to recede and the roads are cleared, people are starting to pick up their lives.  But many find themselves destitute and the extent of the damage remains huge.

title: Slideshow: MSF Activities at Somalia's Jamaame Hospital
description:
Located nearly 20 miles north of the Somali city of Kismayo, Jamaame Hospital was opened in 2007. At this site, MSF provides nutrition, maternity, general medical, and emergency care. Javier Roldan, a 35 year-old nurse worked as Jamaame field coordinator for seven months this year. 

Through Roldan's photos and interviews with Somali health workers, he puts a human face on the situation in Somalia.

Somali language version available here: 
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7yOgDrVle3g

title: DRC: More Assistance Needed Due to Violence in the Northeast
description: Since late 2008, the civilian population of Haut-Uélé and Bas-Uélé has been caught in a dramatic cycle of violence. Hundreds of thousands of people have been displaced and violent attacks continue to send thousands seeking shelter and greater security in towns.

title: MSF Frontline Reports Podcast - September 2009
description: We take you to northern Nigeria, where MSF is providing surgery to repair fistulas  life-altering internal injuries that can happen to women who endure prolonged, complicated labor. In Burkina Faso, malnutrition is at its annual peak and MSF is responding.Well hear from an MSF doctor who was there at the same time last year. You'll also hear emergency updates from MSF projects around the world.

title: Why We Need a Patent Pool: Patient Testimony
description: Thembisa Mkhosana explains how she has run out of treatment options. A patent pool could help deliver newer, affordable medicines.

title: Central African Republic: MSF responds to nutritional emergency
description: With more than 1,000 children facing a severe nutritional emergency in southwestern Central African Republic (CAR), Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is stepping up its activities in the area.

title: Malawi: Decentralizing HIV/AIDS Care
description: In Malawi, where around 930,000 people are living with HIV/AIDS and human resources in the health sector are scarce, MSF is delegating treatment from district hospitals to local health centers to bring care closer to the patients.

title: Chagas Disease - Improving Patient Diagnosis and Treatment
description: The search is on for new diagnostic tests, better medication and drug trials for Chagas, a neglected disease that kills 14,000 people each year.

title: Southern Sudan - New Northern Borders for Abyei
description: The Hague-based Court of Arbitration has changed the borders of Abyei province in central Sudan. Some MSF teams had previously been expelled from the north, but all MSF sections are still working in the south.

title: Identifying and Treating the Most Severe Cases of Influenza A
description: With close to 165,000 cases and a death toll of more than 1,000 people, the H1N1 flu virus outbreak is prompting questions about the virus' future scale and the strategies in place to deal with it.

title: Southern Sudan: LRA Violence Leaves People Terrified, Vulnerable
description:
Photojournalist Brendan Bannon documented the deep wounds caused by attacks on civilians by the Lords Resistance Army rebel group in Southern Sudan.

Learn more:
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=3762&cat=field-news&ref=youtube

title: Chagas: Its Time to Break the Silence - Gualberto
description:
Gualberto Paniagua, 33, was diagnosed with Chagas and now he is being treated for the disease.  He is from rural Cochabamba, Bolivia and thinks he got infected when he was living with his parents as a young boy.

Learn more about Chagas: 
http://chagas-break-the-silence.com

title: Guatemala: Survivors of Sexual Violence Speak Out
description: About 10,000 people are raped every year in Guatemala. Many survivors are afraid to speak out. Hear these MSF patients speak about how they have been affected and how they have sought treatment.

title: Thailand: MSF Leaves Huai Nam Khao Camp
description: MSF has stop providing assistance at Huai Nam Khao Camp in Thailand's Petchabun Province. For four years, MSF had been the only organization working at this camp for Lao Hmong people who had fled their country. The decision to leave was made after conditions imposed by the Thai military threatened MSF's impartiality and ability to deliver care.

title: Working with MSF Now Satisfies Doctors' Training Requirements
description: For doctors, working in the field and training with MSF are now officially recognized as medical training, satifying continuing education requirements in EU countries, the US, Canada, and Australia.

title: HIV/AIDS: Preventing Mother-To-Child Transmission
description: In Malawi, MSF focuses on preventing the transmission of HIV from mother to child using antiretroviral medication.

title: AIDS Emergency is Far from Over
description: The ARV treatment program run by Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) in Khayelitsha outside Cape Town, South Africa is one of the longest running ARV treatment programs in sub-Saharan Africa. MSF is seeing patients failing first-line treatment in increasing numbers and others not responding to available and affordable second-line treatment regimens. It is a wake-up call to all those in the global health field who no longer consider AIDS an emergency.

title: The Photographer on "The Rachel Maddow Show" on MSNBC
description: MSNBC's Rachel Maddow interviews illustrator Emmanuel Guibert and former Head of Mission in Afghanistan for Doctors Without Borders Juliette Fournot, and hails The Photographer as  One of the most amazing publications Ive ever read.

title: Voices of the Youth from Eastern Congo: Survive
description:
This video is part of MSF's Condition: Critical, a multimedia project that gives a voice to the people affected by war in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
MSF has been working in North and South Kivu provinces since 1992, carrying out emergency surgery, treating injuries such as gunshot wounds and burns, and running mobile clinics to reach those who have fled to remote areas. MSF teams respond to epidemics such as cholera and provide medical and mental health care to victims of sexual violence.

Voices of the Youth from Eastern Congo
Express: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EgjWFpz4Ss8

title: Voices of the Youth from Eastern Congo: Express
description:
This video is part of MSF's Condition: Critical, a multimedia project that gives a voice to the people affected by war in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
MSF has been working in North and South Kivu provinces since 1992, carrying out emergency surgery, treating injuries such as gunshot wounds and burns, and running mobile clinics to reach those who have fled to remote areas. MSF teams respond to epidemics such as cholera and provide medical and mental health care to victims of sexual violence.

Voices of the Youth from Eastern Congo
Survive: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SFrDkg2c8JM

title: No Refuge: Access Denied - Zimbabweans in South Africa Struggle to Survive
description: Despite the fact that many Zimbabweans risk their lives to flee Zimbabwe, the South African government has historically characterised them as voluntary economic migrants and aggressively deported them. Zimbabweans say they had little choice but to leave and thousands continue to cross the border every day, legally and illegally, as a matter of survival.

title: Meningitis: 7 million vaccinated in West Africa
description: A total of 1,900 people have died in Nigeria, Chad, and Niger in a recent meningitis epidemic and MSF has launched its largest ever vaccination campaign against the disease.

title: Sudan: MSF Expulsions from Darfur
description: Following MSF's expulsion earlier this year the organization affirms that it would be ready to provide emergency aid if the situation changes and conditions allow its work with complete neutrality, impartiality, and independence.

title: Yemen: Primary health care and Surgery
description: Conflict has been underway since 2004 in northern Yemen between a rebel group and government forces. War breaks out every year, but tensions persist even when there is no open fighting.

title: Thailand: Hmong Refugees and MSF under Pressure
description: MSF has treated nearly 8,000 Laotian Hmong refugees in northern Thailand over the last four years. Now MSFs work in the Huai Nam Khao camp is threatened.

title: Somalia: Abducted MSF staff released
description: Although the recent abduction of a Belgian doctor and a Dutch medical coordinator ended positively, such attacks pose dangers to MSFs health care activities in a country where millions of people depend on humanitarian aid.

title: Kala Azar: "A Disease of the Poorest of the Poor"
description: Every year, kala azar kills more than 50,000 thousand people worldwide. A neglected disease, the treatment for it was developed in the 1930s and requires a long, painful course of intra-muscular injections. The treatment is also prohibitively expensive for many of those who have the disease. In Kacheliba, West Pokot District, Kenya, MSF provides free treatment for kala azar.

title: Multidrug-Resistant Tuberculosis: Recovery Possible If Patient Receives Treatment
description: Countries most affected by multidrug-resistant tuberculosis - India, China and Russia  are being urged to treat more patients and to conduct research critical to finding improved treatments.

title: Sri Lanka: Inhabitants Held Hostage to Conflict
description: Tens of thousands of people in Sri Lanka's northern areas of Vavuniya and Vanni are displaced or caught in fighting between the Sri Lankan army and Tamil Tiger rebels. MSF teams operate on nearly 200 wounded patients every week in Vavuniya's hospital.

title: Sudan: MSF's International Teams Withdraw from Darfur
description: MSF has withdrawn international teams from Sudan's Darfur region following the kidnapping and subsequent release of MSF volunteers. The organization was one of 13 NGOs expelled from Darfur after the International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir.

title: Zimbabwe: MSF Cleans Water and Educates to Stem Cholera Spread
description: Tens of thousands of Zimbabwean families are exposed to conditions that promote the spread of cholera. MSF teams are disinfecting well water with chlorine and alerting populations to the role of hygiene in stemming the spread of the potentially fatal disease.

title: West Africa: Millions Affected by Meningitis Epidemic
description: MSF teams are responding to a meningitis epidemic affecting millions of people in the West African countries of Nigeria, Niger, and Burkina Faso, and also Chad and Cameroon.

title: Perilous Journey
description: Somali refugees and Ethiopian migrants are risking their lives at sea for a better life in Yemen, where MSF teams provide assistance to those who survive a treacherous journey on smuggler boats through the Gulf of Aden.

title: MSF in Afghanistan 1984
MSF in Afghanistan 1984
Homeless Asylum Seekers in Paris Receive MSF Support
description: Asylum seekers in France falling outside the country's social and health safety nets can end up destitute and in need of medical treatment. An MSF service in Paris offers assistance and referrals to those living on the street.

title: More Funding Needed for Neglected Diseases
description: Leishmaniasis, Chagas disease and sleeping sickness are little-known but fatal diseases threatening the lives of about 500 million people around the world. Research has shown that these three diseases receive less than five percent of the world's Research and Development funds for neglected diseases.

title: TB Patients Need Better Tests
description: On World TB Day this month, MSF focuses on the urgent need for Tuberculosis tests to deliver faster and more accurate results for all patients, including those in remote settings.

title: MSF Expelled From Darfur
description: Two sections of MSF have been expelled from western and southern regions of Darfur, Sudan, leaving vulnerable populations at increased risk from outbreaks of diseases such as meningitis. In some areas MSF was the only medical organization present.

title: DRC Project Urges Early Treatment For Rape Victims
description: MSF is one of the few organizations in North Kivu, Democratic Republic of the Congo, that provides comprehensive medical care to victims of rape and carries out awareness-raising activities emphasizing the importance of early treatment to help prevent the spread of HIV.

title: Swaziland: HIV / AIDS and Tuberculosis - Breaking The Silence
description: More than 50 percent of Tuberculosis (TB) patients in Swaziland are reportedly also infected with HIV, and it is estimated that this figure is well below the actual percentage of co-infected patients. This video highlights a forgotten humanitarian emergency, showing the link between HIV and TB, and the importance of early diagnosis.

title: What do you wish for? Support the women of Eastern Congo!
description:
In support of the women of Eastern Congo we invite you to send a message to them by making your own video or by posting a comment on Condition: Critical, stating what you wish for them for their future.

You can post your video to the What do you wish for? Facebook group or upload it to YouTube (just tag it congowish). We will then feature selections of these videos on Condition: Critical.

Condition: Critical
http://www.condition-critical.org/what-do-you-wish-for/

Facebook Group:
http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=61779871930&ref=mf

YouTube
http://www.youtube.com/msf

title: Zimbabwe's Cholera Epidemic Spread by Drink of Water
There Is A Solution, Here's How A Patent Pool Could Work (Patent Pool 4 of 4)
description:
These animations explain why people in developing countries can't get the HIV medicines they need to survive and how setting up a 'patent pool' could change that.

MSF calls on researchers and pharmaceutical companies: put your patents in the pool!

More information: http://www.msfaccess.org

title: How Tricky It Is To Get the Right HIV Treatments (Patent Pool 3 of 4)
description:
These animations explain why people in developing countries can't get the HIV medicines they need to survive and how setting up a 'patent pool' could change that. 

MSF calls on researchers and pharmaceutical companies: put your patents in the pool!

More information: http://www.msfaccess.org

title: Why There Aren't Enough HIV Treatments Suitable for Children (Patent Pool 2 of 4)
description:
These animations explain why people in developing countries can't get the HIV medicines they need to survive and how setting up a 'patent pool' could change that. 

MSF calls on researchers and pharmaceutical companies: put your patents in the pool!

More information: http://www.msfaccess.org

title: Life Saving HIV Treatment: Three Problems, One Solution (Patent Pool 1 of 4)
description:
These animations explain why people in developing countries can't get the HIV medicines they need to survive and how setting up a 'patent pool' could change that. 

MSF calls on researchers and pharmaceutical companies: put your patents in the pool!

More information: http://www.msfaccess.org

title: Shattered Lives
description:
This video features testimony from MSF patients who have been victims of sexual violence, and MSF staff who treat them.

To mark International Women's Day, MSF released a report summarizing the organization's experience assisting victims of sexual violence in Liberia, Burundi, Democratic Republic of the Congo, South Africa, Colombia, and other countries. In 2007 MSF teams treated more than 12,000 victims, in both conflict settings and stable environments.

The report, titled "Shattered Lives," highlights the need for emergency medical care to be made available to people who have been raped. MSF also stresses that such services need to be truly accessible, with guarantees for confidentiality and the offer of comprehensive care. 

Learn more: 
http://www.msf.org/shatteredlives

title: Statement from President of MSF International Council, on MSF expulsions from Darfur, Sudan
description:
Sudanese authorities in Khartoum this morning demanded the immediate expulsion of a second section of MSF from Darfur.

The decision, brutal and sudden, follows the expulsion yesterday of the Dutch section of the organization. MSF is appalled by this order, which clearly holds the needs of the population of Darfur hostage to political and judicial agendas. The organization protests the order in the strongest of terms and appeals to the government to repeal these decisions and allow MSF to resume independent and impartial humanitarian assistance immediately.

title: New Study Shows Dramatic Effect of Food Supplements on Child Malnutrition
description: Children in rural Niger who received ready-to-use food in addition to their normal diet were nearly 60 percent less likely to progress to the most life-threatening form of malnutrition.

title: DRC Refugees in Uganda Camp Report Attacks During Flight
description: People among the 5,000 refugees from eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo arriving at a camp across the border in Uganda report assaults by armed groups as they attempted to flee fighting.

title: Attacks Continue in Eastern DRC, Situation Calmer in North Kivu
description: Nearly 900 civilians have been killed in recent weeks by members of the Lord's Resistance Army at sites across the Haut-Uélé province of eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo. The situation in the region's North Kivu is calm in spite of Rwandan troops crossing the border.

title: Doctors Provide Follow-up Surgery to Gaza Patients
description: Medical teams in the Gaza Strip provide follow-up surgery and care for people wounded during the three-week Israeli military operation that began at the end of last year.

title: Deadly Attacks on Civilians in DRC
description:
The Lords Resistance Army has increased its attacks on villages in Haut Uélé, in the northwest of Democratic Republic of the Congo. These extremely violent attacks have left dozens dead and wounded.

More information:
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=3352&ref=youtube

title: Sleeping Sickness Threatens 60 Million
description: This fatal disease threatens some 60 million people. In 2006, there were 17,000 reported cases. But a new treatment is now available. Its the result of three studies conducted by Epicentre, an epidemiological center created by MSF, and the DNDi, a foundation that develops medicines for neglected tropical diseases. Started nine years ago, these studies now show the efficacy of a combination of eflornithine with nifurtimox.

title: Assistance For Illegal Migrant Workers in Italy
description: Originally from Ghana, Nigeria or Mali, they're working illegally as seasonal farm workers. Living in appalling conditions without running water, electricity, or heating, they're surrounded by garbage. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières distributes kits consisting of a sleeping bag, a toothbrush, toothpaste, and soap.

title: Treating the Wounded in Gaza
description: Twenty-two days after launching its offensive, the Israeli army announced a unilateral ceasefire. A team of three international and 70 Palestinian staff sought to address the lack of access to healthcare. A surgical team that just entered is now working in Al Shifa hospital.

title: Ebola, Another Epidemic in DRC
description:
In Western Kasai, in the center of Democratic Republic of the Congo, seven people have contracted Ebola hemorrhagic fever. Some 39 others are showing symptoms of the virus. Results are due back from a laboratory confirming whether or not they are infected. Thirteen have already died.

More information:
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=3329&cat=field-news&ref=youtube

title: On Both Sides of the Frontline
description:
In the area around Sake, west of Goma, MSF supports the hospital in Kirotshe and provide psychological assistance to displaced people in Shasha. Mobile clinics provide medical and psychological care to the populations of Karuba, Mushake, and Rubaya - three areas controlled by the rebels.

MSF also crosses the frontline to transfer patients to Kirotshe hospital. To work on both sides of a frontline, MSF teams develop contacts with communities and also with the different armed groups. To get access to conflict areas, neutrality is key.

title: Somalia: Catastrophic Situation
description: Over the past two years, almost 300,000 Somalis have fled to Kenya and Yemen in a bid to escape random violencein the Somalia. Around 900,000 others are displaced within their own country. Three million people need immediate aid. Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is currently working in nine regions of Somalia, trying to provide assistance to the population.

title: 2008 Year in Review
description:
In 2008, Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has worked in armed conflicts, natural disasters, and medical emergencies and frequently, in increasingly difficult circumstances.

Learn more:
http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/topten

title: Condition Critical: Voices From the War in Congo
description:
SEE THE FULL-LENGTH FEATURE:
http://www.condition-critical.org

Hundreds of thousands of people are on the run, fleeing a war that rages in eastern Congo, in the provinces of North and South Kivu.

They are frightened. Many are sick or wounded. Others have been harassed or raped, or have had everything they own stolen.

The people of the Kivus are in a critical condition. The destiny of everyone in this region is shaped by the war.

The story of their struggle to survive needs to be told.

http://www.condition-critical.org

title: Condition Critical: Voices From the War in Congo
description:
SEE THE FULL-LENGTH FEATURE:
http://www.condition-critical.org

Hundreds of thousands of people are on the run, fleeing a war that rages in eastern Congo, in the provinces of North and South Kivu.

They are frightened. Many are sick or wounded. Others have been harassed or raped, or have had everything they own stolen.

The people of the Kivus are in a critical condition. The destiny of everyone in this region is shaped by the war.

The story of their struggle to survive needs to be told.

http://www.condition-critical.org

title: An MSF Finance Coordinator in Darfur
description: Yvonne Biyo served as finance coordinator for two MSF projects in North Darfur from December 2007 to September 2008. Based in El Fasher, she was in charge of finances for projects in Tawila and Shangil Tobaya. During her assignment, the projects and staff experienced a rash of robberies, prompting an evacuation and a risk-analysis study. Yvonne, along with the rest of the team, had to decide whether to stay and continue providing the only medical care people in this area had access to, or to close the project.

title: 'In the End, I Didn't Want to Leave'
description: A Kenyan clinical officer, similar to a physician's assistant in the US, talks about how she very reluctantly started working with MSF in a refugee camp.

title: Explaining Basic Mental Health Care to Kids
description: At the Refugee Camp exhibit in San Diego, Luis Encinas explains mental health care in the field.

title: Mayor Welcomes MSF to San Diego
description: Mayor Jerry Sanders welcomed MSF and A Refugee Camp in the Heart of the City to San Diego during a press conference held at the exhibit on Thursday. See video of Mayor Sanders urging all San Diegans to come to the exhibit in order to better understand what many of their former refugee neighbors have been through.

title: Providing Aid Doesn't Always Earn Respect
description: MSF began work in West Kalimantan, Indonesia, in 1999 after horrific ethnic violence forced thousands of Madurese into makeshift urban camps in the areas of Pontianak and Singkawang. They were not welcome in the area and MSF nurse Kelly Grimshaw, who arrived in 2001, says the resentment extended to the aid workers there to protect this vulnerable population. Here, Kelly explains the project and why it was her most challenging yet.

title: Treating a Child Soldier in a Refugee Camp
description: Peninah Ndungu, a Kenyan national and an MSF clinical officer (similar to a physician's assistant), talks about one of the hardest situations she had to deal with while working in a refugee camp in Uganda.

title: MSF Projects Treating Iraqi Civilians
description: MSF anesthetist Shobha Varthaman talks about MSF's programs in Sulemaniyah in northern Iraq and Amman, Jordan, where surgeons perform maxillofacial, plastic, and orthopedic surgery on civilian victims of war.

title: Intro to Latrines in Refugee/IDP Camps
description: MSF logistician Martin Studer explains latrines to visitors to A Refugee Camp in the Heart of the City in Santa Monica.

title: Logistician's First Mission to Liberia
description: During an MSF panel discussion in San Diego before the Refugee Camp exhibit, MSF logistician Alan Hickey described the nerve-wracking lead-up to his first mission in Port Harcourt, Nigeria.

title: Successive Storms Leave Haitians Stranded Without Shelter
description: A series of four hurricanes devastated the island of Haiti in the course of a month. According to the most recent figures, 793 people have died and more than 165,000 families hae been directly affected by the disaster. The town of Gonaives was particularly hard hit.

title: Masssive Vaccination Campaign Launched in Eastern Congo
description: MSF launched a massive measles-vaccination campaign in the Tanganyika region in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The epidemic has spread throughout this vast region which covers more than 150,000 square kilometers and where the majority of the population do not have access to treatment. The plan is to vaccinate all children between 6 months and 15 years of age; reaching them is a major challenge. The campaign began in July. More than 270,000 children have been vaccinated.

title: MSF Hospital in Iran Offers Treatment for Wounded Iraqis
description: Since 2006, MSF has set up range of surgical programs to treat victims of the violence inside Iraq's most intense conflict zones. It is too dangerous for MSF to operate programs inside these areas. As a result, MSF surgical teams are working in two hospitals in northern Iraq, and running two reconstructive surgery projects, one based in Jordan and the other in Iran.

title: MSF Suspension Leaves Children in Niger Without Treatment
description: Three months after Nigerien authorities suspended the activities of the French section of Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), the international medical humanitarian organization is calling for an immediate resumption of its nutritional operations in the Maradi region.

title: Democratic Republic of Congo: War Resumes in North Kivu
description: Hundreds of thousands of people have fled fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo's North Kivu province since late August when fighting resumed. Many of them were already living in camps. Repeated displacement has left them in great need of food, access to water, shelter and medical care.

title: Delivering Babies in Haiti
description: MSF nurse Michelle Belletete worked at Jude Anne Hospital, in an obstetrics program in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, for high-risk pregnancies. Once the free program became well-known, it became constantly inundated with pregnant women trying to get into the program, some desperately in need of help for complications or already well into labor.

title: What is it Like to be a Female Logistician in the Field?
description: In some communities where MSF works, women are viewed quite differently than what we are accustomed to in developed countries. MSF logisticians are often in charge of hiring and managing teams of local workers - usually men - and negotiating with authority figures. MSF log Amy Segal talks about how she manages the disconnect.

title: Outreach and Impartial Treatment Yields Results
description: Being a logistician in a refugee camp and in other settings includes reaching out to different communities within and around the camp to address their needs and make sure that MSF is not excluding any groups. This is important to carrying out MSF's purpose of impartially providing care, and helps provide some measure of security by keeping in close communication with all parties. These ties with the communities also come in handy when something is stolen from an MSF project, as logistician Amy Segal recounts.

title: Philip Sacks: Working in Petchabun, Thailand
description: MSF logistician Philip Sacks describes the challenges of his work in a camp for Hmong refugees in Thailand, during the Refugee Camp exhibit in Los Angeles.

title: Mental Health: A Patient Paralyzed With Guilt in Darfur
description:
Janet Kerr helped create a mental health component to MSFs project at Kalma Camp -one of the largest internally displaced persons (IDP) camps in the world - in Darfur in 2006. She and a Sudanese assistant trained 12 community workers in Kalma in basic mental health coping mechanisms. The workers staged dramas and spoke with members of their communities to communicate these coping mechanisms and to identify patients who needed more intensive mental health assistance. This is the story of one patient.

title: Interview with Nicolas Beaudoin
description:
MSF aid worker and office staff Nicolas Beaudoin helped conceive of and initiate the Refugee Camp exhibit, first in France in 1996 and again in the U.S. in 2000. Over the last 12 years MSF has staged this exhibit in 16 countries, including Australia, Italy, Japan, Switzerland, and United Arab Emirates. More than one million people worldwide have visited the exhibit; many have been refugees themselves. Here, Nicolas talks about how some of these visitors have reacted.

title: Southern Ethiopia: Nutrition Situation Stabilizing in Some A
description:
Nearly 40,000 people have received food distributions through MSF in southern Ethiopia over the last four months. While admissions to the MSF nutrition program are decreasing, there is still a need for outside assistance.

Learn more:
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=3123

title: Fighting Erupts in Democratic Republic of Congo's North Kivu
description: MSF is working to help those who have fled displaced persons camps in North Kivu as violence between the Congolese Army and rebel groups continues to intensify. But providing basic medical care to the displaced is becoming increasingly difficult.

title: Patient Stories from Oromiya, Ethiopia
description:
Parents of affected children talk about their situations, and MSF medical staff describe treatment of severe malnutrition at a stabilization center in Oromiya region in southern Ethiopia.

Learn more: 
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/news/report.cfm?id=2829

title: Tensions Mount in South Sudan's Bahr el Ghazal Region
description: This short film focuses on the deteriorating situation, including outbreaks of malnutrition, in South Sudan's northern Bahr el Ghazal region.

title: Civilians and Aid Workers Caught in the Crossfire in Somalia
description: This short film provides an overview of MSF programs and the situation in Somalia from 2007 to mid-2008. Hundreds of thousands of people have fled the capital, Mogadishu, as a result of increasing violence. And attacks against aid organizations has limited the amount of relief deployed.

title: Conflict Sparks Massive Displacement in North Kivu, Democratic Republic of Congo
description: This short film gives an overview of MSF programs and the situation in North Kivu, the Democratic Republic of Congo. Continued fighting and violence has lead to repeated population displacement. MSF carries out vaccination campaigns, works in the referral hospital in the ER, surgery and pediatric wards, and offers medical care for rape victims.

title: Mount Elgon, Kenya: A Terrorized Population in Desperate Need
description:
The international medical humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) is calling for an immediate increase in assistance for the people of Mount Elgon in western Kenya, and an end to the indiscriminate violence they have endured for almost two years.

Since August 2006, the civilian population of Mount Elgon has been trapped in the violent conflict between the Sabaot Land Defence Force (SLDF) militia, which took up arms over a land allocation scheme it considers unfair, and the Kenyan authorities. Tens of thousands have been displaced. Many have lived through atrocities, mutilation, and loss.

title: MSF Treating Thousands of Malnourished Children in Ethiopia
description:
In the past month Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has admitted more than 4,000 severely malnourished children into its nutritional programs in the Oromiya and Southern Nations and Nationalities People's regions (SNNPR) of southern Ethiopia. On May 13, MSF set up a stabilization center to provide 24-hour medical care to severely malnourished children suffering from complications such as malaria or pneumonia in Ropi, Oromiya region. Since then two more centers have been set up in Senbete Shinquille and Shashemene, Oromiya region. In total 927 children have been admitted to these three centers, with 290 currently receiving care.

Many of them are suffering from kwashiorkor—a form of edema caused by malnutrition, which manifests in liquid retention in the legs and feet. Kwashiorkor is a serious condition that can lead to death from heart failure or other complications.

Children who are not suffering from complications are treated on an outpatient basis in 'outpatient therapeutic programs. They are provided with therapeutic food on a weekly basis, but are able to stay at home with their families. They return to these outpatient centers every week to be monitored by MSF medical staff and can be referred to a stabilization centre if necessary. In Oromiya MSF has eleven such outpatient centers in various locations throughout the region.

On June 2, MSF teams also started working in the Kambata zone of SNNPR. One stabilization center has been set up in Kachabira district. As of June 13, 150 children were receiving medical care there. Four outpatient centers have also been established; two in Kachabira district and two in Hadero district. In the last two weeks, more than 900 severely malnourished children have been admitted into these programs and are receiving therapeutic food.

In the coming days MSF will continue to expand its activities by increasing the number of outpatient centers in both Oromiya and SNNPR. In addition, MSF teams will continue to carry out assessments in order to identify the worst affected areas and respond where necessary.

title: Forced Return of Hmong Refugees in Thailand
description:
Nearly 8,000 ethnic Lao Hmong currently confined to a guarded, barbed-wire enclosed camp controlled by the Thai military in the village of Huai Nam Khao in Petchabun province in northern Thailand face the imminent threat of a forced return to Laos. 

Many of these refugees have told the international medical humanitarian organization Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), the sole nongovernmental organization working in the camp, of a life in Laos spent fleeing violent attacks and persecution, witnessing the murder of family members, suffering rape, surviving bullet and shrapnel wounds, and enduring malnutrition and disease.

Read more: 
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/publications/article.cfm?id=2705

title: Sierra Leone: Training Health Workers to Respond to Malaria
description:
One of the biggest barriers to accessing treatment for malaria is distance from health clinics. MSF trains laypeople in remote areas to test for malaria and treat simple cases.

Read more about MSF's work in Sierra Leone: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/allcontent.cfm?id=67

title: DR Congo: Assisting Displaced People in Eastern Congo
description: Read more about MSF's work in DRC http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/allcontent.cfm?id=22

title: Dying in Peace: The Ongoing Emergency in Southern Sudan
description:
Despite the signing of a peace agreement between North and South Sudan on January 9, 2005, which ended decades of civil war, medical needs in southern Sudan remain overwhelming. Outbreaks of disease and violence continue, while many people still do not have access to basic health care, resulting in preventable deaths.

Although MSF has handed over some projects, a shortage of organizations willing or able to work in southern Sudan means that MSF remains one of the largest health-care providers in the region. MSF has worked in southern Sudan since 1983. In 2007, 137 international staff and 1,359 Sudanese staff were employed and MSF spent 19.76 million euros providing medical care in the region.

title: MSF Assists Sudanese Refugees Fleeing to Chad
description:
In February, bombings and attacks on villages in parts of West Darfur, Sudan, led to an influx of thousands of refugees into the Birak region of eastern Chad. MSF teams have been providing assistance by distributing essential relief items to the refugees and administering nutrient-fortified, ready-to-use foods (RUF) to prevent and treat malnutrition. 

As a new wave of refugees arrives in Birak from the Jebel Moon region in Darfur, MSF is distributing an additional round of relief items, setting up mobile medical clinics, and organizing a measles vaccination campaign alongside another distribution of RUF.

Read more: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/article.cfm?id=2563

description:
All photos by Spencer Platt/Getty Images

Spencer Platt, a staff photographer with Getty Images, spent two weeks in December 2007 with MSF in the Central African Republic. Here, he describes photographing a population living in extreme distress.

title: Images of Congo's War
description: Photographer Cédric Gerbehaye visited the Democratic Republic of Congo's (DRC) North Kivu province, where MSF supports the hospital, runs a nutritional program for malnourished children, and delivers assistance to displaced and resident populations. In this audio slideshow, he speaks about his experiences in the region.

title: Sierra Leone: Treating Children with Malaria
description:
Warning: The images contained in this video may be upsetting to some viewers.

Pediatrician Leo Ho worked in the intensive care unit of the MSF-run Gondama Hospital in the Bo region of Sierra Leone in 2007. During his assignment, Dr. Ho was continually treating the most severe malaria cases: children brought to the hospital who had already fallen into a coma; those who were severely malnourished; or also suffering from tuberculosis or HIV/AIDS. "We were just trying to keep them alive," says Dr. Ho.

title: Providing Surgical Care to Victims of Violence in Nigeria
description:
Doctors Without Borders/Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) has been managing this 70-bed trauma center since October 2005. Port Harcourt is located in the heart of Nigeria's densely populated, oil-rich Niger Delta region, where the struggle to gain power and control natural resources has sparked sporadic and deadly outbreaks of violence among a fragmented network of armed groups.

Read more on MSF's work in CAR:
http://doctorswithoutborders.org/news/car.cfm

title: CAR: Bringing Medical Care to War-Affected Populations
description:
In the northwest of Central African Republic, tens of thousands of people are living in the bush in extremely precarious conditions.  They have fled an armed conflict between government troops and rebel factions that began in 2005.  In addition there are attacks by armed bandits who are active in the region. Access to health care has been drastically reduced due to insecurity.  This has led MSF to open programs in several towns in the region providing free health care for the population.

Read more about MSF's work in Central African Republic: http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/news/car.cfm

title: Mouna's Story 4: An Iraqi Girl Struggles to Walk Again
description:
Episode 4 of 5: Overcoming the pain

A five-part series of short films chronicles the story of Mouna, a young girl who suffered severe injuries in Iraq three years ago and who is now learning to walk again, on artificial limbs with the help of MSF surgeons and physiotherapists in Amman, Jordan.
